project_name: TO IMPROVE WOMEN AND GIRLS LIVELIHOOD THROUGH 'SAVING AND LENDING' AND ENERGY SAVING STOVES.
project_summary:
TO SENSITIZE AND TRAIN GROUPS WOMEN AND GIRLS WHO ARE NOT GOING TO SCHOOL TO START GROUPS WHICH WILL DEAL WITH SAVING AND LENDING ALSO IMPROVED COOK STOVE MAKING AND USES. THESE TWO ACTIVITIES WILL ENABLE TO ACQUIRE BUSINESS AND LIVELIHOOD SKILLS AS TO EMPOWER DISADVANTAGE WOMEN AND GIRLS OF AFRICA BASED IN KARAGWE AND KYERWA DISTRICT AREA OF KAGERA REGION OF TANZANIA.  THE FOLLOWING THINGS SHOULD BE DONE;_x000D_
I.-OVER ALL SENSITIZATION SHOULD BE TAKEN TO ALL GIRLS AND WOMEN OF TARGETED AREA TO MAKE THEM AWARE TO THEIR FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS AND OBLIGATION. ALSO TO IDENTIFY THE OPPORTUNITIES WHICH SURROUNDING THEM TO CATER THEIR NEEDS. THESE ARE:_x000D_
- ENTREPRENEURSHIP_x000D_
- SAVING AND LOANING._x000D_
- ENERGY SAVING TECHNOLOGIES_x000D_
_x000D_
II.-TRAININGS WILL BE DONE ON THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES:_x000D_
- THEY SHOULD BE PROVIDED WITH SUSTAINABLE PROJECT; EXAMPLE SMALL AND MIDDLE ENTERPRISES THEN TO BE SUPPORTED WITH SOFT LOANS_x000D_
- SAVING AND LENDING WHERE THE GROUPS WILL LEAN HOW TO SAVE IN GROUP AND USE THE SAVED MONEY FOR LOANING IN ORDER TO START SMALL BUSINESS, THE SINGLE MOTHERS WILL BE SUPPORTED ECONOMICALLY, THUS MANAGE TO TAKE CARE FOR THEIR CHILDREN, THEIR CHILDREN ESPECIALLY GIRLS WILL GO TO SCHOOL BY BEING SUPPORTED BY THEIR MOTHERS, THE TARGETED PERSONS INVOLVES THE PARENTS OF THOSE GIRLS _x000D_
- TO BE GIVEN THE ENTREPRENEURSHIP SKILLS, SO THAT TO BE BUSINESS ORIENTED._x000D_
- THEY WILL BE TRAINED ON THE IMPORTANCE OF USING IMPROVED COOK STOVE ALSO HOW THEY CAN MAKE/START BUSINESS OF MAKING AND SELLING OF SUCH STOVES. WITH IMPROVED COOK STOVES THEY WILL REDUCE DISEASES CAUSED BY INDOOR AIR POLLUTION, REDUCE ENVIRONMENTAL DESTRUCTION(CUTTING OF TREES,GLOBAL WARMING) AND ALSO, FUEL GATHERING CONSUMES A CONSIDERABLE AMOUNT OF TIME FOR WOMEN AND CHILDREN, LIMITING OTHER PRODUCTIVE ACTIVITIES AND TAKING CHILDREN AWAY FROM SCHOOL. IN LESS SECURE ENVIRONMENTS, WOMEN AND CHILDREN ARE AT RISK OF INJURY AND VIOLENCE DURING FUEL GATHERING5._x000D_
- THEY WILL BE TRAINED ABOUT CROSS CUTTING ISSUES LIKE GENDER AND HIV/AIDS. WHEREBY IN GENDER THEY WILL LEARN HOW TO DEAL WITH PROBLEMS HINDERING THEM TO DEVELOP DUE TO ISSUES LIKE CONFLICT, TIME OF WORKING, GENDER BALANCE IN FAMILIES, LEADERSHIP AND ITS SKILLS AND HOW TO BUDGET TOGETHER._x000D_

project_name: Creating workplace for girls and women from Rural areas of Tajikistan through social enterprise That's Tajik (Edited version)
project_summary:
We are a start-up - That's Tajik- it helps artisans and designers to realize their works and promote them through an online platform (website) and cooperation of That's Tajik with other businesses. It is the finalist of Best business plan competition organized by National Association of Business Women of Tajikistan and supported by US Embassy in March 2014. The project launched in June, it's website will be up on July 20th, we are already working with 20 artisans from Khujand and cooperating with over 10 businesses (Hotels, Tour agencies) in terms of realization of products on whole sale term.The Head Office of That's Tajik located in Khujand, Sughd Region of Tajikistan. _x000D_
Currently we want to reach out to artisans from other regions too, but limited sources and long distance between the regions is a hardship which we are working on._x000D_
We are running a fundraiser-crowd-funding to cover costs of opening the work - center , hub in Sughd region, which will engage 20 artisans in producing works and will employ 10 girls and women, we received support from the government and found a place, raised funds will cover costs of equipment.(We may provide you with an information on fundraising if you request.) The center to be opened by August 10th._x000D_
_x000D_
We see an opportunity of decreasing poverty through educating women and girls from rural areas of Tajikistan about how to produce handmade products and helping to sell them those through our platform._x000D_
With 25000$ we will set an education and engagement program in 4 regions of Tajikistan and a network between women and our enterprise. _x000D_
We will use one year to cover activities in all 4 regions, each quarter is for 1 region (3 months-1st - Educating, 2nd - Producing and information gathering process, 3rd- promotion of products through That's Tajik Platform). _x000D_
_x000D_
1.Education and engagement into entrepreneurship:_x000D_
_x000D_
It will cover 12 cities and 480 women and girls. Our team of artisan experts and marketing specialist will choose series of products which are low cost and easy to make, then in each region our artisan expert will teach women and girls on how to make them. In first period ,with the support of the money we receive, we will buy materials for those products and women will produce them. The profit made will be continuous funding for project in region. _x000D_
Our trainings will cover next topics: _x000D_
_x000D_
-effective use of resources/materials in producing _x000D_
-law and taxation policies_x000D_
-designing products_x000D_
-quality making process_x000D_
-leadership_x000D_
-financial opportunities (using bank loans, rules and regulations)_x000D_
_x000D_
2. Creating a network and communication:_x000D_
In each region we work on we will create a Representing hub which will have next functions:_x000D_
_x000D_
*work-center- there we will create conditions for women to come and work, work includes next -packing of the prepared products, preparations of products(they can prepare their works at home as well, but in the center there will be all the needed material and equipment)_x000D_
*gathering all products and quality control - all the products that are to be made by women will be featured on our website, if anyone orders we directly get in touch with the representing hub in region, which then sends us out collected works or orders to women if there isn't any. As we are the service that brings not only high quality service, but products we will be working on improving the quality of works made by our women through quality check._x000D_
*communication center - it is important to continue working with women who attended our training, so they improve and practice the knowledge they received, center will act as Hub for women to meet on daily basis and receive any needed help._x000D_
_x000D_
3. Connection_x000D_
As the Each region is far from HQ of That's Tajik, we will purchase a car which will make the transportation of products to HQ from Region's hub easy and fast._x000D_
_x000D_
project_details: Unemployment and access to market . Tajikistan is one of the poorest post-soviet countries and poverty is prevalent in rural areas. Among the CIS countries, Tajikistan ranked last as regard to GDP per capita. While man go to labor-migration to Russia, women stay home with their children. It is common that men don't send enough money for the family or don't sell at all. We want to create opportunity for women to produce handmade product and sell them through our platform. Women doesn't have access to market- there isn't a demand for handmade works in rural areas, but women herself can't sell them in capitals or bigger cities. We want to support women and engage them in activity where only thing they have to do is produce products designed by us, and we will do marketing, promotion , delivery and selling ourselves bringing her income and employment. It is also a win/win employment opportunity for women and girls, because they can work from their homes.

We hope to secure a network of 1000 makerBelle fans by June 2015, 100 of which will enter into our pilot program and 10 partner submissions by August 2015. These 100 makerBelles will use the platform to perform the following actions during the grant phase 1. Enter a project or research challenge by our partners 2. participate and/or invite team members to collaborate 3. Learn from resources put together by makerBelle community_x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_

makerBelle wants to be an organization that champions women's involvement in future technology design and development. From consumer research to product design, women can bring their creativity and insights to transform their role as consumers in the world's market place to become prosumers or producers. makerBelle aims to move to a business model that eventually helps women monetize for their invention ideas. A self-sustaining marketplace whereby women makers and sellers interact. 
makerBelle movement seeks to establish itself as the leader in the growing space of maker movement across the world that is still dominated by men or geeks. makerBelle would like to reach out to Asian women who are interested to innovate or invent something. Lowering the barrier to entry to getting involved in technology deisgn and development will be makerBelle's goal. That can be done with content push and tie-up with publishing partners from all over the world to provide makerBelle with informational resources to spark their imagination. 
100 women who signed up to participate on makerBelle platform, 10 partner submissions for projects. A mix of curated community content and resource library from publishing partners on makerBelle.com
No. of women who submitted projects.
project_summary: makerBelle will be the platform that truly harnesses the creativity of women in product design and development to produce meaningful everyday or even Nobel prize worthy, game-changing ideas to move humanity forward. Initially we will use the funds to create a women centric community of inventors. With enough voices and content we plan to use the majority of our funds in creating a user submission portal similar to 99designs for inventors. The platform will be a tender system, where corporate partners post challenges and patents for women to compete and finish for the partners sponsored prize or reward. Our final phase for the funds will be to create a marketplace whereby makerBelle women can sell their inventions.
project_details:
Women think invention has to be a long and tedious process with high domain expertise. This makes women less willing to take risks and start a STEM career where the financial returns are not guaranteed. _x000D_
makerBelle hopes to lower the barrier of entry for women of any ages to gain access to science and technology know-how in order to realise invention dreams, while also providing a framework where there know their efforts can be monetized._x000D_

project_details_other:
By December 2015, 'Two Rabbits' will have reached 180 young women through the workshop and have raised 10 facilitators to run the workshops to cover geographical coverage of the program. The participants will have gained a new outlook on their current situation of career and mothering and will have a specific plan to further their action on an individual basis. We expect that their co-workers or friends in similar situations will witness the changes in the lives of our participants and begin to rethink about societal norm concerning young women's career and child birth. We hope that such regained possibilities of a work and family balanced life which seems out of context in Korea will bring more babies, siblings to be born and raised into an ever aging generation. 
We aim to take the stories and testimonies collected through 'Two Rabbits' and have them reported to governmental bodies so that policy changes can be on the agenda to show the important role young mothers make as a working citizen as well as a mother. Another important change should happen in the business sector as companies will make necessary changes to their existing model of work to cater for the much needed balance between work and family life.
We expect that 'Two Rabbits' will raise social awareness about the hidden stories of the reality young mothers face with their career path.And hope to spark practical debates and media coverage in order to communicate our message with the general public. Our participants wll have found a new motive and strength to live as proactive working citizens with a commitment to heightening their effort to continue the career and also happily accept the role as a mother. The participants will go on to experiencing a special form of internship at various company settings which will lead to potential recruitment opportunities. 
'Two Rabbits' will have all of its 180 participants to own an indivdual report about the new findings through the workshop.We will also set up an on-line community of alumni members and potential members to discuss issues related to two rabbits and share their stories of struggle and sucess. Suggestions and practical guides will be given out based on the information gathered._x000D_
We will have trained 10 facilitators(with different career backgrounds to cater for varying needs of groups)to run workshops, this will create a new job in itself. We aim to have all the specific data of the 180 participants during the workshop for further R&D and analysis which then will be used to write policy suggestions and reports to government bodies. _x000D_
Follow-up of the participants will be done through offering special internship opportunities. _x000D_
Companies which are open to experimenting a new form of working conditions will be carefully selected and through indiviadual consulting, be ready to run internship with our participants. _x000D_
In time, we believe that 'Two Rabbirs' will act as a spark in makng life-changing differences in young women who hold pivotal social positions of raising the next generation while setting a social context of a growing nation._x000D_

By the end of the project period, 'Two Rabbits' will have gathered and analysed reports from all of our participants and have record of a list of places our reports were sent to, to initiate change on a wider level. We will have evidences of media coverage and how a small act of change have sparked a social movement. We hope to also have a list of companies whose working manual have amends made based on the experiences through 'Two Rabbits'. Most importantly, we will have testimonies of young women who have made willing decisions to have children, and how their lives have changed by learning that it is more than possible to live with the two rabbits in life.
project_summary:
South Korea is renowned for its top rankings in many aspects. We have one of the smartest students yet they are the least happy in the world. We are the most educated population yet the most unemployed. We have the longest working hours, the lowest birth rate and the highest suicide rate. As a nation, we have long battled with a very challenging social epidemic that seems to require complicated solutions and strategies to find solution to._x000D_
 _x000D_
As a trained social worker I was aware that all systematic changes begin with locating a root cause and as a mother I was able to empathize deeply with the social/educational situation our kids were put in. Behind the devastating ratings of dying youth and crazy busy lives all striving for an endless measure of success, there was a very important group of people who were neglected. They were young women who were once valuable workers of society, turned into fulltime mothers- a generation raised to believe that achieving success is the only reason and goal of life. Students study impossible hours for the best possible scores, once in University young people battle for a socially respectable job, once settled into a job they delay getting married, and it is common for couples to be childless for long years. _x000D_
_x000D_
One may think that this sounds familiar in the lives we witness in the 21st century but the issue gets very serious when a nation is confronted with young women who need to make life-changing decisions between a career and a child. As in South Korea, it is close to impossible to have these two rabbits (career and children) to have and to hold at the same time. Hence the lowest birth rate as choosing to raise children equals having to let go of the responsibility to care or to let go of everything you have studied and worked so hard to achieve._x000D_
_x000D_
Young full-time mothers are put to a situation where oneâs social identity is completely cut off from the rest of the world they used to belong to. Hence rebuilding a new self revolves completely around what kind of children they are raising. It is no mystery that Korean children since very young go into an endless spiral of schooling. By the time these mothers have the time to look back on their career, they have already lost touch with their skills, have different sets of values and most importantly have been cut off from the rest of the working society for too long._x000D_
_x000D_
It is a given destiny for most of us women to live with two rabbits. For women to live proactively as working members of a society as well as take on the responsibility of raising happy and healthy children, it is crucial that the society accommodate for their need to be workers and mothers at the same time. _x000D_
The sian co,.ltd is a working platform for such young mothers who need flexible working conditions and have the initiative to make positive impact with the skill base they have acquired. Working at home, mostly online while keeping in close touch with the latest trends and insights in the education field, we provide solutions to schools and communities with limited resources and manpower to create much needed contents through R&D and consulting. In the 3 years we have worked, we have experimented with different ways to cater for the two rabbits in our lives and have proven stories to show that it is possible. We have also discovered how this continued identity and positioning in society lifts the huge burden on children to live as a measure of their motherâs need for acknowledgement. _x000D_
_x000D_
With the help of Project Inspire, we plan to take our experiment into a social movement. We have had numerous requests from mothers and companies wanting to uncover an alternative way to work for each other. With the experiences we have gathered as a working group, we have pinpointed three areas that need to be developed in order to influence and persuade the two groups (mothers and companies) to take appropriate action. _x000D_
Firstly, the young mothers need a collective time for healing and rediscovery. Participants of the âTwo Rabbits workshopâ will be young full-time mothers and working mothers who want to rebuild a career path. Through the workshop, we will be focusing on three things;_x000D_
1. Re-finding â an objective overview of oneâs identity as an individual, mother, and a citizen._x000D_
2. Re-positioning â a professional overview of oneâs career path and newly developed skill set and changed value system through child-rearing experience, A detailed overview of the changes in oneâs lifestyle and outlook in career. _x000D_
3. Re-building â a combined analysis and plan to locate areas of societal need where oneâs skill and value can make a difference hence rebuilding oneâs identity as a worker and also a mother. Getting participants ready to take on the challenge of searching for a place to take a step._x000D_
_x000D_
After the workshop the participants will be given an option to follow up on their new discovery through a tailored internship experience that matches their skill, values and needs. A list of companies who are willing to open up to a new way of working to these ready career makers will be individually selected and consulted with an opportunity for recruitment. _x000D_
_x000D_
A socially embedded issue that greatly influences the life-changing decisions young women make in life and thereby impacting on the lives of her direct family do need a fundamental solution on multiple layers of policy and systems. But for changes to take place, someone needs to take that adventurous step built on oneâs own experience to try something different. Finding a creative way for young mothers to take on their professional self again while continuing to be genuine mothers may not seem like a quick fix solution to some of Koreaâs long-fought struggle. But it will surely provide a new way of living to some. And that some will testify for all._x000D_
_x000D_
project_details: Through 'Two Rabbits' we aim to provide solution to social problems on a macro level, related to low birth rate, youth suicide and also atim to change the working culture and environment that make it very difficult for young women to live as working mothers. We are also expecting to have positive impact on the serious depression rate found among young mothers, which in turn will influence the way they communicate with their direct family members as well as the wider society.

project_summary:
Singapore is a foodieâs paradise. From hawker centres to seven-star restaurants, the city-state is known for its delicacies. What if there was a way to experience authentic, home-cooked meals in the comfort of a home?_x000D_
Mamakan.com is a home-cooking program aimed at bringing foodies to the homes of aspiring food entrepreneurs, with a special emphasis on mothers from low-income families. It builds on the idea of experiential dining, exposing the guests of Mamakan to the food, lives and homes of the mothers that cook the meal for them. Through Mamakan.com's website service, guests from Singapore and other cities will be able to visit the homes of their host and share a meal with them. _x000D_
_x000D_
Mamakan is created from the blend of the words âmamaâ, meaning mother in casual English, and âmakanâ, meaning food in Malay and home in Hindi. Literally translated, Mamakan stands for motherâs home-cooked meal. _x000D_
_x000D_
More than just a chance to expose the guests to an authentic dining experience, Mamakan will allow the host mother to earn a living through her daily activity of cooking. This is particularly important to a mother from a low-income family, as she often has to support a large number of family members on her husband's income. By encouraging mothers from low-income families to use their cooking skills to earn an income, Mamakan will empower these women (âmama cooksâ) to contribute monetarily to their homes. Over time, Mamakan is positive that it will instill these women with self-pride and confidence, since these mama cooks will feel proud of their contributions to the family and to society._x000D_
_x000D_
Using the USD $25,000 grant, the Mamakan.com team will set up a protoype website.
project_details:
Mothers from low-income families face a double-threat. They are faced with lesser opportunities to work and mostly are also faced with lesser access to resources. This means that even if they want, they have neither the avenue nor the resources to pursue a job that allows them to focus on their homes too. Most often, these women have received higher level education but are unable to make monetary contributions to the household because of societal factors such as gender bias and prejudice._x000D_
Mamakan.com will allow such women to host guests in their house, and use their cooking skills to make some money that will contribute as additional income to the family. Mamakan.com also aspires to be a shift to the basics: enjoying home-cooked meals in a host's social setting, thereby promoting the values of: i)economic empowerment for the mama hosts, ii)healthy eating habits and iii)preservation of family recipes and cultural heritage.

But staff turnover and our association with Youth Connect means many girls will pass through Puzzlebox. Youth Connect sends us 4-8 girls per year for general job training, although they donât necessarily stay as apprentices._x000D_
Weâll focus on hiring more female artists, and bringing back art teacher Sein Sein Lin to inspire them. Weâd also like 1 girl as business assistant. Weâre one of the only local business partners of Youth Connect offering office work._x000D_
_x000D_
Our current female artist Sell Khu Paw should be teaching apprentices by the end of 2015. _x000D_
_x000D_
Younger girls frequently ask to help us on Saturdays for pocket money, which we currently can't afford. It's a mutually-beneficial learning experience for them and teaching practice for our staff; plus the chance to subtly discuss their life skills. Weâd like to support up to 4 girls per year.
Weâd like to show the community that a business can be creative and non-exploitative. Weâd like to prove that art is a viable career choice. We want young Burmese migrants to feel they can express themselves in a variety of ways, perhaps even express through art their frustrations with their lives in Thailand. _x000D_
We expect that our trainings in creativity and design will be applied by the youth in other aspects of their lives. When the young generation learns to think critically and outside the box, they can be beneficial to others in the community. And of course, we want to increase staff enough to increase production, as well as keep the business sustainable through turnover.
We want show potential new artists that Puzzlebox is a comfortable place for girls to work. Despite our friendly atmosphere, Youth Connect girls look around our workplace that is (currently) majority boys and may choose to apprentice elsewhere. We are absolutely not interested in discouraging boys, as our studio is great place for the boys to learn respect and kindness. We simply want to rectify the imbalance, and encourage girls to explore their talents.
Weâre pushing for higher salaries for current staff as well as future hires. While we already provide a relaxed workplace, short working hours and many holidays, salary is key for attracting more girls. Under the ever-changing rules for working documents, our 2014 apprentices wonât have their papers covered by Youth Connect. Salaries now must cover their visas and passports. _x000D_
With increased funding, weâll feel confident to actively recruit more girls. We can also focus on training for the current female artist Sell Khu Paw and improving her confidence to teach others._x000D_
_x000D_
We are committed to asking teacher Sein Sein Lin to return for 2 months in 2014 and 2015, not only to teach but to serve as a female role model. _x000D_
_x000D_
There are many talented girls in post-high school programs in Mae Sot. These girls are too highly-trained to work in a minimarket, but with limited university slots, many fall through the cracks. With our financial situation, we donât really promote ourselves to these students. Weâd like to start doing more presentations and encourage these bright girls to consider us._x000D_
_x000D_
We bought a sewing machine and serger last year, but then lost a tailor. We still use tailors in the community, but want to hire a tailor to regularly work on our own equipment._x000D_
_x000D_
An optimistic goal would be to bring back Pyae Phu Cho, a brilliant young artist who was pressured to work in a factory in Bangkok. Weâd love to bring her home, with a competitive salary.
The increased salaries represent an investment. We will be re-investing in this 3-year-old business, attracting the best people possible, spending as much time on training as possible, and giving back to the Burmese community with heavily-discounted or free workshops. We will be using this luxury of timeâprovided by increased savingsâto work on improving our sustainability in the future. By the end of 2015, when some of our senior artists may be ready to move on, we will be able to judge if we correctly trained their replacements. Weâll be able to see through the artistsâ self-assuredness if they are ready to continue activities like teaching art courses to customers, training apprentices to make products, and run the business._x000D_
The evidence is always directly in front of us. We donât use home-based artisans. We nurture all our staff artists, discuss their home lives when they wish to, and work to increase their confidence. We will continue our new âcreativity days,â during which staff do not work on any Puzzlebox products, but show us they can either make fine art or saleable products of their own design._x000D_
_x000D_
Obviously, weâll know if we succeed in getting more girls on staff. Thatâs the biggest goal, to encourage girls to explore their creative and critical sides, and have girls support the growth of the studio. Girls will have a more vested interest in keeping a business like this viable.
project_summary:
Puzzlebox Art Studio is an art-focused social enterprise on the Thai-Burma border, working with Burmese youth to handcraft thoughtfully-designed products. Through art, we also encourage critical and creative thinking, which is unusual in the Burmese education system._x000D_
Puzzlebox Art Studio receives art apprentices from Youth Connect, a vocational training program founded in 2008. Youth Connectâs program begins with life-skills courses with students in their last terms of high school, then selects the top students for an intensive training program, and finally places them in 10-week apprenticeships at Mae Sot businesses. Youth Connect continues to provide career counseling for alumni as needed._x000D_
_x000D_
In 2011, Youth Connect created three social enterprises at the same time: Picturebook Guesthouse, a boutique guesthouse and training center; Ironwood Studio, creating furniture from reclaimed wood; and Puzzlebox. Puzzlebox and Ironwood were founded purely to make dÃ©cor for Picturebook, and the junior staffâs training fed into this purpose. Only Picturebook Guesthouse received funding past the first year._x000D_
_x000D_
With our unique jewelry, scarves, bags, and cards, business has increased steadilyâbut so have expenses. The more we increase production, the more we have to invest. _x000D_
_x000D_
We began the studio with professional art teachers. Picturebook Guesthouse opened in April 2012, so after the initial year of training and creating dÃ©cor, our American designer/manager helped create our own product lines to reach a wider audience. If we only count the local staff salaries, we barely break even each month. In actuality, our âextraâ staffâinternational teachers, designers and managersâalso ate into our savings, although they have been phased out. Currently our Burmese business manager doubles as occasional art trainer, and the American general manager is the last to phase out._x000D_
_x000D_
We have always had a shared workspace, as most of our products cannot be made easily in the home. We leapt into renting a space and hiring our three art teachers at a time when we had a little money but perhaps not enough. Rent has recently increased, as has electricity; weâre facing the repercussions of starting with too little savings._x000D_
_x000D_
With $25,000, we would have the comfort of knowing our rent and bills are covered for at least a year; that all current staff can get a good raise; that all future potential apprentices will see us as a viable way to support their families. We would be able to push forward as a wholesale business, seeking out partnerships for bulk orders, rather than constantly hustling to produce enough to fill our shop shelves._x000D_
_x000D_
Recently, as weâve faced a shrinking customer base in Mae Sot, the staff artists have had time to re-develop their fine arts skills. Weâre reviewing techniques for the less-experienced staff, and discussing composition and design with the advanced staff. Everyone is learning the benefit of constructive critique, and having fun working on less-commercial art. Having some more money in the bank would allow the staff to continue spending about 1/3 of our working time practicing art that inspires them. It would also give us time to experiment with new products._x000D_
 _x000D_
As our savings shrinks, we fear taking risks on untested staff. The $25,000 would give us a safety net. We could invite larger groups of apprentices from Youth Connect to join us each term, and determine the best potential staff rather than accepting all apprentices. We could advertise open positions to the wider community outside Youth Connect, which weâve only done once (and had to recoup lost time after some of those staff didnât measure up)._x000D_
_x000D_
$25,000 going towards increased salaries also reduces risk for potential hires. Many migrant Burmese families in Mae Sot live a subsistence existence, and girls are heavily pressured to help their familiesâ finances. At our current savings level, we can offer a fair salary, but not a competitive salary. When a creative, responsible girl tells us sheâs going to work at a mobile phone shop or big box store, we canât afford the time or salary to persuade her otherwise. Unlike these other businesses, we offer short working hours and generous holiday time, but thatâs not enough. Having a solid amount of money saved up would allow us to offer greater salaries to assure these girlsâ families, and assure the girls themselves that rather than only making products 8 hours a day, theyâd get an continuing education in critical thinking, community development, and English language._x000D_
_x000D_
At the base of it, $25,000 gives us time. Time to focus on finding international retail shops. Time to spend recruiting girls who lack confidence. Time to try out girls who may not ever be artistic, but want to learn how to run the business. Time to wait until the previous female art trainer can come back for a few months, and to pay her what sheâs worth. Time to shape our current female junior artist to becoming an art trainer herself._x000D_
_x000D_
We wonât ever lose focus on our boys, as Puzzlebox builds up all youth, and not just women. But weâve been extremely lucky with our senior artists, who are so respectful and big-brotherly towards the girls weâve had in the past. Continuing to build up their skills directly helps future women hires, as these boys will be their teachers. These senior artists also teach art in migrant schools and special workshops for Burmese students at Puzzlebox, classes which are 60% girls. And of course, all our male staff indirectly support women in their families.
project_details:
Burmese schools both in Myanmar and Thailand teach students by rote. Art is rarely taught. We encourage critical thinking, professionalism, and creative growthâall through art!_x000D_
Girls bear a great burden, and are pushed to earn wages or get married as young as 14-15. Married youths are prohibited from attending Burmese schools. Girls that get as far as Youth Connect feel the pressure of lost time. Without NGO-level qualifications, they might work at a factory or business 29 days per month._x000D_

Money is at the root of most departures. Unlike many women-focused programs, we work with young people who donât need to stay home with kids, donât want part-time employment, and donât want sewing skills. We aim to help girls work creatively and contribute to their communities.

project_name: Economic empowerment of Kani Tribals through Collective Enterprise: 'Banana Fiber Extraction/Rope making Unit'
project_summary: The Kani tribal (primitive) people live in the forests of the Kanyakumari, Thirunelveli districts of Tamil Nadu and Thiruvananthapuram district of Kerala in south India. In Tamil Nadu, the Kanikkars live in Kannyakumari and Nellai-Kattabomman district. Their current population is estimated to be approximately 18,000. Their settlement system is such that a few families live in a cluster interspersed with the forest.They do limited cultivation of tapioca, banana, millets and cash crops such as pepper, coconut, rubber, arecanut and cashew nut etc., in small plots of land given by the Forest Department. The project intends to use their existing strength ie living in cluster and cultivating banana. The project would establish a collective banana fiber extraction and Rope making unit. Around 2 batches (40 members) will be deployed for this purpose.It takes two years for the units to breakeven which is shown in budget. Marketing of the finished product has been already ensured with an agency called ROPE.(http://ropeinternational.com)
project_details: Rubber has been a major crop cultivated by Kani tribals along with Banana as an intercrop. But slowly due to liberalization policy of the government there has been huge inflow of finished rubber distorting the domestic market. Hence the Kani tirbals were supposed to depend on Banana for their present livelihood.In banana except the fruit, other things like bark goes as waste. Through an elaborate study the project was able to scout that there are organizations working extensively on banana waste and one such organization was ROPE. The project has already sensitized the tribals on the prospects of establishing a Banana fiber extraction and fine product(rope) making unit with marketing of the product being taken care of ROPE. This way the kani tribals will be able to strengthen their alternate livelihood ie banana cultivation and also will be better placed to use the waste of banana in a more useful way resulting in generation of more income for their households.

project_name: Online Education for Female K-12 Students in Rural Sichuan Province
project_summary:
Our project aims to address the historical bias still existing in Chinaâs rural areas that females, as they depend on their husbands for their living, do not need an education. Even though China has entered an era of prosperity, many negative cultural conventions survive because most rural areas are impoverished. _x000D_
Instead of building more schools for women and delegating volunteers to encourage women to pursue an education, efforts that in the past have been proved inefficient, we approach the problem with an economically favorable and accessible solution that will fundamentally alter cultural perspectives on education for women: online education._x000D_
_x000D_
The preparation will first go to Chengdu, capital city of Sichuan Province as our pilot village._x000D_
_x000D_
In Chengdu (Da yin Province: our pilot village):_x000D_
_x000D_
Cooperating with Chengdu NO.7 High School Long Distance Education, we recruit volunteers and professionals to record online courses, design course materials, create and maintain our main online learning website. As a startup, weâll only design courses (Chinese, math, English) for first year elementary school students in the first semester, since the majority of our target students do not have any educational background. _x000D_
_x000D_
1. Course design and recording_x000D_
_x000D_
Most of our courses are recorded by either high school students or college students who have solid background in elementary school knowledge and who show assessed talent and interest in education. We will have various subjects that are available in Chinese compulsory education. For each subject, a supervising teacher is delegated to that subject team and assesses the quality of the course material. _x000D_
_x000D_
A complete course project should include: video lectures (high resolution), course-embedded questions that come up repeatedly to test a studentâs learning result and give her instant feedback, office hours (live) where students interact online with teachers, reading materials, assignments, a mid-term and a final exam._x000D_
_x000D_
2. Expected time devotion and detailed schedules_x000D_
_x000D_
Weekly time devotion for our target students is estimated to be 25 hours a week, including watching and learning the course materials, doing assignments and a 5-minute virtual office hour for each subject with an assigned teacher in Chengdu. The first semester, starting in September 2015, is 16-week long. Students get access to the course materials when they are free, though they are encouraged to follow the planned course schedule we design:_x000D_
_x000D_
Chinese: Monday/Wednesday/Friday_x000D_
Math: Tuesday/Thursday/Friday_x000D_
English: Monday/Wednesday/ Thursday_x000D_
Virtual office hour: Friday night_x000D_
_x000D_
3. Online learning platform design_x000D_
_x000D_
Since the core of our learning program is online, it is imperative to maintain a stable and accessible website that contains the above-mentioned complete course projects. Besides asking students to sign agreements of honor code before course starts, weâre going to develop an online exam supervision program that allows the testing proctors to see every studentâs face when sheâs doing the exam. _x000D_
_x000D_
4. Our pilot class_x000D_
_x000D_
In the first stage we survey 35 families as our pilot families whose average annual income is below 3000RMB (approximately 500USD). Each pilot family, while meeting the required income bracket, must have at least one girl who is below the age of 18 and is not allowed to go to school. We give each family an flat computer, set up Wi-Fi network, and pay the electricity. Total cost for each family is estimated to be 800 USD. Upon finishing the courses and meeting the required grades (above B), weâll give an unofficial transcript to each student and a 50 USD scholarship as further incentives. _x000D_
_x000D_
5. Broadening the effort_x000D_
_x000D_
During the first academic semester of our first class, part of our team goes on to research other areas in Sichuan that need our project. By the end of the first term, we could again pilot another 50 families in area B. In 2016 spring we enroll another class of students who start as first graders. Because of our generous incentives and (estimated) good reputations from our pilot families, more families may want to take part. Though we only pay full tuition and cost for pilot families, we provide financial aids that meet every familyâs demonstrated need. When students graduate, we offer them graduation certificates which will be approved by the Sichuan Education Ministry. As mentioned above, weâre aiming at fundamentally altering peopleâs perspectives on women education, and our efforts will continue beyond our online curriculum. Weâll connect sample middle schools that provide boarding facilities as our sister schools, and our students, if willing to pursue higher education, are encouraged to enroll. In the meantime, we develop our middle school and even high school curriculum that can be an alternative for our graduating class. _x000D_
_x000D_

By December 2015, we will have trained 3 self-help groups, representing 30 women, in the assembly and servicing of solar lamps. These women will assemble an average of 80 solar lamps per person per month, for a total of 24 000 lamps by December 2015 (of which the first 3000 will be directly subsidised). The lamps directly subsidised by NERD Society will provide better studying and education opportunities to 3000 students (50% girls, or 1500 girls), providing an extra 4.3 million study hours per year. It is expected that 90% of the recipients of these lamps will adopt them as a part of their daily life, and that the maintenance of these, combined with sales of new lamps, will provide 96 000 Rps (about 1960 US$), worth of employment per year per SHG member. It is also expected that, as the market for solar lamps expands, an additional 10-15 SHGs will join the programme over the next 3 years.
As we will have established a demand for solar lights in the target communities by the end of the grant period, income-generating opportunities will continue to grow for local women. NERD Society has a long history of experience in organising and training women groups in a variety of enterprise and handicraft skills, and it is also expected that, as their confidence and success with the present project grow, some of the women involved will later on expand their enterprises into other business fields. The project will thus lead to increased opportunities and women empowerment into the foreseeable future.We also expect to see increased studying opportunities and emphasis on education for the schoolchildren involved, leading to higher school success rates and human development in the targeted villages. In addition, the replacement of kerosene lamps with emission-less solar lamps will have longer-term impacts on respiratory and eye health in the communities.
By December 2015, the project will have improved living conditions for the 30 women initially involved in the production of the lamps. Through assembly in SHGs and distribution in the villages, 3000 subsidised lamps will have been sold, and the communities will have adopted solar study lamps as an integral part of their childrenâs school supplies, ensuring the SHGs with a steady demand for solar lamps and their maintenance. We expect each woman involved to benefit from 8000 Rps (160$) in extra revenue every month (100 per lamp), which represents a typical working wage. We will also have linked the women SHGs to the producers of the solar lamp parts, allowing the women to form their own business supply-chain relations and to continue developing their enterprises after the end of our direct intervention.In addition, through the replacement of kerosene lamps with solar lamps, the recipient families of the solar lamps will benefit from expenditure savings on fuel.
The project will accomplish the following results:1. Gather low-income and marginalised women to form self-help groups to provide them with empowerment opportunities._x000D_
2. Train these groups in entrepreneurship and business management skills_x000D_
3. Train the women in the assembly, repair, and maintenance of solar lamps._x000D_
4. Raise awareness on the benefits of solar lamps for studying in local village households, and provide them with the initial solar lights produced by the SHGs._x000D_
5. Connect the women SHG start-up businesses with both their clients in the villages and the upstream suppliers of solar lamp parts in order to assure a self-sustaining business model._x000D_
6. Through better studying opportunities, increase the educational success of the recipient households, including improved school performance for girls, which will contribute to the alleviation of poverty and gender inequality for the next generation.
We will use the following metrics and indicators to measure the success of the project in each of the six main goals of the project mentioned above.1. The success of the formation of SHGs will be measured by the number of groups formed, the number of members per group, and the percentage of groups that successfully persist over time (current average for NERD society is over 90 %)._x000D_
2. The success of the entrepreneurship training will be measured by the percentage of SHG members who successfully start a new business, as well as by the financial success of these businesses._x000D_
3. The efficiency of the solar lamp training will be measured by the percentage of SHG members who successfully choose to start a solar lamp business, by the initial number of lamps assembled, and from qualitative feedback about the training sessions._x000D_
4. Awareness for solar lamps will be measured by the number of solar lamps successfully distributed._x000D_
5. Successful establishment of the solar lamp business in the community will be measured by the number of unsolicited solar lamp purchases after the initial phase, as well as by the number of solar lamps brought back for repair and maintenance._x000D_
6. Increased study opportunities will be measured through the number of successful solar lamp adoptions, as well as from participatory feedback from the communities.
project_name: Solar lamp entrepreneurship for young children and tribal women
project_summary:
In India, poorer women, especially uneducated ones, have seen themselves quite limited in their opportunities and are generally forced to rely on men for subsistence. Although levels of education in India, in particular in the poorer parts of society, have traditionally been quite low, education is now free and compulsory, which, given that 29.7% of Indiaâs population is below 14 years of age, could have dramatic impacts on human and social development. However, lack of access to electricity in remote village regions hinders the ability of students there to study and to take advantage of this opportunity, threatening to stall progress unless interventions are made._x000D_
Our project will address this double challenge of women empowerment and education in the villages of Tamil Nadu, India through a two-pronged approach. NERD Society has a long history of empowering women in Tamil Nadu through the formation of self-help groups (SHG), whom we train in business management as well as a specific trade (soap making, goldsmiths, etc.) with which they then start a business. To date, approximately 3100 SHG have been started by NERD Society, directly affecting 45000 women members. With this project, we will add the assembly, servicing and repair of solar lamps to these activities, allowing uneducated women with limited social and economic opportunities to earn a living through the production of solar lamps. These lamps, in turn, will go to young students in remote villages, giving them better study opportunities after sunset and assuring that the next generation of girls will be better educated and equipped to take on a productive and equal place in society. NERD Society has already distributed 260 solar lamps in the region and established four sales service centres as a follow-up mechanism; with this project, we will be able to greatly expand the scope and reach of the programme._x000D_
_x000D_
Training local women in both assembly and servicing of lamps, rather than simply providing ready-made lamps to the communities, ensures two goals, namely, (1) that womenâs businesses will last beyond the start-up phase and into the foreseeable future, and (2) that the local communities will maintain control over the project as well as the skills and knowledge needed to maintain it. Training local women in both assembly and servicing of lamps, rather than simply providing ready-made lamps to the communities, ensures 2 goals, namely, (1) that womenâs businesses will last beyond the start-up phase and into the foreseeable future, and (2) that the local communities will maintain control over the project as well as the skills and knowledge needed to maintain it. The project will consist of five phases:_x000D_
(1) Nov-Dec 2014: Groundwork (organising material procurement, preparing NERD Society employees)._x000D_
(2) Jan-Feb 2015: Start of fieldwork: gathering local women to into self-help groups and training them in entrepreneurship management, based on NERD Societyâs current work. We will initially start 3 SHG for this project, each of 10 members._x000D_
(3) Mar-Apr 2015: Training the self-help groups to assemble and maintain solar lamps. NERD Society will provide this training free of charge and subsidise 50% of the price of the components for the first 3000 lamps produced (at a cost of 500 Rps (about 10$) a lamp, this will amount to 15 000$). As each lamp takes approximately 2 hours to assemble, each woman trained will be able to produce approximately 4 lamps per day, which will be sold at around 600 Rps. each (excepting the first 1500 NERD Society-subsidised lamps), providing an increased income of around 400 Rps. per woman per day._x000D_
(4) Jun-Dec 2015: Distributing solar lamps among families with students in more remote regions. We plan on working in two regions of Coimbatore District, namely Thondamutur and Anoor. The lamps can charge on 6 hours of direct sunlight and provide illumination for 8hours, more than sufficient for the studying needs of students in the household. The original subsidy on the price of the solar lamps will serve to increase community acceptance until the usefulness of the lamps is recognised and local demand for solar lamps becomes self-sustaining._x000D_
(5) (Jun 2015 and on) Continuous support to the groups and monitoring of results, both at the level of the SHGs and at the level of the village end-users._x000D_
_x000D_
With 15 000$ going to solar lamps, the remainder of the grant will cover the salaries of the NERD Society employees who will organise, train, and offer long-term support to the SHGs, as well as distribute the assembled lamps to their end users and connect these to the SHG enterprises who will continue the production and servicing of the lamps (at the standard wage of 500 Rps (10$) per employee per day, the grant will cover 1000 hours of NERD Society employee work, or approximately 30 hours of support per SHG per month)._x000D_
Once the lamps have been distributed, and their value recognised, we transition to self-sustaining businesses based on the demand for (1) new lamps and (2) lamp maintenance by the village users.

The project will first identify potential second time animal rearers(dalit women alone) through a process of Participatory rural appraisal.Then a larger level of awareness will be developed across these 20 dalit hamlets on the need/benefits of milch animal rearing. Following this the first time milch animal rearers will be selected through a process of intensive appraisal. A baseline info will be developed for these project participants and also for the control maintained in separate dalit hamlet . Then a continuous capacity building initiative will happen among this first time and second time milch animal rearers through the available resources like regional veterinary institutes. In the meantime locally grounded women para vets will be identified and trained with the support of the professionals. These trained para vets will help the milch animal rearers in understanding the essential criteria of milch animal rearing(dalit women) like feed/fodder management, calf management,and disease management. The project will work these landless dalit women from 20 settlements and form them as twenty milk producer associations. _x000D_
The project will work with local nationalized formal banks and enable a positive atmosphere where the banks will be able to understand the credit product needs of the landless dalit women especially for the purchase of good cross bred milch animals integrated with adequate milch animal insurance program.Thus resulting in higher level of resilience among the dalit women to face eventuality like animal death as the investment/capital she has made is on the higher side. Further through linkage events, the formal financial institutions will lend credit to these landless dalit women without any collateral attached to it. Akso the project will try to link the Milk Producer groups with the milk market.

project_summary:
While the atrocities of a 20-year civil war inhibited Uganda's development, the rest of the world was rapidly changing with the emergence of the Information Age. Thus, U-TOUCH was born to bridge the global digital divide by offering a proven, scalable and sustainable solution for young women and men in the most impoverished and isolated communities worldwide. Since 2010, through its Digital Training Centers, U-TOUCH provides free IT-related employment and life skills training, including software, Internet, graphic and web design, media arts, and more. There are now five Digital Centers that have graduated over 3,500 people. A recent survey of U-TOUCH graduates indicated that they had increased their monthly household income an average of 246%. With these new opportunities, graduates are able to support improved family nutrition, healthcare, childrenâs education and more._x000D_
This July, U-TOUCH is opening its first self-sustaining model: a Technology Innovation Hub in Gulu, Uganda. Businesses and individuals will be able to rent desk and classroom space and conduct activities that will generate income for themselves and for the Hub by selling skilled technology and business services._x000D_
_x000D_
U-TOUCH is planning its first program targeted specifically for women to empower them with business and computer literacy skills. Women will learn technology skills accompanied with life and entrepreneurship skills. Upon graduation, students will be paired with a mentor, a continued learning support community, and employment opportunities through the Hub. The program offers job-specific training paired with employment and professional development opportunities. The program accelerates women to the next level by creating a pipeline to employment. _x000D_
_x000D_
Ground preparation phase: From January 1 until February 1st, 2015, U-TOUCH will partner with existing womenâs empowerment organizations and combine forces with current U-TOUCH trainers to train a new pool of female technology trainers. These women will conduct technology trainings accompanied with gender-specific discussions. The training sessions will also include motivational and educational guest speakers. During this time, staff will recruit their first womenâs only participants and gather pre-training demographic information to prepare for post-training evaluation. Additionally, staff will oversee the purchase and installation of computers and software._x000D_
_x000D_
Pilot phase: From February 2nd to March 27th (8 weeks), the first session will train 20 women in basic and advanced computer, business and life skills. Students will undergo a 6-week training in basic computer literacy and life skills accompanied with discussions and guest speakers targeting womenâs issues. Immediately following the course, students will participate in a 2-week intensive advanced level course in a specialized skill, such as Agribusiness, Microsoft Word, Excel, Social Media Marketing or report writing. _x000D_
_x000D_
Mentorship and Community Building Phase: From March 30th to April 3rd (1 week), graduates of the womenâs program will be paired with a mentor in the area of their chosen interest. Students will meet regularly with mentors to help them through the initial phases of finding or creating employment. Additionally, recent graduates will form âentrepreneurship clubsâ which will meet weekly to collaborate and support each other as their socioeconomic roles shift, thus laying the foundation for a womenâs support community. U-TOUCH will lead mentors and trainees through the guided formation of relationships and lead initial discussion within the clubs. The clubs and mentorship program will provide an ongoing support system for program graduates. _x000D_
_x000D_
Pilot Evaluation Phase: From April 6th to April 17th (2 weeks) U-TOUCH will evaluate the activities conducted during the pilot phase and accommodate for challenges it experienced. U-TOUCH will also recruit and interview participants for the next training session and set up a system for ongoing recruitment and interviews for training program acceptance. _x000D_
_x000D_
Training Period: From April 20th to December 4th (4 training sessions), U-TOUCH will conduct four 8-week training programs for 20 women per session. After each 8-week period, each student will be paired with a mentor and form a support group or âentrepreneurship club.â Each woman will be allotted 50 hours of free guided computer time after the class in order to practice skills, search for employment or conduct research to start or scale a business. _x000D_
_x000D_
Evaluation Phase: December 5th to 31st (3 weeks). Staff members will collect post-training data at 6 month, 1 year and 3 year intervals after each student has progressed through the program. At the conclusion of the first year, project staff with analyze impact and success rates of the program as well as rate of return on investment to determine whether enough business is being generated to deem the program sustainable after the first year; based on whether enough U-TOUCH graduates are using the Hub services for mutual benefit to offset the training costs of future womenâs programs. _x000D_
_x000D_
Standard Operating Program: By January 1st, 2016, U-TOUCH-FEM will become integrated into the Hub as a regularly scheduled program. Women will participate in discussions around womenâs role in society, poverty, development, health and family, while generating skills to become members of the workforce. By the end of the training period, women will have learned computer basics, internet and e-mail, life skills such as goal setting, and much more. They will have also participated in guided discussions surrounding womenâs roles in society and the relationship to poverty and disease. These skills will be followed with advanced training in a tech skill of their choice. By the end of the training, women will be in a place to innovate and collaborate within the Hub to develop solutions to problems in their own lives and own communities._x000D_
_x000D_
The proposed program will add sustainability to the Technology Innovation Hub by investing in technology and women. Investing in women is likely to have a greater social and financial return on investment due to womenâs caretaker role and responsibility to the wellbeing of the family. The program will propel women forward by expanding their worlds through access to the Internet and guide them through a pipeline to generating consistent income for their families and improving the economic conditions of their communities. By the end of the 2016, U-TOUCH-FEM expects to be a self-sustaining program.

project_name: THE COMMERCIALISATION PLAN OF A UNIQUE CO-WORKING FACILITY FOR WOMEN IN MALAYSIA
project_summary:
LIION's Lab is a unique co-working and fitness space for women with childcare space for their kids. The co-working office concept that began in the US (Dunsby 2014) is a hybrid between retail and a traditional office in which the current need for business professional who always on-the-go and don't need a full time office space is catered (Manegre 2014). This year, 2014 is the best time to launch a co-working office to fulfill the increasing demand for this concept (Dunsby 2014). This business concept is normally operated on a membership basis with provision of suitable furnishings, internet services, phone line, Wi-Fi and extension of service and equipment offerings for competitive advantage (Dunsby 2014). Bill Jacobson, CEO and Co-Founder of co-working space Workbar in Boston and Cambridge, mentioned that co-working spaces are the intersection of both a private space and a public space (Manegre 2014). Based on this concept, a new conceptual design, LIION's Lab is proposed._x000D_
LIION's Lab provides a supportive community for working women who want a space closer to their kids to work, get fit and to connect and collaborate with peers. The main LIION's Lab business model is through membership. Members will enjoy the cosy but fun atmosphere with perks that include; (1) open workspace and lounge area with internet and utilities for collaboration and for organizing events, (2) kitchen and pantry to cook, create new recipe and entertain guest, (3) gym for maintaining health and fitness, (4) creche where babies and young children are cared for during the working day. _x000D_
_x000D_
LIION's Lab offer societal value and economic value where working mother can spend more time with the children, and be closer to them without compromising their work and network. In order to succeed and have sustainable profits over a period of time, there are multiple revenue opportunities available. This include selling (1) combine membership to have working space and child care space, (2) separate membership for women who want either working space or child care space, (3) membership for women who only need access to women-only gym, (4) hourly pass (5) daily pass and (6) non-member ticket for events. _x000D_
_x000D_
The first facility will be started in Malaysia. This could be achieved by buying a 3-bedroom apartment that is located on top of retail premise and turn it into a co-working space, fitness space and child care space. USD $5,000 will be used for bank payment to pay deposit (including legal fees) to buy an apartment in a developing suburb that is located 78km away from Kuala Lumpur Central. USD$300 will be used to get business license, business registration with Companies Commission of Malaysia and to build and maintain company website with domain name for 1 year. USD $1,000 will be used for trademark protection. USD$700 will be used to pay high speed internet installation and for 1 year internet bills. USD$200 will be used for advertising. Refurbishment for whole apartments will need USD $4,000. Fitness equipment and furnishings will require USD $5,000. Accounting and legal service will require USD $2,000. Casual fitness instructor salary payment will require USD $2,000. Business training salary payment will require USD $3,800. USD $3,500 will be used for salary payment for management and administration duties. USD $1,500 will be used for salary payment for casual babysitter. These are just the rough estimation of the initial budget._x000D_
_x000D_
The reasons of choosing this apartment in this location are (1) closer to my family where I could get business advice along with emotional and financial support, (2) there is no existing business nearby that provide either a women-only gym or a co-working space (3) located 3km away from The Sultan Idris Education University, a public university where there are currently have 3235 female undergraduate, 32 female international student, 1,093 female post-graduate students, 266 female academic staff, 348 female non-academic staff and 6 female international staff (UPSI 2014) that contribute to the main 4,980 target market (4) 5km away from the main Tanjung Malim town that has always been known as the Education Town (5) the presence of other various education institutions that include preschools, primary schools, secondary schools, Private Higher Education Institutes, Public Higher Education Institute and Education Institute specific to civil servants, and (6) the existing economic activities and industrial planning such as the automobile by the construction of the national car factory, Proton in Bandar Proton (Proton Town), agricultural, manufacturing and the development of new housing projects, recreational facilities and others (Tanjong Malim District Council 2014)._x000D_
_x000D_
As a practical matter, it is likely that this concept will be initially rolled out in Tanjung Malim region before expanding to Kuala Lumpur City. The potential market for this project in Malaysia consists of three segments. The primary market is made up of 1,122,000  women entrepreneurs who participate in Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) (Teoh and Chong 2008). A secondary market includes approximately 6 million working or professional women, who may need a flexible working arrangement or childcare service. All 0.84 million of women in Kuala Lumpur (Department of Statistics Malaysia 2013) especially the young ones who are interested with fitness make up the final market segment. At this stage, it is difficult to accurately determine the likely usage of LIION's Lab, as utilization will be greatly dependent on location and the services provided. However, a total potential demand for this kind of space is estimated to be from 5,300 to 3,350 women entrepreneurs and small businesses just in the targeted sectors in the Kuala Lumpur area.  _x000D_
  _x000D_
Over the decade, Malaysian women participation in labour market has risen. Moreover, more and more women in this generation are taking the initiative to start their own business ventures and getting involved in the creation of new industries (Hoe et al. 2012). Over 7,000 Malaysian freelancers are found on global freelancers recruitment company, Elance (https://www.elance.com) and most of them are women. LIION's Lab facility will be helpful for these women freelancers to solve their isolation problem while working at home and letting them escape the distractions at home. The growing of small online business among Malaysian women with majority of them doing their business from home would be very advantageous for this project. _x000D_
_x000D_
In addition to that, this concept is applicable to other women and girls across Africa, Middle-East and Asia Pacific._x000D_
project_details: Malaysia's major challenge after successfully eliminated most gender gaps in education is to increase women's opportunities to bring their talents to labor markets (World Bank 2012). A big increase in Malaysia's output per capital could be realized if more women participated in the labor market or became entrepreneurs, which adds to the managerial talent pool in the economy. The fifth Malaysia decennial census demonstrated that the percentage of employed females had increased from 33.5% (2000) to 37.7% (2010). However, working women in Malaysia faced two big problems; (1) the lifetime choice between work and family formation that attribute to low earning and (2) lack of technical and managerial skills invested for women as they are expected to leave their job while they are raising young children or, in many cases, to stop all work once they are married. Therefore, LIION's Lab will be implemented to help women to contribute in the economy without compromising their family values.

There has been a positive impact on over 90% of the HIV+ members to the program);2. Learn about family planning, health, hygiene, nutrition, ARV adherence, HIV & TB and the rights of people living with HIV/AIDS;_x000D_
3. Taught basic business skills and receive grants to start their own business and are therefore guided to start table banking within the group._x000D_
_x000D_
ChildsLife offers a safe meeting venue where the women share their stories in confidentiality. Our beneficiaries get practical advice, learn about basic life skills and receive training directly applicable to their situation. They then have the tools to take care of their families.
With the implementation of the LLE program, we hope to achieve the following during the 15 months that the program will be initiated and the effects of the program will be observed even after the stipulated program time:-Educate 30 HIV+ mothers on issues relating to health, nutrition and family planning_x000D_
-Empower 30 HIV+ vulnerable women by improving their self-confidence and independence_x000D_
-Help 30 HIV+ women become agents of change in their communities_x000D_
-Battle the spread of HIV by preventing (mother-to-child) transmission and create awareness_x000D_
-Create income opportunities for 30 HIV+ women thus creating more gender equality_x000D_
-Stimulate sustainable economic growth on grassroots level_x000D_
_x000D_
Women drive economic development in Kenya: they operate the majority of small businesses. And when women work, most of their income goes to food, medicine, education and other family needs which enhances the possibilities for development on grassroots level. Women are key to HIV response. By empowering them to be able to protect themselves and make informed decisions about their health and that of their children, we can eliminate new HIV infections among children and keep women and children living with HIV alive.
Well-being is not just about increased income. Other aspects include health, food insecurity, social inferiority, exclusion, lack of physical assets, and vulnerability. Our approach is people-centered, and though some aspects of member's progress can be objectively measured becoming healthy and economically active is only part of this program. It is also about acceptance of your HIV+ status, about empowerment and lifestyle change, about general well-being and the ability to care for your children. That is why ChildsLife will measure a variety of data in four stages:1. Exploring existing data: to be collected and reviewed before fieldwork starts (WHO, UNAIDS, population data, other relevant background information)_x000D_
2. Data collection: gather basic quantitative and qualitative data covering member's health, participatory workshops and semi-structured interviews_x000D_
3. Analysis: structure and analyze all data gathered, identify key explanatory factors and compare to basic community standards and comparison groups_x000D_
4. Evaluation: assess main livelihood impacts for LLE members and summarize overall findings and conclusions. After evaluating the results, conclusions can be drawn about effectiveness and possibilities for future expansions.
Key stakeholders: ChildsLife Kenya is the key stakeholder and will be responsible for the implementation of the action of the program from inception to the end. They will work closely with ChildsLife International-Netherlands who will be responsible for monitoring and evaluation and ensuring best practice. ChildsLife Kenya will also work closely with local health partners, policy organizations, community partners as well as researchers to enhance the level of success. ChildsLife Kenya has had consultative meetings with ChildsLife International-Netherlands and is in agreement of corporation as far as the call is concerned.

project_details: ChildsLife LLE program seeks to address HIV/AIDS, limited access to healthcare, gender inequality and poverty, which remain to be major challenges in Kenya, especially in the urban slums. While adult HIV/AIDS prevalence rates have been declining in the past years, the fight is far from over. HIV/AIDS is still a catastrophe amongst the poorest of the poor. In Kenya, an estimated 1.6 million people are living with HIV, around 1.1 million children have been orphaned by AIDS and in 2011 nearly 62,000 people died from AIDS-related illnesses. Women have a higher risk of getting infected. In Kenya, for every 10 young men with HIV there are 45 young women. Women often suffer the synergistic effects of poverty, illness, unequal opportunities and the infringement of their rights. Their vulnerability has major consequences for their children and a negative impact on grassroots community development.

More children will move on and encourage others to tell their âsecretâ _x000D_
More children will function better at school, restore their self-esteem and be empowered to become productive members of society which will lead to a new sense of hope for a positive, brighter future. _x000D_

The short term impact PATCH will have on each child who reports their case of abuse will be that each child who reports their case of abuse within 72 hours of the abuse taking place will receive the medical treatment needed to prevent the transmission of HIV, Sexually Transmitted Diseases and pregnancy. A child will be safeguarded from their perpetrator(s) should the perpetrator(s) be living in the childâs home. PATCH will be able to create a sense of safety for each child which will empower them to work through the trauma of having been raped, they will be able to heal and eventually cope with daily, overwhelming events. 
PATCH is committed to ensuring the physical safety of the child at home as well as emotionally safety of the child. Once the child feels a sense of safety, they will be able to speak about the abuse. Symptoms of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) are often shown in a child when a child starts their therapy process. To prevent these symptoms from developing into a disorder, the child needs to be in a supportive environment. This is done in conjunction with the childâs parents. Parents will be educated on how to provide a security safe environment for their child at home. Often the attachment with the parents has been damaged by the trauma experienced by the child. The child is constantly on the lookout for danger, they struggle with everyday things such as going to school in fear of getting into trouble. Small things will rattle them as they are continuously hyper vigilant. For a child, the world is experienced as a dangerous place, the goal is to change the pathways in the brain to help the child experience the world as a safe place again._x000D_
PATCH therapists will teach the child the skills needed to deal with difficult, daily events in life and help them to repair their trust in relationships. This is accomplished when it is seen that a child starts to handle things with ease, their startle response to things becomes less, they find it easier to make friends and interact with their parents, and they become more happy and carefree.
Good measurement tools are in place to evaluate the trauma symptoms shown in each child during the assessment period and the therapy process. These symptoms are evaluated to see if there has been a shift in symptoms of PTSD (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder) displayed when the child was first referred to PATCH. _x000D_
These symptoms are measured by the qualified professionals employed by PATCH as they are able to determine the rate at which a child responds to therapy and the positive responses of the child as a result of the therapy process, thereby gaining the strength needed to progress to the next positive level. _x000D_
 There are however, lots of society and community factors that PATCH has no control over. PATCH provides each child with the tools needed to deal with daily obstacles, but the environment will not always support them i.e. if the childâs family live in poverty or if the mother of the child supports the alleged perpetrator. _x000D_
PATCH never closes a door on a child client and occasionally a child who has been treated by PATCH will come back for therapy during different stages of their adolescence to instil the support and love that PATCH has shown them.
