project_name: The Hope, Help and Healing Project
project_summary:
Child sexual abuse is increasing at a shocking rate in South Africa. Sexual abuse often leaves children with feelings of powerlessness and despair and can result in both short-term and long-term harm such as nightmares, bedwetting, anxiety and later on in life can lead to substance abuse as well as a number of psychiatric disorders if left untreated.In response to the tragic yet preventable problem of Child Sexual Abuse, PATCH implemented an accessible and free project known as the 'Hope, Help and Healing' Project which is available to all child victims of sexual abuse in the Helderberg area of Cape Town, South Africa. _x000D_
_x000D_
The services included in this project are as follows: _x000D_
To deliver a comprehensive 24 hour crisis intervention service to child victims of sexual abuse during their medical examination._x000D_
To provide access to PEP treatment (Post-Exposure Prophylaxis) in order to prevent HIV and/or STDâs (Sexually transmitted diseases)._x000D_
To provide unbiased, forensic assessments on allegations of child sexual abuse._x000D_
To provide free, professional therapy to child victims of sexual abuse in their mother tongue at a PATCH facility close to the childâs home._x000D_
To provide court preparation should the child's case go to court._x000D_
_x000D_
Its costs on average R 2500 per child per year to receive the free, professional treatment needed to help them heal themselves from the horrible wounds of trauma they have experienced. _x000D_
With the grant provided by Project Inspire, PATCH will be able to provide these services to 104 children from January, 2015 to June, 2016 to help each child overcome the trauma of having been raped or sexually abused in hope of them becoming strong, empowered individuals. _x000D_
_x000D_
The main service provided by PATCH is the Therapeutic service. Each child will receive a weekly hour of therapy at a PATCH facility closest to the childâs home and in the childâs home language for a minimum period of six months to a year. The therapists at PATCH make use of a wide range of therapies from narrative and play therapy to cognitive-behavioural therapy. Each therapist will work according to the individual childâs need whether it is a need to work on feelings of guilt and shame and/or court preparation should the childâs case go to court. The therapy provided ensures that the childâs sense of control over his/her life as well as their self esteem is restored. This professional intervention is successful in the sense that it allows the child to deal with the trauma of having been raped or sexually assaulted._x000D_
_x000D_
Receiving therapy after an incidence of child sexual abuse is of the utmost importance and PATCH staff members have seen the positive impact it has had on the children they come into contact with and therefore wish to continue for years and years to come. _x000D_
project_details:
When a child does not work through the trauma of sexual abuse, it influences their school life, their personal life and can affect their adult relationships. It almost always affects the person they become or even the parent they become by them either being under protective or overprotective towards their own children.This problem can however be solved by providing every child victim referred to PATCH with free, professional therapy.Therapy will assist each child to deal with the pain of what has happened to them. 'Breaking the silence' is one of the most important components of the healing process. Achievement will reflect when each child, through therapy, no longer shows signs of trauma and no longer feel powerless with regards to the abuse, instead they will realize that they have control over their body and a voice to say âNO!â _x000D_
Therapy will allow a child to be who they were before the abuse took place and empower them to be the adult they are meant to be, free from pain.

The main long-term impact expected from the Investing in Opportunity project is that participants become socially conscious and financially literate citizens of their communities with added entrepreneurial skill. With financial literacy, participants will learn to save for education expenses (school fees, supplies, uniforms) thus engendering educational empowerment and overcoming fixed cost barriers to attaining further education and mitigate financial duress linked to disasters, both personal and natural, that impede financial independence. Similarly, participants starting micro-enterprises where they live benefits everyone. _x000D_
Communities benefit from the proceeds of these enterprises and business ideas are founded and continued on a long term basis. Additionally, female entrepreneurs in these lower socio-economic communities become role models for other young women. Thus this project is the impetus for continued female empowerment and ongoing financial and market access for women.
The short term impact of the project will be the knowledge gained by participants in the areas of social and financial education and entrepreneurship development and its dissemination to the community. Participants will host several events that share knowledge with the community. At these events, youth share the skills that they have gained as a part of the training program. Through these social enterprise events, community members will become more aware of the dangers of early child marriage, the importance and the benefits of wise spending and saving of resources, and the importance of including women in the decision-making process as equality fosters stronger communities and nations.

Children International (CI) is the main funder of the Aflateen program; however, in order to expand and enhance this program for more youth and incorporate the Entrepreneurship Development Training for women component, additional funding is needed.
project_summary:
The Investing in Opportunity project includes entrepreneurial development training for adult women and a social and financial education program called Aflateen that seeks to empower adolescent girls to become change makers in their own lives and the lives of others. _x000D_
With the support from Project Inspire, Children International would not only be able to continue the Aflateen program for 800 youth in West Bengal, but would expand the training components for these youth and add a new entrepreneurial training program targeting 80 adult women. _x000D_
_x000D_
Children International originally chose to implement Aflateen for its tiered, age-appropriate curriculum that focuses on the development of pertinent life skills, the promotion and protection of the rights of the child, social responsibility and community service, which all resonate with Children Internationalâs programmatic goals and approaches to education and youth development. Additionally, CI has seen its impact on the lives of young women who for the first time are empowered to make decisions in their lives. Although the programâs participants are majority female, male participants work side-by-side their female counterparts on enterprise projects that results in them recognizing women as community and business partners._x000D_
_x000D_
The Aflateen curriculum is based on five core elements: _x000D_
â¢ Personal Understanding and Exploration_x000D_
â¢ Rights and Responsibilities_x000D_
â¢ Savings and Spending_x000D_
â¢ Planning and Budgeting; and _x000D_
â¢ Social and Financial Enterprise_x000D_
_x000D_
With Project Inspire funding CI would be able to continue and expand the program to benefit 800 youth, who participate in a minimum of twenty sessions, or 40 hours of training on the five core elements. Based on feedback from prior youth participants, four new components will be added to the five core elements to expand and enhance the current training program, which will require two additional staff people. The four new components will be implemented through ten additional sessions:_x000D_
â¢ Gender (3 sessions) - Concept of gender; sex and gender; and gender roles, stereotypes and ideology_x000D_
â¢ Assertiveness training (2 sessions) â Concept, problem solving, and decision making; and time and stress management_x000D_
â¢ Adolescent Reproduction Health (2 sessions) â Reproductive anatomy and hygiene; and reproductive health decision making_x000D_
â¢ Leadership (3 sessions) â Understanding power; leadership styles; and qualities of a leader _x000D_
_x000D_
These additional components are topics that the program participants have expressed as necessary in order to enhance their social and financial skills, life planning and business development skills. This will strengthen the overall impact of the program._x000D_
_x000D_
Although Aflateen is a youth program, older youth (above the age of 20), mothers of Aflateen participants and other women in the communities where CI works have expressed interest in receiving a training program like Aflateen as they see the positive impact it is having on the young people in their communities. In order to address this need, we will also offer an Entrepreneurship Development Training for 80 women with the Project Inspire Funding. _x000D_
_x000D_
The Entrepreneurship Development Training (EDT) for Women course, based on the Aflateen methodology, will include a more technical training on business development skills for a group of 80 female small business owners and entrepreneurs. The training will help the trainees improve their existing small scale trade in terms of stronger management, greater outreach, marketing and distribution. After the intensive training, which will last two to three weeks, the trainees can apply for seed money to start or upgrade their businesses. The strongest proposals will be selected and trainees will receive up to 30,000 rupees each. Upon receipt of the funds, CI will continuously follow-up with these women to provide advice and regular support. _x000D_
project_details: In West Bengal, CI serves a lower socio-economic population where the cross-cutting issue for women is the lack of opportunities to make decisions. In 2013, UNFPA reported that 47% of children in India are married before the legal marriageable age, which is 18 for girls and 21 for boys. Despite Indian law, the populationâs cultural mind-set accepts early marriage for daughters, which prevents her from completing her studies and compromises her health. Early intervention in key areas â raise the marriage age, provide reproductive health information, and reduce gender-based violence â has long term payoffs for girls, their households, and broader communities (USAID Policy on Gender Equality and Female Empowerment, 2012). This project will assist women to be empowered citizens that make wise life and financial decisions for themselves and their families.

project_name: Economic empowerment of vulnerable peasant women through apiculture and agroforestry in Noni- Cameroon
project_summary: Noni is a Sub Division in Bui Division , North West Region of Cameroon. Noni is one of the deprived Sub divisions In Cameroon that has no electricity, roads, potable water and schools. Noni is still rural with community members living below poverty line. There is a high rate of rural exodus especially amongst the men and youths in search of jobs and education. They leave behind women and children especially girls. Women in this part of the country have to fend for their families. They have to feed their children, educate them, fetch firewood for the house, etc. This leaves the women with little or no money. Womenâs economic power is weak. There is a low rate of scolarisation especially amongst girls because families are poor. The consequence is that young girls are forced to go for early marriage. The main economic activities here are farming and livestock rearing. The farming methods are mainly subsistence farming systems like the slash and burn, the Ankara system (burning grass in buried ridges), etc. This bushfires destroy beehives of other community members placed for colonization. These methods over the years have degraded farmland and reduce crop yields. Recently there has been a rush for the use of chemical fertilizers for farming which is not affordable by peasant farmers to use because of poverty. This grant will be used to empower peasant women in Noni to become economically sustainable through apiculture and agroforestry techniques in their farms. Bee farming is an income generating activity in this area and is generally considered as a masculine activity. Women will be trained on modern bee keeping techniques. These techniques will involve on beehive construction; beehive mounting; the use of bee smokers and bee suits in honey harvesting and honey processing. This training will ensure the quality of honey produced and add to family income when sold. CAMGEW will distribute hives to women who will who will be trained. These hives will serve as a start-up point for the trained women in bee farming. The trained women will act as trainers to other women. CAMGEW will organize women from the trained communities in two honey producing and marketing cooperatives. Markets for honey produced by the women will also be created and secured through formed cooperatives. Through these cooperatives, honey women will benefit from upfront buying of their honey to enable them meet their needs like school fees for children, improved seeds for farms and basic household needs that cannot wait till honey harvesting is done. Cooperative members will also benefit from honey produced interest. The importance of honey as medicine will be thought to the women. The importance of bees in crop pollination for increase in crop yields and promotion of biodiversity will also be taught to women. The aim of all this will be to reduce bush fires and the cutting of gallery forest for firewood by women. Each cooperative will benefit from material and equipment used in bee farming and these materials and equipment will be the cooperative property that will be open to use by members. Beehives will be placed on valleys and peripheries of their farms. CAMGEW will also organize agroforestry training workshops for women during which women learned agroforestry techniques. This agroforestry techniques taught will help peasant women farmer improve soil fertility, serve as wind breaks, provide flowers for bees to produce honey, increase source of income and provide fuel wood. Women and children move long distances to fetch firewood. Agroforestry tree species like Leuceana, Acacia, Tephrosia, Calliandra and Prunus africana will be planted in womenâs farms through field-based trainings. Considering the importance of agroforestry as climate change adaptation and being aware of the pressure on the finite amount of land available for agriculture, CAMGEW through this project will give peasant women the opportunity to learn and communicate the importance of protecting their soils using agroforestry practices through exchange visits among women farms. CAMGEW hopes to use a participatory approach in training workshops to facilitate exchange and sharing of knowledge, experience and skills on agroforestry techniques that can help these women practice conservation agriculture. Women need opportunities to share indigenous knowledge on best local agroforestry practices. Hunger, poverty, rural livelihoods, nutrition and human health are critical issues linked to climate change faced by Noni that need to be addressed in ways that are environmentally, socially and economically sustainable. Food production in farms has reduced over the years. Existing farmlands have become less fertile with soil erosion by wind and rain dominant. Slash-and-burn has reduced soil fertility too. Soil is the basis of survival for the present and future generation but if it remains bare human reliance on it will be doubted. Agroforestry practices promote true soil conservation that leads to soil carbon management. CAMGEW through this project will help peasant women farmers in Noni use agroforestry techniques to properly manage carbon in agricultural ecosystems that will lead to less erosion, healthy soil, natural fertility, high productivity and increase biodiversity through radio programmes. Poor soil management is part climate change problem and good soil management is an integral part of the solution. Peasant women need to increase their ability to adapt to climate change through soil fertility management to increase food production. There is need for CAMGEW to promote agroforestry practices that will give peasant women farmers the opportunity to increase food production and conserve the soil while getting other benefits. Storing carbon in soil through agroforestry reduces atmospheric level of carbon. This will be done through radio programmes and community sensitization. The form cooperatives could also be used to market farm inputs and outputs where women are best organized. Bi-monthly radio programs through the Oku Community Radio will sensitize women on the importance of agroforestry techniques in conservation agriculture and bee farming on improving women livelihoods, the disadvantages of bushfires both to farmers and bee farming and the importance of women getting involved in bee farming will also be discussed.
project_details: The initiative is aimed at fighting poverty in rural communities of Noni. The lives of marginalized, abandoned vulnerable peasant women will improve through apiculture and agroforestry. Honey produced will be sold and income generated used to improve women lives. Problems associated with soil degradation will be solved using agroforestry techniques. These techniques will improve on crop yields. Hunger will reduce with increased income and yields from farms and bee farming. The availability of wood from agroforestry trees will also reduce deforestation by community members for firewood and reduce women and children suffering of moving long distances to fetch firewood. Gallery forests and patches of the montane forest close to their residence will be protected. Women will be economically empowered through this project. Solidarity among them will be strengthened through created cooperatives. They will get involve in bee farming after training. Women will get employed through bee farming.

project_name: COUNSELLING AND REHABILITATION OF TEENAGE MOTHERS
project_summary: We will increase the number of our beneficiaries and expand our territory of operation of our activities. From January 2013 when we launched our operations till present, we have received over 60 teen mothers and 15 young women up to 35 years old for counselling. Out of this group 18 selected girls, are being sponsored in various rehabilitation programs. The 18 girls so far are into the following: 5 into small businesses, 5 special trade apprentices, 5 resuming & completing secondary education and three into vocational training. Our target group is teen mothers with a ceiling age of 22 years (to help give us an impact focus). The project forms a chain from previous year to another because some of the trainings take longer. This Projects Inspire program is really timely and would help us assist over 100 more girls in various programs, as we are currently limited by our means. Should we receive the funding, we will expand our area of focus. We reinsert the younger teen mothers (below 17 years) who dropped out of school in the standard educative system and sponsor them up to a level where they can learn a trade and be self-sufficient. They will receive on-going counselling sessions during their reorientation programs, while older women who do not qualify for our rehabilitation programs, will nonetheless benefit from individual counseling and orientation sessions. The teen mothers we sponsor will be of the following categories and rehabilitation programs: -with minimal education, (primary level and up to form 2) to learn a trade through apprenticeship and help them establish their own business; we will give stipend to the more matured and better educated ones (form IV and above) to pursue studies in higher level of vocational and technical institutions; for those who cannot count on the support of family members to help them with their children, we will give them loans to start or enhance their business after giving them basic classes in business management; we will expand our present orientation to capacity building of girls and women in selected villages to reduce the rate of illiteracy, and give them the possibility to learn trades so that they too can contribute to the economic development of their communities.
project_details:
-Reinserting young mothers who dropped out of school due to child bearing, imposed illiteracy caused by this, coupled with the long-term frustration are reduced.-Families are relieved from the extra burden of having to meet the needs of their daughters and her child(ren), due to their state of inertia caused by the shock of lost dreams, which very often lead to having more children as a single mother. Thus the economic strain on the family is avoided and the purchasing power improved._x000D_
-Building up their self-image and giving them the opportunity to give a fresh start to their lives prepares them to be responsible and influential citizens in their communities, thereby improving the economic and living standard of their communities._x000D_
-Capacity building of women and girls in villages, will arrest a growing problem in those villages and contribute to their economic and social development. Thereby, the long-term benefit to the community is reduced teen pregnancy. _x000D_

project_details_other:
A critical objective of this project is to enable these young women develop a sense of self-worth. Armed with an ability to think intelligently and independently they will have the power to stand up against exploitation; the resources to not only access their rights but also develop the community and society around them. _x000D_
By having access to opportunities and tools to fend for themselves, they live a dignified and self sufficient life. The training and resultant career opportunities will make them financially secure and help restore the much needed social balance needed to minimise inequalities. The choice of career will bring about a perspective change on gender and create a more inclusive society. _x000D_
_x000D_
We aim to create greater avenues in the fields of vocational skills and employment for the homeless youth - ones that are aligned to their innate potential and brings it out in all its glory. They would also act as role models to other girls from similar backgrounds._x000D_

Diversity and Inclusion is gaining prominence in todayâs world. Government laws are mandating women leaders on company Boards and women representation in socio-legal bodies is being advocated. The demand for women professionals is rising especially in male dominated fields. Companies are gaining comfort from the presence of female professionals in the outdoors. Travel companies are employing female guides / tour leaders for the safety of women clients. _x000D_
Meeting this increasing demand of skilled and competent women professionals is what we aim to achieve. _x000D_
200 girls would have undergone an adventure-based outbound camp of 3 days duration and become more empowered to make informed choices regarding their lives. 60 girls would have undergone an eight month as an Outbound Professional. They could take up jobs or freelance in the area of adventure and outbound or set up their own adventure company. Career opportunities to these young women would not be restricted to the country of origin.
We see more and more girls participating in the camps and training, confronting their demons, overcoming fears and taking with them a âcan doâ attitude. _x000D_
By being better informed of their choices, they can avoid and counter exploitative practices. This will help bring out a change in mindset and galvanize their immediate surroundings as they can help other girls in their area or community take charge of their lives too. _x000D_
_x000D_
A sense of self-worth and self-esteem will help these women break the shackles that have restrained them and deal with life on their own terms. Livelihood opportunities will create financial security leading to long-term economic and social independence. This will help them increase their self-confidence, lead a stable life and be seen as productive members of the society._x000D_
_x000D_
Women professionals in a male dominated career will also break-down gender and role perceptions existing in society vis-a-vis women at large, and help create a more inclusive work place at all levels. _x000D_
_x000D_
All of the above will lead to a shift in the mindsets of people, the way they see the homeless, sensitise them to their causes and issues and look at ways to bring about changes at a societal level. _x000D_

The entire journey and transformation of the girls, from âFoundation to Consolidationâ will be documented in written and audio-visual form. This will form the primary evidence of our work. This will be complemented by further evidence at two levels viz. individual and societal_x000D_
 At an individual level_x000D_
_x000D_
1. The internal change and transformation of the girls / young women reflected by_x000D_
â¢ Their ability to take ownership of their lives_x000D_
â¢ Make informed choices pertaining to all aspects of their life_x000D_
â¢ Stand up to exploitation, make their voices heard_x000D_
_x000D_
2. The external evidence will be the economic and social independence of the girls measured through_x000D_
â¢ The number of girls qualifying as Outbound Instructors and using the outdoors as a primary mode of earning their livelihood (independent business venture, jobs with organisations, freelancing as an outbound professional)_x000D_
â¢ No. of girls taking up jobs / pursuing career opportunities in their areas of interest, empowered by their experience of the outbound_x000D_
_x000D_
At a societal level it will be changes being brought about in the families and communities that the girls / young women are a part of, because of their experience of the outdoors_x000D_
_x000D_
1. Change in the mindsets, perceptions of family members of the young women_x000D_
2. Other girls joining this vocation, inspired by the stories and experience of these young women_x000D_
3. The girls having a say in the decisions pertaining to their lives and their voices being heard_x000D_

project_summary:
Give a âWomanâ a fish, you feed her for a day. Teach her to fish, you feed her for a lifetime. This is what we at URJA intend to do with US$ 25000 for HOMELESS YOUNG WOMEN, through the medium of OUTBOUND VOCATIONAL TRAINING._x000D_
Inequalities in societies, existent since time immemorial, have stemmed from birth, class, race, religion, gender and wealth discrimination amongst others. And through the ages, women have been at the receiving end of these adverse situations, with little or no tools to cope up with._x000D_
_x000D_
Field experiences show that about 70% of these women are forced out of their homes while 30% voluntarily abandon them in search of a better life. They end up in the streets of the big cities of India. Innocent, vulnerable and lonely, they are prime targets of the exploitative elements with many ending up in sex trade and beggary, vulnerable to sexual, physical and emotional abuse._x000D_
_x000D_
However, true to the indomitable human spirit, many of these women do not resign themselves to fate. They possess a burning desire to change their state of being and are willing to push themselves to their limits to live a life of dignity. What they lack though are the tools to accomplish this, often clueless as to where to start from. This is where URJA steps in._x000D_
_x000D_
Its mission is to work towards an equitable and inclusive world for all, with a focus on the rights and needs of runaway adolescent girls and homeless young women living on the streets, and act as a responsible partner in their lives. _x000D_
_x000D_
URJA facilitates their journey with informed choices for living a life of dignity. It provides them with shelter, education, healthcare, counselling and vocational skills training, employing various mediums like drama and dance therapy and outbound adventure camps to initiate the process of internal healing. They create an environment where the girls can open up, regain the ability to trust a fellow human being, confront their demons and equip themselves for the new journey they have embarked upon._x000D_
_x000D_
Financial independence and the ability to earn a living is the key to unlock the doors to a better life. Here, it was important to choose an area where a very high level of education was not a pre-requisite; where women could excel based on their innate strengths and skills, where they could blossom in an environment that is friendly and offers a diverse look at the world, one that is very different to what they have been exposed to all along._x000D_
_x000D_
One such field was Outbound Adventure activities. This encompasses all outdoor-based adventure activities on land, water and air â trekking, rock climbing, rappelling, mountaineering being a few. _x000D_
_x000D_
It offers these girls a life of freedom yet discipline, where they can leverage their innate strengths and most importantly LEARN TO LEAD. This, for us at URJA, is the single most important value that our project focuses on - the most precious tool these young women walk away with, acting as a catalyst to impart them with the confidence and belief that they can succeed on their own and develop their sense of self._x000D_
_x000D_
The Outbound Vocational Training (OVT) Programme_x000D_
_x000D_
We work with youth, especially women (between the ages of 17 and 24) from difficult backgrounds, and over a eight-month period train them to become Outbound Adventure Professionals. The OVT programme consists of three phases: _x000D_
1. Foundation_x000D_
2. Creation_x000D_
3. Consolidation _x000D_
?_x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 1 â Foundation _x000D_
_x000D_
The process starts by reaching out to youth through community leaders, non-governmental organisations and participants who have undergone the journey, and informing them about the field of Outdoors. _x000D_
_x000D_
Multiple introductory camps of 3 days are conducted for groups of 18-20 participants, over a period of 3-4 weeks. Most of the participants may have never experienced the outdoors, with the exception of those from rural areas, who may have lived in villages. _x000D_
_x000D_
These camps open the doors to their selves as much as they serve as an introduction to the world of outdoors/adventure sports. Through games and activities the participants get glimpses into their selves, are able to overcome their fears and get the first realisation that âthey too can doâ. _x000D_
_x000D_
About two weeks after the camps, a half day orientation session is conducted for all camp participants. They are asked to share their experience and their interest in pursuing this field as a career option is ascertained. _x000D_
_x000D_
Information is shared about life as an outdoors professional and opportunities emanating from this field. They are also told about allied career options in Adventure and Theme parks, Fitness industry, Security industry, Professional sports and job opportunities in State Government departments (Disaster Management cells, Safety and Rescue Operations, etc.) amongst others. _x000D_
_x000D_
Youth who express interest are enrolled into the OVT programme and further work on self with skill building commences hereon. _x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 2 - Creation _x000D_
_x000D_
The training is spread over eight months and consists of lectures, activities, day treks and outdoor camps. The curriculum is divided into three stages:_x000D_
_x000D_
(a) Initiation (2 months)_x000D_
The first leg in the journey starts with the Dreaming process. Individual wants, needs and desires and explored and understood, so that they make an informed choice of career. It is also an opportunity for them to look within, overcome their fears, realise their strengths, discover hidden potential. This is especially needed if the change has to sustain. _x000D_
_x000D_
The journey into self is accompanied with an orientation to the world of outdoors. They learn the basics â ethics, fitness, knots. They spend time in the classroom discovering themselves and each other and learning the ropes. Self discipline is inculcated at this stage along with memory exercises to help retention of learnings. This stage also helps us identify potential outbound instructors in the group. _x000D_
_x000D_
(b) Preparation (4 months)_x000D_
The basics at this stage include environment education, social skills, safety and first aid. Training shifts to the outdoors (bouldering, day treks and testing fitness levels). The rock-climbing sessions and treks are as much a self discovery process as they are a validation to the participants regarding their choice of a career. _x000D_
_x000D_
(c) Endurance (2 months)_x000D_
In this stage, they are exposed to advanced mountaineering techniques. The focus is to prepare them, mentally and physically for eventual enrollment in an accredited mountaineering institute. _x000D_
_x000D_
For those who would not like to attend the mountaineering course immediately, the focus over the next one month remains strengthening their concepts. _x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 3 - Consolidation_x000D_
_x000D_
Participants are enrolled in the prestigious Nehru Institute of Mountaineering (NIM), Uttarkashi, India, to attend the Basic Course in Mountaineering. This month long course gives them an opportunity to not only hone their skills and test themselves, but also meet and interact with industry professionals from across the country and widen their horizons. _x000D_
_x000D_
Those who successfully complete the Basic Course move to the last leg of the training. Those who fail to qualify are groomed for the next round of application to NIM. (The Basic course in Mountaineering by NIM is offered twice a year in April-May and September-October). The NIM certificate is valid all across Asia._x000D_
_x000D_
Apprenticeships are offered to all participants who complete the eight-month training. As their skill levels get approved by industry experts, they move into a job placement programme to get a regular employment in the outdoor/adventure sports field._x000D_
_x000D_
Those with an independent streak are encouraged to prepare and qualify for the Advanced course in NIM, and trained in Entrepreneurial management so as to be able to start their own venture down the line. _x000D_
_x000D_
Cognisant of the fact that not everybody may get through to NIM in the first round of application, the OVT programme offers continued support to participants by way of refresher classes, day treks and camps, so that they are able to practice the skills learnt and qualify whenever they choose to apply. _x000D_
project_details:
A society is as successful and happy as the people who inhabit it. In countless communities in India, young women still find themselves staring into an abyss created by gender, caste discrimination and poverty with no hope of improving their lot. Education, freedom, dignity, are concepts alien to them._x000D_
Through our work, we empower homeless women to stand as equals on the basis of their own effort and industry and lead a life of dignity. We help release them from the environment of compromise and subjugation that has been their world. We help them deal with their traumas, boost their confidence and self esteem, which will help them guard themselves from further exploitation. _x000D_
_x000D_
On a macro level, we are creating a society with fewer inequalities. We are working towards breaking some dysfunctional social structures created by the patriarchal system, discriminations, myths and perceptions. A more inclusive and nurturing society will in turn bring down the exploitation of women._x000D_

Qualitative data will be sourced from interviews with participants, program staff, and clientele and will focus primarily on the quality of work the women produce, increases in self-confidence, empowerment and decision-making capacity as well as shifts in community attitudes regarding gender stereotypes and equality. _x000D_
_x000D_
A womenâs empowerment framework will be used to monitor and evaluate empowerment of Light the Spark participants. This will include a detailed analysis of influencing factors and will focus on the intersection between a) perspectives of the women themselves; b) the structures they live within, for example gender, culture or the law; and c) their relationships, for example within their household, with community or with authority._x000D_

project_name: Light the Spark: Electrical Training Pilot Program for Women in Nepal
project_summary:
This $25,000 grant from Project Inspire will be used to implement the Global Womenâs Projectâs âLight the Spark: Electrical Training Pilot Program for Womenâ in Nepal. _x000D_
Light the Spark is a program that equips socially and economically disadvantaged Nepalese women with the training and skills they need to find employment or establish their own small service-oriented business in the highly under-resourced field of electrical wiring work. The program is the co-creation of the Global Womenâs Project (GWP) and its partner organisation, the Womenâs Foundation Nepal (WFN), in collaboration with technical experts from both Australia and Nepal. _x000D_
_x000D_
The program has been designed to respond to an identified skills gap in the local Nepalese economy. The programâs targeted yet holistic approach increases the chances of women finding work and adds value to the local community and economy. In addition, the program challenges traditional gender stereotypes by supporting women to participate in a vocation that has historically been the domain of men. By equipping women with skills outside traditionally assigned gender roles, and through the integration of a community engagement component that supports critical thinking on gender, this program promotes behaviour and attitudinal shifts in the broader community and creates the necessary conditions for sustainable positive change towards gender equality. _x000D_
_x000D_
Light the Spark has two distinct yet interrelated phases: a technical course component, and a livelihood pathways component which supports women to enter the workforce. _x000D_
_x000D_
The first phase entails the delivery of a six-week training program for women incorporating both practical classroom work and on-the-job training. The course teaches participants to work with low current (up to 50A) and low voltage electricity (up to 2230V) as well as electronic assembly work. It includes modules on soft skills training (personal presentation, customer service, leadership, critical thinking), workersâ rights, electrical safety awareness and basic business management._x000D_
_x000D_
This component of the program was designed by Dr. Peter Freere, Senior Energy Advisor with World Vision Australiaâs Program Research and Advisory Team and board member of the Kathmandu Alternative Power and Energy Group (KAPEG), in collaboration with a local Nepalese expert, Muniraj Udaphyaya. Following a successful crowd-funding campaign, the first phase of Light the Spark was successfully piloted in January/February this year. Twelve socioeconomically disadvantaged Nepalese women who were selected by WFN participated in the course. The first phase was delivered on budget for AUS$6500, including initial program research and development costs. In the future, we believe this component of the course could be delivered at a significantly reduced cost per cohort thanks to identified cost savings and implementation improvements._x000D_
_x000D_
Following completion of the first phase, GWP (in collaboration with WFN, Dr Peter Freere and course trainer Muniraj Udaphyaya), conducted one- and three-month evaluations. These evaluations found the program to be successful on a number of key subjective and objective empowerment indicators, such as an increase in participantsâ self-confidence and their successful uptake of a highly applicable skillset. However, the evaluation also identified a number of important barriers that exist to women finding work in this field in Nepal, despite them now being equipped with the necessary skills and knowledge. These barriers range from practical obstacles, such as limited access to transport or communication, to more complex hurdles like resistant community attitudes, reputation and perceived credibility/expertise. _x000D_
_x000D_
The second phase of Light the Spark seeks to research, design and implement a series of solutions to the barriers elucidated through the evaluation of the first phase, with a view to establishing a suitable business model to support women to generate an income using their newly-acquired skills. The $25,000 grant from Project Inspire will be integral to developing and implementing this second phase, as well as identifying course improvements and cost savings to allow GWP to continue offering the initial training to new cohorts in the future._x000D_
_x000D_
Specifically, the funds will be used to:_x000D_
_x000D_
â¢ Invest in the capacity of women through continued on-the-job training and skills acquisition, further mentoring in business and technical skills, and development of complementary training modules based on need;_x000D_
â¢ Investigate, design and implement an appropriate business model for program graduates to work under, such as co-operatives, micro-enterprises or micro-franchises;_x000D_
â¢ Develop relationships with industry and local business with the intention of carving out connections and employment opportunities;_x000D_
â¢ Promote and advertise the services of each applicable business;_x000D_
â¢ Implement targeted community engagement and outreach activities, particularly those that focus on engaging men, with the intention of reaching a shared understanding about why women participating in the workforce is beneficial for the whole community;_x000D_
â¢ Evaluate and implement the learning from both phases of the program and seek to share our learning with others; and_x000D_
â¢ Identify improvements and cost savings for the initial training program in order to offer this course to multiple new participant cohorts in the future (funds for additional program delivery will be sort from sources outside of this grant);_x000D_
â¢ Explore the feasibility of incorporating renewable, off the grid, energy, for example solar energy systems, into the program, once the core components have been delivered upon. _x000D_
project_details:
The Light the Spark program contributes a solution to three interrelated problems: 1. Through provision of training and support to enter the economy, the program offers a solution to the lack of access to education and livelihood opportunities for women in Nepal. _x000D_
2. There are wide disparities in womenâs access to literacy, education, health care and livelihood opportunities in Nepal. Through provision of training in a male-dominated field, combined with targeted community engagement activities that aim to generate community support for the program, the program challenges gender inequalities and community attitudes that work to inhibit womenâs empowerment._x000D_
3. The program contributes to alleviating entrenched poverty in Nepal. It has been shown that women invest up to 90% of their income back into their families and communities as opposed to 30-40% for men. Consequently, empowering women through this program is likely to yield intergenerational benefits. _x000D_

project_details_other:
In 3 years, the initial Phrao cooperative will become a self-sufficient business of at least 20 women in ongoing partnership with Warm Heart and Trade Monkey. Warm Heart will continue to expand its microenterprise cooperatives. The long-term goal is for women to maintain their businesses year-round rather than suspending them to work in lower-skilled, physically demanding agricultural work. We would consider the project a strong success if in 3 years at least 10 women maintained the cooperative year-round. This would be a distinct shift in employment trends in Phrao District and a significant advance in empowering female artisans._x000D_
Trade Monkey will have a permanent social impact staff that consistently assesses and undertakes development projects with all of its local partners. Three years out, Trade Monkey will be a leader in the social venture field and will have brought its business-based development model to producer communities in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America.
In the short-run, Trade Monkey and Warm Heart will support stable incomes for 10 women and their families in Phrao District. On average, each woman has a 5-person household in the dry season and often cares for her daughtersâ children while they are away working. Consequently, the first year will directly influence 50 family-members at home and approximately 15 daughters away working. Indirectly, Project Inspire will strengthen the ongoing work of Warm Heart who annually impacts the lives of 80 women in its other cooperatives, 65 children in its home and at schools, and all their families. Supporting Phrao women with steady employment will have a multiplier effect that will positively impact at least 215 women and children in the community by January 2016. By creating a sustainable cooperative model we also hope to build trust in the local community towards building additional cooperatives in the future.
We are committed to establishing a strong cooperative structure in Phrao tailored to specific community needs and challenges, providing stable incomes and financial literacy training for 10 Phrao women and their families during the economically uncertain dry season and eventually year-round; expanding the role and skillset of Ms. Somjai; designing, producing, marketing, and selling 2,000 handmade, upcycled products to generate seed money for Warm Heart and the Phrao cooperative; launching a targeted marketing campaign across 8 college campuses and online; developing a social impact team and program at Trade Monkey for future development projects. _x000D_
We are purposefully launching our social impact program with a small group of 10 women to build our model and ensure that we have a lasting impact beyond the initial group. Trade Monkey currently works with 20 distinct producers in Thailand and Cambodia and are vetting an additional 30. We aim to expand the number of producers we partner with to over 100 by December 2015 and ultimately implement our social impact program in all our producer communities. 
The biggest indicators of success will be the return of all 10 Phrao women to the cooperative in January 2016, the establishment of the cooperative as a financially independent business, and demonstrated interest among other women in joining the cooperative structure. _x000D_
We will also verify success based on increased demand for Trade Monkey products among our target college-campus market; we will measure this through tracking sales, return customers, social media involvement, and referrals. At the producer-level, we will monitor the ability of Phrao cooperatives to expand sustainably to meet that increased demand by tracking staffing levels, number of orders, quality, and turn-around time. _x000D_
_x000D_
Long-term we will work with Warm Heart to monitor seasonal income and employment in Phrao District and at its cooperatives. Finally, Trade Monkey will consider its Project Inspire project successful if our team is able to replicate our business-based development model in other communities, always being sure to assess specific community needs to identify appropriate goals and projects.
As this project will be integrated into Trade Monkey and Warm Heart's existing workload, both organizations will necessarily contribute certain labor, organizational, and transportation costs beyond the Project Inspire budget._x000D_
Trade Monkey will independently contribute grant management, support services including product design, photography, and sales management, its own labor costs, and any transportation and marketing costs in excess of our Project Inspire budget. _x000D_
_x000D_
Warm Heart will donate the majority of Ms. Somjai's salary as well as labor costs of any other staff involved with the project. _x000D_
project_summary:
Trade Monkey is a social enterprise that connects consumers to trendy, unique, high-quality handmade products while actively promoting stable incomes in developing communities. Without targeted design, production, and marketing strategies, local artisans struggle to access the global marketplace and scale up their businesses. Such artisans are overwhelmingly women who provide the primary income for their families. Trade Monkey already closes the gap between female artisans and overseas consumers, but is poised to expand our socially responsible business practices into direct reinvestment into our producer communities._x000D_
Project Inspire presents an ideal opportunity for Trade Monkey to develop its social impact program via a much-needed development project with one of our local producers in Northern Thailand. In collaboration with our nonprofit partner Warm Heart, Trade Monkey will use the $25,000 grant to create stable jobs for women in rural Phrao District while building a sustainable and innovative model for future development projects._x000D_
_x000D_
In operation since 2008, Warm Heart Worldwide, Inc. is an American nonprofit based in Phrao District, one of the poorest districts in Northern Thailand. Warm Heartâs Thai operations are managed by the Warm Heart Foundation, a Thai NGO registered with the Ministry of the Interior. Warm Heart supports 25 children in nearby schools and operates childrenâs homes for 40 children, microenterprise programs for landless women, coffee programs for mountain farmers, and community public health programs._x000D_
_x000D_
Warm Heart has strong community connections, but lacks capacity to effectively market its microenterprise products on the global market. Trade Monkey and Warm Heart have formed a valuable partnership where Trade Monkey provides design, market access, and organizational capacity. Our partnership melds the best of Warm Heartâs nonprofit, service-providing structure with Trade Monkeyâs expertise in international trade and marketing._x000D_
_x000D_
Through a joint community needs assessment, we have identified seasonal unemployment and low wages as the most pressing problems confronting local women. In Phrao, women work in rice planting and harvesting seven months of the year and can earn 120 baht ($4) per day. During the five months of the dry season, however, there is no agricultural work in Phrao, and able-bodied adults migrate to the South to find work. A core of middle aged women stay home to care for family members. These women are the Warm Heart Microenterprise Programâs target population. They are already skilled artisans, but currently lack organizational structure, design experience, and marketing skills. _x000D_
_x000D_
With this grant, we will help these women create an effective organization and secure stable, dry season â and eventually year around â jobs. Specifically, we will provide capital equipment, working capital, business development training, design consulting, and global marketing. _x000D_
_x000D_
We will begin by purchasing high-quality, industrial sewing machines, glue guns, and grommet machines. This capital equipment will allow women to significantly increase production, improve quality, and diversify the products they make. Specifically, industrial machines allow artisans to work with thick materials such as rice bags, vinyl, and recycled seat belts to create âupcycledâ products. By using discarded materials, such products are inexpensive to produce, unique pieces, and have low environmental impact. Warm Heart will permanently transfer the capital equipment to the cooperative once it is fully trained and functioning ($3440 into capital investment, $480 into transportation). _x000D_
_x000D_
The key to forming an effective cooperativeâ and to the subsequent expansion to additional groups in Phrao â will be Warm Heartâs Microenterprise Manager, Suwaphit Somjai. Ms. Somjai will draw on Warm Heartâs strong community connections to bring skilled artisans into a cohesive group. Ms. Somjai brings her previous experience as a designer, retail manager, pattern cutter, and sample sewer; through this project she will become a financial and business skills trainer. Her permanent place at Warm Heart and in the Phrao community will guarantee our projectâs continuing impact ($2,700 into manager subsidy)._x000D_
_x000D_
We also anticipate engaging the Micro Economic Development Foundation, a Thai organization based in Chiang Mai, to provide business literacy training to the cooperative. Rather than dictating solutions to local women, the consultant will assess their needs and goals to form the cooperative that works best for them ($640 into training)._x000D_
_x000D_
It is not enough to simply give women equipment and a business structure; a business requires working capital to purchase raw materials and pay artisans. We will use a portion of the grant to cover materials and pay fair wages based on Warm Heartâs existing payment structure â 166% of current rainy season agricultural wages. Furthermore, we will subsidize Ms. Somjaiâs salary in recognition of her important role as Project Manager. Trade Monkey will independently contribute grant management, support services, its own labor costs, and some marketing costs ($11,446 into working capital)._x000D_
_x000D_
Effective marketing strategies are crucial for sustainable economic growth, but are often missing from development programs in marginalized communities. Trade Monkey will design a line of upcycled products for U.S. college students. We have targeted this demographic for its size, interest in social impact, and because of timing. By the end of the dry season (May 2015) the Phrao cooperative will have completed 2,000 items ready for the 2015 fall semester. Then, we will launch a specific marketing campaign targeting eight college campuses with which Trade Monkey has existing connections. Investing in marketing will be the key to continuing the project ($1,200 into distribution; $5,060 into marketing)._x000D_
_x000D_
Through sales revenue, we aim to double the grant and reinvest the first year profits back into Warm Heart and the Phrao cooperative. After assessing lessons learned, Trade Monkey will expand its business-based development model to its other partner communities. As such, our Project Inspire proposal will exponentially impact more women in the long-term. _x000D_
_x000D_
Trade Monkey will launch its social impact program in 2015 regardless, specifically focusing on empowering women through sustainable business practices that provide market access, marketable designs, and organizational capacity. However, the grant will allow us to conduct a more impactful pilot project than we could achieve on our own initial fundraising. Moreover, we are eager to participate in the Singapore training, which will not only provide us with mentorship but allow us to brainstorm and problem-solve with our peers.
project_details:
We are solving a two-fold problem common to South East Asia and rural agricultural communities: seasonal employment and market access. In the dry season, women age 45-60 remain as care providers while the working age population migrates away. Men are absent as providers, either leaving or remaining unemployed at home. Women struggle to provide for their families with inconsistent handicraft jobs that provide a meager but primary source of income._x000D_
Warm Heart works to provide reliable product orders and pays a competitive 200 baht a day during the dry season; their goal is to motivate women to run their businesses year-round. However, Warm Heart lacks capacity to develop effective design, production, and marketing strategies. In a productive partnership, Trade Monkey provides such strategies and global market access. Warm Heart and Trade Monkey intend to develop a model applicable to womenâs cooperatives in general, linking business and community development for sustainable change.

project_details_other:
Young people have a glaring lack of interest in agriculture stemming from the low returns characterising the agricultural sector due to lack of technical skills, poor management practices and a general lack of understanding of agricultural value chains. This project addresses these misconceptions, especially among the young girls by proving that agricultural ventures have income generation and wealth creation opportunities; that farming can also be a successful business venture and that there are various disciplines aligned to agriculture and not limited to just subsistence crop production. The young women who participate in the program will be empowered through education on productive living. There will be sustainable development in the community attained through the establishment of income-generating projects. The community will also benefit from sustainable development models which include access to finance through microfinance opportunities and internal savings and lending schemes.
The basic agriculture course will have a strong focus (60%) on practical project assignments carried out under supervision by experienced teaching staff. For those, market linkages with some private sector entities are already established which shall be expanded. Young Farmer Clubs will be established and extension services set up. The Agricultural Technical Education Programs will be synchronised to the season (crops) livestock production cycles and markets. They will comprise basic training on universal agricultural principles followed by specialisation which is exchangeable according to regions, and markets. When the programme participants return to practice, assessment on productivity and support will continue. The key to the success of this approach is on leveraging on strategic partnerships and market linkages with the private sector which will ensure that support and technical advice continues throughout the production cycle. 
Girls are the most powerful force for change in the world. Better lives for girls mean better lives for everyone in their communities - their brothers, fathers, future husbands and sons. When you improve a girlâs life through education, health, safety and opportunity, these changes have a positive ripple effect. As an educated mother, an active, productive citizen and a prepared employee, she is the most influential force in her community to break the cycle of poverty. Expected project results include:- 100 girls empowered with agricultural technical skills, entrepreneurial skills and financial literacy who have access to capital to enable them to set up their own agriculture based, income generating projects._x000D_
- A viable revolving fund and internal lending and savings scheme where members can borrow money for their farming enterprises._x000D_
- Access to markets and market linkages for the farming ventures._x000D_
- Self-confident and self-aware young girls who contribute positively to community development._x000D_
- Improved household food security and income generating capacity._x000D_

A mid-term internal and end-of-project external evaluation will be held to assess the impact of providing an agriculture-based technical education, technical and entrepreneurial skills development to rural young girls who did not complete formal primary education on their livelihoods and welfare. An external evaluation will be commissioned towards the end of the project. The evaluations will specifically assess best practices and methods for a national roll out and will form the basis for the development of a roll-out plan. Success will be evidenced through the number of successful agricultural enterprises set up by the girls on the program. Success will also be evidenced through the viability of the revolving fund and the internal savings and lending schemes. As more and more young girls are trained on entrepreneurship and financial literacy, they will get access to small funds to enable them to set up their ventures. Their ability to repay into the revolving fund is key to the success of the project. Household standards of living are also expected to improve through better nutrition, access to healthcare and access to education. Several social ills are also expected to decrease. Girls play a crucial role in solving the most persistent development problems facing the world today. By investing in their economic potential through education and by delaying child marriage and teen pregnancy, issues such as HIV and AIDS can be resolved and the cycle of poverty can be broken.
Funding has been obtained through the Zimbabwe Farmer's Union, Fit for Life project to empower the girls through the catch up literacy and numeracy skills as well as provide them with the agriculture-based technical skills. The funding we now require for the project is for the Entrepreneurship training, Life Skills training, Financial literacy training as well as seed capital for the revolving fund.
project_summary: With $25,000 our project is going to provide an integrated approach to youth empowerment which comprises of agriculture-based technical training, entrepreneurship training, financial literacy training, access to microfinance through a revolving fund to enable the participant to set up their own viable enterprises.The project is going to improve the livelihoods of 100 rural young women, whose ages range from 14 years to 25 years, who did not complete primary education by providing an integrated approach to youth empowerment. The program is going to provide a 'catch-up' program on literacy/numeracy for the target group, enabling them to participate in technical training. The technical education which includes horticulture, small livestock rearing, poultry and potato production, will increase productivity and thereby self-sustainability, income generation and employability among the target young women. The project will also facilitate the development of sustainable models for agricultural input and output market linkages as well as linkages to potential employment opportunities for the young girls. The project also will help the young women reclaim their dignity that poverty denies them and enable them to build successful futures for themselves and their communities. The fundamental goal is to build confidence and self-worth in the young girls, creating positive behaviour change and improving their quality of life. The project also provides the young women with life skills training, combined with microfinance opportunity and a safe space, so they can become self-confident and self-reliant individuals within their families and their communities. The project will also provide training on Personal Care, Hygiene and Grooming , training on Sexual Reproductive Health as well as provision of sanitary towels with the hope of lowering pregnancy rates and reducing risky social behaviour through sexual reproductive health interventions. Once fully equipped the girls will finally be training on entrepreneurship and financial literacy through internal savings and lending schemes so that they get access to finance to set up their ventures. Part of the $25,000 will be set aside for a revolving fund for their projects.
project_details: Education is central to human development and has the power to transform societies. The once exemplary educational system in Zimbabwe was impacted from the rapidly deteriorating economic situation. The proportion of children completing primary school between 2006 and 2009 fell from almost 70% to below 40%; in rural areas this figure was as low as 22%. The danger is that a 'lost generation' without or with only rudimentary education will grow up in Zimbabwe and will impact negatively on the economic and social development of the country. Household financial constraint account for the biggest reason for school drop outs. Poor nutrition, having to work for food and money, illness and death of parents/guardians due to HIV/AIDS also prevent the children from attending school. Unfortunately, young girls are at a disadvantage as they are forced to drop out of school and this project seeks to give these girls a second chance in life.

project_summary:
GWWI addresses the lack of womenâs leadership in their local communities by training African women leaders to become water and sanitation technicians, trainers, and social entrepreneurs through sustainable, demand-driven clean water initiatives. _x000D_
The $25,000 will be used to provide seed grants for 10 teams of women who will be selected to attend our Women and Water Training Program. This program is unique in that it addresses one of the core problems that result in the lack of sustainable water projects. The Food and Agriculture Association of the UN has found that the exclusion of women in community water and sanitation projects is the cause of their high rate of failure. _x000D_
_x000D_
In this unique 2.5 year Women and Water training program, GWWI will equip women with the tools and skills to address all their local water needs. This intensive leadership and hands-on technical training program equips trainees with the tools, capacity, and support necessary to offer and implement a variety of valuable water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) solutions to their communities. Trainees also develop the capacity to professionalize their services and market their skills as technical experts. Thus, GWWI âlevels the playing fieldâ for women offering in-demand services who can be sometimes be excluded from social, economic, and political equity in the region._x000D_
_x000D_
GWWI trains women to become WASH technicians, trainers and social entrepreneurs._x000D_
_x000D_
â¢ As technicians, women are trained to build self-supply WASH solutions such as rainwater harvesting systems, toilets, and water treatment technologies. _x000D_
â¢ As trainers, women offer hygiene education in the community to encourage proper hygiene practices, water source protection strategies to reduce the risk of water-related disease as well as train other women in construction._x000D_
â¢ As social entrepreneurs, women and the organizations for which they work diversify their funding streams. GWWIs training program equips women to diversify their income on five different levels:_x000D_
o As masons and trainers â Women can professionalize their services by constructing multiple WASH technologies and training others to do so_x000D_
o As manufacturers - Women earn income by making and selling water and hygiene related products like soap, shampoo and reusable sanitary pads _x000D_
o As grantees â the women-led organizations they work for have increased access to international WaSH funding_x000D_
o As contrators â GWWI prepares the organizations to qualify for local government contracts_x000D_
o As micro-loan agents â GWWI has established a groundbreaking partnership with KIVA to help the organizations establish themselves as loan agents offering micro-loans to finance their own projects _x000D_
_x000D_
The GWWI training transfers knowledge and technologies to grassroots women leaders in the areas of 1) water access 2) water quality and 3) and sanitation. Women trainees trained as WASH specialist have greater opportunities in their communities as leaders, equipped with specific knowledge and skills to help solve water and sanitation concerns. _x000D_
_x000D_
The training cycle will be conducted in 3 phases over the course of the 2.5 years._x000D_
_x000D_
In each phase, trainees: _x000D_
1. Attend one participatory and hands-on intensive Core Training led by African women trainers_x000D_
2. Apply for and receive seed funding to build WaSH technologies in their communities. GWWI regional coordinators and our Head Tech Trainer provide onsite coaching and hands-on training._x000D_
3. Replicate the same technologies, but on their own. Although GWWI continues to provide online and virtual coaching to support trainees in reaching their goals, trainees are empowered to mobilize money and resources and to construct the technology independently. _x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 1 - Water Access. Trainees will learn to:_x000D_
â¢ Introduction to WaSH_x000D_
â¢ Construct various rainwater catchments and water storage tanks _x000D_
â¢ Develop WaSH Advocacy campaigns_x000D_
â¢ Mobilize resources and facilitate participatory integrated community development techniques_x000D_
â¢ Conduct water quality testing, and promote best hygiene practices for disease reduction_x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 2 â Sanitation. Trainees will learn to:_x000D_
â¢ Construct toilets (ventilated improved pit latrines and composting toilets) and menstruation cleaning bays_x000D_
â¢ Manufacture soap, shampoo, perfume, reusable menstrual pads and toilet digesters_x000D_
â¢ Write compelling funding proposals _x000D_
â¢ Develop business and entrepreneurial skills_x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 3 â Water Quality. Trainees will learn to:_x000D_
â¢ Manufacture water treatments like chlorine, slow sand water filters, solar pasteurizers_x000D_
â¢ Generate income by professionalizing their water quality services and making and selling products _x000D_
â¢ Conduct water quality testing as a marketing tool to promote their products and good hygiene practices_x000D_
â¢ Design a WaSH program to integrate into their existing social programs_x000D_
â¢ Be effective leaders providing demand driven services to their communities_x000D_
_x000D_
Specifically for this $25,000 grant, GWWI will apply this towards Phase 1 of the training, supplying seed grants and brick making machines. It will equip the women to build their first technology in their home villages with our financial and technical support so they can train other women. After they use the seed grant to build their first technology, they are then required to raise enough money and community support to build the next one. _x000D_

Since its launch in 2008, GWWI has trained and supported select grassroots women leaders to launch their own water and sanitation projects in Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, South Africa, Ghana, Nigeria, Togo, Liberia, and Cameroon. To date, the projects implemented by Women and Water Training graduates have provided over 35,000 people with improved water access and/or sanitation and 15,000 people with the skills and practices to reduce the risk of water related diseases. _x000D_

GWWI is changing that. We train women to become water and sanitation technicians, trainers and social entrepreneurs. They can build water technologies, train other women and make money!

SUMMARY: Udaan seeks to prevent the intergenerational cycle of prostitution among girls living in the red light area. It is the primary project of Apne Aap Womenâs Collective (AAWC)._x000D_
ABOUT AAWC: Founded in 1998, Apne Aap Womenâs Collective is an anti-trafficking organization that serves the women and children of Kamathipura, the red light area of Mumbai that is also one of the largest and oldest red light areas in Asia. We operate three programs: (1) Umeed (âhopeâ) for women in brothel-based prostitution (ages 18+), (2) Udaan (âflightâ) for daughters of Umeed women (ages 6-18), and (3) Umang (âjoyâ) for toddlers of Umeed women (ages 2-5). Through these programs, we provide our members with the tools and resources to create a better quality of life. Since 1998, we have served more than 2,800 women and children._x000D_
_x000D_
ABOUT UDAAN: Udaan is unique because we empower these girls to develop a passion for education and confidence in their individual talents and abilities, despite the socio-cultural messages that they are valuable only for sex, child-bearing and housekeeping. Moreover, unlike many other NGOs in this sector, we encourage aspirational professions and genuine socioeconomic mobility, not just vocational training in menial skills and low-wage positions. Once they are empowered to make voluntary and autonomous decisions, and become financially self-reliant, they can also help their mothers exit the vicious cycle of violence, exploitation and debt bondage from their pimps or brothel owners, and relocate to places away from the red-light area._x000D_
_x000D_
IMPACT: Since 1998, 100% of Udaan graduates have found mainstream professions outside of prostitution, and 97%+ pass their board exams. Our alumni have obtained Bachelorâs and Masterâs degrees and launched successful careers in respected professions like accounting, beauty, business, dance, hospitality management, luxury cuisine, nursing, photography, retail, teaching, social work, etc._x000D_

At adolescence, they face solicitation on the street and persuasive gifts from brothel owners. Meanwhile, the demand for younger girls is rising due to various myths, e.g., sex with a virgin cures HIV/AIDS. As such, girls seldom develop the academic and professional skills to secure a mainstream job and, consequently, face a high risk of coercion into second-generation prostitution. It is not uncommon for new Udaan girls to say, âI want to be a brothel madam when I grow upâ, since the madam is the wealthiest and most powerful person in their world.
