Currently the Indian Sanitary Napkins market is 2,000 crores which is remaining untapped due to the socio-economic hurdles.We hope that this SHG based model would tap this market resulting in huge increase in Napkins usage in rural women, resulting in safe practice in reproductive hygiene,reduction in RTIs, less risk of cervical cancer creating a healthy community. The other underlying impact of this project is to bring rural community women together in an environment where they feel empowered.Local community women who are currently working as health worker, will be the SHG members.Being socially acceptable & highly regarded in the community, they will be the educator, marketer and distributor to the local women.The SHG members will be earning a decent income, running a business and satisfying a basic yet very private need of all womenfolk and will be seen as role-models. We envision that, the success of this women-led SHGs will encourage other rural communities to adopt this model.
In conjunction with local community,we are providing Maternal & Child HealthCare(MRCH). We have achieved 95% ANC coverage (National avg 19.6%) & 100% institutional delivery in this area.Our physicians & women health workers are educating women about importance of safe,sanitary menstrual practice including usage of sanitary napkins. We have already seen an interest among the local women in using sanitary napkin provided the cost is low & directly available from the Women Health workers. We will establish two SHGs & corresponding manufacturing unit in two Gram Panchayet/Community catering to approx 5000 women in each community(refer Population.xls file). For each pilot sites the two short term impacts are: A.Increase use of Sanitary Napkins.Goal is to achieve 50% usage by 1st year & 95% usage by 2nd year. B.Making the Self-Help Group(SHG) self-sustained by 1st year & generate enough profit by 3rd year, which will be used as capital to open up another SHG run unit in a nearby community.
We are committed to achieve the following two results: 1. Raising awareness of reproductive hygiene & increase use of sanitary napkins among the community women.Goal is to achieve 50% usage by 1st year & 95% usage by 2nd year.Quantitative &qualitative health surveys in Maternity Healthcare camps and door to door survey will be the mechanism of evaluating this success. 2. The other success factor of the project will be making the Self-Help Group(SHG) self-sustained by 1st year & generate enough profit by 3rd year (Approx $8000) from itâs operation, so that the same model can be replicated in another rural area with collaboration with local NGOs and community. The profit will augment the initial seed funding required to do all the setup of a new SHG and manufacturing unit.
Our project evaluation is a rigorous,scientific process following either of the options. 1)The population is divided into 2 arms:The intervention arm & Control arm (intervention not applied). 2)Compare before intervention(baseline) & after intervention (follow-up) data among whole population. The 2nd option is currently being followed. For accurate collection of baseline data, Field Assessment, Qualitative Surveys(Focus Group Discussions & In Depth Interviews) and finally Quantitative survey based on properly designed questionnaire has been conducted. During & after the Intervention the same questionnaire(slightly expanded) will be used for follow up data collection for final evaluation.Evaluation is a continuous process in our project, starting from the onset of the project and continuing during implementation & operations. We have already obtained baseline data regarding current usage of napkins & related disease burdens.During implementation,among local community women, appropriate questionnaire based health surveys will be conducted before and after intervention to evaluate the change in awareness in reproductive hygiene. The primary success criteria, usage of sanitary napkins compared to the baseline data will be collected as follow-up data during the last three months of operation phase.The reduction of RTIs & other diseases will be collected over time as part of our âArogyaMaternalCare' health program to evaluate the reduction in the associated disease burdens. 
The seed of our organization was planted in Rahimpur Village in India in 2009, when a group of young medical students & public health researchers got together to bring quality Maternal & Child Healthcare.Realizing potential of technology, the physicians started to collaborate with few engineering students & professionals for better delivery of Healthcare in rural India. In this site 'ArogyaMaternalCare' project was started initially funded by few social entrepreneurs and by volunteer support. The need of this project, low-cost sanitary napkin, was identified in the 'ArogyaMaternalCare' project and for the initial capital investment we applied for few projects. The project was semi-finalist in the Dell Social Innovation in 2013. Later, on 5th April, 2014, it won the Virginia Gildersleeve International Fund (VGIF) award for 2014, as one of the 37 grants from around the world and we have just started to implement our first SHG & the sanitary napkin production unit in our first community.
project_name: Self-Sustainable community based model for producing & distributing low-cost sanitary napkins in Rural India via women Self-Help Groups (SHG)
project_summary:
In rural India, 97% of woman lack access to basic hygienic means that allow them to stay clean throughout their menstrual cycle. Women resort to unhygienic alternatives like old cloth rags, husks, sand, or even ashes which results in vaginal infections often leading to chronic Reproductive Tract Infections (RTIs), pelvic inflammatory diseases, Child-Birth issues and sometimes life-threatening cervical cancerm the most prevalent form of cancer among woman in India.A countrywide survey conducted AC Nielsen and Plan India, among women and adolescent girls all throughout India revealed that nearly 70 percent of women said that their families cannot afford sanitary napkins and that over 88 percent of women resorted to shocking alternatives such as cloth, ashes and husk sand during menstruation, thereby causing severe reproductive health problems. The study showed that Reproductive Tract Infections (RTIs) was 70% more common among women using unhygienic practices while 12% of women who use napkins are at a lower risk of cervical cancer which is the most prevalent form of cancer among women in developing nations. The primary reason cited for this problem in rural India is unaffordability and high cost of sanitary napkins whose average price range is approximately Rs. 60/- to as high as Rs 100/- for a pack of 8. As the sanitary napkin products are not available in a single pack, the rural women, who are mostly daily wage earner at Rs 120/day, needs to shell out Â½ of her wage to buy a single pack of Sanitary napkin. The cheapest sanitary napkin available at Rs 30/- for a pack of 8, is also not cheap enough, if we take into consideration the large Below Poverty Line(BPL) population ( The threshold of BPL population in rural India is Rs 32/- day). Also, the cheap napkins are so poor in quality that instead of one, multiple napkins (at-least two) are required in a day, thus effectively costing twice as much or Rs. 60/- (Rs 30 X 2) for the whole period_x000D_
Still, a large population of rural women, who could have afford the sanitary napkins, do not use them for the following two reasons:_x000D_
â¢ Low awareness of proper reproductive hygienic practices. This is probably the biggest barrier for adoption, as reproductive hygiene education and sexual education is not part of any education system in India. The adolescent girls only form of such education is from her mother and grandmother, who themselves had practiced the unhygienic behaviors for years and thus do not see any harm in the practices of using old cloths during menstruation. Though in urban India the trend has changed in recent years, but in rural India, these topics remained significantly taboo among all, irrespective of social and economic status. _x000D_
â¢ Poor Accessibility and Social barrier. Sanitary Napkins are only available in the Pharmacies generally located in the largest village in that area. Without proper metallic road and public transportation, it is very difficult to reach the pharmacy. On top of that, social issues prevent women from obtaining sanitary napkins at local pharmacies due to embarrassment on the topic. As all pharmacies are run by men, women feel socially uncomfortable asking for these products from male pharmacists._x000D_
To solve these three hurdles, we are enabling local women, currently working as women health worker, to form Self-Help Groups (SHG) to produce low-cost, yet high quality Sanitary Napkins which will be distributed by them (as Direct Sales Channels) to the local community women, as part of the existing door-to-door to maternal health services program. _x000D_
We are changing definition of Self-Help Group(SHG). While traditional SHGs are generally, micro-finance groups, our SHGs will produce tangible products, whose need has been organically identified (Instead of market survey,the product/need was organically identified from the Reproductive Health programs of our team which also created awareness of using napkin), and revenue,similar to a manufacturing startup. The women SHG members working with local women will create an environment of women empowerment not only in the immediate communities, but also will create a ripple effect of women empowerment by means of producing something very close, personal and important for a women's life cycle, in nearby and fur-flung rural communities of India._x000D_
The high-level plan and activities of executing the project is:_x000D_
â¢ The SHG members will act as the educators of safe & sanitary feminine hygiene practices among local women and the necessity of sanitary napkins. Currently this activity is being executed by the local physicians and the members._x000D_
â¢ The SHG members will be trained in inexpensive, low-maintenance manufacturing equipment ($2500 machine compared to high-cost machine of $500,000) producing 50% cheaper sanitary napkins compared to what is available in the market, which will still be profitable thus self-sustaining the SHG within a year.. This machine has already been invented by an Indian social entrepreneur, ArunachalamMuruganantham, and is capable of producing 1000 high-quality sanitary napkins per day at a total cost of Rs 1 (including all overhead) which is significantly more affordable than any other sanitary napkin on the market (Rs. 3.50/-). As such, for a pack of 8, these sanitary napkins can be sold at Rs. 15 earning profit and still will be 50% less compared to the cheapest, low quality sanitary napkins available in the market. Also, unlike the current sanitary napkins which are only available in packs of 7 or 8, we will sell the sanitary napkins individually at Rs.1.50 to Rs. 2. This price point will make it more affordable to the daily wage earner rural women._x000D_
â¢ The SHG members will be trained in end to end business process, such as marketing, sales, distribution and finance. _x000D_
â¢ The SHG members will create a direct distribution/sales channel to the local community women as part of the existing door-to-door to maternal health services program . _x000D_
The SHGs are also deploying unique distribution channels to increase usage & sales of sanitary napkins_x000D_
â¢ Unlike the current sanitary napkins which are only available in packs of 7 or 8, the SHG will sell the sanitary napkins individually at Rs.1.50 to Rs. 2. This will be achieved by deploying Vending Machines at strategic and convenient locations (schools, colleges, community halls) where the women can securely and privately obtain individual sanitary napkins by dropping a coin of Rs. 2/- only._x000D_
â¢ Finally, create a multi-prong distribution channel for taking it to the all women in the rural area, such as, recommending it through local physicians, government community health workers (ASHA workers) as well as convincing the local government health officials to provide it through the public primary health centers, government hospitals and village offices and community centers (such as Panchayet office, Clubs)_x000D_
We have identified our pilot site for this project in a rural community in West Bengal, India where we have experienced similar unhygienic practices during conducting Maternal and Child healthcare services. Currently, a few women volunteer health workers are providing door-to-door Maternal and Child Health Care in this site, [which is in Jangipara Community block in West Bengal, India consisting of following Gram Panchayats (Villages): Antpur, Dilakash, Furfurah, Jangipara, Kotalpur, Mundalika, Radhanagore, Rajbalhat I, Rajbalhat II and Rahimpur]. These women will be the initial members of our Self-Help group._x000D_
project_details:
The problems are two-folds for rural Indian women:1)The ubiquitous issue of women empowerment in male dominant society.Our approach is gradual empowerment, by first training & employing few women as Health Workers. It is followed by skill-set & business training turning them into entrepreneurs forming SHG. They are not only self-sustained but being trained in domains ranging from healthcare to manufacturing, they are role models for others. Organizationally, the SHGs success & profit will help in replicating such SHG in other rural communities._x000D_
2)The second one is wider in scope & was organically identified from the work of the Health Workers. They identified the lack of awareness in reproductive hygiene combined with non-usage of napkin resulting in high occurrence of infections & diseases among rural women. Being the care-taker of the family & often being the only wage earner earning daily wage in back-breaking jobs, this health issue affect them & their family significantly.

project_summary:
We are a socially responsible fashion company that empowers women of Hohoe, Ghana through jobs, education and skills training. We started our business in 2010 with 4 employees. Four years later our impact has greatly increased - we now have 35 full-time employees and up to 20 part-time employees in Ghana. Our employees have access to a number of trainings including literacy classes, financial education, health and business among others. In order to further expand the reach of our company, we would like to build a community space so that we can open our classes to the public and create a batik apprenticeship program. _x000D_
Building a Community Classroom and Batik Center will allow us to grow our impact. After four years of working in partnership with our employees in Ghana, we have learned how to empower them to make positive changes in their lives. We have worked with them to improve spending habits and save money. Weâve learned the best way to bring a local expert in to do workshops with our employees. We know that given the chance, our employees want not just to improve their reading abilities, but that they also want to participate in leadership building activities as well as staff sport matches. _x000D_
_x000D_
Weâve seen the impact that these classes, workshops and activities have had upon our employees. Weâve always wanted to open these programs to other women within the community that we work, but we have never had the space. As it is, our current classes are held outside and are often cancelled if the weather is bad (which it is, six months of the year). By building a Community Classroom, we will be able to offer stronger, better programming and open this resource up to the community. _x000D_
_x000D_
Within the last year, we as a company have started to experiment with batik making. This is a style of textile dyeing in Ghana that uses wax and different color dyes to create beautiful prints on fabric. Though popular in Ghana, there are very few trained batik artists in the community in which we work. We would like to open a Batik Center alongside our community classroom so that we may create additional jobs and apprenticeship opportunities in the region. In January, we secured a partnership with Vans in which we produced batik fabric for a line of shoes. If we are able to create this Batik Center and train more women in the art of wax printing, we will be able to bring additional revenue to the region through similar partnerships in the future. _x000D_
_x000D_
Unemployment and underemployment are tremendous problems for women in Ghana. In a 2012 survey, our employees reported struggling to make ends-meet before coming to work for Della. Most estimate that they earned less than one dollar per day._x000D_
_x000D_
Those who were employed beforehand worked as seamstresses in independent shops or at home. They found that their income was inconsistent - some weeks they would do very well and earn enough money to provide for their families, but often, monthly income did not cover living expenses. This means seamstresses would forgo meals or have to withdraw their children from school until they earned enough to pay the fees. With the money from the grant, we would be able to create more jobs in our community center as well as empower more members of the community who would gain access to involvement opportunities. _x000D_
_x000D_
In addition to increasing our positive impact on the lives of the women with whom we work, we are dedicated to ensuring our expansion efforts are sustainable and appropriate for the community in which we work. When we do construct our community classroom and batik center, we will use sustainable building materials and local building techniques. Like batik, these traditional building methods are quickly being forgotten as Western influence sweeps through the region. By constructing a facility using Rammed-Earth techniques, we will showcase the technique and retrain local workers in this construction process. _x000D_
_x000D_
We will use the $25,000 to sustainably construct the center, expand our programs and raise awareness about their availability in the community. _x000D_
project_details:

project_name: Empowering young women through soccer and entrepreneurship
project_summary:
RV United (RVU) is the first ever girlsâ soccer club in Khayelitsha, South Africaâs second-largest township, and is a product of a grassroots movement ignited by young women in the community. In a country with high unemployment and countless barriers to womenâs equality, RV United works to empower young women through the dual-pronged approach of soccer and entrepreneurship. In early 2012, RVU formed when a group of adolescent girls ages 13-24 who had participated in Grassroot Soccer (GRS), a nonprofit that uses soccer as a tool to educate about HIV & AIDS, found they enjoyed playing soccer during the program. The girls wanted the opportunity to continue playing despite the widely held local belief that girls cannot, and should not, play soccer. Khayelitshaâwhich is home to an estimated half a million peopleâdid not have a single girlsâ soccer team, so the girls took the initiative to approach GRS staff with a proposal to form their own squad. Initially the players were hesitant to play publicly because boys would ridicule and tease them. However, after 6 months of public trainings and participation in local tournaments, attitudes began to visibly shift. Boys became true fans and supporters of the team, traveling to games and tracking playersâ statistics. _x000D_
By June 2012, the powerful impact of RV United in the community became vividly apparent. A group of girls ages 8-13 approached RVU and lobbied to form a team for younger players, RV Juniors. Meanwhile, girls from neighboring areas started contacting RVU coaches, pleading for transport money so they could travel 45 minutes every day to play. Within RVUâs first year, the club had expanded to three full-sized teams with 60 girls spanning two age divisions. The rapid growth of RVU emerged in response to the girlsâ desire to belong to a team and play soccer, challenging gender norms and emerging more empowered and confident young women._x000D_
_x000D_
While girls were eager to join RVU, paying for league fees, transport, and equipment was a constant challenge, as most players resided in households with an average annual income of R21,000 [~USD$1,980]. To address the issue, in 2013 RV United approached Ragball International (RBI) for a pilot project that uses soccer to develop financial empowerment. RBI is an income generation project in which youth produce handmade soccer balls from recycled materials in exchange for a fair wage and financial education. Ragballs are used in many parts of the country where young people are unable to access or afford real soccer balls. Together, the two organizations piloted an economic empowerment model that encourages playersâ entrepreneurial spirit and includes the creation of ragballs, a small income, workforce skills, and a workshop on financial education and business literacy._x000D_
_x000D_
During the pilot RVU players created 100 handmade ragballs, which sold online to international buyers. The girls agreed to split their portion of the proceeds: half went to the individual players as âwagesâ and the other half went towards the team budget for transport, equipment, and league fees. Their decision to work as a team to support RVU helped reinforce the lessons of earning money to support something about which they care deeply. Alongside the creation of the ragballs, the team participated in innovative soccer-based financial education and entrepreneurial training workshops and learned about saving, spending, and how to plan for their futures. Based on the Aflatoun Social & Financial Education curriculum, the Ragball experience has allowed the girls access to new platforms to learn and share ideas about financial awareness among youth, including participation in the Child & Youth Finance Internationalâs Global Money Week._x000D_
_x000D_
RV United will use the USD$25,000 to elevate the partnership with RBI to a more comprehensive full-year program. The ragball workshops will continue throughout 2015, using a newly developed 17-session curriculum. _x000D_
_x000D_
The money will be used to achieve three objectives. First, building off their early success selling the ragballs internationally, the team will identify and exploit local markets, setting up formal stalls in tourist markets and booths at events and soccer tournaments throughout Cape Town. This will raise local awareness about the changing status of soccer as a âboys-onlyâ sport in Khayelitsha while providing a new type of work experience for the players, who will work as salespeople at the stalls. Thus, they will have the opportunity to experience each step of the retail process: product development, manufacturing, and sales. As salespeople, they will share the inspiring story of RVU while selling products they created with their own handsâproducts they are truly proud of. _x000D_
_x000D_
Second, the RVU players will lead a re-design of the Ragball product, a chance to hone their skills in creative and innovative product design. The new balls will be more complex than the originals and will sell at a higher price, earning a higher profit for the team. The launch of a new product line will help the players gain additional ownership of this entrepreneurial venture and provide an opportunity to be truly creative. _x000D_
_x000D_
Third, this year-long program offers RBI the opportunity to refine and improve upon its model for use in RVU and other youth groupsâspecifically girlsâ soccer teamsâin Khayelitsha and the neighboring townships. During the workshop, the girls on the RVU Senior team will be trained as peer educators, gaining tools to spread their financial knowledge to other youth in the community. Money will go towards stipends and transport for these RV players to deliver the program to other youth groups and teams, and during HIV Testing & Counseling (HCT) soccer tournaments hosted by partner GRS. Based on the learnings from this year-long project, RBI will scale up its educational workshops by replicating the model to other GRS sites in Alexandra and Soweto, where community teams already exist. This expanded reach will provide a platform for individual economic empowerment to more youth across South Africa._x000D_
_x000D_
Thus, the income generation partnership with RBI provides the means to continue playing soccer and challenge gender norms and an opportunity for meaningful, first-hand entrepreneurial experience and training in healthy money management.
project_details:
In Khayelitshaâwhere unemployment reached 38% in 2011âpoverty, HIV/AIDS, and lack of education hinder successful entrepreneurship. Youth have little opportunity to advance beyond a high school education and in 2012, just 1 in 8 South Africans ages 15-25 was employed. Unable to find work, youth can become frustrated and disengaged. Young women are particularly vulnerable and often become victims of the myriad societal norms that keep them from reaching their full potential._x000D_
The absence of gender equity limits womenâs freedom to exercise their rights to work, recreation, and collective organization. The absence of females engaged in physical activity creates a cycle in which girls grow up without seeing themselves as physically active beyond childhood, instead associating sports with masculinity. project_name: Udaan (âflightâ): Empowering girls in one of Asiaâs oldest and largest red light areas
project_summary:
SUMMARY: Udaan seeks to prevent the intergenerational cycle of prostitution among girls living in the red light area. It is the primary project of Apne Aap Womenâs Collective (AAWC)._x000D_
ABOUT AAWC: Founded in 1998, Apne Aap Womenâs Collective is an anti-trafficking organization that serves the women and children of Kamathipura, the red light area of Mumbai that is also one of the largest and oldest red light areas in Asia. We operate three programs: (1) Umeed (âhopeâ) for women in brothel-based prostitution (ages 18+), (2) Udaan (âflightâ) for daughters of Umeed women (ages 6-18), and (3) Umang (âjoyâ) for toddlers of Umeed women (ages 2-5). Through these programs, we provide our members with the tools and resources to create a better quality of life. Since 1998, we have served more than 2,800 women and children._x000D_
_x000D_
ABOUT UDAAN: Udaan is unique because we empower these girls to develop a passion for education and confidence in their individual talents and abilities, despite the socio-cultural messages that they are valuable only for sex, child-bearing and housekeeping. Moreover, unlike many other NGOs in this sector, we encourage aspirational professions and genuine socioeconomic mobility, not just vocational training in menial skills and low-wage positions. Once they are empowered to make voluntary and autonomous decisions, and become financially self-reliant, they can also help their mothers exit the vicious cycle of violence, exploitation and debt bondage from their pimps or brothel owners, and relocate to places away from the red-light area._x000D_

project_details:
BACKGROUND: 88% of Kamathipura women are trafficked under the pretext of a job, marriage, or the banned devadasi system. Without education, employable skills, or even sufficient Hindi skills, they remain in prostitution to take care of their children._x000D_
PROBLEM: Surrounded by pornography, disease, narcotics, poor sanitation, and sexual abuse, their daughters lack a conducive study environment, role models, or even access to formal schooling. At adolescence, they face solicitation on the street and persuasive gifts from brothel owners. Meanwhile, the demand for younger girls is rising due to various myths, e.g., sex with a virgin cures HIV/AIDS. As such, girls seldom develop the academic and professional skills to secure a mainstream job and, consequently, face a high risk of coercion into second-generation prostitution. It is not uncommon for new Udaan girls to say, âI want to be a brothel madam when I grow upâ, since the madam is the wealthiest and most powerful person in their world.

project_summary:
Currently, Aakar Innovations has 10 sanitary napkin production units operating all over India where we have successfully launched our low-cost proprietary machinery, trained women to manufacture affordable pads adhered to Bureau of Indian Standardsâ quality requirements and validated market readiness in each unitâs location. With USD 25000, the amount would be used to propel Aakar to our next phase of operations, which is to perform community outreach and capacity training of women village entrepreneurs in order to enable the last mile distribution of sanitary pads to rural villages. _x000D_
We will train women village entrepreneurs for a period of 6 months where they are equipped with entrepreneurial skills so that they can firstly educate others on the importance of menstrual hygiene and secondly, sell sanitary napkins to their peers. Given the strong stigmatization which surrounds menstruation as well as the deeply entrenched traditions and customs practiced by local rural women, it is of paramount importance to train local village women entrepreneurs to become change agents in their own communities as we believe that true change has to come from within. Called Anandi ben (sister), these women would become role models for their own communities to emulate. _x000D_
_x000D_
In the following year, Aakar will expand to an additional 30 units, with each unit having 10 women trained on public speaking, sales and accounting. Each segment of the training curriculum i.e. sales is designed to last for 2 months and at the end, each village entrepreneur would be ready to carry out community outreach and awareness. They will also be confident enough to sell Anandi pads and have a sustainable livelihood with the skills being taught by the trainer. _x000D_
_x000D_
Each trainer is selected and employed based on a strict hiring metrics such that we ensure Aakar Social Ventures receive sufficient dedicated talent in the training arm. Each trainerâs salary amounts to USD 415 per month and we would hire 10 of these trainers. As such, by year end, they would have trained village entrepreneurs from 10 different units, which adds up to 30 units and 300 village entrepreneurs trained.
project_details: According to âEvery Womanâs Health Rightâ (A.C. Nielsen), there are 312 million women who do not have access to hygienic menstrual protection. This problem is multi-dimensional; on one hand, current sanitary napkins sold in the market are too expensive and inaccessible for the women to purchase and on the other hand, many do not yet understand the importance of proper menstrual hygiene. As a social enterprise, Aakar uses a hybrid business model where Aakar Innovations is built to equip rural areas, where access is most limited, with a proprietary sanitary napkin production unit which manufactures comfortable, affordable and 100% compostable pads while Aakar Social Ventures is founded to ensure women are educated on the importance of proper menstrual hygiene by training local women to be change agents in their own communities. Not only does this solve the problem of affordability, access and lack of awareness, it also creates livelihood when women are employed to make and sell the pads.

Lack of education, vocational training, social and economic skills reproduce the vicious cycle of poverty. In this neibourhood, poverty forces many to resort to muggings, prostitution, and drug dealing. The AMDG centre provides vocational and social skills training as well as basic literacy to women and girls. Empowering women and girls strengthens the community, improves economic condition of its residence, allows for further sustainable changes to eradicate poverty, addiction and prostitution. Main Goals of the Centre. Long term impact of the program includes: Empowering Women and girls/ Promoting Gender Equality and Social inclusion / Improvement of Economic condition and eradication of extreme poverty/ Possibilities for social mobility/ Improvement of physical and mental health condition of women / stronger sense of self and community 
- Improving Economic condition of families- Raising self confidence and sense of community_x000D_
- Healing physical and mental damages through improved social skills_x000D_
- Family planning Education will reduce the number new cases of sexually transmitted Illness_x000D_
- Literacy classes, allow women to improve the quality of their daily lives. _x000D_
- Supporting girls who struggle with their studies, reduces the possibility of dropping out of school and getting pulled into child labor 
The main objective of the centre is to enhance and strengthen the women and girlsâ ability in dealing with the great problems they face in their social and family environment. This can be achieved by creating appropriate conditions for the development and growth of women and girls who are condemned to forced marriage, unwanted pregnancies, family violence and discrimination. Every step in this direction brings us closer to the Centreâs objective of enablement of women and girls. As a belief in hope and in their ability had to blossom in women and girls, and each had to begin the change in herself, educating them was an obvious starting point. Therefore, literacy, vocational and art classes were set up in the Centre. This helped them to see the relevance of education in their own vocation. A simple example: âusing a tape measure in tailoring is better than using spans.â
The most important development that has taken place in the Centre has been the empowerment of women and girls. Their belief in their knowledge and ability, and the advancement of their self confidence, has developed into a great and beautiful truth, the effect of which has been evident, not only in the women and girls themselves, but also in families and men in the community. Those who have gone through this Centre are now employed as skilled workers in sewing workshops. The Centre has become a place for learning to read and write for women and girls of the neighbourhood, women and girls who, despite heavy work and child care, and under unfavourable conditions, willingly participate in literacy classes. Transformation is clearly apparent in parenting skills of mothers who have just learned to read and write. The teaching of âparenting skillsâ is a new light in the lives of these women that helps them to improve their approach to their children. They have gradually learned to raise their children without using force and punishment. In a neighbourhood where addiction and other social are prevalent, lessons in life skills can be the best teaching for a girl who is faced with these social problems. A girl who lives with addicted parents can learn how to take care of herself, and how to free herself from the vicious cycle and the unhealthy environment that dominates her family relations. This in itself is a great task. Some even travel long distances to come to the Centre becaus
45 Private funders provided the centre with steady annual support of USD $18000.The estimation is based on current exchange price of dollar.
project_name: Economic Empowerment of Women and Girls
project_summary:
The Centre was established in âDarvaze Gharâ neibourhood, located in the 12th district of Tehran municipality. Darvaze Ghar is considered to be the centre of drug dealership and drug distribution in Tehran. Material and cultural poverty, large and dense population, early marriages, high level of fertility, widespread level of addiction, low level of literacy, and absence of any vocational or educational centres for women and girls in the locality are some of the reasons behind our decision to establish AMDG in this neighbourhood. Providing training for girls and women is aimed at enabling them to rely on their own abilities, and play a greater part in provision of material needs of the family, but also to acquire skills necessary for facing problems at home and in the society. The ultimate aim is enabling them in a multi facetted process of work, education, and training._x000D_
The aim of the Centre is social and economic empowerment of local women and girls through education. The centre focuses on providing Literacy, vocational, social and economic skills in a safe and trusting environment. _x000D_
_x000D_
The prize of 25'000 dollars will allow us to: _x000D_
_x000D_
A) Purchase necessary machinery and tools;_x000D_
B) provide micro loans to women who are becoming self employed after completing their trainings;_x000D_
C) Expand our vocational and literacy classes;_x000D_
D) Create a healthier and safer work environment by repairing ventilation system of our building and install proper lighting._x000D_
E) Purchase necessary material such as fabric, stationary, etc.
project_details: Lack of education, vocational training, social and economic skills reproduce the vicious cycle of poverty. In this neibourhood, poverty forces many to resort to muggings, prostitution, and drug dealing. The AMDG centre provides vocational and social skills training as well as basic literacy to women and girls. A particularity of the teaching system at the Centre is the short distance between learning and production. Within a week after joining the Centre one learns to perform basic functions on the sewing machine. By sewing products (i.e. bed sheets) that requires only basic skills they become productive and gain a basic income. However, improving social skills, healthcare and family planning, and strengthening the community by encouraging the spirit of cooperation instead of competition, are all parts of the process of empowerment. This fund will allow us to expand our capacity, provide loans and foster and train women women and girls.

project_details_other:
In three years, the initial Phrao cooperative will become a self-sufficient business of at least 20 women in ongoing partnership with Warm Heart and Trade Monkey. Warm Heart will continue to expand its cooperative structure to provide ongoing employment in the dry season for Phrao women. Warm Heartâs long-term goal is to encourage women to maintain their businesses year-round rather than suspend them to work in lower-skilled, physically demanding agricultural work. Accordingly, we would consider the project a strong success if in three years at least 10 women maintained the cooperative year-round rather than returning to agricultural work. This would be a distinct shift in employment trends in Phrao District and a significant advance in empowering female artisans. _x000D_
Trade Monkey will have a permanent social impact staff that consistently assesses and undertakes development projects with all of its local partners. Three years out, Trade Monkey will be a leader in the social venture fiel
In the short-run, Trade Monkey and Warm Heart will support stable incomes for 10 women and their families in Phrao District. On average, each woman has a 5-person household in the dry season and often cares for her daughtersâ children while they are away working. Consequently, the first year will directly influence 50 family-members at home and approximately 15 daughters away working. Indirectly, Project Inspire will strengthen the ongoing work of Warm Heart who annually impacts the lives of 80 women in its other cooperatives, 65 children in its home and at schools, and all their families. Supporting Phrao women with steady employment will have a multiplier effect that will positively impact at least 215 women and children in the community by January 2016. By creating a sustainable cooperative model we also hope to build trust in the local community towards building additional cooperatives in future.
We are committed to: providing stable incomes for 10 Phrao women and their families during the economically uncertain dry season; creating a sustainable cooperative structure for Phrao women and Warm Heart to continue in future years; designing, producing, marketing, and selling 2,000 handmade, upcycled products to generate seed money for Warm Heart and the Phrao cooperative; launching a targeted marketing plan across 8 college campuses and online to generate and fulfill demand for those products; developing a social impact team and consistent business-based development model at Trade Monkey for future development projects. _x000D_
We are purposefully launching our social impact program with a small group of 10 women in Phrao to build our model and ensure that we have a lasting impact beyond the initial group. Trade Monkey currently works with 20 distinct producers in Thailand and Cambodia and are vetting an additional 30. We aim to expand the number of producers we partner with to over 100 by December 2015 and ultimately implement our social impact program in all our producer communities.
The biggest indicators of success will be the return of all ten Phrao women to the cooperative in January 2016, the establishment of the cooperative as a financially independent business, and demonstrated interest among other women in joining the cooperative structure. _x000D_
We will also verify success based on increased demand for Trade Monkey products among our target college-campus market; we will measure this through tracking sales, return customers, and referrals. At the producer-level, we will monitor the ability of Phrao cooperatives to expand sustainably to meet that increased demand by tracking staffing levels, number of orders, quality, and turn-around time._x000D_
 _x000D_
Long-term we will work with Warm Heart to monitor seasonal income and employment in Phrao District and at its cooperatives. Finally, Trade Monkey will consider its Project Inspire project successful if our team is able to replicate our business-based development model in other communities, always being sure to assess specific community needs to identify appropriate goals and projects.
As this project will become a part of Trade Monkey and Warm Heartâs ongoing workload, the two organizations will necessarily contribute certain costs out of their own budgets._x000D_
Trade Monkey will independently contribute grant management, support services, its own labor costs, and any transportation and marketing costs in excess of the Project Inspire budget._x000D_
_x000D_
Warm Heart will contribute the majority of Ms. Somjaiâs salary, labor costs for other staff involved in assisting with their microenterprise program, and some transportation costs.
project_summary:
Trade Monkey is a social enterprise that connects consumers to trendy, unique, high-quality handmade products while actively promoting stable incomes in developing communities. Without targeted design, production, and marketing strategies, local artisans struggle to access the global marketplace and scale up their businesses. Such artisans are overwhelmingly women who provide the primary income for their families. Trade Monkey already closes the gap between female artisans and overseas consumers, but is poised to expand our socially responsible business practices into direct reinvestment into our producer communities. _x000D_
Project Inspire presents an ideal opportunity for Trade Monkey to develop its social impact program via a much-needed development project with one of our local producers in Northern Thailand. In collaboration with our nonprofit partner Warm Heart, Trade Monkey will use the $25,000 grant to create stable jobs for women in rural Phrao District while building a sustainable and innovative model for future development projects._x000D_
 _x000D_
In operation since 2008, Warm Heart Worldwide, Inc. is an American nonprofit based in Phrao District, one of the poorest districts in Northern Thailand. Warm Heartâs Thai operations are managed by the Warm Heart Foundation, a Thai NGO registered with the Ministry of the Interior. Warm Heart supports 25 children in nearby schools and operates childrenâs homes for 40 children, microenterprise programs for landless women, coffee programs for mountain farmers, and community public health programs._x000D_
 _x000D_
Warm Heart has strong community connections, but lacks capacity to effectively market its microenterprise products on the global market. Trade Monkey and Warm Heart have formed a valuable partnership where Trade Monkey provides design, market access, and organizational capacity. Our partnership melds the best of Warm Heartâs nonprofit, service-providing structure with Trade Monkeyâs expertise in international trade and marketing._x000D_
 _x000D_
Through a joint community needs assessment, we have identified seasonal unemployment and low wages as the most pressing problems confronting local women. In Phrao, women work in rice planting and harvesting seven months of the year and can earn 120 baht ($4) per day. During the five months of the dry season, however, there is no agricultural work in Phrao, and able-bodied adults migrate to the South to find work. A core of middle aged women stay home to care for family members. These women are the Warm Heart Microenterprise Programâs target population. They are already skilled artisans, but currently lack organizational structure, design experience, and marketing skills._x000D_
 _x000D_
With this grant, we will help these women create an effective organization and secure stable, dry season â and eventually year around â jobs. Specifically, we will provide capital equipment, working capital, business development training, design consulting, and global marketing._x000D_
 _x000D_
We will begin by purchasing high-quality, industrial sewing machines, glue guns, and grommet machines. This capital equipment will allow women to significantly increase production, improve quality, and diversify the products they make. Specifically, industrial machines allow artisans to work with thick materials such as rice bags, vinyl, and recycled seat belts to create âupcycledâ products. By using discarded materials, such products are inexpensive to produce, unique pieces, and have low environmental impact. Warm Heart will permanently transfer the capital equipment to the cooperative once it is fully trained and functioning ($3440 into capital investment)._x000D_
 _x000D_
The key to forming an effective cooperativeâ and to the subsequent expansion to additional groups in Phrao â will be Warm Heartâs Microenterprise Manager, Suwaphit Somjai. Ms. Somjai will draw on Warm Heartâs strong community connections to bring skilled artisans into a cohesive group. Ms. Somjai brings her previous experience as a designer, retail manager, pattern cutter, and sample sewer; through this project she will become a financial and business skills trainer. Her permanent place at Warm Heart and in the Phrao community will guarantee our projectâs continuing impact ($2,700 into manager subsidy)._x000D_
 _x000D_
We also anticipate engaging the Micro Economic Development Foundation, a Thai organization based in Chiang Mai, to provide business literacy training to the cooperative. Rather than dictating solutions to local women, the consultant will assess their needs and goals to form the cooperative that works best for them ($640 into training)._x000D_
 _x000D_
It is not enough to simply give women equipment and a business structure; a business requires working capital to purchase raw materials and pay artisans. We will use a portion of the grant to cover materials and pay fair wages based on Warm Heartâs existing payment structure â 166% of current rainy season agricultural wages. Furthermore, we will subsidize Ms. Somjaiâs salary in recognition of her important role as Project Manager. Trade Monkey will independently contribute grant management, support services, its own labor costs, and some marketing costs ($11,466 into working capital)._x000D_
 _x000D_
Effective marketing strategies are crucial for sustainable economic growth, but are often missing from development programs in marginalized communities. Trade Monkey will design a line of upcycled products for U.S. college students. We have targeted this demographic for its size, interest in social impact, and because of timing. By the end of the dry season (May 2015) the Phrao cooperative will have completed 2,000 items ready for the 2015 fall semester. Then, we will launch a specific marketing campaign targeting eight college campuses with which Trade Monkey has existing connections. Investing in marketing will be the key to continuing the project ($1,200 into distribution; $5,060 into marketing)._x000D_
 _x000D_
Through sales revenue, we aim to double the grant and reinvest the first year profits back into Warm Heart and the Phrao cooperative. After assessing lessons learned, Trade Monkey will expand its business-based development model to its other partner communities. As such, our Project Inspire proposal will exponentially impact more women in the long-term. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Trade Monkey will launch its social impact program in 2015 regardless, specifically focusing on empowering women through sustainable business practices that provide market access, marketable designs, and organizational capacity. However, the grant will allow us to conduct a more impactful pilot project than we could achieve on our own initial fundraising. Moreover, we are eager to participate in the Singapore training, which will not only provide us with mentorship but allow us to brainstorm and problem-solve with our peers.

We are solving a two-fold problem common to South East Asia and rural agricultural communities: seasonal employment and market access. During the rainy season (August-January), all able-bodied adults in Phrao work in agriculture with women earning around 120 baht a day. In the dry season, women age 45-60 remain as care providers while the working age population migrates for work. project_summary:
Made in O Viveiro is a project aiming at empowering girls and women in the Province of Chitima, northern of Mozambique, through giving them access to education, training for skills development and entrepreneurial opportunities in the field of crafts-making and fashion. We offer teenage girls from poor and disadvantaged family background access to secondary education, vocational skills training, while catering for their basic needs. Through our laboratory, we provide girls and women of the neighbouring village the opportunity to join training classes to learn technical skills required to produce fabric, clothing and craft items according to high-quality standards._x000D_
O Viveiro centre launched the activity of the laboratory on early 2013, having already conducted a pilot phase of the program to produce fashionable items and house accessories successfully presented at Casa Idea international Expo on March 2014 in Rome. Since May 2014 we opened two local shops in Chitima city and next to our centre to sell the produce to the local market and in July 2014 we launch our Made in O Viveiro online store to propose the production on the international market._x000D_
Currently the production is managed by the girls of the centre and supported by few externals._x000D_
_x000D_
We are ready to scale our reach to engage more women in the training programme to foster the development of entrepreneurial activities focusing on engaging particularly women of the community.To achieve that, we will support the creation of a cooperative, Made in O Viveiro, to certify the production and brand it to access local, regional, national and international markets, scaling the opportunities offered to the women._x000D_
Our support aims at providing women with the needed skills and empowering them to take ownership on the laboratory and start-up their own entrepreneurial activity specialising their production and differentiating their focus on different elements of the supply chain._x000D_
The production of fashionable items, already successfully tested in the market, will be scaled by licensing women who are part of the training as member of the cooperative to become franchisor of the brand. Each woman will have access to the facilities of the laboratory, produce by herself using the common items and the common space. At the end of each month, each woman will pay royalties on the license and keep all the rest of the profit. The bamboo production will run for the first year financed by the grant and managed by the cooperative directly, to test the production, position it in the market and hopefully capitalise on it to recover from the costs of the expansion of the laboratory._x000D_
_x000D_
Every woman who will join the cooperative will receive personal skills training to foster their presentation skills and management capabilities while enhancing their self-confidence to allow them to gain the needed self-esteem to successfully engage in an entrepreneurial experience launched through Made in O Viveiro products._x000D_
_x000D_
Our trainers will engage the women who will join O Viveiro cooperative in management skill training such as production planning, store management, stock management, customer services, basics of accounting and basics of marketing._x000D_
Some of the girls who already had access to high schools, will be trained on IT skills, photography and basics of online marketing to empower them to manage the website and the online store www.madeinoviveiro.com._x000D_
The women-entrepreneurs joining Made in O Viveiro cooperative will identify their management team, who will participate in a specific set of training on the development of leadership skills and receive coaching from Dona Lucia, the manager of O Viveiro in Mozambique._x000D_
_x000D_
Made in O Viveiro aims at empowering girls and women of Chitima to self-manage their cooperative and to acquire the needed skills to develop a proper marketing and business development strategy to propose their products to the growing Mozambican middle class in the regional capitals of the Country as well as to target high-markets of international attracted by the growing tourist business on the Mozambican coasts._x000D_
_x000D_
Made in O Viveiro Fashion product portfolio includes:_x000D_
- Colouring local cotton fabric, named Capulana _x000D_
- Design clothing and accessorizes and prepare the cut on the fabric_x000D_
- Sewing women collections (skirts, dresses, bags); men collections (trousers and shirts), school line including uniforms, logo, bags. Pencil cases_x000D_
- Design and production of house accessories as table clothes, hot pot holders, napkins, runners, pillow covers, sofa covers (on demand), sunglass cases, women make-up case_x000D_
- Production of Running shorts and tops to support the youth of Chitima training in the athletic academy to participate to sport competition in the region_x000D_
_x000D_
The new production line includes Bamboo house products made of local wood. The production includes fruit woven, toiletries woven covered with Capulana fabric, chairs, tables, bamboo pencil cases, flower vases. _x000D_
_x000D_
Project Inspire grant will support Made in O Viveiro project to cover the start-up investment of O Viveiro cooperative to build a new laboratory, acquire new mechanical machinery, sustain transport costs to enter new markets in the Country and create a sustainable supply chain._x000D_
Majority of the funds will be invested to expand the existing laboratory and divide the spaces devoted to clothing and fashion from the bamboo production._x000D_
_x000D_
We already opened two Made in O Viveiro shop, one next to our Centre and one in Chitima city to sell Fashion and Bamboo production together in addition to food and bread, which we process in the mill of our centre._x000D_
_x000D_
Made in O Viveiro will become a focal attraction for the craft business of the whole Tete Region, empowering girls and young women to build their economic freedom, support their households and offer a safer future to their families._x000D_
Engaging women in entrepreneurial initiatives will allow them to unleash their creative potential and contribute to the development of their territory._x000D_
_x000D_
Furthermore, the cooperative allows women to start their activity with little initial capital, rather capitalizing on the tools of the laboratory and having access to local, regional, national and international markets through Made in O Viveiro Brand._x000D_
In the middle term, more O Viveiro shops will be open in the major cities in the Countries, so that more women will have the opportunity to join Made in O Viveiro Coop and work through their SMEs in the supply chain of the cooperative. Another scaling strategy will be social franchising to open shops empowering local business owners._x000D_
Each woman will receive training in Portuguese on personal and management skills. Shop owners will be part of an on-going coaching program._x000D_
_x000D_
Made in O viveiro will run quarter-reviews of the project for the first one year, and semester review for the first five years. Made in O Viveiro Management team will allocate an internal team to run training to the women in Portuguese, and to collect feedback. Furthermore, the coaching program will be structured to support the women in managing their local business to trade Made in O Viveiro products in the country.

Our long term aim of empowering women entrepreneurs enables us to impact the community on a smaller scale, however through the knowledge that weÃ¢â¬â¢ve gained and processes that we have refined we are able to use these experiences to design an educational package that can be delivered to the masses. We anticipate that, through the projects that we will be taking on, we will be able to incorporate the knowledge into a Ã¢â¬Ëboard gameÃ¢â¬â¢ and ultimately mass produce the board game at a low cost and provide them to schools, local communities where the masses can gain assess to the product and gain essential business and financial planning skills through playing the board game. Therefore in the long term, the potential impact of our project range from impacting the entrepreneurs that we work with will directly and potentially create a product that can educate the masses, not just within Kenya but throughout the sub-Saharan region within the time from of 3-5 years of the commencement of out project. 
The impact of the project ranges from the skills and opportunity given to these women entrepreneurs to start their own business and using a bottom-up approach to enable them to create change within the community through their own initiative. Given that they understand the local problems the best, by equipping them with the necessary resources and tools they are able to design solutions to targeted problems thus resulting in more effective problem resolution. Towards the end of the grant period, our project would have better training materials which would go towards our long term objective of empowering more women entrepreneurs and developing of our educational package which would reach the masses, and accumulate case studies and data gathered from our pilot projects to provide better support for future entrepreneurs. 
We are committed to educating the minority to empower the majority, where the knock on effect of our efforts will be translated by our beneficiaries to benefit a wider group. We firmly believe in focusing on education where we educate the locals and using the power of knowledge to create change in the community that they operate in. We believe in sharing knowledge, therefore to achieve the goal we hope to provide a conducive environment for women to exchange ideas and good practices, while for our project we hope to harness this knowledge, experiences and good practices and incorporate them into an educational package where we can mass produce and reach out to the masses. 
We will be able to measure success through the number of businesses started, as well as if the entrepreneurs are able to manage their businesses efficiently. Using quantitative methods to measure the success of businesses gives us a snapshot on the effectiveness of our program, however the use of qualitative measures such as feedback, focus groups and periodic assessment of the progress of our beneficiaries will give us a better understanding on the impact of our program and the success of our projects. Quantitative measures include financial information of each business and the use accounting ratios such as return on investment, profit margin ratio, and inventory turnover rate to assess the success of the business. Success is determined by their ability to transform their business idea into a working business, as we adopt a consulting approach in supporting them, therefore the process of business development is wholly done by them and we will adopt a more Ã¢â¬ËbackgroundÃ¢â¬â¢ approach where we will only intervene when necessary. _x000D_
In the long term, the success of our program is verified by the number of sustainable businesses that we help in starting, as well as how effective our educational package is in delivering essential business skills and in assisting entrepreneurs in starting their businesses.
project_summary:
Boost! Venture Group was a spin off from a University Project started with the objective of using education to empower entrepreneurs, as we believe that by equipping the local community with the necessary skills will enable them to create a positive impact within the community._x000D_
We design our operating model in a way where we are able to provide basic business support to entrepreneurs to develop their business ideas holistically, while ensuring that they are sustainable. To achieve our objective we focus on educating our beneficiaries by adopting a hands-on approach in every business idea we invest in and we tailor our support to meet the needs of every entrepreneur. Upon educating and developing their entrepreneurial idea, we will provide several rounds of seed funding to help them implement, grow and sustain their businesses. We firmly believe that through our support, women can be empowered by providing them with the necessary tools and resources to pursue their entrepreneurial ideas, and in the process changing their lives and the community they live in. We adopt a 4-step action plan to carry out our business model and create value for our social enterprise and the community. _x000D_

_x000D_
Initial Phase (first 3 months) _x000D_
In order to ensure that our model is effective, we plan to take on 8 pilot projects to test our assumptions and to streamline our operating processes. During the process, funding will go towards refining our identification process, being aware of our limited resources we only have the capacity to support the most deserving entrepreneurs with the best idea. Therefore during our pilot phase we will be assessing the effectiveness of our identification model and criteria implemented to ensure that we have a comprehensive identification process. _x000D_
_x000D_
Teaching plays a crucial role in achieving our objective, thus funding will go towards constantly refining our teaching methods and evaluating the training materials. This allows us to conduct more on-site testing by running workshops in various settings across the control to gather a larger sample size, and the resources to collect the data and evaluate them effectively. It also allows us to engage professional opinion to assess our evaluation to ensure its relevance, and compatibility towards our beneficiaries. _x000D_
_x000D_
Thereafter, our beneficiaries will develop their ideas, transforming them into a working business using the knowledge that theyâve learnt with our constant support. At this stage, funding will go towards observing the results of our training by monitoring their decision making process, and the areas in which more support is required (e.g. market analysis in their intended business area). This enables us to critically refine our model to ensure that we are providing the right support to achieve our intended objective. _x000D_
_x000D_
Simultaneously when they are implementing their business ideas, funding will go towards providing them with multiple rounds of seed funding (depending on the nature of their business) to help them in starting, growing and sustaining their business. _x000D_
_x000D_
Expansion Phase (next 6 months) _x000D_
Upon streamlining and refining our model, we seek to expand our support to the wider community. This stays in line with our objective of empowering the people most in need of support, therefore by delivering skills and providing tools to regions that are less accessible, enable us to create a greater impact to the community. Funding will go towards assisting us in expanding our reach to a wider community where we will be visiting rural areas across Kenya to deliver basic business skills to the locals, while at the same time identifying potential business ideas that we can support._x000D_
_x000D_
By taking on more projects (32 projects) for our 1st phase of expansion, funding will go towards maintaining our ability to deliver quality advice to every project that we assist. Funding will help us in training business consultants that we hope to recruit from the university (graduates/interns), to be involved in candidate selection, delivering of training materials and business development. _x000D_
_x000D_
In addition, funding will enable us to monitor the impact we have made to our pilot projects, through continued mentoring and viability test to help achieve sustainability in their businesses. Through these pilot projects, we are able to identify good practices that should be shared among entrepreneurs, thus the funding will enable us to create a community where women entrepreneurs can interact and exchange ideas in a conducive environment._x000D_
_x000D_
Additionally, funding will enable us to test assumptions that weâve conceptualised with regards to expanding our project, where we are able to assess the region that will benefit the most from our support (e.g. demographics, region stability, culture,). Selectively targeting regions enable us to develop a comprehensive expansion plan that will enable us to utilise our resources effectively to achieve maximum impact to the community. _x000D_
_x000D_
Business Roadmap (4 years) _x000D_
The funding that we receive will go a long way in helping us in realising our business roadmap of educating the minority to empower the majority. This creates a knock on effect where women are equipped with the knowledge and tools to create value for the community, and such actions would empower the people within the community. Therefore with the funding we receive, we hope to provide holistic business support to women entrepreneurs within Kenya and with our planned expansion program using our success in Kenya to bring these services to countries within the sub-Saharan region. _x000D_
_x000D_
The development of our model will ultimately contribute to our development of a business educational package that is easy to understand in the form of a board game, integrated with local context, essential business planning skills, basic financial accounting and practical life skills at a low production cost. This will provide essential support to a larger target audience, as we will incorporate processes and skills that have been tried and tested in real world scenarios and deliver it to the wider community. _x000D_
project_details: Research has shown that, the amount of aid going into the sub-Saharan region is negatively correlated to the economic development of the region (Easterly, 2006), and the growing disparity in the standard of living within Kenya is due to high unemployment rates and the lack of access to education, resources and skills. In addition, women are constantly being overlooked by the local government regarding education & job opportunities. Therefore, our project hopes to address the problems by educating women and providing them with the necessary knowledge and tools and enabling them to create value within the community through entrepreneurial ideas. Our philosophy of adopting a hands-on approach to build ideas alongside entrepreneurs enable us to incorporate business concepts and strategies into local problems, tapping on the local knowledge of entrepreneurs and equipping them with the necessary tools and resources to address the problem of poverty within their community. As William Easterly

project_name: Improving livelihood of marginalized women farmers through market-led development and financial training in Mpigi district
project_summary:
This project identifies and addresses the challenges for integrating emerging young rural women farmers into Fair Agricultural Trade and associated value-added activities, building their capacity to respond to agricultural marketing issues and promoting training, education, networking, technical assistance and information sharing among farmers. The project also fosters gender equity, recognizing that women play a key role as farmers and household workers yet are often the most disadvantaged. _x000D_
The overall aim is to train and provide support to marginalized rural women farmers in increasing agricultural productivity and enhance their knowledge in market access and financial literacy in Mpigi district in Uganda. The project seeks to enhance the ability of resource-poor women farmers to diversify their links with markets, resulting in improved incomes and an overall economic development. We believe equipping women small farmers with the skills to improve production and manage changes is therefore an important step towards securing livelihoods and reducing poverty. _x000D_
The broader strategic goal of the project is to contribute to the reduction of rural poverty in Mpigi district through strengthened capacity of small women farmers to engage in marketable agricultural production and enhanced business knowledge._x000D_
_x000D_
Specifically the project aims at:_x000D_
_x000D_
1. To assist 60 marginalized rural women farmers in developing to commercialized farming thus increasing agricultural production and eventually their income earning capacity. _x000D_
2. To organize a group of 60 marginalized women farmers into a fully functioning women agricultural cooperative supported with knowledge to develop high-value agricultural products and strengthen links with profitable markets and service providers._x000D_
_x000D_
3. To train 60 marginalized women farmers in agricultural skills, financial literacy and business development. _x000D_
_x000D_
4. By December 2015, we aim to have promoted sustainable production practices in the community that maintain and increase biodiversity and crop diversification in Mpigi district. We anticipate that the 60 trained women will multiply each train 10 more farmers in the community._x000D_
5. To empower a group of 60 women with modern knowledge and skills in crop production in order to attain food security and self-sufficiency through larger scale and group farming._x000D_
_x000D_
The project targets emerging women farmers in agriculture aimed at building a strong team at the grass root and promoting cluster formation among the them intended to increase productivity as a result of the collective cluster farming that will later strengthen their production capacities, learn how to market their produce collectively hence increasing their bargaining power._x000D_
_x000D_
By engaging women in entrepreneurship trainings and supporting them through relevant networks, it will increase their production levels and change their status to commercial production. This will also increase their skills and level of engagement in any entrepreneurship initiative at any level. The project will not only create a strong foundation for the beneficiaries but also create a âpoolâ of experts and commercial farmers at the grass root._x000D_
_x000D_
Project Activities:_x000D_
Below are mutually re-enforcing and supportive approaches of the project:_x000D_
1. Community Sensitization and Dialogues_x000D_
The project will undertake a community mobilization and sensitization exercise for further understanding of its aims and objectives. This level will involve re-organizing beneficiaries through village meetings aimed at raising awareness of the project. During this stage, the project importance, advantages and benefits are highlighted and discussed in detail. It is during this exercise that farmers will be re-arranged and grouped for effective execution of the project activities._x000D_
_x000D_
2. Training in Agricultural Techniques and Financial Literacy_x000D_
The Project is community based, in that the participants themselves decide and design their training curricula and networking opportunities. We believe using a collective action-reflection model for defining the projectâs trajectory is at times more work than simply attending predesigned trainings, but is ultimately more empowering and tailored to fit the needs of resident farmers._x000D_
This level being the core aspect of the project will involve more structured activities like linking farmers to processors through contract farming, building capacity on negotiation skills, and other skills required for effective transaction and minimizing the negative impacts of middlemen. _x000D_
The trainings are a combination of theory, interactive interventions from resource persons to illustrate the farmer-to-market linkages in practice and presentations to and by beneficiaries. _x000D_
_x000D_
The training program will focus on key cross cutting issues including but not limited to Farm Management and Efficiency, Strengthening Market Information Systems (MIS), Marketing Channels, Strategies and Credits, Quality Improvement, Business Management and Financial literacy, Soil Fertility Management Technologies and Linkage techniques with buyers and farmers. Basic numeracy is particularly useful for women in managing their agricultural and off-farm enterprises, more so when credit and savings are involved._x000D_
_x000D_
3. Set up a Demonstration Farm:_x000D_
A fully equipped demonstration farm is to be set up as a point of practical training and perfection throughout the project period. The demonstration farm will act as a learning center to the farmers to showcase modern sustainable agricultural techniques. A mix of traditional and modern information and communication technology tools will augment other avenues to provide access to information to the women. _x000D_
The farm will be managed and operated by a farm committee chosen among the women who will seek and recruit employees on the farm as required. In the initial set up of the farm we shall rely on the beneficiary farmers and the youth as volunteers to do the necessary work with limited help from sourced labor. _x000D_
_x000D_
4. Exchange Visits and Study Tours_x000D_
This activity is aimed at facilitating farmers learning from their successive counterparts, discussing and sharing experiences and gain motivation. Beneficiaries will be exposed to visits to other prominent farmers in different areas and witness for themselves that what they learn is practicable. This enhances farmersâ interaction and promotes farmer to farmer learning. _x000D_
The purpose of these tours is to educate the group by demonstrating other innovative and proven ways how local small farms manage risk in areas such as production, marketing and finance. On these tours members will learn about unique growing methods, farm management systems, crops, equipment, facilities, value-added products, marketing, sales and much more. _x000D_
_x000D_
5. Follow Ups and Evaluation_x000D_
Trained farmers are offered post training services geared towards smooth transition to sustainable practices. These include continuous and regular visits by the field based staff in order to guide, advice, direct and motivate them. Final project evaluations are done at this stage in line with project indicators and objectives. _x000D_

Uganda is one of the worldÃ¢â¬â¢s poorest and least-developed countries. People are predominantly subsistence farmers, with small plots of land- much of it unproductive. Women farmers in rural Uganda suffer the most as very few have rights over land since traditionally land passes from father to son. They are unable to produce enough food for income and home consumption. Literacy levels among these women are low, agricultural support is limited and opportunities to establish a livelihood are few. This particularly applies to women and girls who have dropped out of school due to unintended pregnancies or lack of school fees, who face widespread social discrimination, and have very little say in community and local governance issues. Agriculture is their option._x000D_
Even women who have land are hampered from earning a decent living by lack of business skills, marketing opportunities and negotiating power and also struggle to access the inputs at the right schedules and at a reasonable price.

project_summary:
TATU Project is a Tanzanian non-governmental organization working for the development of the rural community Msitu Wa Tembo. One of our main goals over the next 10 years is to decrease the marginalization of women from decision-making levels and improve their quality of life through a local women empowerment group. This group has two sides: Economical empowerment improves their family situation and gives a more concrete legitimacy and benefit to their participation in the group; the other side is their Personal Empowerment through developing their self-awareness, self-esteem and self-confidence. We strongly feel that Personal Empowerment can help them realize their capacity to claim their rights, participate in decision-making and voice their opinions to the rest of the community. It includes educating them about their rights, helping them care for themselves, their health and hygiene and facilitating their progress towards self sufficiency. Both Economic and Personal empowerment contribute to a woman's individual well-being and their personal conviction in being a vital factor in the positive transformation of their society. _x000D_
_x000D_
