project_summary:
Currently, Aakar Innovations has 10 sanitary napkin production units operating all over India where we have successfully launched our low-cost proprietary machinery, trained women to manufacture affordable pads adhered to Bureau of Indian Standardsâ quality requirements and validated market readiness in each unitâs location. With USD 25000, the amount would be used to propel Aakar to our next phase of operations, which is to perform community outreach and capacity training of women village entrepreneurs in order to enable the last mile distribution of sanitary pads to rural villages. _x000D_
We will train women village entrepreneurs for a period of 6 months where they are equipped with entrepreneurial skills so that they can firstly educate others on the importance of menstrual hygiene and secondly, sell sanitary napkins to their peers. Given the strong stigmatization which surrounds menstruation as well as the deeply entrenched traditions and customs practiced by local rural women, it is of paramount importance to train local village women entrepreneurs to become change agents in their own communities as we believe that true change has to come from within. Called Anandi ben (sister), these women would become role models for their own communities to emulate. _x000D_
_x000D_
In the following year, Aakar will expand to an additional 30 units, with each unit having 10 women trained on public speaking, sales and accounting. Each segment of the training curriculum i.e. sales is designed to last for 2 months and at the end, each village entrepreneur would be ready to carry out community outreach and awareness. They will also be confident enough to sell Anandi pads and have a sustainable livelihood with the skills being taught by the trainer. _x000D_
_x000D_
Each trainer is selected and employed based on a strict hiring metrics such that we ensure Aakar Social Ventures receive sufficient dedicated talent in the training arm. Each trainerâs salary amounts to USD 415 per month and we would hire 10 of these trainers. As such, by year end, they would have trained village entrepreneurs from 10 different units, which adds up to 30 units and 300 village entrepreneurs trained.
project_details: According to Ã¢â¬ÅEvery WomanÃ¢â¬â¢s Health RightÃ¢â¬Â (A.C. Nielsen), there are 312 million women who do not have access to hygienic menstrual protection. This problem is multi-dimensional; on one hand, current sanitary napkins sold in the market are too expensive and inaccessible for the women to purchase and on the other hand, many do not yet understand the importance of proper menstrual hygiene. As a social enterprise, Aakar uses a hybrid business model where Aakar Innovations is built to equip rural areas, where access is most limited, with a proprietary sanitary napkin production unit which manufactures comfortable, affordable and 100% compostable pads while Aakar Social Ventures is founded to ensure women are educated on the importance of proper menstrual hygiene by training local women to be change agents in their own communities. project_name: Economically and Socially Empower HIV positive single mothers
project_summary:
The overall project goal will be to contribute to the social and economic empowerment of young single HIV positive mothers living in Katwe slums-Makindye division by promoting HIV prevention (Elimination of Mother To Child Transmission), equipping them with life skills to become active players in transforming their lives, earn descent income and positively impact their families and communities.The Project objectives include;_x000D_
1) To increase economic opportunities for HIV positive single mothers by equipping them with key entrepreneurship and employment skills, as well as with social/life skills to enable them to confidently negotiate life options with clear perspectives _x000D_
2) To increase uptake and access to Sexual and Reproductive Health Services especially antenatal, family planning and PMTCT/EMTCT services so as to reduce on the rate of unplanned pregnancies, reduce child mortality and improve Maternal Health _x000D_
3) To establish a support system for peer mentoring within the community on issues concerning health and entrepreneurship creation._x000D_
The project entails a 12-month mentoring and training program targeting 20 marginalized and low-income single mothers living with HIV/AIDs aged 15-30 years from Katwe I&II slums located in Makindye division, one of the biggest urban slums of Kampala. _x000D_
Mentors will guide the women through an innovative curriculum in socio-economic empowerment, including practical skills to design and manage sustainable income-generating activities in their communities. At completion, participants will form a mentoring club and become peer mentors, each required to mentor two other youth in their community and the two will mentor four to grow the factor tree. They will also form savings and investment clubs as a source of future financing. The project will build upon existing networks among women Savings and Credit Corporative Organizations (SACCOs), civil society and local authorities to help foster a more respectful and friendly environment for HIV positive single mothers living in urban slums. _x000D_
A mentoring, training and community engagement program targeting HIV positive single mothers aged 15-32 years from the slums of Katwe I&II, will be conducted where these young women will be equipped with vocational, employment, leadership and life skills, creation of income generating activities that are sustainable in their communities, training in financial literacy with emphasis on establishment of Savings groups and support systems in the community. _x000D_
_x000D_
At the start of the project, a community outreach program will be conducted targeting young single mothers aged 15-32years living in slum communities of Katwe I&II, where a free voluntary HIV counseling and testing will be conducted to ascertain their HIV status and those found to be HIV positive will be started on ARVs as well as provide them with reproductive Health services such as family planning, antenatal, STI treatment and PMTCT/EMTCT services. Health Education sessions will also be organized at Zaam Medical Center on different topics affecting women especially on issues of reproductive health. The young mothers will further be engaged in discussions about the existing challenges, their specific needs and tasked to map out existing resources and networks available within their community._x000D_
During the project, mentors will guide the young women through an innovative curriculum in socio-economic empowerment, including practical skills to design and manage sustainable income-generating activities in their communities. _x000D_
The project will mentor the young women to discover their lifeâs purposes, develop key leadership, vocational, entrepreneurship, life skills, self-confidence, communication, goal setting, critical thinking, advocacy, negotiations and use of basic social media to secure productive and fulfilling livelihood by becoming the best at whatever they choose to do and will comprehensively inspire, equip and skill young people to transform their thinking, take charge of their lives, lead change and make positive social impact in their communities. _x000D_

project_details: Slum dwellers face challenges such as security of tenure, access to affordable and quality education, medical care, water and sanitation management, along with a high incidence of HIV/AIDS. Approximately 940,000 Ugandans are living with HIV/AIDS. Where the HIV prevalence is at 10% in urban areas and 6% in rural areas that stands at 8.5% in Kampala, women have a higher HIV prevalence than men (7.5% compared to 5% for men nationally (Uganda Demographic and Health Survey, 2011). Women in general are particularly vulnerable to the epidemic, as commercial sex is often their only option for income since most of the women are illiterate and do not have any expertise that will allow them any decent employment. Women living with HIV/AIDS also face a specific set of challenges including lack of family support, poverty, single-parenthood, frequent illness due to low immunity and stigmatization in addition to social discrimination, economic exclusion and poor healthcare among others.

project_name: Introduction of Improved Chorkor Fish Smoking Oven to generate income for Women in Rural Fishing Communities in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria
project_summary:
Fish processing is a major source of livelihood of the poor women in the rural fishing communities in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria, a region, home to some 31 million people and location of Nigeriaâs oil industry operation with its attendant environmental hazards such as water, land, air pollution with human activities such as depletion of biodiversity, oil spillage, gas flaring, water pollution, deforestation, etc which pose great challenges to womenâs economic development. Besides the massive problems arising from oil spillages, there is also the cutting of immature mangroves which is predominantly the source of fuel currently available to the fish processors in fishing communities. Adegbulugbe (1994) reported that the demand for fuel wood is expected to be risen to about 2,134,000 metric tons, while the supply would increase to about 28,400 metric tons by the year 2030. He suggested development of appropriate fish processing equipment that will reduce fuel (wood) consumption. The women in the rural communities lack basic social infrastructural facilities to use more sophisticated method of preserving fish; as a result they preserve their fresh fish by traditional methods which are characterized with low-batch capacities and long processing methods. Just like their counter parts in other parts of Nigeria they perform certain economic responsibilities within the family as wives, mothers, farmers and breadwinners. They are the principal care giver of the children and the aged. Even though they are food producers, harvesters and cook, they are also expected to perform the function of wage earners. This is because the intra housing income distribution pattern and the rise of matriarchal household in the country, coupled with poverty, force them to take active financial role in their families. Most of them are uneducated and therefore unemployed outside the home, their major source of livelihood is subsistence farming as they comprise 60 to 80% of the agricultural labor force and account for 90% of family food supplyâ it is also worthy of note that despite the agony of these women, 90% of them still rely on the use of other crude implements like cutlasses, hoes, knives and poor processing tools to carry out their economic activities. In many rural fishing communities, the infrastructure for post-harvest processing and preservation of fish, especially during peak fishing seasons is inadequate. As a result, losses reach 40 per cent of total catch by weight. Such losses not only have detrimental impact on the socioeconomic life of fishing communities but reduce the amount of animal protein available to large segments of the population. _x000D_
To ameliorate all these challenges Morgan Smart Development Foundation (MSDF) will use the $25,000 to provide improved fish smoking oven called the Chorkor Fish Smoking Ovens for the poor but resilient rural women workers. The proposed improved Chorkor Fish Smoking Oven is developed from appropriate technology, built from local materials to communities preference and specifications, uses up to 80% less fuel, has high fish smoking capacity, is faster and healthier to use, and supplies a uniform and better products that attracts higher prices. The oven can actually smoke about 100 fishes of good size on each tray and depending on the size of the fish and the number of racks provided. A Chorkor oven of 3 racks can process a minimum of 300 fish of considerable size within 3-6 hours to achieve the desired low moisture content. The project implementation process/activities will include; Mobilization & Sensitization of beneficiaries on the project, Selection of Beneficiaries, Construction of double chambered Chorkor oven with smoking trays and smoking covers enclosed in a Banda/shed house to ensure uninterrupted operations by shielding the women from direct sunlight or rain, Formation of Project Implementation Committee / training of youths in the communities on construction, use and management of the tools. The selected trained youths will be tasked with ensuring maintenance and construction of additional Chorkor fish smoking tools to other workers in the communities and training of the women leaders from the cooperative group in business and enterprise development to enable the women employ commercial and business approach as to effectively manage their businesses. The business skills will include Financial Management, Saving and Credit Management, Micro-credit, Enterprise development (wealth creation) and Group Memberships. The training methodology to be employed for training the women will be basically drawn from the Center for Development and Population Activities (CEDPA) based in Washington DC, USA. It is based on three (3) methodologies which are Appreciative inquiry, Adult learning theory and Experiential learning cycle. The appreciative inquiry and adult learning theory are predicated on the fact that adult learn best when they can identify immediate uses for the new knowledge and skills and when the subject matter directly relates to their own life experiences. Adult learners bring a lot of information even at their level and talent that influences their own learning and facilitates new learning amongst their peers. Experiential learning cycle is based on the process that people learn best by participating directly in their own learning. Morgan Smart Development Foundation (MSDF) has successfully carried out a baseline study on socioeconomic, health and livelihood systems in the communities inclusive of collating data on the state of women processors/co-operative groups in the communities. The data provided insight into local history and current practice as well as physical inspection of present traditional method of fish processing in the communities which revealed the poor state of the traditional smoking ovens. The improved oven when constructed will be handed over to three (3) identified and selected women fish processing co-operative groups made up of twenty (25) members per group (75 women) from three rural fishing communities in the Niger Delta. The implementing group will further carryout an Evaluation of the project after the introduction of the improved smoking equipment / tools to measure the outcome of the innovation/ project deliverable on the health status, livelihood and income system of the beneficiaries. The evaluation process, will involve conducting surveys and in-depth interviews and interaction with all groups in the communities which will be used as a comparative measure on the initial baseline survey conducted. The evaluation process will verify the success of the project and measure the impact of the improved Chorkor Fish Smoking Oven long after they have been put to use._x000D_
 _x000D_
project_details: Smoke drying is one of the most common preservation methods used by the women. This drying often takes place in some poorly constructed round mud or extended-drum oven. This local technology is characterized with significant draw backs as most of these ovens are of poor quality construction materials with low production capacities. The mud ovens are cumbersome and potentially dangerous to operate because the women workers must labor over an open fire to rotate the drying of the fish which usually requires a minimum of 30 hours to process their products and this has led to work-related health risk including heat stroke, lung infections and eye defects from smoke inhalation and burns. In some case the entire products purchased for processing have been burnt down leading to loss of revenue and post-traumatic stress on the women. Provision of the improved oven to the resilient working women workers will generate income and improve economic empowerment amongst the women workers.

_x000D_

_x000D_

The team of LoomÃ¢â¬â¢s has been working on a product line over the past 3 years, which targets international customers in Europe and the US. We have been working with some international women volunteers, which lead to the launch of some branded products under the name of OlaRe in Europe. Products from this collaboration have been successfully marketed in Switzerland. We work towards putting a brand value on handcrafted silk accessories produced by women artisans in Cambodia, which can ensure a fair and sustainable income to the women artisans we work with. Our core philosophy is to help through work, so that women working with silk (weavers and artisans who finish the product) can lead a life with dignity from their well deserved income. The team of LoomÃ¢â¬â¢s has been servicing international customers at small scale for years, but it is increasingly difficult to secure fair income to women artisans simply by supplying unbranded products. Buyers are looking for bargains, which is difficult to secure via artisan production despite the relatively low labor costs in Cambodia. If we want to continue to pay fairly women, keep them in the workforce and not loose them in the poverty cycle, we need to secure not only considerable increase in sales, but also find ways to maintain, or even increase the value of these products. There are some good international examples, for instance in the coffee sector, when adding a brand value to a product helped the uptake by bigger market players, which secured prices translatable to higher income to the farmers. OlaRe has been an experiment, with tangible success, and now this initiative is ready to be taken into more markets._x000D_
Based on our experience working with silk artisans we concluded that putting a brand value to some flagship products is worthwhile, and allows to explore market segments which can secure sustainably fair income to women silk artisans, beyond the current scale of LoomÃ¢â¬â¢s. An expansion of this branded market segment would equally help to safeguard centuries old silk weaving traditions in Cambodia. To succeed with the expansion of the international market the following steps need to be completed over the coming 18 months:_x000D_

The long-term impact that this project will have on the community we hope to influence, is that the ex-Devadasis will be able to properly support themselves and have established businesses running. Through this self-employment, these women in once unfortunate situations, will be able to erase the perpetual stigma that surrounds them and their families. Additionally, even further into the future, we aim to impact the lives of the children of the ex-Devadasis, who will be able to receive a quality education as a result of a steady income into the family, and will no longer have to resort to the temple, and instead can go further in life.

With the help of these micro-loans, these soon to be entrepreneurs can benefit from a 60% increase in revenue, and we aim to help these women accomplish this and become self-reliant. 
The loan-repayment rate will primarily serve as a method to verify how successful the ex-Devadasis have been in their pursuit of independence and to rise out of their circumstances. This grant will allow our team to gain a more comprehensive understanding of how to improve the lives of these women, by helping them rise out of the disheartening cycle of social stigma. Additionally, in the event that some of our borrowers do default on their loans, this grant allows us the opportunity to resort to this capital first, before cutting into the expenses of individual lenders.
project_details:
An ancient problem in India, the Devadasi (meaning: 'servant of God') system involved dedicating a girl, as young as 5-6 years of age, to the temple Goddess. This meant that she would spend her entire life serving the temple and was not allowed to marry anyone else. The system was abused by the rich and the powerful who began to force the young Devadasis to sleep with them. _x000D_
Over the years, the Devadasis were reduced to being incorrectly termed 'temple prostitutes'. This merciless practice, although illegal and outlawed, still exists in certain small towns of India and its stigma continues to cling to the women who attempt to escape. Because of the social stigma around their roles, employment opportunities are denied to them. It is a vicious cycle where future generations too, are drawn into this ruthless system.

project_name: GirlZtalk - Connecting girls across the nation to share
project_summary:
We will  use the funds to run GirlZtalk which is a social business connecting girls across the nation to share their voice and provides access to the information girls need to make informed choices. GirlZtalk is a Seed Community initiative. SEED Community is an organisation providing interest free loans to girls from financially disadvantaged backgrounds for their higher education in South Africa (www.seedcom.org). All SEED girls are studying a business degree in Johannesburg. They are motivated, bright and dynamic and each have a minimum of 20 hours a week to dedicate to the development, implementation and expansion of the GirlZtalk platforms. _x000D_
This sponsored work provides the financial means for SEED loan recipients to pay back their loan. Fostering entrepreneurship amongst the SEED loan recipients is key for the girls to pay back their loans, gain valuable work experience in a business environment, and make a real contribution to the empowerment of girls in South Africa._x000D_
All activities of GirlZtalk are designed to raise awareness and address the challenges girls face, growing up in South Africa today. GirlZtalk will partner with Corporates and companies in South Africa to contribute their CSI funds towards the GirlZtalk local-to-local exchange platforms where SEED Community girls will work with girls in their communities in small groups and on a one to one basis to be able to gain a clear understanding of the real issues girls are facing today and the information they need to make informed choices. _x000D_
_x000D_
The SEED girls are providing the following in the schools and communities:_x000D_
_x000D_
1. Mentorship in Schools_x000D_
Working with school learners and tertiary students in the inner city of Johannesburg, the GirlZtalk School Mentoring Programme is designed to provide positive and creative solutions to the issues students face, helping them to make informed choices. Under the guidance of Nikki Florence, who has been working as a mentor with youth groups for over 20 years, the SEED students have been professionally trained and currently mentor learners from grade 6 offering continued support until matriculation and beyond to tertiary level. The objective is for each SEED student to mentor learners at a ratio of 1:12. With time, those learners will in turn mentor junior learners at a ratio of 1:12. Today sponsorship of all SEED students will impact the lives of 4212 students._x000D_
_x000D_
2. Educational Theatre in Schools_x000D_
Tackling the issues of teenage pregnancies, HIV, violence and the stigma of sexuality through short drama pieces we will be providing schools with a creative tool to explore the issues affecting school-aged girls and boys._x000D_
_x000D_
3. GirlZtalk School Workshops_x000D_
Working with small groups we will take a more in-depth look at the issues girls are facing at schools and work together to find possible solutions. Topics to be covered will include sexual health, teenage pregnancies, violence, peer pressure, rights and responsibilities._x000D_
_x000D_
4. GirlZtalk Leadership Camps_x000D_
An in-resident camp set in the secure nature reserve of Ezemvelo. These weekend and holiday camps are designed to bring girls together focusing on leadership development, team building, creative arts and life skills. Through nature-based activities, games, and expression platforms such as theatre, song and dance, girls are able to explore the issues they face and together seek to find positive solutions. Highly motivational, these camps empower girls to rise to their potential and pursue the goals they set themselves._x000D_
_x000D_
5. GirlZtalk Bus Tour_x000D_
Once a year, 28 Seed girls will undertake a road trip acroos the rural heartland South Africa for 9 days. Engaging with girls from rural communities as part of a local-to local exchange of knowledge and ideas, each workshop will enable issues to be raised that girls are facing from both an individual and communal perspective. Guided by their rich, cultural heritage the girls used dialogue, song poetry, theatre and dance to explore, what it means to be a young girl growing up in South Africa today._x000D_
After the success of this trip we would like to continue to engage with girls from rural communities across South Arica, through workshops and the establishment of rural GirlZtalk groups._x000D_

Selection Phase, Workshop Training, and Mid Term Assessment._x000D_
Selection: The selection will include an arrangement with the local government councils in the local community where women will be selected based on their identification by the council members. This will be done specifically by women leaders in the council. These women may or may not have started business before, they may also be women or girls above 20 years. The age limit for the women is 50 years. This minimum age is set because at this age, they have more control and can be independent in their decisions. The age limit of 50 is selected because after this age, the productivity level of the women will likely be lower compared to the younger women. The selection is the first activity that will be carried out. The training is scheduled to hold in 5 communities in the state. The target number of women to be trained in each community is 200 women, making a total of 1,000 women. _x000D_
Training: The training will be held at the city council hall of the host community. From our initial findings, we discovered that the number of women in each community is within the range of 200,000 to 300,000. The aim of the project in this initial stage is to select a number of women from this range, train them using the train-the-trainer model, such that after successful implementation, they can be ambassador, key trainers of PROJECT-INSPIRE. _x000D_
The training will last for 5 days. The courses covered will include basic business management methods, marketing, book keeping, mindset development and accessing capital using cooperative development. The lecturers/facilitators are consultants, business owners, people who have their businesses running already in port Harcourt. Most of these consultants have been involved in other similar projects and are experts in the field of women and entrepreneurship development. Course materials and certificates will be given to the women at the end of the training._x000D_
Assessment: the assessment will be done by the consultants and team set by the local government councils. This assessment will be done in batches as the project continues. KaruKotha will attempt to cater to the ever-changing trend of its target market at home: middle class and higher middle class urban youths. Besides, the growing market of crafts items at international scales offers a big opportunity for KaruKotha. Through nurturing internally developed innovation team and fellow community craftspeople, KaruKotha will attempt to give a new identity to the international crafts business; innovative yet age-old.KaruKotha is unique in that its craft lines will offer a blend of modern design and age-old artisanship. Communities, who once produced their daily necessities out of local scraps or even disposed of such scraps, will now work for KaruKotha to be creative crafting communities._x000D_
NGOs will be partnering with KaruKotha because of inherent social return prospects  Till now they can only ensure training and skill development, not employment. KaruKotha, as a social venture, will act as a building block, creating employment for the trained craftspeople
To train up and engage communities in creative craftsmanship, KaruKotha will partner with local NGOs to set up seven pallis at underprivileged rural points around the country. These pallis(incubators) will work as design, innovation, and training incubators and will be set up in 2.5-3 acres of rural land close to the targeted communities. Partnering NGOs will set up cottages at each palli to provide training facilities while KaruKotha will offer design and market linkage support to the trained craftspeople. Once training is completed, creative designers will be engaged with the internal design team of KaruKotha to work at pallis. Other craftsmen will be encouraged to start their own micro-entrepreneurship venture at their homes and work as independent craftsmen for KaruKotha and other crafts retailers. We also have courses in vocational training that include sewing, cooking, gardening, husbandry, computer education, business and entrepreneurship to help women and girls in the surrounding region. project_name: From drudgery to improved productivity and income for the Bahiingi women in Southwestern Uganda
project_summary:
The Uganda Association of University Women proposes to empower a marginalized group of women of the Kiga ethnic group in South Western Uganda called the Bahiingi, with agricultural mechanization and business skills. These are groups of women who largely make a living by working as manual labourers on other peoplesÃ¢â¬â¢ farms. They are part of the 76% of the small scale farmers in Uganda who live on small pieces of land, ? 2acres of land and earn less than a dollar a day.  The Bahiingi also use the primitive hand-held hoe for tools of agricultural production, which exacerbate the drudgery and low productivity per unit area of land. UAUW proposes to introduce an innovative, practical and sustainable technology, which is new in the area- ox drawn implements such as ploughs, weeders and carts to alleviate the drudgery associated with the hand-held tools. The main objectives of the proposed project are:_x000D_
(1)	Build capacity in modernized agriculture for the Bahiingi  : One hundred and fifty women from 7 Bahiingi groups shall be trained in agronomy and the use of more modern farming tools, specifically ox drawn implements like ploughs, weeders and carts. They shall also be trained in the use of draught animals and their maintenance. Also, 50 men shall be trained alongside the women to encourage gender sensitivity. Four service centres in each of 4 subcounties shall be established at a technical institute for purposes of sustainability of using ox-drawn equipment in the area.  Ten girls who have completed their ordinary level of education shall be trained at these institutes in agricultural mechanization so that they can become resource people in their respective communities. A pair of draught animals shall be procured for each of the 7 groups alongside a plough for land preparation and a cart for carrying harvests from fields to stores._x000D_
(2)	) Build their entrepreneur and business management skills._x000D_
_x000D_
UAUW proposes to empower and mentor these women on how to manage their labour services profitably. The goal here is to transition them from being casual and small scale labourers to managing their labour services as competitive businesses. Fundamental principles like book keeping, planning, setting goals and strategies (long and short term), marketing, investing, quality assurance, building healthy relationships and networking shall be taught to the groups. We propose to also focus on strengthening and developing the groups and boosting their esteem since the Bahiingi are generally marginalized in their communities due to their poverty status. Pertinent issues in maintaining effective groups such as leadership, defining roles and responsibilities, managing process and communication will be handled in team building activities with the women._x000D_
project_details: The main problem being addressed in this project is drudgery that results from use of primitive agricultural tools and practices by the Bahiingi. With such methods for instance the efficiency and agriculture productivity is far too low as it takes almost five times longer to accomplish farming tasks with hand held tools as opposed to using ox-drawn implements. Ox-drawn implements are a practical solution and also cost effective and within reach for the Bahiingi. Mechanisation is limited in Kabale in Uganda.

project_summary:
The WWE social venture is positioned to systematically and purposefully address the issues of poverty among female farmers in Fatick Region and the lack of skill amongst, their daughters, often school dropouts. These are pressing issues as in Fatick, 85% of agricultural work is completed by women, yet up to 90% of the corps go to waste. What is left of the harvest is sold immediately, when the prices are lowest giving them bare income that hardly lasts till the next harvesting season. They can barely sustain their families, and their daughters, who often drop out of school drift aimlessly, faced with a dim and hopeless future. These young girls are a part of the 75% of girls who do not complete high-school in Senegal._x000D_
In Fatick, manufacturing sector or industries are non-existent. Ninety percent of the population is involved in farming, 85% of which are women. Yet these women remain impoverished with their children bearing the heavier brunt of the burden. This is because all the harvest is sold when prices are lowest giving them bare income that hardly lasts till the next harvesting season. In the same vein, younger girls who drop out of school drift aimlessly, faced with a dim and hopeless future. _x000D_
_x000D_
To address this, our social venture will establish a sewing center for younger girls to acquire skills in sewing traditional attires, embroidered outfits, baby clothes, reusable sanitary pads, clothe bags and accessories. After the completion of the training, each graduate will be supported with a sewing machine so she could start making garments or start a business, earn enough to buy their food, educate and take care of the health needs of their children and thus lift them up from poverty._x000D_
_x000D_
With the older women who are mostly involved in the agriculture sector, the social venture will constitute them into a cooperative. _x000D_
Thanks to our working relationship with Credit Mutuel du Senegal, a renowned bank, the social venture will logde a consecrated fund as a guarantee for loan provision for the cooperative members.   _x000D_
_x000D_
The women access the loan during harvest (when the price of millet is rock-bottom). With the loan at an 8% interest, they buy millet and store up in the granary built by the social venture. The social venture puts a mark up of 12% on the amount of millet stored and sold. Each season will leave the women with enough funds to spend on themselves, their children, some to spare and help extended family members and some to save against the rainy day._x000D_
_x000D_
The strength and uniqueness of this proposed solution lies in its nature and scope. It is simply, creatively, and innovatively revolutionizing a local business evolving around a local produce run by local women for the entire community. It is supportive, positive and collective.        _x000D_
Thus in a traditional agrarian setting traumatized by endemic poverty, my social venture will significantly increase the earning of local women farmers, ensure sustainable livelihood and healthy well-being of their family especially the children._x000D_
_x000D_
The social venture guarantees a storage facility and loans without collateral. The lack of these two had held these women down in abject poverty over the decades.  With an 8% interest and a service fee of 12% to the social venture, 80% profit is freed as personal gain for the women. The customer relationship is underscored by a Ã¢â¬ÅbondÃ¢â¬Â which is cooperative in nature as the women are held responsible one to the other. This dedicated customer relationship coupled with familiar core activities (cultivation , selling, buying, reselling of millet)  will give the required customer acquisition drive. The cost structure requires an initial take off fixed asset cost invested in the construction of a warehouse, the guaranteed fund lodged in the bank to fund micro-finance and a weighing scale._x000D_
_x000D_
Therefore the uniqueness of this social venture is in its focus (women) and its innovation (from grassroots level) and in its impact (curtails post-harvest wastage). It trades in local content.  The overhead is pretty minimal. Neither electricity nor water is required. The venture is locally relevant. The cooperative concept gives the customers a local sense of belonging. Over and above all, it is sustainable, profitable and effectively meeting a social need. With its full potential of growth, it stands as a path that had been barely trodden by any individual or organization in this society.   _x000D_

Esnad Ã¢â¬ÅPalestinian Initiative for Supporting StudentsÃ¢â¬Â is introducing an innovative approach developed by Jihad Shojaeha to addressing the issue of unequal access to higher education in Palestine and also breaking the cycle of poverty. Though many underprivileged students are determined and willing to pursue higher education, they are denied the opportunity because they lack the funds to pay for tuition. Even when given highly subsidized loans, their families fail to meet the payment deadlines due to poverty and high unemployment rates in the country.Esand is doing partnership with private sector in Palestine such as Paltel group and Aramex to manage the scholarships to students in Palestinian university, from 2008 to 2013 70% of the beneficiaries where girls, The issue of engaging more females in the initiative was of great importance in a context were women would have been denied access to higher education by their families._x000D_
Our   project focuses on developing the capacities of school students in certain classes( English), by Palestinian university students who were given the scholarships with help from our side , the University students will take training,  this  trainings will focus on the ability of  transferring the information from the youth(University Students) to the schoolÃ¢â¬â¢s student, and on developing the leadership and the communication skills, it will also focus on the important of implementing extracurricular activities in education, this will allow the participant to gain actual experience in the field of education._x000D_
This training will focus on communication and leadership skills, and how to implement gained knowledge in their specialization in the real life situations, and skills for workplace success. At the end, it requires all the participants in this program to commit and to be willing to volunteer in teaching school students for the next year._x000D_
In this program, 100 university students will be chosen (100females); after the completion of the training, the students will understand the idea of Ã¢â¬Åstudent to studentÃ¢â¬Â initiative, which is fighting poverty through education and contributing positively in building a safe environment in the community through volunteering and engaging in their community._x000D_
After the training, these university students will start  selecting school students with our help and supervision, each university student will volunteer in teaching 10 school students(100females) for the next five months, their teaching will focus on learning English through extracurricular activities such as drama, presentations, movies, debate Ã¢â¬Â¦etc, in  order to make learning process more interesting for students, this also encourage university and school students in interact effectively with each other in a safe environment. This method enriches the students understanding of themselves and of the world, beside, it challenges them to gain self-confidence, stretch their thinking, express themselves, and use foreign languages. To make the meeting between the University students and the school students easier, they supposed to have 2-3 meetings per week, for 2-4 hours each. This process enables both university and school students to draw out their skills and strength in their community._x000D_
Target groups: _x000D_
First category: university students majored in English, in their third and fourth year, aged between (19-24)._x000D_
Second category:  School student who need improvement in the English language, aged between (14-17)._x000D_
Methodology: _x000D_
Peer Education is our selected methodology, working from peer to peer (youth to youth) has successfully proven its effectiveness in transferring knowledge and based on the experience of youth trainers, peer to peer training is one of the best approaches to gain, exchange and develop knowledge. In one part, University students will gain practical experience, enhancing their communication and leadership skills, and their ability to enter the labor market in the field of education. project_summary:
Our Project aims to improve the life of many Syrian families by helping Women achieve personal development.By providing training ( Both Personal and Business), Our plan is to give Women the ability to reach their full potential not only as business owners but also as future mentors for their kids and young girls of their local communities._x000D_
It is our belief that through this project and similar ones that true change can be made in society. Starting with its smallest, most basic unit, Family, and ending up with communities as a whole, we know that the empowerment of women can only lead to a better, more prosperous Social structure._x000D_
One way to insure that women are free to leave their impact on the world is to give them the economic Independence, and that's where we come in._x000D_
In this proposal you'll find our detailed plan to enrich the lives of  Syrian women by giving them the opportunity to take their rightful position in their communities as breadwinners and role models, also help them evolve to much more than the typical role of homemakers._x000D_
Keeping in mind that change is an ongoing process, our project will work on providing the necessary funds and expertise to help our beneficiaries kick start their businesses, but our main focus will be on personal growth. Our training program will try to reach out (with affective results) to as many women as possible to help cultivate the idea that women can be in control when it comes to the financial aspects of their lives, and other aspects as well._x000D_
25,000$ may not seem like a lot of money to some people, it's what a minimum wage worker makes in a year in some parts of the world, and to more than most Syrian families, It's a distant dream. To us, it's a stepping stone for our community, for Syrian women and families, to take that first step towards achieving their dreams._x000D_
project_details:
Due to the ongoing state of unrest in Syria, Poverty has struck what was previously called the Middle Class in Syria.Many Syrian households are now without a male provider, with no financial support system, and no source of income._x000D_
This project will offer sufficient training and funding for Women who are now heads of households to start their own successful small businesses in order to provide for their families and ensure a better life quality for themselves._x000D_
There are no up-to-date statistics regarding the current economic state of Syrian families, therefore we decided to choose a sample from one of the poorest areas of Lattakia. (Al-Da'toor) Where people were already in financial distress before the state of unrest even began, and are now facing bankruptcy due to the loss of the male provider. _x000D_
We will target Businesses that were ran by women and went down due to unexpected shifts in the Syrian economy, and women in need for a source of income and show entrepreneurship._x000D_

Crafts making using corn wings is an innovation of enactus Kaduna polytechnic, were cornwings, which is a readily available waste products from corn is used as raw materials to make bags, baskets and shoes._x000D_
Though corn wing is a waste from corn, we came up with innovative ideas that make us see this waste as bags and basket.  Most of these women have the material available but lack the skill to convert it to wealth. We will teach these women how to convert these readily available corn wings waste into bags and basket. This is how we apply entrepreneurial approach into all we do at enactus. 30 women/girls will be empowered with the necessary skills._x000D_
Fishery products are by far the most popular animal products in the market, constituting more than 60% of meat products in the Nigerian market.  It is one of the most lucrative business in Nigeria due to high demand for the product.  However, most fishes consumed in Kaduna state are imported into the state as iced or smoked. The few fish ponds in the state cannot meet the demand for the product in the state and fingerlings and juvenile fishes are mostly purchased from the southern part of the country. Therefore, we will empower these women with the skills involved in fish farming, fish hatchery, juvenile and fingerlings product and also connect them to important markets for their products. Fish sells faster than any other animal products in the market and is relatively cheaper than meats, making it the number one choice when it comes to affordability. 25 women will be selected for training in the fishery business. These women will mostly be peasant farmers so that they have multiple stream income as their crop farmer business is never enough to cater for their needs._x000D_
Bead making and wire works is a very lucrative business in Nigeria, though only a few engage in the business. Customized beads are in high demand by brides who are about to get married and festival lovers and they are usually willing to pay any amount to have them. Our intension is to empower 20 women in the art of bead making._x000D_
In Kaduna state, only a few tailors have the modern fashion designing skills and follow the current fashion trends. This is because many tailors cannot afford the necessary fee to acquire such skills._x000D_
We will select 30 women/girls for this section of empowerment. 20 of them will include already practicing tailors who are not making enough income from their business and they will be carefully selected to upgrade their fashion designing skills to modern trends and 10 young girls will be selected and to begin their fashion design training. Finally, 15 women will undergo training in upholstery making._x000D_

project_name: Inspire Women: Educate, Empower and Employ through Yoga
project_summary:
Africa Yoga Project's mission is to empower, educate, elevate and employ through yoga. A non-profit social enterprise, this project will equipping underemployed young women in Africa to develop as professionals and leaders in women's health and to create new economic opportunities by tapping into the multi-billion-dollar global wellness industry. Starting by engaging young women in the development of the yoga market, we have created a professional development model that incorporates self-discovery to unlock participantsÃ¢â¬â¢ innate capacity to transform themselves and their environment. Through this project we will demonstrate how young women, deemed unemployable in the current job market, can be empowered to create employment for themselves and others and be a contribution to the global women's health crisis.  This project trains young, disadvantaged Kenyans to become yoga teachers and professionals through a model that empowers them to actively develop the market for their skills, including identifying and creating new market opportunities. At the same time, the model cultivates a culture of inclusion and community service, and makes the health and wellness benefits of a practice like yoga, previously a luxury of the wealthy in Africa, accessible to low- and middle-income communities. With the $25,000 grant we will implement a three part program. _x000D_
First, Africa Yoga Project will facilitate 22 young women from Kenya's urban slums in a 100 hour training to teach Pre-Natal and Post-Natal Yoga. This training will address optimal well-being practices for women's reproductive, cardiovascular and community health. It will also focus on preparing and planning women mentally, emotionally physically for childbirth, motherhood and family planning. Yoga, proven to reduce pre and post natal depression, addresses both the physical body and the attitudes and empowerment of the young women we work with. The training will rely on Africa YogaProject's professional development model that combines self-discovery, community outreach, skills training, and market development, all of which will put these young women in control of their own career opportunities while also bringing wellness benefits to their communities. The young women coming into the program have rough lives in the unsafe environment of the urban slums, some of them perpetrating violence and crime themselves and 40 percent with only a primary school education. The focus on self-discovery is critical in helping them shift their mindset about what is possible for their lives and has had a transformative effect on many of them. They simultaneously learn to be professionals and develop a specific skillset (teaching yoga throughout the lifecycle of a women's health) that they can deploy immediately to continue learning._x000D_
Secondly, after the training each of the 25 young women will engage in a one year 'Learn and Earn' model - where they utilize there newfound teaching skills and are employed by Africa Yoga Project to teach weekly classes to over 10,000 young people in the urban slums. This year will allow the young women to develop their professional skills while bringing health and wellness benefits to low-income women in the urban slums. Each woman will be required to identify and enroll their communities for the free classes themselves, enabling them to build additional skills as they contribute to development of the yoga market. We have identified over 40 locations that we will deliver these free services to. Notably, we have received partnership from the Langata Women's Prison (Kenya's largest Women's Prision), Remand Girls School (Youth Prison for Girls), and Voluntary Counseling and Testing (VCT), Kenya's largest source of free HIV testing and counseling. The outreach program, in addition to classes facilitated by the students at the Africa Yoga Project studio, contribute to each studentÃ¢â¬â¢s 200-hour requirement. This training model is a powerful way of developing leadership skills among the students in preparation for their launch as independent professionals. _x000D_
Finally, we will train these young women to be social entrepreneurs. As the year ends, they will be educated experienced and empowered professionals that can create their own offerings that bridge the gap between the demand for preventative wellness services in in Kenya, both in the urban slums and in the middle and upper class. We will use our proven model to advertise and promote these classes to the burgeoning middle and upper class that pay for service. We will market and organize pay for service classes in both private homes and institutions. At the same time, in 2010, Kenya estimated that its health and wellness tourism market would reach a revenue value of $35 million by 2016. There is a ready and growing market for yoga among wellness tourists in resorts and hotels all across Kenya, representing a large potential new job market.Africa Yoga Project is seizing this opportunity not only to create jobs for young, unemployed Kenyans, but also to empower them to help develop a broader local market that makes the health and wellness benefits of yoga accessible to KenyaÃ¢â¬â¢s middle and lower income communities. _x000D_

project_name: Energy Saving cookstoves for poor women
project_summary: Women's from developing countries are the most affected by issue relating to climate changes, this range from decrease in water volume due to deforestation which has taken place in most forests, unsustainable methods of farming which is leading to flooding and poor soil fertility, changes in weather patterns where by its very hard to predict seasons and thus leading to crop failure and food insecurity. Causes of climate change in developing world  starts with  open fire cooking which is contributing to emission of carbon into the atmosphere, this is the  second leading the first one being emissions from factories, and third being waste disposal and deforestation. My project aims at reducing emission from open fire cooking by supplying 800 energy saving cook stoves which are smokeless and fuel wood efficient.  These energy saving cook-stoves will reduce fuel-wood usage by 85% as well as reducing emission of carbon into atmosphere by 80 %. Currently open fire cooking is consumes between 15-20 kilograms of fuel-wood in a day compared to energy saving cook-stoves which consumes 2-3 kilograms of fuel-wood in a day. These 15,000 trees will provide these households with fuel-wood through pruning as well as reclaiming deforested areas of  Mount Kenya forest.

project_summary:
Project satisFactoryÃ¢â¬â¢s ultimate goal is to employ and directly change the lives of 100 women for the good, and indirectly change an estimated 330 more women and girls as well as another 330 community members, thereby having an impact on over 660 people in Cambodia after the 3rd year of operation. With funding from Project Inspire we will open a small garment factory and turn it into a medium scale operation in its third year._x000D_
Inside Project satisFactory, women will be paid at minimum $160 per month, what the Cambodian labor union has requested as the minimum wage for garment factory workers, and what the government has assessed as a livable wage for a worker and one dependent, plus other benefits, such as the following: Daycare for their young children, so that they can focus on their work and be secure that their children is taken care; Maternity leave should they need it, so that they get to enjoy their right as new mothers without being scared of losing their jobs; Free lunch so that they can supplement their daily nutrient and caloric intake; Weekends off, so that they can get to enjoy leisure time like most workers in the developed countries._x000D_
_x000D_
Project Inspire funding will go to initial startup capital for 6 months, which will provide us enough time to show our capabilities, sign contracts with buyers and generate enough revenue to survive on our own. The funding will go towards the following: Rent and utilities of a larger space to accommodate more employees and the daycare center space; Salaries and benefits of all the employees, including the daycare center nannies; Sewing machines and sewing and tailoring kits; Fabric and materials for new product, and; Business development. As importantly, the women who work at Project satisFactory will receive personal hands-on training from me in the area of fashion design, sewing, tailoring and entrepreneurship so that they can be set up to pursue their own business ventures one day should they wish to pursue this endeavor.
project_details:
The Cambodian garment industry employs over 400,000 people, 90 percent of whom are women, and pays its employees the second lowest wage in the world, only surpassing Bangladesh. Today, the minimum wage paid to garment factory workers is $100 US dollars per month. This is $60 below what the government of Cambodia and the Cambodian labor unions assessed as a livable wage. _x000D_
The rock bottom minimum wage paid to factory workers has an immediate and long-term detrimental impact on the women of Cambodia and on Cambodia as a whole. When women cannot afford to even feed themselves sufficiently, imagine what will have to their newborn and future generations._x000D_
_x000D_
Our Project, called Project satisFactory will contribute to providing dignified work at fair wages to its employees, all of whom will be women, and provide her with the necessary tools for her to lead her own entrepreneurial business venture in the future. Thereby having her being able to provide for herself and her family.

'Loombands for peace' could be the next 'Rags2Riches' -- a sustainable social enterprise that will provide continued livelihood to women and provide a better life for their families._x000D_
'Loombands for peace' is also an educational tool for public awareness about the need for peace in Mindanao and the plight of women and children in conflict-affected areas. It is a perfect tool for educating school children about what is going on in the southern part of the Philippines.
Women will have hands-on training on small business by creating a specific product and experiencing marketing these products. This is easier to manage and scale because the product is singular. _x000D_
Livelihood will also be generated. First of all, our instructors will be women from these conflict affected areas. Second of all, the women they will train (who will each receive a loomband kit of their own) will have the ability to make the loomband bracelets and sell them as well. Our estimate is that for every loomband sold, these women can earn 20 to 50 US cents per bracelet. This is because the loombands have very affordable materials. Each kit can make 20 to 30 loomband bracelets, and women can make 10 to 20 bracelets easily per day. Whatever they earn from this they can use to augment the household income of the family, for food or to send their children to school.

project_summary:
We will teach women in Philippine conflict-affected-areas (CAAs) in Mindanao how to start their own small business making loomband bracelets for peace. These loomband 'peace' bracelets will have a peace message by the women who made them, and will be sold at souvenir shops and schools to help raise awareness about the peace process in Mindanao as well as create a livelihood for women in conflict affected areas. _x000D_
Phase 1 of the project will be to select women leaders in the communities for whom we will run the train the trainer program. They will be taught different designs one can make with the loomband loom, as well as business and marketing skills and cash flow management. They will be the ones to train the women in their villages, so they can teach in their local dialect._x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 2 is to distribute loomband kits to the women in the villages. We will be targeting 150 women in conflict affected areas, where there usually are no jobs available and very few means of livelihood. The trained instructors will then teach these women how to make designs as well as how to market these bracelets._x000D_
_x000D_
Part of our work will be to create good packaging and find means for distributing the products these women will create. In initial stages, we can buy back the products of the ladies at a discounted price so we can offer to souvenir shops and distributors. However part of the women's training will be to market their own products specifically in their own localities. _x000D_
_x000D_
Phase 3 is turn-over of the project to the conflict affected areas. Once the distribution network has been established, the women leaders can now take care of the project on their own. Any profit made from selling loombands for peace are to be redistributed back to the women and the community. We can now focus on training other conflict affected areas outside of Mindanao. _x000D_
_x000D_
project_details:
We are solving a lack of livelihood opportunities for women in conflict affected areas (especially in Mindanao). All too often, businesses and tourists are wary of visiting these areas because of fear for safety. For this reason, most of these women either become victims of human trafficking or resign to subsistence living. Their disatisfaction with their way of life also affects their view on government and peace. They feel they have been forgotten and left behind, and that is why some of them support rebel groups seeking to overthrow the government and establish their own state._x000D_
By providing them livelihood opportunities with 'loombands for peace' we can help give them hope and sway them towards joining the peace movement. Moreover, by riding on the loomband bracelet trend right now, we should be able to raise awareness about the conflict in Mindanao and hear the peace messages of women who are making these loomband bracelets.

project_name: Empowering the Musahar Girls and Women through Mithila Arts and Products Entrepreneurship
project_summary:
About Musahar community and their girls and women Musahar (also known as rat eaters) is worldÃ¢â¬â¢s poorest and extremely vulnerable, community residing in 24 districts and constitute one percent population of Nepal.  Literacy rate among Musahar ethnic group is only 7 % and women literacy is almost Zero. About 100 percent of Musahar community is landless, deprived from owning property, a means of livelihood and education and facing food insecurity. Centuries of exploitation have resulted in passive acceptance of the situation among Musahar. They suffer not only from economic deprivation in all its forms but also social exclusion, degradation, discrimination, political powerlessness, alienation and face untouchability even at the hands of other Dalits._x000D_
Expectedly, women and girls get the worst treatment. Along with the burden of feeding their families amongst degrading poverty, many Musahar women face sexual exploitation by the upper castes. Women are not engaged in any productive works throughout the year even as their men work as laborer in agricultural fields or do some other forms of physical labor for their survival with low wages of the remuneration and have no saving habit. _x000D_
_x000D_
About Mithila Arts & Product_x000D_
Despite lagging behind economically and socially, the Musahar girls and women are rich in cultural and traditions skills. Mithila Arts and Products (MAP) is one of the well-established cultural assets practiced by women of all ethnic groups including Musahar residing in southern part of Nepal. For centuries, the Mithila (Terai region) women of southern Nepal have elaborated traditional arts, paints and designs on the mud walls, floors, cloths, and utilities products to celebrate wedding, festivals and religious celebrations. From generation these traditional arts, skills and designs were passed down from mother to daughter. The designs and paintings are full of life, bright and colorful focusing on the themes of animals, especially peacock birds, fishes, reptile, amphibians, and elephants that are believed to bring good luck in Mithila culture. Poor and disadvantage Mithila women and girls can be greatly benefited with immense support in their livelihood, if such cultural assets can be transformed into micro entrepreneurship. _x000D_
_x000D_
BHORE & Its Existing Initiatives _x000D_
BHORE is a campaign based and research focused philanthropic organization working established in Mithila region of Nepal to contribute in building prosperous Nepal with dignified lives of all Nepali citizens. BHORE has formally launched three campaigns based on the principle of social philanthropy on 11th October 2009. Among theses campaigns Ã¢â¬â Empowering the Powerless: Holistic Welfare of Musahar community is one._x000D_

a.	Child Marriage & Dowry System Eradication: the prerequisite for socio-economic transformation_x000D_
b.	Mithila Culture & Heritage Preservation and Promotion_x000D_
_x000D_
INSPIRE Project Description _x000D_
Goal _x000D_
The purposed project aims to empower Musahar girls and women economically and socially through micro entrepreneurship and business literacy by enhancement and transformation of their existing cultural assets and skills on Mithila Arts and products for sustainable impact. This initiative will make the Musahar girls and women part of the productive economy and decrease gender disparity, which will eventually give them decision making power in other aspects of social and family life. _x000D_

project_name: Entrepreneurial Development Program for Women In Need (EDP-WINs)
project_summary:
The EDP Ã¢â¬â WINs (Entrepreneurial Development Program for Women in Need) is one of the substantial programs of TECH, which has started in 2005.  Our EDP-WINs is assisting disadvantage communities especially single mothers, abused women, abandoned women and women with incapacitated husbands.  We give them small loans ranging from USD300.00 to USD350.00 and train them to initiate small business ventures that will help them increase their livelihood, living conditions and social status.  _x000D_
TECHÃ¢â¬â¢s EDP-WINs developed a Savings and Credit Scheme which is a modification of the Grameen Model by Professor Muhammad Yunus of Bangladesh.  TECH Outreach Malaysia has conceptualized a business model for rural women belonging to the poorest of the poor (POP) called TOM (TECH Outreach Model).  TOM is a savings and credit scheme which loans out funds to disadvantaged women at 0% interest to help these women initiate small business ventures that will empower them to become economically independent.  We hand hold these women for a period of 6 to 12 months after the loans are given by assigning business coaches to them and training with an entrepreneurship management to ensure business sustainability.  This Model has been successfully applied in Malaysia and Sri Lanka since 2009.  We plan to help these women in Nepal by replicating the model.  We have started with a small group in Nepal last year._x000D_
_x000D_
The savings and credit scheme will transform disadvantaged communities to become entrepreneurial and self sustainable.  It will ensure empowerment and allow the women to live a life of dignity as opposed to them depending on handouts for survival.  It will help them meet their basic human needs as providing them with decent shelter, clean water and sanitation and food sustainability._x000D_
_x000D_
The change that will take place is that women from the rural areas of Nepal will be selected using our stringent selection criteria to select women who are genuinely interested in starting a business venture to sustain themselves, and who have the capacity to repay their loans on a weekly basis.  The repayments to into a revolving fund which is then used to fund more women.  Women are selected based on recommendations from other members in their group who will vouch for their trustworthiness and integrity. After this process, TECH Outreach members ensure that the loan applicant is genuine and meets the criteria of a loan recipient by conducting a house visit.  The next step is for these women to undergo a five-day entrepreneurship course during which time they are taught basic business skills using the Gender + Entrepreneurship Manual by the International Labour Organization (ILO)._x000D_
_x000D_
TECH Outreach Malaysia volunteers will have a three-year exit strategy to train and develop the Partnering NGO in Nepal so as to empower them to replicate the TOM. The proposed project will look at a pilot project of 100 women at 20 women per village from 5 different villages and each woman will receive approximately USD350.00.  The TECH Outreach Team from Malaysia will make two visits per year to Nepal to build the capacity of the local partnering NGO and train and develop the woman on entrepreneurship skills and business sustainability.  The transformation of these rural women must be sustainable and for this to happen, close monitoring by both the local NGO in Nepal and TECH Outreach Malaysia is critical.  The cost of travel from Malaysia to Nepal will be part of the operating expenses.  Operating expenses will be capped to 25% per annum._x000D_

project_summary:
INTRODUCTIONIn a lot of poverty stricken neighborhoods around the world, especially in Africa, women find it difficult, and sometimes impossible, to gain access to good quality medical care. A few factors come into play and include:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Lack of funds _x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Inaccessibility of hospitals or clinics due to poor road structure or lack of transportation_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Lack of time as women are busy taking care of their homes and businesses_x000D_
A major issue affecting most women and girls is sexual and reproductive health. Most rural women shy away from talking about their sexuality and thus engage in sexual practices without the necessary information or materials to prevent them from acquiring sexually transmitted diseases as well as unwanted pregnancies. _x000D_
_x000D_
STATISTICS_x000D_
In Sub-Saharan Africa, over 50% of girls aged 15-19 years are sexually active, and over half of these give birth before age 20 (Senderowitz 1995). Early sexual debut is often associated with the risk of unwanted pregnancy, unsafe abortion, gynaecological complications, maternal death and STI/HIV infection (Ondimu 1997). The main factors contributing to high pregnancy rates among teenagers include lack of knowledge about contraceptives as well as early marriage accompanied by the need to prove oneÃ¢â¬â¢s fertility (Ajayi et al. 1991, Ondimu 1997, Toroitich-Ruto 1997). The fact that reproductive health care programmes to cater for the needs of young people are sparse and scattered aggravates the issue._x000D_
Following a research conducted by UNICEF in 2012, the prevalence of HIV among young males     between 15-19 years of age was found to be 1.8% while that of females was 3.6%. On top of that, a recent study conducted by avert.org in 2012 showed that women between the ages of 15 and 24 were four times more likely to become infected with HIV/AIDS than their male counterparts. A quarter of these women had been exposed to HIV/AIDS through violent sexual contact._x000D_
From the findings above, it is clear that women are at a disadvantage when dealing with the HIV menace. Measures clearly have to be put in place to prevent the spread of the virus amongst young women as well as preventing them from catching other sexually transmitted diseases as well as early pregnancy. The young rural women need to be empowered with the information necessary to face these challenges and this project is directed toward achieving that objective. _x000D_
_x000D_
PROJECT OUTLINE AND IMPLEMENTATION_x000D_
A solution to address these problems is a mobile application that serves the following purposes:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	provides women with 24/7 access to contraceptive information and usage_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	allows them to order contraceptives which will be delivered to them once they have accumulated a few orders in that geographical region_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	gives them a forum for reporting sexual abuse and place a request to order post exposure prophylaxis drugs if sexually abused_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	gives them access to phone numbers of counseling centers so they can access counseling facilities over the cell phone _x000D_
This mobile application shall be easily downloadable and run by a team that is able to quickly address the girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ issues and give them appropriate responses._x000D_
The application will offer women and girls vital information including the accessibility of condoms within the womenÃ¢â¬â¢s locality. Alternatively, condoms can be delivered to the area on a monthly basis if there are none accessible to them in the vicinity. The usage of condoms can also be provided to ensure their maximum effectiveness is guaranteed._x000D_
This application will also allow the women to report any cases of sexual violence and abuse so that necessary help can be dispatched to them in form of post exposure prophylaxis drugs within a time frame of 72 hours to prevent them from contracting HIV._x000D_
A mobile counseling center will be offered to them as well so that they can call those centers and receive counseling services free of charge. This will encourage them to speak up about the abuse as most of these women and girls do not raise their voices due to the stigma they will receive from their families and the surrounding neighborhood._x000D_
This mobile application is to be tested within a selected cohort in one of the areas with the highest prevalence of new HIV cases among young women, notably the Nyanza region. Once proven successful, the service can be used in other parts of the country as well._x000D_
_x000D_
PROJECT OUTCOMES AND CONCLUSION_x000D_
It is my belief that the use of such a service will spearhead the fight against the HIV pandemic as well as reduce the rate of teenage pregnancy and subsequent dropout of school by rural women. Through acquisition of knowledge on how to use condoms and other contraceptive methods,  these women will have more control over their lives and save themselves the unnecessary anguish and turmoil that comes when dealing with unplanned pregnancies or even worse, getting infected with sexually transmitted diseases._x000D_
I also believe that such a service will reduce depression rates among young rural women as they will be provided with an outlet to express their feelings and concerns should they experience the unfortunate trauma of being sexually abused._x000D_

Health: The long term impact of MaMaBy exceeds the healthcare service delivered to pregnant women during pregnancy. MaMaBy Food aims to mitigate NCD risk for their children, reducing the inherent risk passed from  mothers. We would also use this platform to subliminally promote healthier eating patterns on a long term scale, with our community groups being a vessel for such life-style changing messages._x000D_
Gender equality: By training and employing women and girls, we hope to empower them in earning their own income, and indirectly help them shift the household dynamics to a position of greater independence and equality._x000D_
_x000D_
Economic development: As we would be selling our product through street food channels in the city, we hope to partner with the local authorities in Mumbai, hugely invested in finding a way to regulate the unofficial street food market. _x000D_

Health: The short term impact of the project concerns the pregnant women and their unborn children, who will benefit from community based care that will hopefully improve pregnancy outcomes. If discovered early and managed with simple tools (e.g. low-dose aspirin, diet change), the progression of both gestational diabetes and hypertension into NCDs later in life can be reversed or mitigated. MaMaBy Care would provide women with appropriate early diagnosis, facilitating appropriate prevention. _x000D_
Employment: Our programme aims to create employment for women, providing them with training and a reliable source of income. Additionally, to facilitate the data collection on this project, we will train young girls in highly transferrable computer skills. Once fully trained, each girl will help to train a new girl and will receive help in finding a better job in the city. _x000D_

In the first stage of the MaMaBy project, we are committed to establishing the necessary infrastructure and training programme for the schemeÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s employees.. MaMaBy will capitalise on existing channels to maximise impact, optimise resources, and avoid duplication of effort; for example, using local kitchens that were initially assembled/introduced by the University of Southampton for several nutrition studies. During this stage of the project, we will also further expand our network of relevant local business and clinical counterparts; for example,   establishing ties to local clinics to which pregnant women can be referred if complications are identified,  as well as food vendors in the city of Mumbai who could sell MaMaBy Food. The precise numbers of employees that will receive training are listed in our Results Statement._x000D_
During the first year of operation, MaMaBy is committed to reaching 100 pregnant women. In our community groups, these women will receive our dual intervention on a regular basis - MaMaBy Food will provide them with a pregnancy appropriate nutritious product and MaMaBy Care will provide continuous monitoring of vital signs to detect early onsets of NCDs. _x000D_
_x000D_
Throughout this project, MaMaBy is committed to collecting and analysing longitudinal data of diagnostic and demographic parameters that will best inform the progression of our programme._x000D_

Scientific validation: Throughout programme, MaMaBy will collect data of diagnostic and demographic parameters. This data will be used to provide continuous clinical monitoring of NCD risk, as well as the effects of nutrition on vital signs. This will provide metrics by which we can assess the impact of MaMaBy Food on the mothers.MaMaBy will use secondary data from proven nutritional interventions (C. Fall, University of Southampton), as well as defined ranges of normality by the Oxford InterBio and InterGrowth studies, to compare and quantify the effect of nutrition on the newborns. Thus, this will provide metrics by which we can assess the impact of MaMaBy Food on the newborn infants._x000D_
_x000D_
Social validation: The proposed nutritional product has already undergone trials as part of a study conducted by the University of Southampton. During that period, the product experienced multiple variations in order to best match the nutritional needs of the population, whilst complying with contextual requirements and consumer preferences. MaMaBy will collect consumer satisfaction data to validate this result, and thus assess the social impact of MaMaBy Food._x000D_
_x000D_
Financial validation: MaMaBy will use this pilot study to also validate the financial sustainability of the proposed social enterprise model. This data will be used to make predictions on whether the business can be scaled up to reach a significant proportion of the slum population. _x000D_
