project_summary:
The Challenge: Non-communicable diseases (NCDs), such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes and cancer, constitute a global challenge, posing an unbearable burden on healthcare systems worldwide as well as undermining social and economic development.  Policy makers have urged for effective implementation of preventative and early diagnostic strategies to ensure health infrastructures are not crushed under the burden of treating millions suffering from preventable NCDs. 80% of the NCD-attributable deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries. Globally, over 250 million slum dwellers suffer from NCDs. For them, the debilitating effect of NCDs is exacerbated by poverty, lack of basic medical services and the lingering presence of infectious diseases. _x000D_
MaMaByÃ¢â¬â¢s Solution: MaMaBy integrates NCD management into maternal care to deliver a dual intervention - diagnose early manifestations of NCDs in the mothers and prevent inherent passage of NCD risk to their children. MaMaBy would use the Project Inspire investment to set up community groups in the slums of Mumbai, where pregnant women will come together to receive our dual health intervention - MaMaBy Food and MaMaBy Care. Sensitive to their everyday needs, MaMaBy Food provides these women with a nutritious product to help them carry a healthy baby. Simultaneously, within the community groups, these women will also receive regular screening for early manifestations of NCDs (MaMaBy Care). The scheme would be set up as a social enterprise, where profits made from selling MaMaBy Food in the city of Mumbai would be used to subsidise the scheme in the slums._x000D_
_x000D_
MaMaBy Food_x000D_
WHY? The impact of NCDs goes beyond just the health of the mother: maternal health and nutrition, before and during pregnancy, are inextricably linked to the child's risk of developing NCDs such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease later in life. The mother's nutritional intake during pregnancy is particularly important, with nutrient deficiencies and inappropriate overfeeding causing low-birth weight  and overweight infants respectively; these infants are more susceptible to developing the above-mentioned NCDs in the future. _x000D_
HOW? MaMaBy Food takes popular local recipes, such as the samosa, and improves their nutritional content using natural ingredients; this provides mothers with essential micro- and macro-nutrients during pregnancy and thus mitigates the NCD risk associated with malnutrition._x000D_
_x000D_
MaMaBy Care_x000D_
WHY? No longer just regarded as a disease of the elderly, some of the biggest NCD killers, such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes, first manifest during pregnancy. Gestational diabetes affects 15% of pregnant women worldwide, and untreated it can lead to obstructed labour; hypertensive disorders complicate 5-8% of pregnancies._x000D_
HOW? MaMaBy Care provides basically trained health workers with simple diagnostic tools, combined with advanced analytical algorithms, to allow screening and monitoring  for NCD risk in pregnant women._x000D_
_x000D_
Program infrastructure: MaMaBy's programme will be carried out by women for women. We would train and employ women in the production and distribution of our food products, as well as the acquisition and processing of medical data. The training which women and girls would receive from MaMaBy's programme would provide them with transferrable skills, raising their employability even beyond their time with MaMaBy.  _x000D_
MaMaBy's programme would alleviate some of the growing long term burden of NCDs, whilst simultaneously satisfying some of the current needs of women and girls in low resource settings. MaMaBy is therefore not just a healthcare programme but a social venture that aims to help low income societies overcome the challenges they face regarding education, employment and gender inequality. _x000D_
project_details:
Non-communicable diseases (NCDs), such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes and cancer, represent 43% of the worldwide disease burden, a figure expected to jump to over 70% of all deaths by 2020. Treatment in advanced stages of these diseases is very expensive._x000D_
NCDs are no longer diseases of just the elderly; the onset of many NCDs has shifted down a generation. Pregnant women worldwide are affected by gestational diabetes and pregnancy induced hypertension. If uncontrolled, these conditions often progress into chronic diabetes and chronic hypertension later in life. _x000D_
Recent studies have clearly demonstrated that ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ãâmaternal and child health is inextricably linked with NCDs and their risk factors, as prenatal malnutrition and low birth weight create a predisposition to obesity, high blood pressure, heart disease and diabetes later in life.ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬ÃÂ _x000D_
_x000D_
Preventative interventions for women and children at risk can reduce subsequent mortality and morbidity due to NCDs at an affordable cost.

With more applications in our library, a growing user base of women, and increased knowledge capacity of the users themselves, we hope to generate sufficient demand for Social Apps so that women will begin to pull content into their applications directly from the internet and share content with other community members, creating virality. 
By the end of the grant period, we will have worked closely with 100 CHWs to co-design applications useful for them, other women and members of their community. Information packaged in the applications will come from the community for the community and therefore, in the short term, the information included in the applications will be representative of the communityÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s lived needs. By using Social Apps communities will learn about gender and empowerment topics through a culturally appropriate lens, think through decisions that lead to better health practices vis-ÃÆÃÂ -vis choose your own adventure stories, understand information about health and other topics through interactive quizzes, and have access to a wide range of videos modules, including a set of videos that enhance mobile and digital literacy.
Dimagi will develop 15 Social Apps of various design formats and content streams in partnership with organizations and CHWs themselves. We will randomly distribute these apps among 100 women CHWs. We will analyze application usage data for at least three months and correlate usage data with user demographic information to segment users. This will allow us to understand the kinds of information women users of our platform are interested in accessing. Knowing this information will be critical in order to fill the mobile gender gap and improve access to information for women and girls.
The CommCare mobile platform automatically captures usage data and sends it to the CommCareHQ cloud server. We will monitor the number of users, frequency of submissions, session duration, and time between sessions to gain insights into the uptake of Social Apps by 100 CHWs and their community members. We will correlate application usage data with user demographic information to segment women users, application usage patterns and preferences. Understanding emerging user segments will help us design and develop specific and refined applications for women at the base of the pyramid. 
The development of Social Apps as it relates to Gender-Based Violence (GBV) will also be partially supported by USAID-funded Mobilise! Project being conducted by Dimagi, the Research Triangle Institute, and the St. JohnÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s Research Institute in Bangalore, India.
project_name: Social Apps to Empower Women Community Health Workers
project_summary:
In 2010, the GSMA, Cherie Blair Foundation for Women, and Vital Wave Consulting examined the gaps and opportunities of how mobile technology can benefit women in middle and lower income countries. _x000D_
Information available through mobile phones has been shown to transform the lives of people living in extreme poverty. However, this potential is limited by a wide array of barriers. The Ã¢â¬ÅWomen in MobileÃ¢â¬Â report revealed that women are 21% less likely to own a mobile phone than a man, a significant Ã¢â¬Åmobile phone gender gapÃ¢â¬Â, influenced by social, cultural and economic reasons. Women in particular often lack access and awareness to culturally relevant information, as well as the literacy and technical skills to take advantage of this information. There currently is a substantial missed opportunity to address these barriers through the spread of mHealth applications in developing countries. Many mHealth projects, including DimagiÃ¢â¬â¢s projects, equip women with mobile phones and train women to use mobile phones for their jobs. This underrated and virtually untapped opportunity offers a powerful platform to provide women with a wide range of information. _x000D_
_x000D_
We propose to Ã¢â¬Åpiggy backÃ¢â¬Â on the growing mHealth application deployments for community health workers (CHWs). DimagiÃ¢â¬â¢s CommCare platform (www.commcarehq.org) has over 3,000 active users, a number that is doubling every 6-8 months, and has been deployed in over 30 countries in Africa, South Asia and South East Asia. Most CommCare users are women living in rural areas. CommCare applications are enabled with images, videos, and audio clips that present important, engaging material. CommCare has transformed the way community health is delivered. A CommCare application running on cheap phones ensures that community-based women health champions are able to provide the right information at the right time to women seeking care.  _x000D_
Dimagi and our partners will co-design content with CHWs to create modules that can be added to existing CommCare applications for personal use. Co-designing content with women themselves will represent actual lived needs as reported by them. Social Apps seek to provide CHWs access to new information they want to learn about as per their personal aspirations and preferences. _x000D_
_x000D_
CHWs we spoke in our initial focus group discussions suggested that Social Apps include healthy recipes, information about gender and womenÃ¢â¬â¢s empowerment, childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s stories, household budgeting tools and guidance on digital literacy. The content will be designed so CHWs can offer it to other women in their communities or use it themselves. The apps will include multimedia supported lessons and simple quizzes, and videos.  It will be important that these apps are engaging, easy to use, and accessible enough that women are independently motivated to use the app, without too much oversight from the program._x000D_
_x000D_
This innovation expands the scope of the CommCare platform for existing users by creating avenues for them to gain knowledge on topics they decide. A large emphasis will be placed in the design stage through exploratory fieldwork with CHWs current users of CommCare. Early on, this will include focus group discussions to assess opportunities and interest areas. In later stages, this will include extensive rapid prototyping of suggested content in various app designs._x000D_
_x000D_
In 2015, our goal is to test 15 co-designed Social Apps which contain different kinds of content with 100 community health workers. Through this expanded deployment, we will gain an unimaginable understanding of the kinds of information women are most interested in and why. It would be one of the first glimpses into the informational needs of women at the base of the pyramid._x000D_
The Project Inspire grant will allow Dimagi to answer the call to action to bridge the mobile gender gap. We believe Social Apps have the potential to positively impact women who use our mobile platform in the region and globally. Health workers report perceiving higher credibility and acknowledgement from their communities after using CommCare. Dimagi is pushing the envelope for mHealth and testing Social Apps as a means of empowering women as themselves, in the many other roles they play during their lives._x000D_
_x000D_
A detailed budget and project implementation plan is included. Ground preparation will involve conducting focus group discussions with women users of CommCare at five rural sites. The pilot phase will involve developing Social Apps on site with CHWs based on their feedback from focus group discussions. Apps will be installed on the phones of a small group of users to understand usage patterns. We will collect information from users and other community members about content and design and rapidly iterate to include their feedback. Followed by the piloting and rapid iteration and development of applications, a large proportion of the funding will be used to deploy and evaluate Social Apps at a rural site with 100 CHWs. Dimagi will train 100 existing users of the CommCare platform on basic premise of the applications and then monitor application usage remotely. We expect a very low barrier for training as users selected for the evaluation have a good understanding of navigating the platform.
project_details: Social Apps is the first leap in designing mobile services for women at the base of pyramid at Dimagi. Information available through mobile phones has been shown to transform the lives of people living in extreme poverty. Women in extreme poverty face significant barriers in using mobile technology and using mobiles to access information. The mobile industry is just beginning to understand aspirations and learning needs of women using mobile devices. We strive to bridge the gender gap for women living in low resource settings in developing countries by designing mobile applications that provide important life-enhancing information and tools.

project_name: Inspiring Women to Alleviate Poverty through Small Business Ventures in Rwanda
project_summary:
The Community of Potters, also known as the Ã¢â¬ÅTwaÃ¢â¬Â pre-genocide, is known as Ã¢â¬ÅThe Forgotten PeopleÃ¢â¬Â in Rwanda. It is a historically marginalized population of about 200,000 people who were hunter-gatherers and lived a nomadic lifestyle until they were forced out of their forests in the 1970Ã¢â¬â¢s. They continued hunting and cultivating produce from small plots of land in the mountains until 2011, when they were forced to resettle to a compound in Cyaruzinge, a small village on the outskirts of Kigali. They currently reside in Cyaruzinge, where they have very small plots of land that are insufficient for supporting the communityÃ¢â¬â¢s nutrition needs. In addition, the community members are often viewed as uncivilized by others due to their prior nomadic lifestyle. This leads to discrimination that hinders their ability to find jobs and support their families. As a result, the Community of Potters in Cyaruzinge face extreme poverty, food insecurity, and unemployment. _x000D_
To promote community development, Health Development Initiative supported Cyaruzinge villagers to start income-generating activities such as pottery making and basket weaving. The Dusabane (Ã¢â¬ÅletÃ¢â¬â¢s come togetherÃ¢â¬Â in Kinyarwanda) basket-weaving cooperative was formed in 2010 by 33 women in the community. The cooperative received an initial training sponsored by the Kigali City Council, which provided the 33 women with basic weaving skills; however their capacity was limited and they were unable to create colored baskets or designs. The women also faced many challenges in the beginning due to discrimination and lack of resources. They did not have housing, so they worked under trees in their village where their work was at risk of being tarnished by the elements. They also had trouble finding markets for their products due to discrimination in the marketplace. Many women took time away from raising children, doing household chores for neighbors, or begging on the streets to do their weaving and found it difficult to support their families on the small income it was generating. As a result, women began dropping out of the cooperative._x000D_
_x000D_
Since 2010, the community has also come very far in terms of improving their lifestyles and fighting discrimination in the community, which has improved access to markets for selling products for the community members. In 2013, HDI sponsored an intensive training for cooperative members in partnership with Agaseke to master the art of weaving. Through the training, the women gained confidence in their skills, moral was improved and the cooperative was restored to 25 members. Now, the women are re-energized and focused on strengthening their cooperative, expanding their efforts to reach 55 women in their community, and using their knowledge to empower other Community of Potters women throughout the country. _x000D_
_x000D_
In partnership with the Dusabane cooperative, HDI proposes a project that is divided into three parts: handicraft skills strengthening and diversification, business management and entrepreneurial skills cultivation, and an introduction to marketing and communications. The first part involves 6 months of intensive artisan skills trainings. During this time period, the 7 master weavers in the community will work with women at beginner/intermediate levels to improve their skills and ensure everyone can produce high-quality baskets. The cooperative will also undergo training with Agaseke to learn how to diversify their skills and develop expertise in making different products (i.e. bags, shoes, key holders, hair clips, table mats, jewelry, etc.).  Money will be used to support training fees, handicraft materials, and cooperative member facilitation for the first 6 months to give the cooperative members time to master their crafts and become profitable. It will also sponsor a small center where the cooperative can meet to make goods and display and sell their products. _x000D_
_x000D_
There are many Ã¢â¬Åcopy catÃ¢â¬Â businesses in Rwanda, and cooperatives that specialize in handicrafts are one of them. The cooperative members know that if they want to be competitive in the future, they will need to expand their business and entrepreneurial skills. For this reason, the second part of the project involves workshops in business management and entrepreneurship. In the fourth month of the project, cooperative members will receive a workshop from Agaseke in business development and finance management. This will help the cooperative to professionalize their business and integrate basic finance and organizational systems.  In the seventh month, the cooperative will undergo an entrepreneurship workshop through the Babson-Rwanda Entrepreneurship center. The workshop will give the women an in-depth introduction to entrepreneurship and how to identify community needs and solutions. They will be challenged to develop business proposals to address solutions to community needs, and the best projects will be sent to a current HDI donor who is interested in supported small business ventures._x000D_
_x000D_
Many members of the cooperative never finished primary school, so they were never exposed to English. As a result, it is incredibly difficult for them to be competitive in selling their goods to expatriates. It is also impossible for them to communicate their stories and needs to potential supporters without the help of an intermediary like HDI. This is why we propose to include English training in months 7-12 of the project timeline. HDIÃ¢â¬â¢s M&E and Communications Officer will also provide the community with a 5-day communications and marketing workshop to introduce the cooperative to marketing and help them develop a marketing strategy.  The English and marketing skills will make the cooperative members more competitive in the Rwandan marketplace by giving them the skills to communicate with international visitors and make their business most appealing. It will also give them the capacity to communicate directly with supporters, understand exactly what HDI is communicating to donors, and ultimately become less reliant on NGOs to improve their lives. We realize that if we are truly dedicated to building capacity of our beneficiaries, then English training must be included to give them voices in the international development arena. _x000D_
project_details: The community of potters faces discrimination that has impacted their ability to find work and sustain their families. Through this project, we are empowering an existing cooperative of women from the community to fight poverty and improve their lives and the lives of their families. Through intensive training, we will provide them with the necessary skills to be competitive in the local marketplace. Through business management and entrepreneurial skills training, we will inspire them to specialize and start additional business ventures. Through English lessons, we will enable them to share their stories and communicate directly with international donors and clients. Should this project be successful, we will expand it to include similar communities and empower them with the skills to fight discrimination and poverty.

project_name: The Sinag Store Project: Social Entrepreneurship and Design Skills Training for Financially Disadvantaged Girl Students
project_summary:
From Disadvantaged Girls to Social Entrepreneurs and Designers_x000D_
Through the Sinag Store Project, financially disadvantaged girl students will gain marketable design skills and experience first hand how to use those skills to launch a social enterprise project. With a $25,000 grant, we will 1) teach disadvantaged girl students, aged 16-20, about social entrepreneurship and financial management 2) train girls in graphic design and design-thinking, and guide them towards creating their own design projects 3) (in partnership with the girls) launch an online store selling girl-designed products and 4) (from the StoreÃ¢â¬â¢s income) start a fund for the non-tuition school expenses of disadvantaged students. _x000D_
_x000D_
Training Girls on Social Entrepreneurship and Financial Management_x000D_
_x000D_
The Sinag Store Project involves a two-month training program with the first month setting the stage for girls to become financially savvy social entrepreneurs. The Social Entrepreneurship course will introduce the girls to the value of business skills and how these skills can be used to benefit society. A course on Financial Management will follow, where girls will learn the basics of financial literacy that can be useful for any business venture. Distinguished speakers and facilitators from the field of social entrepreneurship and business will lead these courses, imparting their technical knowledge and breadth of experience to the girls. At the end of the first month, the girls would have developed an understanding of the value of social entrepreneurship and gained financial know-how that they can build on for their future careers. _x000D_
_x000D_
Training Girls on Design Skills and Design Thinking_x000D_
_x000D_
On the second month of the training program, girls will gain skills on Graphic Design and Human-Centered Design. The Graphic Design sessions will train the girls on the Elements of Design and on using digital programs, Photoshop and Illustrator. These skills will be valuable for girls not only for the duration of the Sinag Store Project, but also for their own academic projects, or income-generating side projects that can open financial opportunities while they study. These design and computer skills will also give them technological edge when they graduate and start looking for jobs. The course on Human-Centered Design will closely guide the girls towards planning and creating their own design projects that are not only creative but also user-centric. At the end of the second month, the girls will have become familiar with design thinking, gained valuable computer skills, and come up with their own design prototypes. _x000D_
_x000D_
Launching the Sinag Store in Partnership with Girls_x000D_
_x000D_
After learning about Social Entrepreneurship and Human-Centered Design, the girls will now have the chance to put to practice the concepts and skills that they have learned in the two-month training. Depending on their interests, the girls will be divided into 3 groups: production, web development, and marketing. Each group will be paired with a professional mentor who will closely guide them throughout the process. The production group will be in charge of producing the final prototypes of the design projects. The web development group will put together an online Sinag Store webpage that will house the girl-designed products. The marketing group will be responsible for effectively advertising the Store and tapping its market. The entire Project will culminate in a Sinag Store launch event that the girls will help organize. Proceeds of the Store will go to the Sinag Fund which is used to give interest-free tuition loans to students in financial need. _x000D_
_x000D_
Measurement and Evaluation_x000D_
_x000D_
The last stage of the project involves systematically measuring and evaluating the programÃ¢â¬â¢s impact through the following methods:_x000D_
1.	Test assessment of the girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ grasp of Social Entrepreneurship and Design-thinking concepts after the training period._x000D_
2.	Interview on the girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ opinions on the value of the training they received and how they feel it has impacted their lives._x000D_
3.	Focused-group discussion with trainers, mentors and girl participants on the success of the Sinag Store launch event._x000D_
_x000D_
Project Time Line (2015)_x000D_
Jan.-Feb.	Groundwork: designing a training curriculum with mentors and trainers; securing venue and equipment; selecting pilot test participants_x000D_
Mar.	Pilot test: condensed one month training with 5 girl participants_x000D_
Apr.-May	Evaluation of pilot test; improving training curriculum based on evaluation; selecting 50 girl student participants_x000D_
Jun.	Training: Social Entrepreneurship_x000D_
Jul.	Training: Design Skills and Design Thinking_x000D_
Aug.-Oct.	Production, web development, and marketing; preparation for the Launch_x000D_
Nov.	Sinag Store Launch Event_x000D_
Dec.	Project Evaluation_x000D_

project_summary:
Ã¢â¬ÅIf a mother never learns, how can she teach the next generation? A woman is a school. If you teach her, you teach an entire generation.Ã¢â¬Â _x000D_
Education changes lives. But too often, women and girls in rural areas donÃ¢â¬â¢t have the opportunity to receive an education. Rural girls are less likely to achieve the same level of basic education as boys. According to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), Ã¢â¬ÅIf one of the children in a household has to drop out of school because of family (usually the mother's) workload, the cost of schooling or for other reasons, it is usually the girl child. If poverty precludes sending more than one child to attend school in town, then it is the boy who is normally selected to attend.Ã¢â¬Â Moreover, research has shown that even when provided education, it is typically only of intrinsic value to women because of social and cultural factors that prevent them from actually implementing their educations professionally. Several IFAD reports have shown that although rural women may acquire literacy and numeracy, their educations often do not provide any instrumental value to them. Social and cultural factors continue to lead women to rely on men to run businesses or keep accounts. This persists even in womenÃ¢â¬â¢s enterprise associations. Apart from having empowerment considerations, failure to use financial literacy skills can result in the loss of those skills. Ultimately, rural women are marginalized in their ability to access education and employment._x000D_
 _x000D_
Considering the rural regions of Cambodia, employment options in the form of wage labor or operating a business can be a very important source of income for a household. Most Cambodians generate wage and business cash income outside the Ã¢â¬Åformal sectorÃ¢â¬Â of the economy, in what we know as the Ã¢â¬Åinformal sectorÃ¢â¬Â. The Ã¢â¬Åformal sectorÃ¢â¬Â often provides more regulated, secure, and higher income employment options than the Ã¢â¬Åinformal sectorÃ¢â¬Â. Businesses in the informal sector are commonly household based micro-enterprises, which are unregistered, unregulated, and often have poor access to credit, business, and legal services. These micro-enterprises are diverse, including agriculture and natural resource processing, small- scale industrial/handicraft and service enterprises._x000D_
 _x000D_
These socio-economic vulnerabilities are related as well as contribute to food insecurity in Kampong Thom. One such vulnerability is dependency on low, erratic, and insecure sources of cash income to buy household needs including food. Another characteristic vulnerability is illiteracy, which is associated with higher levels of poverty, low incomes, and higher rates of child malnutrition. Most households in Kampong Thom do not produce their own crops for consumption, but rice production and availability in the region was higher than average levels in the rest of the country in 2004 (Food Security Atlas). Malnutrition, stunting, and protein-energy deficiency was recorded in the region (Food Security Atlas). A further set of vulnerabilities here relate to remoteness from markets, major transport networks and social services such as health and education. (Sourced from Food Security Atlas Report on Kampong Thom 2004)._x000D_
 _x000D_
Considering the inequality of opportunity and social and cultural factors that disempower women in businesses, Plant It Forward Cafe is a social business subsidiary of the Cambodian Kids Foundation that will train, employ, and educate local women and girls from the Kampong Thom region to become full business partners and create a cafÃÂ© that is an educational, social, and economic resource for the community. Moreover, Plant It Forward CafÃÂ© will source its beverages and menu items from local producers, contribute to the Plant It Forward community garden, and focus on contributing to regional food security and combating malnutrition._x000D_
 _x000D_
Ultimately, Plant It Forward CafÃÂ© will be a social enterprise that advocates for various issues within the community. It is an organization founded on the values of womenÃ¢â¬â¢s empowerment, education, and fostering entrepreneurship. The second phase of the cafÃÂ© will focus on community programming that discusses these issues, along with workshops on nutrition, job training, networking, and opportunities for local arts and culture to flourish. The cafÃÂ© is intended to serve the community as a social and business gathering space that is utilized to foster camaraderie amongst community members and social enterprises. We intend to utilize the grant by investing approximately $16,000 in startup costs for setting up our physical space. This will cover expenditure including furniture, generator, appliances, construction fees, reoccurring monthly costs, etc. The remaining funds will be used as reserve funding for  approximately 4-6 months in case our total revenue does not equate to our total monthly expenditure.
project_details: Through our project we are addressing an interconnected web of problems that ranges from job security, to the need for transferable job skills, to the under utilization of education to make independent decisions. Many women and children living in rural villages are not provided with the same opportunities as men, especially when it comes to attaining an education. The cycle of education loss starts at a young age for many girls, when families make the decision to educate a son instead of a daughter due to financial limitations. Even when girls are provided with the chance to get ahead and obtain an education, cultural stigmas and social beliefs hinder their personal and professional growth leading to the atrophy of the foundation that built they up in the first place. The limitations on education also affect a woman's ability to secure well paying, reputable employment, which is not limited to the textile industry or the 'informal sector' of day laborers and per diem workers.

The proposed project model consists of 10 design-driven skills stories and their corresponding 10 skills activities that teach entrepreneurial skills to 15,000 children (with a special intensive focus on over 8,000 girls) from low-income groups in Grade 9 in 100 government secondary schools in Bihar, India.  Be! Schools aims to teach entrepreneurial skills, reduce the dropout rate at school (with special emphasis on girls, because girls are most at risk from dropping out of school, increase attendance, and improve reading and math proficiency._x000D_
To implement this model in Grade 9, we will train two teachers and one head teacher from 100 government secondary schools once in a year to use Be! skills content with children. The teacher training will be to introduce teachers to the skill content and how to run the skills program inclusive of a special Ã¢â¬ËgirlÃ¢â¬â¢ focus running through the training. _x000D_
_x000D_
We will print and deliver 150 copies of each of the 10 skill books to each school, with an estimate of 150 kids in each school.  Mandated by the government, we will design the program to ensure that teachers and children read one book every week for two hours on a Saturday as part of their current school calendar for 10 academic weeks every year. Every weekend, children will be asked to complete their skills-action project, which follows their reading of each skills book. _x000D_

Every week, the GTS field team will collect childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s completed skills projects, grade and evaluate them. If a child does not come to school or complete a project, we will take action by visiting the school, talking to the teacher about the issue, meet the child and her family to encourage her to do the project and stay on in school. We will be closely tracking girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ attendance, performance and results, and take action to visit families when girls do not attend class to understand why, and what actions we can do to allow her more support to go to school._x000D_

After a period of three years 75 trainees will have taken part in the Vocational Sewing Project. The individual impact of completing training is described in the following section. At this stage it is also likely (and encouraged by Rachna Satrei) that graduates will forge business partnerships with other graduates. Trainees from the first cycle are also encouraged to provide advice and support to recent graduates. At this stage the project will also impact the wider community. In decreasing unemployment it not only provides economic benefit but also social benefit as community members understand the necessity and forging new skills and finding employment. It is also one of our central goals that the language lessons and lessons on individual rights will spread throughout the community. Rachna Satrei will work with the community through seminars and small meetings to reinforce these valuable lessons and to encourage community members to share them with others. 
At the end of the grant period the 25 trainees will have the skills required to pursue a successful career as a tailor/seamstress. As mentioned previously these women may use their newly acquired skills to pursue their own business ventures or they can choose to sell their products with the help of Rachna Satrei. In both cases we strongly believe that these women will achieve economic self-sufficiency and will be able to support their families financially. We also believe that the language lessons will enhance the success of their businesses by helping them to effectively advertise their products and to interact with customers. Furthermore, an education of their health and civil rights will help them to appreciate their self-worth more fully. 
The grant period can be viewed as the pilot phase of our project; we will learn from our mistakes and take strength in areas of success so that the training continuously improves with time. It is important to set challenging but realistic targets which will be used to measure the success of our training phase. Firstly, it is important to look at the economic success of the project. The central aim of this project is to provide young women with the skills to make themselves economically self-sufficient. Consequently, we are committed to train each woman to a level where they can successfully begin a career as a tailor / seamstress. We are also committed to supporting each woman on completion of the project, advising them on them on their business plans and offering to sell their products in local markets. It must be noted that there is a possibility that one or more women may choose to end their training early, or they may choose a different career path on completion. While we will support these women as best we can they have the right to make their own choices and this must be respected. It is also important to evaluate the social success of the project, focusing on trainees overall level of well-being and changes in self-perception. 
The evidence used to assess economic success is relatively straightforward. After initial discussions with community members we can confidently predict that the majority of the graduates will choose to sell their products in partnership with Rachna Satrei. In this case we will keep records of all expenditures and sales so that we can accurately assess economic success (as a not-for-profit we will not make any money ourselves during this venture). We will establish a target amount and minimum amount of profit (US dollars per month). The minimum amount will allow the individual to be economically self-sufficient whereas the target amount will also allow them to support their families and/or make improvements to their situation (for example purchasing land, improving their home, or purchasing livestock). In cases where the graduate decides to pursue their career independently we will introduce monthly meetings where their finances are examined. In addition to determining the economic success of the project these meetings will enable us to offer continued support to every graduate (not exclusively those who chose to form a partnership with Rachna Satrei), it will also encourage them to keep accurate records of their finances. It is more challenging to quantify the social success of the project. Nevertheless, through informal meetings (as mentioned above), questionnaires, and recorded interviews we aim to assess the levels of social improvement for each graduate.

Costs related to the building phase include those incurred from purchasing land, purchasing building materials (including basic building materials and infrastructural materials such as wiring and pipes), hiring tools and machinery for construction, and hiring laborers (two employees of Rachna Satrei also work on construction voluntarily).The total cost of the building phase is $28,180 (US). The cost of the land is not included in this total as it was rented on a long term lease by Rachna Satrei director Phoungmaly Nhean, prior to the start of construction. A breakdown of costs is can be viewed in the attached project budget. The NGO has already secured funds to complete the building phase of the project with the help of Minnesota Veterans for Progress and private donors from Australia. _x000D_
_x000D_
Rachna Satrei requires $25,000 from Project Inspire to complete the first year training phase of our Vocational Sewing Project. On completion of the building phase we will select 25 disadvantaged, vulnerable women, from a rural community in the Siem Reap province, to take part in our project. These women will be selected through a rigorous interview process and in close consultation with senior community members. We are particularly looking for young women who are struggling to find employment, this may be due to a limited skill set or simply because of a lack of opportunities within their community. Women in this situation are often forced to migrate to different regions or internationally in search of work. Migration increases vulnerability as women with no money or family/community support are left open to exploitation (this is discussed in greater detail in a later section). Once the 25 women have been selected the training phase will commence. The $25,000 will be utilized in the following ways:_x000D_
_x000D_
- project facilitators paycheck (coordinator, director, assistant)_x000D_
- sewing training staff paycheck_x000D_
- cooks paycheck_x000D_
- utility costs _x000D_
- provision of sewing materials_x000D_
- provision of food and cooking equipment_x000D_
- provision of teaching equipment (stationary)_x000D_
- provision of healthcare plan _x000D_
project_details: Unemployment is a prevalent issue among women and adolescents in Cambodia due to a lack of proper education and vocational skills. The enrollment rate in primary school is a mere 15 percent or less in rural areas. The lack of education is compounded by the poorÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s limited ability to utilize available local resources, which in turn causes many women to migrate abroad where they fall into exploitative employment with low daily wages. Girls and women are often physically and sexually harassed or abused by business owners. They are often forced to a life in the slums where some resort to prostitution. When they ultimately return home to Siem Reap, they are no longer economically self-sustainable and instead become dependent on others for assistance. Rachna Satrei strives to combat these issues by working with individuals and communities to change existing social norms and negative attitudes. This change is imperative to womenÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s empowerment and community development.

project_details: Unemployment is a prevalent issue among women and adolescents in Cambodia due to a lack of proper education and vocational skills. The enrollment rate in primary school is a mere 15 percent or less in rural areas. The lack of education is compounded by the poorÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s limited ability to utilize available local resources, which in turn causes many women to migrate abroad where they fall into exploitative employment with low daily wages. Girls and women are often physically and sexually harassed or abused by business owners. They are often forced to a life in the slums where some resort to prostitution. When they ultimately return home to Siem Reap, they are no longer economically self-sustainable and instead become dependent on others for assistance. Rachna Satrei strives to combat these issues by working with individuals and communities to change existing social norms and negative attitudes. This change is imperative to womenÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s empowerment and community development.

project_details_other:
After a period of three years 75 trainees will have taken part in the Vocational Sewing Project. The individual impact of completing training is described in the following section. At this stage it is also likely (and encouraged by Rachna Satrei) that graduates will forge business partnerships with other graduates. Trainees from the first cycle are also encouraged to provide advice and support to recent graduates. At this stage the project will also impact the wider community. In decreasing unemployment it not only provides economic benefit but also social benefit as community members understand the necessity and forging new skills and finding employment. It is also one of our central goals that the language lessons and lessons on individual rights will spread throughout the community. Rachna Satrei will work with the community through seminars and small meetings to reinforce these valuable lessons and to encourage community members to share them with others. 
At the end of the grant period the 25 trainees will have the skills required to pursue a successful career as a tailor/seamstress. As mentioned previously these women may use their newly acquired skills to pursue their own business ventures or they can choose to sell their products with the help of Rachna Satrei. In both cases we strongly believe that these women will achieve economic self-sufficiency and will be able to support their families financially. We also believe that the language lessons will enhance the success of their businesses by helping them to effectively advertise their products and to interact with customers. Furthermore, an education of their health and civil rights will help them to appreciate their self-worth more fully. 
The grant period can be viewed as the pilot phase of our project; we will learn from our mistakes and take strength in areas of success so that the training continuously improves with time. It is important to set challenging but realistic targets which will be used to measure the success of our training phase. Firstly, it is important to look at the economic success of the project. The central aim of this project is to provide young women with the skills to make themselves economically self-sufficient. Consequently, we are committed to train each woman to a level where they can successfully begin a career as a tailor / seamstress. We are also committed to supporting each woman on completion of the project, advising them on them on their business plans and offering to sell their products in local markets. It must be noted that there is a possibility that one or more women may choose to end their training early, or they may choose a different career path on completion. While we will support these women as best we can they have the right to make their own choices and this must be respected. It is also important to evaluate the social success of the project, focusing on trainees overall level of well-being and changes in self-perception. 
The evidence used to assess economic success is relatively straightforward. After initial discussions with community members we can confidently predict that the majority of the graduates will choose to sell their products in partnership with Rachna Satrei. In this case we will keep records of all expenditures and sales so that we can accurately assess economic success (as a not-for-profit we will not make any money ourselves during this venture). We will establish a target amount and minimum amount of profit (US dollars per month). The minimum amount will allow the individual to be economically self-sufficient whereas the target amount will also allow them to support their families and/or make improvements to their situation (for example purchasing land, improving their home, or purchasing livestock). In cases where the graduate decides to pursue their career independently we will introduce monthly meetings where their finances are examined. In addition to determining the economic success of the project these meetings will enable us to offer continued support to every graduate (not exclusively those who chose to form a partnership with Rachna Satrei), it will also encourage them to keep accurate records of their finances. It is more challenging to quantify the social success of the project. Nevertheless, through informal meetings (as mentioned above), questionnaires, and recorded interviews we aim to assess the levels of social improvement for each graduate.

We will provide the seed money to each project. We will provide ways for community leaders to interact with the young women so they can learn more about business opportunities.
We will look at participation rates, drop out rates, unplanned pregnancy statistics, profits, completion rate of the program and the employment rates for girls graduating who have been part of Dadpreneurs.
We have been using funding from Comic Relief for seed money in our pilot project of Dadapreneurs.
project_summary:
Make women and girls into entrepreneurs a huge challenge in the slums of Nairobi. We want to showcase what women can do. Over the last three years we have gradually grown our nugget of an idea into a bold, plan for changing. Three years ago, we started in one of the schools where we teach self-defense with a small entrepreneurship program. We provided eight weeks of lessons learning about the practicalities of small business. After the twenty girls completed the lessons, they worked together to form a business selling donuts to their classmates. The girls earned a profit of about $1 a week. Emboldened from their success, the girls broke off into groups of four and started a project with 1,000 KES. Their projects included selling donuts, bead work, socks and sweets.The girls continue with their project and with making a small project. We anticipate with a portion of the $25,000 we will be able to provide the program Dadapreneurs to our eight schools where we work with approximately 800 girls between the ages of 9-18. (Dadapreneurs is so called because the word for sisters in Swahili is Dada.)_x000D_
Last year, we also started a small entrepreneurship program for young women ages 19-35. We currently have about ten women where Box Girls provided seed funding for their project who are about two months into the project. Box Girls staff work closely with the women to work through challenges. So far, we are addressing challenges in providing child care, family obligations, changing demands from family and changing the product to unforeseen market challenges. The women also are collectively facing the downturn in the market due to the security situation in Kenya. Learning ways to confront challenges and deal with conflict is important and the Box Girls staff stick with the young women helping them with the problems. For example, one young woman was living with her mother and has a young child. She wanted to be able to afford his school fees, as no education is completely free in Nairobi. Once her mother say that she was earning a little bit she took a step back and stopped providing food or working as much. The mother, who thought she had the school fees earned, now had to use that money for food. Working with the mother and young entrepreneur, Box Girls staff is able to make suggestions and ensure a conversation occurs discussing the way forward for the family. Box Girls teaches self-defense to girls and women in five different slums in Nairobi through zones. In each zone, girls taught in schools and girls who have graduated school can come together for additional sport. The women in the entrepreneurship program are women from the Kariobangi zone. With a part of the $25,000, Box Girls would increase the number of young women allowed to participate in Dadapreneurs by offering the opportunity to all zones. We anticipate each year approximately 200 Box Girls graduate from secondary school without employment or additional schooling opportunities. We would provide them a start down the path forward._x000D_
_x000D_
We are also currently starting an on-line radio station as an entrepreneurship project to give women and girls a voice. The radio station will be run by five young girls with two Box Girl staff members and a professional adviser to assist them. Not only will the radio station provide programming opportunities for girls in the community but also provide a business opportunity for the girls to showcase the entire community. Learning about programming, marketing and dealing with production companies and local talent will provide the young women the opportunity to take a leadership position in the community. Currently, the slums in Nairobi have a population in excess of one million. The online radio station will use current technology to be played through an App on a Smart Phone allowing access to the radio station locally through cell phone technology rather than relying on the internet in Nairobi, which can be sporadic due to inconsistent broadband capabilities in the city and electricity. We will use part of the $25,000 to support this small entrepreneurship project._x000D_
project_details:
We are solving a number of problems with this project. We are directly challenging the social norm that women don't have a voice and can't be providers. In many households in Kenya, from a young age children are traditionally taught that the boys will be providers and the girls will run the household. It is necessary for a young women to have a man to survive. Unfortunately, many young women find themselves without resources at a young age and turn to using sex to acquire what they need leading to pregnancy and prostitution. Many girls also drop out of school._x000D_
We are also confronting one of Kenya's greatest problems, which is the unemployment rate for young people, those under 35. Today, unemployment in Kenya is 40% and 70% of the unemployed are youth. The World Bank estimates that approximately 800,000 Kenyans join the labor market each year, and only 50,000 succeed in getting professional jobs. Young Kenyans constitute 36% of the population, estimated to be about 39 million people._x000D_

project_summary:
Our project, called Hearing Express, is a model to quickly fit and deliver affordable, high-quality hearing aids in developing countries. By using rapid-fitting hearing aids, mobile diagnostic devices, and an entrepreneurial distribution system, this model is a sustainable and scalable way of addressing hearing loss on a global scale._x000D_
Hearing Express is a radically new approach to hearing care. We train local women to become Community Hearing Aid Technicians (CHATs) who can fit hearing aids using a kit that fits in a backpack. This eliminates the need for clinics and costly testing equipment. CHATs can deliver hearing aids in under an hour (instead of the 2 weeks it normally takes) using new technologies. These innovations can reduce the cost of hearing care by 90% and exponentially increase the number of patients reached. CHATs receive a commission from each sale of a hearing aid, allowing them to continue to sustainably operate in their communities._x000D_
_x000D_
The Hearing Express model, unlike traditional models, is not just a one-time intervention, but a long-term relationship between the CHATs and the hearing-impaired individuals they serve. It is not just about better hearing, it is about access to education, overcoming marginalization and a chance at a better life. The female CHATs play a vital role not only in providing access to hearing aids, but in educating entire communities and breaking through the stigma of hearing loss._x000D_
_x000D_
All patients are screened by CHATs for medical problems and when needed, are referred to an audiologist or ENT. _x000D_
_x000D_
The business model underpinning Hearing Express is currently operational in Jordan. Five entrepreneurs (soon to be 10 entrepreneurs) are earning an income as CHATs. Our pilot project has shown that people in poor village communities are willing to pay over $57 CAD (37 JOD) for a hearing aid and accessories._x000D_
_x000D_
Based on the success of our Jordanian pilot project in 2013, we are now planning to scale up our operations in Kenya, where the number of people who could benefit from hearing aids is 844,000. Hearing Express will be based at the Giants Center in Nairobi and serve the populations of Nakuru and Kisumu where 16,474 are potential beneficiaries (i.e. people with hearing loss in the mild to lower profound range and no medical complications).

According to the WHO, 642 million people worldwide suffer from hearing loss, 360 million of whom are disabled and require a hearing aid. 32 million of the latter are children._x000D_
Unfortunately, 80% of people with hearing loss live in developing countries, where treatment is inaccessible because of the high cost of hearing aids (average per device cost is $3,000), insufficient clinical services, and a lack of audiologists. In some cases, there is only one audiologist per developing country who fits an average of 300 hearing aids per year. As a result, less than 1% of people who need a hearing aid have one._x000D_

Hearing-impaired children in the developing world are unlikely to attend school. Those who do struggle enormously, grow up without a proper education, and have difficulty finding work as adults. As a result of the isolation they face, many suffer from mental health problems such as depression, anxiety, and low self-esteem._x000D_

project_summary:
The Safar Fund  www.safarfund.org is designed as a mechanism to empower young people primarily of the age group 15 Ã¢â¬â 35 from the Arab World who are involved in a community or personal initiative to search for a learning opportunity in another Arab country. Over the past eight years, this program has empowered over 5000 Arab youth using various means such as travel grants, contacts, mentoring, as well as opportunities for reflection and constructing knowledge based on their experiences through meetings and dialogue. Safar has provided 621 Travel grants in the past 8 years for youth from 18 Arab countries seeking a learning opportunity within the Arab world, 33% of them are women. Such a mechanism, offering the opportunity of a travel grant on the basis of a personal initiative, did not previously exist on a regional level and remains unique up till this day.  The Ã¢â¬ÅMawaten litta3allomÃ¢â¬Â database includes over 400 community organizations and groups active in all 22 Arab countries, and the website statistics of unique visitors on a monthly basis average 1,933 visitors viewing an average of 19,948 pages monthly. Safar has also conducted 8 regional meeting since 2006, reaching out to more than 350 youth from around the Arab world, in addition to local meetings in Jordan, Morocco, Bahrain, Tunisia, Egypt, Syria, Yemen, and Palestine. The local meetings were conducted not only in the capital city but in many rural areas, and reached out to approximately 850 Youth.  The project also produced the first resource on youth initiatives written in cooperation with youth from around the Arab world and is compiling a bibliography of research on Arab youth. _x000D_
In 2011, we initiated a local Ã¢â¬ÅmobilityÃ¢â¬Â initiative in cooperation with the Amman municipality, entitled Ã¢â¬ÅJeeraÃ¢â¬Â which focused on re-stitching the social fabric of the city through internal mobility and learning initiatives. Over the past two years, the biggest enthusiasts for this initiative have been women of all ages from different areas of the city, in addition to several local CBOs and NGOs. The basic structure of the initiative has been to organize twice a month visits to different neighborhoods of Amman, invited by a group/organization in that neighborhood, to get to know each otherÃ¢â¬â¢s work and connect to mutual learning opportunities. So far, 15 such visits have been organized, with more than 100 learning opportunities made available._x000D_

Justification:_x000D_
The range of skills and knowledge which young people, especially young women, report gaining through engagement in Safar activities is wide and highly dependent on their areas of interest and initiative. Young people report on professional, technical and artistic skills gained as well as organizational, communication and other life skills. In general, however, the granteesÃ¢â¬â¢ reflections give far greater emphasis to how engagement in Safar activities has led to a range of affective and social outcomes such as a greater sense of self-esteem, self-confidence and self-determination, as well as the building of relationships with people in the Arab World Ã¢â¬â whether entrepreneurs, artists, human rights activists, development practitioners, intellectuals. Youth also give importance to relationships established with organizations, places, cultures and histories during their journeys (often their first) to particular countries in the Arab World. Given the importance young people award to connections and relationships gained, it is perhaps not surprising that they also report that their attitudes, particularly in relation to values and views of young people and of the Arab World, are regularly challenged through their engagement in Safar activities. Our recent impact research shows clearly the relation between mobility and individuals higher engagement in their own communities. This creates higher awareness to disadvantaged communities as well as an opportunity for connection and change. Another important result of the impact mobility research is the relation between youth travel and their better economic status few years after the trip. They usually link it to connections made or ideas generated through the trip that opens their vision towards taking entrepreneurial steps that benefits their society. _x000D_
We live in a globalized era yet we remain isolated from each other. Our aim is to connect people doing similar work or inspiring work and cross bridges between them through learning that can result in work with the disadvantaged. Who could need support in certain aspects yet carry allot of richness to learn from.  A win- win situation that we want to draw attention to. _x000D_

project_name: Solar Energy as a catalyst for Economic Empowerment among the rural Maasai women
project_summary:
The organization (CBO) has realized that providing solar lanterns to households, on its own does not bring socio-economic growth. This was realized after a successful pilot of creating awareness and solar market linkage. The main barriers to economic emancipation among the Maasai women is high illiteracy levels, inability to exploit natural and subsistence resources, short days loaded with too many non-productive chores. These factors engender poverty succession with poor nutrition and low education especially among girls. The project is needed to break the vicious cycle. Solar lanterns shall result in longer hours of light and hence time is created to mobilize, train and empower the women to engage in income generating activities, _x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
The proposed project is an integrated approach of using solar energy to drive other economic activities. Solar lighting shall enable the women to carry out obligatory chores during early evening/ night. The project considers cultural, behavioral and environmental aspects and shall break the poverty cycle among the Maasai women.
project_details: Lighting Manyatta Initiative aims at supporting the women to break free from the vicious cycle of poverty  that revolve around lack of education, low awareness of family health rights, cultural inhibitions that limit wealth creation and lack of quality time to help them break free from poverty cycle.The first step was promotion of solar energy as a catalyst for economic development. To date 100 Manyattas (village huts) have taken up solar lamps through an innovative business model where one lantern is donated to one homestead which houses an average of 6 manyattas; the donated unit acts as a demonstration unit and draws the rest of the manyattas to see the benefits of the solar lamp over a kerosene lamp. Having been liberated from darkness, Maasai women in the 100 manyattas have recorded real productive gains as a result of longer hours of light. They now embark on bead making and cooking at night.

project_name: Empowering rural women of Ihorombe region through entrepreneurial bio-vegetable farming
project_summary:
During 5 years of crisis, conventional financial backers stopped to support every activity in Madagascar other than urgent humanitarian aids. Also, 92% of Malagasy populations live under the line of poverty especially in the South including Ihorombe region with 80% of poor and 27.5% in situation of food insecurity. Sawing this extreme poverty, with some women (environmentalist and economist), we create EDENA NGO on 2011 in order to help rural population especially women and youth.  This NGO is one of few NGO created by National women which has a goal to integrate women and youth in the protection of environment through project which empower them. So, during the last three years, only EDENA works with women of Ranohira commune by improving their livelihood with projects which respect the environment. _x000D_
Since 2011 till 2013, we organized 6 sensitizations concerning environmental protection for local population. For women, we organized a training concerning the bio-fertilizer and its role in the ecosystem and the improvement of their livelihood / incomes and reforestation for this purpose and honey plants. In 2012, we gave entrepreneurship training for women in Isalo in order to provide basic training in business skills that they can use for selling local products. We provide also training on leadership which enhances womenÃ¢â¬â¢s contribution to household decision-making and to their effective participation in the community life. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our majorsÃ¢â¬â¢ challenges were our tradition which not allowed women to participate in such activities because women are supposed to stay at home. In these contexts, we have proceeded to the sensitization on the necessity of women integration in our community life. We focus also our training more in practice and use an approach as gathering their inspiration in order to identify project which is not in extreme opposition to the tradition. Also, we always search financial supports from individuals and/or organizations in International and National level._x000D_

Actually, we have two majorsÃ¢â¬â¢ projects which are beekeeping financed by The Virginia Gildersleeve International Fund and bio-vegetable farming. We started this last project since 2012 within local women in order to help them to improve their food which is essentially cassava. project_name: Improving parents and children health outcomes (IMPACT)
project_summary:
LISAP would like to use this money to invest in a programme called IMPACT (improving parents and children outcomes) with an aim of strengthening community structures to sustain the positive results beyond the project period which is october 2014.LISAP with funding from tear fund ireland has been iplementing the above project with an aim of contributing to reduction of HIV prevalence, maternal and child mortality in hard to reach rural communities through a comprehensive prevention of parents to child transmission approach (PPTCT). the objective of the project was to reduce mother to child transmission (PMTCT) of HIV by 50% from 14% to 7%. The major problem was that Malawi was identified to still register very high maternal and child mortality rates. In Malawi many women die due to pregnancy and child bearing related causes. 675/1000 under-5 years death per year [Malawi demographic health survey-2010]. in the district of Mzimba where the project is going to be implemented the problem is worse as indicated by a high child mortality of 131/1000 live birth. About 30% of chilldren die before they reach the age of 28 days of their life time and about 50% die within the infancy age._x000D_
Considering the fact that most of Malawi population are female (about 52%) it means that the children that the country is losing would have been women of tomorrow._x000D_
the major contributing factors of maternal mortality in Malawi and Mzimba district include the following:_x000D_
1. Harmful cultural practices which lead to unplanned pregnancies. Women sexual reproductive health rights are violated. Women have very little power to decide on the number of children they want to have and when to have them. they can't even ask a man to use a condom or any other means of protection against pregnancy or HIV. All the decision comes from a man. This predisposes women to alot of harm._x000D_
2. Lack of male involvement in PMTCT services.The decisions to seek type of care, where and when to seek that care care is left in the hands of male partners unfortunately these decisions are made out of little knowledge and lack of involvement by male partners._x000D_
3. poor access to health services. most of the good health services are in urban areas. The rural community faces alot of hardships in as far as accessbility is concerned. Poor staffing where only one nurse manages a population of over 2000 expected pregnant women per health centre coupled by poor road network and transport system make the life of pregnant women difficult._x000D_
4. Gender in equality. women in Malawi and especially among the Ngoni in culture in Mzimba district where the project is implemented are regarded as inferior. they lack good economic status and their voice is less heard._x000D_
5. Lack of awareness_x000D_
the IMPACT project for the past 21/2 years has implemented a project to transform most of the above attitudes and behaviours. Athough the final evaluation is not yet conducted results indicate that the project is going to be sucessful. some of the issues that show good change include the following:_x000D_
Most pregnant women pregnant women and their male partners access vital information on PPTCT/PMTCT at home through community based mother buddies and care group volunteers._x000D_
Most pregnant women attend ANC and over 90% deliver in health facility assited by skilled health professionals_x000D_
Most male partners accompany their wives to antenatal clinics where they test together for HIV. There is incresed cooperation in most families which do things together [over 64% couple HIV testing from 0%]. the husbands and general community support pregnant women with emergency transport systems to deliver at a health facility._x000D_
Most women of child bearing age(15-49) years access different types of family planning methods_x000D_
Almost all HIV+ pregnant women access ARVs and children born from HIV+ mothers are tested using early diagnostic methods at 6 weeks._x000D_
The major strategies that have been used in order to achieve good results include the following:_x000D_
1. use of mother buddies and care hroups where volunteers provide door to door education and awareness sessions to both partners._x000D_
2. identification, registration and systematic follow ups of pregnant women using phone system by mother buddies and simple manual village registers by care group volunteers to make sure every family is conselled and supported with relevant information and even materials where possible._x000D_
3. use of churches and communities to provide different types of support by envisioning religious groups to mobilise the communities._x000D_
4. By women empower through village savings and loans group and self help groups where women are empowered not only economically but also politically. during their metting apart from money transctions they also discuss issues that affect their life and together they are able to advovate for respect of gender equality and their rights to control their sexual and reproductive health life._x000D_
since funding for this project is coming to and end in october 2014 and possibility of another funding is very remote LISAP would like to benefit from project inspire funding to support the communities in Engucwini, Kamwe and Thoza sustain their good transformations by strengthening their exixting systems which have been mentioned above. these include mother buddies and care groups to continue providing awareness, the microfinance groups and other innovative concepts. LISAP will do this by continuous monitoring and providing technical support. Documentation of best practices will be conducted and shared in order to multiply the effects to other communities and countries._x000D_

project_name: Second Wind:  Vocational Training for Victims of Violence
project_summary:
Second Wind is a chance to start over.  Its finding your power when you thought it was gone.   Its finding your voice despite oppression, despite violence.  Its overcoming these obstacles to live a healthy, happy life._x000D_
This is what the Centre for Social Research (CSR) stands for in our work with survivors of domestic violence.  We seek to provide every woman who comes through our doors with the resources she needs to end violence in her life, find her power, and build the life that she truly wants to live. _x000D_
_x000D_
With the Project Inspire grant, CSR will ensure that women who come to us experiencing violence will have access to training and resources that will help her break free from the financial chains that often keep a women in the bondage of domestic violence. _x000D_
_x000D_
CSR will use the grant to replicate the Vocational Training Program that CSR operates in the Northeastern District of New Delhi as part of the Delhi GovernmentÃ¢â¬â¢s Gender Resource Centre program.  The goal of the program will be to empower women to stand up to domestic violence by supporting their economic self-sufficiency. _x000D_
 _x000D_
The program will have five components:_x000D_
_x000D_
1.	Vocational Training classes in beauty culture and tailoring, each of 6 month duration_x000D_
2.	Basic financial literacy and business training that will support women in operating as independent entrepreneurs.   _x000D_
3.	Self Help Groups (SHGs) to support womenÃ¢â¬â¢s entrepreneurial development _x000D_
4.	Link with local bank for microcredit (facilitated through SHGs) to support entrepreneurial activities_x000D_
5.	Business counseling and job placement support_x000D_
_x000D_
CSR is already operating one Gender Resource Centre in Usmanpur in Northeast Dehli.   This Centre is supported by DelhiÃ¢â¬â¢s Mission Convergence program which establishes Gender Resource Centres across the city in partnerships with NGOs.   These centres offer a range of services to support women including access to information about government schemes as well as vocational training services._x000D_
_x000D_
CSR also operates two Crisis Intervention Centres (CICs) in the South and Southwest districts of Delhi that provide family and legal counseling to victims of violence and a range of community awareness generation programs.  The proposed project is part of CSRÃ¢â¬â¢s plan to expand and deepen the resources available to victims of violence.  The plan includes expanding psychological counseling and medical services at the CICs as well offering vocational training to help women transition to an independent source of financial support so that she and her children can make good decisions about how to best eliminate violence from their lives. _x000D_
Through the proposed project, CSR seeks to link these vocational services more closely with women escaping domestic violence through expanding the GRC vocational training program to serve clients of CSRÃ¢â¬â¢s two existing CICs.  _x000D_
_x000D_
The current training centre serves roughly 75 women per year with training in beauty culture and tailoring.  The program seeks to expand this work to train 150 women per year in CSRÃ¢â¬â¢s program areas servicing victims of domestic violence.   _x000D_
_x000D_
In subsequent years, the programÃ¢â¬â¢s offerings will be expanded beyond beauty culture and tailoring and linkages with a new vocational training institute that CSR is establishing in Gurgaon will be established and reviewed.  The institute is currently in the planning stage.  CSR is seeking to covert a property in Gurgaon into an institute that supports the vocational development of women and other marginalized groups.  As the plan and design of the institute develops, CSR will establish a scholarship and referral network within its CIC communities to link women with more educational opportunities to further strengthen their financial independence. _x000D_
 CSR seeks to empower women to transform their experience with violence and to find the power to build stronger, more independent lives.   Financial independence is a key step in this process._x000D_
_x000D_
Domestic violence has a multiplied impact, influencing a womanÃ¢â¬â¢s entire family and broader social circle.  As a women steps into greater financial independence and resolves patterns of violence in her life, all of her relationships are served for the better.  In this way, building the financial independence of 150 women can touch the lives of upward of 1,500 people. _x000D_
_x000D_
The program will also have a multiplier effect in terms of providing increased access to services. Through the awareness generation activities at the CICs, the program will be made available to two communities with outreach to minimally 5,000 people.   By associating this training with our established Crisis Intervention Centres, the community will understand that there is a local Ã¢â¬Åfull-serviceÃ¢â¬Â resource to help women builder stronger, healthier lives free of violence. _x000D_
_x000D_
We encourage the selection committee at Project Inspire to review our documentary, Second Wind* (link below and in the application page).   This film share the stories of women who have benefited from the services at the CICs and have gone on to build stronger, healthier lives. project_name: Empowering Women Farmers in Taraba State, Nigeria to Improve Their Farming Skills
project_summary: The AWP Network is an innovative online learning platform powering small business success for African entrepreneurs. At AWP, we focus on the development, growth, and sustainability of African small businesses. The AWP Network Agropreneur project is a mobile, online, and workshop-based training program delivered in the Hausa language and meant to help women farmers in Northern Nigeria improve their farming skills. Our innovative training program will accomplish the following: (1) create a powerful network of women farmers (2) teach innovative farming techniques through collaboration which in turn will enable these women to increase farming productivity thereby increasing income. (3) teach farming skills to help increase crop yield, crop production skills and yield per land area. (4) develop a mobile application. We currently have an ongoing pilot program and we will continue our relationship with the following bodies (1) the National Council for Women Societies, Taraba State Chapter, (2) partnership with locally based farmer and owner of Farmfield Agro Services, Zanau Hassan.
project_details: Our goal is to help women farmers move strategically from peasant farming to commercial agricultural production. What does this mean? As Africa moves rapidly toward the agricultural economy, many ill-equipped farmers will be left behind because they may not have access to the most up-to-date technological and innovative tools needed to aggressively move their farms and crop production method into the larger commercial production landscape and ecosystem. This training program helps to involve, engage, and update obsolete skills. It aims to provide training on up-to-date farming skills and techniques.
