project_summary:
Ngahkam and Ndombile are two villages placed in ThiÃÂ¨s region, in Senegal._x000D_
In the village of Ngahkam a group of women has set up a health clinic with two rooms, mainly used as maternity wards. Thanks to the sale of local handicrafts, women could afford to buy the equipment, the medications and to employ a nurse. The clinic has been offically recognised, becoming a Poste de SantÃÂ¨, that serves the twelve villages around. _x000D_
_x000D_
The Women's Association of Ndombile wants to duplicate this experience in their village._x000D_
In the village of Ndombile were identified two rooms, two beds were provided and three women were trained in maternal Health Care until now. But still missing funds for employing a nurse, for buying medications, and equipment to set up the clinic. _x000D_
_x000D_
The projectÃ¢â¬â¢s aim is to help set up the new clinic and empower the women of Ngakham and Ndombile by creating a network between the two villages. _x000D_
The network will allow the exchange of knowledge and competencies and facilitate the development of the handicraft trade in order to raise the necessary funds for the clinic._x000D_
The project is designed to be a pilot project: this experience could be transferred to other villages in the Country, supporting the growth of new village networks._x000D_
_x000D_
The projectÃ¢â¬â¢s activities are:_x000D_
- mapping weaknesses, resources and interpersonal relationships in the area using Net-Map Toolbox. _x000D_

- choosing and prioritising activities and feasible actions;  _x000D_
- undertaking these activities, hire a nurse and provide some instruments and medicines;_x000D_
- supervising and providing initial assistance;_x000D_

_x000D_
The general principles are:_x000D_

_x000D_
This project will promote an inclusive and participatory approach, involving the full range of beneficiaries and stakeholders._x000D_

project_summary:
FloHope Indonesia is a social business producing flannelette handicrafts in the form of artificial flowers. We are trying to do the business together with street-sweeper ladies in our university by involving them in the business activities. It is established in a mission to give additional income for the street-sweepers so that their families can have higher income, therefore get them out of poverty level and create better future for their families. It is crucial for us to address this issue because they depict a social problem happening in front of our eyes and is yet to be solved. Currently, they can only get around $3.7/day as their wages for the whole family or less than $2/day per capita, which is below the minimum living cost standard set by The Jakarta Wage Council as $199/month. In FloHope Indonesia, the street-sweepers are taught about how to create flannelette flowers and they will routinely give their creations to us for an exchange of money, as we are the ones who market the product. They will also get financial planning education so that they can allocate their additional incomes for important accounts such as housing, nutrition, education, and health._x000D_
What makes us different from other similar businesses are: 1) we offer social value; 2) we deliver a full package for people to express their feelings and not only will we seize moments, we create them; 3) we have an immense potential target market._x000D_
First of all, we offer social value to consumers. Once they are buying FloHope IndonesiaÃ¢â¬â¢s product, they will know that they are actually benefiting not only themselves but also the street-sweepers. However, unlike many social businesses in Indonesia, we do not want people to buy our products because they feel sorry for street-sweeper ladies; we want them to buy because we have good quality. That is why we will give the social information on goody-bags which is given on the time of delivery: meaning we are conveying the information after-sales, not the opposite._x000D_
Secondly, we have a full-package product. It is sold with cards on which customers can write messages for the people they want to give the flowers to. It is also sold with pretty goody-bags which create easiness for the customers as a packaging for the gifts. We also try to innovate as much as we can to create valuable moments for customers by providing additional value-added products for certain moments, for example creating Polaroid picture-taking service during graduation ceremony._x000D_
Lastly, we have huge potential market. Unlike many social businesses doomed to fail in Indonesia because of the struggle find a market for the product, we have already picked one specific target market which will hopefully bring much income for the business: graduation ceremonies. Graduation ceremonies happen every month in Indonesia, with its numerous universities, both public and private. Our product is also suitable for high-school and middle-school graduation ceremonies. Those facts, added with potential market for marriage and other ceremonial occasions, created immense potential market for FloHope Indonesia. _x000D_
After giving the ability to produce flannelette flowers, we will train the street-sweeper ladies to run their business independently. This trainingÃ¢â¬â¢s including financial, marketing, production, and human resource management. This training will be given continuously in 2-3 years, consists of two schemes: mentoring and simulation. Hopefully, they still could run the business after they resign from their job as a street-sweeper.  _x000D_
With USD$25,000, we want to do these three things. First, we have a plan to empower more street-sweeper ladies. So far, we could just empower 6 women. We have a target to empower 20-30 street-sweeper ladies in our campus, and to do that, we need additional funds to expand our business. We also want to establish a FloHope Store. Currently, we only sell our product via online media (twitter, facebook), and we think that if we have a store, it will increase our revenue. In addition, we could also jointly sell our products with other social enterpreneurship movement in our university. Lastly, we want to establish FloHope Indonesia in other campus in Indonesia. We believe that if we spread this movement into other campuses, it will create a greater impact than now and give an inspiration for the other students to contribute in this movement.

project_name: RURAL AND URBAN SLUM CHILD MOTHER PROJECT
project_summary:
As far as the campaign against women marginalisation is concerned, many issues have been addressed publicly. The above has enabled the woman to engage in development activities that benefit her life without having to worry much about discrimination._x000D_
Most campaigns are proving successful and many women and girls have continued to enjoy the freedom. This has assisted in saving many village girls at risk of FGM, the agony of early marriage, girl child labour, molestation and discrimination in matters pertaining to their education or future career. However, there is one area that has still been left undressed. This is the plight at which child mother have continued to grow at an alarming rate._x000D_
_x000D_
This refers to a group of girl children who, out of no fault of their own find themselves becoming mothers at an early age. They range between the ages of thirteen and nineteen. They live both in urban - slums and rural areas. _x000D_
_x000D_
What drives them in to the child motherhood?_x000D_
Various reasons explain the above. These include:_x000D_
_x000D_
i.	Exposure/ Upbringing in informal settlements. In some situations the above provides environments that are not conducive for the girl child upbringing. This therefore means that the girl-child is subjected to environments that do not suit her growth in matters of healthy social behaviour. Some of the above girl children have mothers, who themselves, are commercial sex workers. They are driven into the bad habits of early promiscuity, which is generated, from watching and learning from their mothers. This is done in pursuit of gaining income for survival._x000D_
_x000D_
ii.	Girl child labour in commercial farms. These include, coffee estates, flower estates, pineapple farms and many other major farms to mention but a few. Many girls seek employment in the above farms for purposes of generating income. In most cases, the salaries are so low that the girls end up accepting gifts in form of money from the other farm workers and farm owners in exchange of sex activities. They in most cases conceive due to ignorance in usage of female contraceptives and therefore end up becoming mothers at an early age. _x000D_
_x000D_
iii.	Kenya is known to have one of the biggest slums in Africa and the slum settings expose most young women to early prostitution in pursuit of sustaining their lives._x000D_
_x000D_
iv.	The urban youth, at their tender age, are4 exposed to the western lifestyles that they deem fashionable. In so doing, most get involved in early sex activities and in some cases end up becoming mothers at a very early age._x000D_
_x000D_
v.	The pastoral communities have been known to marry their young girls between the ages of 13 and 17 to older men as 3rd or 4th wives. They end up becoming mothers at a very early age. _x000D_
_x000D_
In all the above, the girl child finds herself caught in the web of early motherhood thereby becoming a Ã¢â¬Ëchild mother. The girl goes through thick and thin to first survive the pregenancy and then embarks on ways and means of feeding herself as well as the child born to her. Some end up going to the streets._x000D_
_x000D_
A lot of injustice is associated with the child mother. The society looks down upon them. They lack a place where they can be able to express themselves as clearly as can be heard. While talking about, the girl child very few people talk about the child mother. If there is, then it is not loud enough for the society to be able to feel their existence. This becomes the case yet the child mother is the worst hit. _x000D_
_x000D_
The above project therefore seeks to bring to light to all the nations of the world the existence of the child mother. It seeks ways and means of intervening in her situation and assist her survive the agony of early motherhood. It hopes to protect the health of the child mother as well as the one born to her. _x000D_
_x000D_
PROJECT GOAL_x000D_
_x000D_
To bring to the fore (public limelight/attention) with a view to have government, development agencies, private practitioners and all involved in development policies to start addressing the plight of the girl child in a more meaningful way, by informing them of their existence and seek ways of assisting the ones already victimised and cut the cycle of the process repeating itself. _x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
PROJECT ACTIVITIES_x000D_
_x000D_
In bid to achieve the above, the project aims at the following activities:_x000D_
i.	Shoot a 20 minutes documentary highlighting the lives, times and agony of the child mother._x000D_
ii.	Organize 2 workshops to build the capacity of 100 Child Mothers in Kiandutu slum in Thika District. The workshops will be on:-_x000D_
a)	Entrepreneurship Ã¢â¬â developing small business for income generation_x000D_
b)	Life skills_x000D_
iii.	Develop a Ã¢â¬Åbank without wallsÃ¢â¬Â for the Urban Child by giving them business starting capital of Kshs 6,000/=._x000D_
iv.	The funds will be borrowed and returned at an interest so as to develop further their capital asset._x000D_
v.	The Child Mothers will carry out village shows, drama and artistic activities that portray the existence of the child mother and what plight they go through._x000D_
vi.	3000 posters manufactured and distributed to the public_x000D_
project_details:
The project aims to break the vicious cycle of the Urban Child Mother. These are the young girls of the ages between 10 to18. They live in the slums areas where the surrounding environment makes them so exposed to getting pregnant at that age. _x000D_
_x000D_
They give birth when they are still ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬ÃâchildrenÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬ÃÂ themselves. So it ends up being a case of a child who is also a mother to a child. Sometimes they do not even know the fathers to their babies They find themselves in a situation where they cannot be able to neither feed themselves nor their children. They suffer from poor nutrition too._x000D_
_x000D_
Since they themselves live in pathetic situations, their children too are mostly likely going to fall in the same scenario and the cycle continues. This project aims at breaking that cycle and empowering 100 current child mothers. They will be trained on earning a living so that they can be able to meet the basic needs of their children. This will break the cycle and the Urban Child Mother will be empowered .

project_summary:
Re orientation of adolescent girls in Ogwa community in Edo state through community development and total life empowerment.My name is Oboh Ebehireme and I am from Edo state in Nigeria. When I was much younger I had a dream to study fashion design in Italy but here was a huge challenge. Girls from Edo state are notorious in Italy for human trafficking and prostitution. There was no way my visa would have been approved without serious interrogation because by virtue of my state of origin, I was already prejudiced. My fellow sisters were prostitutes in Italy and I would have been perceived seen as one._x000D_
Teenage girls still fall prey to the deceit of going to Europe and their lack of positive role has made the trend persist as a way to escape the culture of poverty they are faced with._x000D_
The culture of poverty is what makes it pass down from one generation to the next until a linage or community is infused with the mindset of lack and poverty as a norm. The life of an adolescent girl caught in the web of poverty is definitely one of the greatest cruelties in life. ItÃ¢â¬â¢s at that stage of their lives factors like mental, emotional, financial, health and educational welfare will determine the quality of lives they will lead in future either as mothers, workers, wives or just as members of a community. ItÃ¢â¬â¢s however our corporate responsibility to empower these adolescent girls with value systems and skills that will make them an asset to their community. _x000D_
This project is aimed at creating a sustainable structure for the rehabilitation of girls in Edo state. Through the impartation of life, capacity building and financial empowerment skills that will initiate a paradigm shift in their lives and in the community. _x000D_
In the course of the project, _x000D_
The project will be carried out in this order:_x000D_

2.	Informing the men: a lot of men do not know how to treat girls and women basically because of ignorant tradition. Informing the men about the importance of girls and women in the society will enable them render their support. Therefore a one day workshop will be held for the men in the community to this regard._x000D_
3.	Girls only clubs. Thirty girls from the community with ages ranging from 13- 22 will be given a comprehensive training on acquiring livelihood skills and business literacy and at the end of the two weeks training, each girl will be given a training kit which includes a manual that will contain all the information she will pass down to other girls in the school club. With the right orientation and equipment, these young people will be set on a path where the former prejudice to their own success is changed. ItÃ¢â¬â¢s this new self concept that will transform communities starting from individual._x000D_
4.	Skill acquisition and financial empowerment: in this aspect, 20 ladies (18-25years) will be trained basic skills that can give them financial independence. Skills like handmade jewelries, catering, hair styling, fashion design, etc. The selected girls for programs like the hair styling and fashion design will be attached to establishments that will give them the required training. At the end of their training, they will be given a small sum of money to support a start up _x000D_
5.	Grinding business: Ogwa is an agro community. Therefore a business that helps to process farm produce is sustainable. project_summary:
Victims of armed violence in Burundi, especially those left with disabilities as a result of their injuries, are some of the most vulnerable people in the world. Often left psychologically, and economically devastated, these victims have few paths available for improving their lives, often facing significant stigma from their communities and even family members. _x000D_
The projectÃ¢â¬â¢s aim is to improve access to livelihood opportunities for 100 women victims of armed violence and women with disabilities in rural Rutegama district, Muramvya Province, Burundi, two groups that are amongst the most disadvantaged in post-conflict Burundi. It will achieve this through the formation of a self-managed community savings group, called Savings and Internal Lending Communities (SILC). Four complementary interventions will be utilised: 1) entrepreneurship skills building 2) leadership strengthening 3) innovative agricultural training 4) psycho-social support._x000D_
_x000D_
This project will have three objectives for empowering vulnerable women: to build a space and an opportunity for vulnerable women to manage their own savings and loans system; to improve womenÃ¢â¬â¢s abilities and skills in business and agriculture; and to improve vulnerable womenÃ¢â¬â¢s mental health. Each component will be mutually reinforcing, and with access to credit, knowledge in entrepreneurship, better mental health and a social support network, women will be empowered to develop sustainable income-generating activities and improve their living conditions and that of their families._x000D_
_x000D_
The project will accompany 100 women to form SILC groups (4 groups of 25 women each, supervised by 2 peer-support workers (PSWs)). The women have been selected based on a previous project AOAV implemented with the support of the Norwegian and Australian governments, which focused on improving the mental health and promoting the rights of victims of armed violence in Burundi, working with a local partner, The National Ex-Combatant and VictimÃ¢â¬â¢s Network (CEDAC). Over 1,300 survivors received peer-support and 85% finished the programme scoring in the Ã¢â¬ËRecoveringÃ¢â¬â¢ category (the highest category). Women survivors and women with disabilities have enhanced self-esteem and are now better equipped to lead their own socio-economic activities. _x000D_
_x000D_
Yet despite the positive gains in their overall well-being, 50% of previous beneficiaries were without employment and 80% expressed a need for income-generating activities. Without means to earn a living income, these women risk sliding back into hopelessness. To avoid this, towards the end of the project AOAV encouraged the formation of SILC groups in several districts. This project will allow the former beneficiaries of Rutegama to also benefit from the SILC methodology, in addition to entrepreneurship and agricultural training which will multiply the impact of the SILC. Priorities will be given to women with disabilities aged 18-35 and other vulnerable women will be invited to join based on spaces remaining. _x000D_
_x000D_
SILC is a methodology developed by Catholic Relief Service (CRS) with proven success in Burundi. Based on the experience of Biraturaba (a local NGO who have helped over 18,000 people to form SILC groups), groups successfully utilizing SILC methods for savings and lending have achieved a 56% increase in income among beneficiaries, and 90% of those who took loans had clear improvement in their economic conditions after two years. This approach is suitable for the Burundian context where access to credit is limited, especially for those with disabilities and survivors of the civil war. _x000D_
_x000D_
SILC: The SILC groups will develop their own rules; they will meet regularly and will save each week a pre-determined amount of money. Shortly after, the members will borrow from the funding pool and will later repay with the interest rates set out by the group. As a result, the SILC group will make profits; as the profit increases so does the amount of money available for lending, creating a continuous cycle.  There will also be a special savings fund for emergency situations affecting group members.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Skills for developing sustainable income-generating activities: Five women in each group (20 women in total) selected by the groups themselves will be trained in basic entrepreneurship (5 days on market assessment, business plan creation and management by AOAVÃÂ´s local partner The Burundi Business Incubator), leadership (2 days by a local expert) and sustainable agriculture (4 days by a local expert). The sustainable agriculture training will assist women to improve the yields and develop effective tools and sustainable farming management practices. Due to scarce resources and land to cultivate, this training will bring farming knowledge and techniques that will teach women on how to grow more with less land, water, fertilizer, while preserving resources. The training will be on Bio-intensive agriculture, Keyhole Gardens construction, rainwater catchment Ã¢â¬ÅhafirÃ¢â¬Â storage and grain store. Each training will be tailored to the specific needs of the women (most are non- or semi-literate) and adapted to RutegamaÃ¢â¬â¢s context. These 20 women will in turn support and guide women from their groups in starting their business. _x000D_
_x000D_
Support Network: The PSWs accompanying these groups will continue to offer psycho-social support during group sessions, to reinforce solidarity and improved mental health. They will facilitate discussions where beneficiaries will share testimonies on the challenges they face and on their successes, while continuing to provide advice and referrals. project_summary:
BackgroundSamoolam Crafts is a hybrid social enterprise based in Delhi in India inspired from the idea of Ã¢â¬ËGiving Back to RootsÃ¢â¬â¢. In this hybrid model, Samoolam is the registered NGO based in Bihar undertaking community initiatives training women in hand crochet craft based livelihoods and Samoolam Crafts is the marketing entity helping market the products to make the organization self independent. _x000D_
_x000D_
Founder Usha Prajapati is born and brought up in Gaya, Bihar where the seed idea of Samoolam comes from. She believes that as youth we owe certain responsibilities to our roots and we should contribute a small percentage of our time or resource for the development of the community from the region we belong to. Being a woman who is born and brought up in this region of Bihar she has faced personal and academic challenges and understands what each woman has to go through in their lives. Her education, experience and deep connection with her roots has brought her back to help the underprivileged women in this region. She is a true believer of Ã¢â¬Ëindividual powerÃ¢â¬â¢ that can awaken collective energy. According to her we all owe certain responsibility to the people, place and environment where our roots come from and we must try to help them. We should inspire others and build a collective effort to make some positive impact in our society. Project - Ã¢â¬ËGiving back to Roots Ã¢â¬Ë Build pride and respectful livelihoods for womenÃ¢â¬â¢ is a small effort in that direction._x000D_
_x000D_
Samoolam Crafts is working in the field of providing respectful livelihoods for women from informal work sector (construction workers, wage workers) by training them in crochet handicrafts. Samoolam is the mother NGO, registered under Indian Society Act 1860 in Bihar takes care of all the community engagement work such as skill building, community awareness and mobilization. Samoolam crafts the marketing entity of Samoolam able to engage and give employment to more than 80 women benefitting them directly and 350 indirectly. Women at Samoolam crafts are empowering themselves creatively and spirituality. _x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
As part of next phase, Samoolam crafts plan project- Giving back to Roots Ã¢â¬Ë Build pride and respectful livelihoods for womenÃ¢â¬â¢. Organization aims to reach out more girls and women from remote villages of Bihar and train them with creative livelihood skills._x000D_
_x000D_
Bihar being of the poorest states of India has been experiencing brain drain for decades. Productive brain has been moving out of the state due to lack of employment opportunities and good education. It has lead to low literacy, GDP and general awareness amongst the community living within the state. Women are one of the most vulnerable sections of Bihar with limited authority and voice on decision-making. Moreover in patriarchal social structure their education gets least importance. Samoolam believes in bringing the self worth, pride along with social and economical independence for the women who are underprivileged in remote villages. Our beneficiaries are from poor families of 6-8 members where total monthly income is INR 2000-3000/- ($ 34 - 50)_x000D_
_x000D_
Women are able to contribute to the household economy while working from home and taking care of the family. We believe that women use the money in the most productive manner for the family while payment utmost importance to the health and education of their children. We aim to bring an impact where children from these families receive basic health and education services along with their overall wellbeing._x000D_
_x000D_
Project- Giving back to Roots Ã¢â¬Ë Build pride and respectful livelihoods for womenÃ¢â¬â¢ is a small initiative in this direction. We have been training women with very fine quality of hand crochet jewelry crafts. After four years of successful journey of becoming self-sustainable now we are aiming to introduce more techniques such as stitching and embroidery along with crochet. We also trying to develop new product range that can fetch better money to these women groups. In the next phase of the project we aim at-_x000D_
_x000D_
1.	Community cum training center- Training space is very important for us where more women be trained simultaneously. The current center is small and we are unable to accommodate more than 15 women at a time. We plan to conduct 10 trainings (5- Craft based and 5-enterprise based) by end of 2015 training appx 150 women. For that we want to rent a bigger space at our community base in Gaya, Bihar._x000D_
_x000D_
2.	Scale up the operation area Ã¢â¬â We are interested in reaching out to more women from rural Bihar who is either school dropout, uneducated, unskilled, poor and underprivileged. At present we are working in Gaya and Kujap in Bihar. We plan to start working in three new villages by the end of December 2015. _x000D_
_x000D_
3.	Setting up audio-visual training center for mobile training Ã¢â¬â We aim to set up an Audio-visual training center. At this center experts will provide trainings to women groups from cities remotely through video call. It will work, as distance training program because every time bringing experts to the villages is a high investment activity for the organization. _x000D_
_x000D_
4.	Training of the trainers- at present most of the trainers & experts are invited from other states of India. We plan to make local team of master trainers who can be trained by the experts. At grassroots level trainer will transfer their knowledge to the local communities. Every six months local trainers will be going through advance training to polish their skills._x000D_
_x000D_
5.	Training the groups in enterprise development- Along with craft development now we want to focus our energy on micro-enterprise development. Women groups will be organized and training will be conducted to teach them how to start a micro-enterprise and how to run a successful business. It will help them become more independent with their small setup and work with us._x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
6.	Training the groups in new Craft techniques- So far Samoolam crafts has been focusing on crochet as technique for skill building. After four years of rigorous training in this craft, our women have mastered the skills and have achieved international standard quality and finishing. As part of the product diversification we are planning to introduce new techniques and product line. We aim to introduce new skills such as stitching and embroidery that is easily adaptable as per their life styles._x000D_

The project will be implemented primarily in rural areas, as the needs of the people in the ethnic areas are poorly catered for. Most of the INGOÃ¢â¬â¢s and NGOÃ¢â¬â¢s are working in Yangon and research shows that the people receiving  training  are often the same group, along with people who work for the government. These people already have greater and easier access to a broad range of educational opportunities. The We women foundation will work together with local partner organizations to ensure that the program is embedded in and supported by the local communities.  In addition, they assist We women with the selection of participants for the training as defined in the criteria._x000D_
_x000D_
Research by We women in Burma has confirmed that many women are in need of project management and business skills. Therefore We women has decided to establish the Project and Business Skills Training Program.  The training program aims to assist two different groups of women. _x000D_
_x000D_
1) Women who want to improve their skills so they can set up their own projects _x000D_
2) Women who want to improve their skills in short business-focused training courses  _x000D_
_x000D_
The We women foundation will cater for these two groups of women. The program will have five modules in total:_x000D_
_x000D_
Module 1: Project Design and Development_x000D_
Module 2: Fundraising Training_x000D_
Module 3: Key Business Processes_x000D_
Module 4: Business Planning_x000D_
Module 5: Coaching_x000D_
_x000D_
The modules are designed in a way that they can be followed independently from each other depending on the need. However we recommend that women who _x000D_
belong to the first group will take part in modules one, two and five. While the second group of women would benefit from participating in modules three, four and five. _x000D_
_x000D_
If  the We women foundation is awarded the grant then the first pilot project  in Burma will plement modules three and four of the Project and Business Skills Training Program. The total costs of implementing all five modules would exceed the amount available through Project Inspire. However,  We women did secure other funds for the development of another module and in the meantime we will continue raising additional funds to implement all five modules.   _x000D_
_x000D_
Background_x000D_
Female entrepreneurship represents a vast untapped source of innovation, job creation and economic growth in the developing world.  However, the barriers to womenÃ¢â¬â¢s entrepreneurship remain with women facing greater obstacles in accessing credit, training, networks and information, as well as legal and policy constraints. _x000D_
_x000D_
The promotion of womenÃ¢â¬â¢s entrepreneurship can play a particularly important role in conflict-affected countries.  Although destruction affects all, conflict often leaves women to carry the double burden of economic and family responsibilities. Women who can no longer rely on steady earnings from male household members during times of hardship must often make ends meet by engaging in informal micro-income-generating activities. Giving women a stake in the national reconstruction process by investing in their economic participation, including through entrepreneurship, is crucial for effective and sustainable development of the already-fragile economies of conflict-affected societies.  (Carmen Niethammer, The 2013 Brookings Blum Roundtable Policy Briefs)._x000D_
_x000D_
Implementation_x000D_
With the grant We women will provide business training to groups of women in both Shan and Kachin states.  We women will therefore use the inside knowledge of  We women alumni who had the opportunity to study thanks to the scholarship support provided by We women.  _x000D_
Both in Shan state and in Kachin state participating women will be trained in both modules over 12 weeks (Module 3 - five weeks 8 hours a week and Module 4 - 7 weeks of 8 hours a week). Each week three different groups of 12 participants will be trained.  After finalizing the training course all participants have been trained almost 100 hours in business concepts and business planning. In each module, we will incorporate two spaces for people to follow a Training of Trainers (TOT) course. The trainer of the modules will teach these two participants how to become a trainer in their area of expertise._x000D_

project_details_other:
Generations of Syrian girls are at the verge of being lost due to their displacement. The dire current situation in refugee camps could have a ripple effect on several generations to come if relief efforts are not targeted towards sustainable projects.Through the FITE project we firstly aim to preserve the heritage and culture of the Syrian refugees through acquiring the written form of their native language. Also, by acquiring a skill we hope to provide these women with a perpetual access to employment & means of sustainable income, even in the case of another forced or voluntary displacement.This project also aims to slowly change the pre-established gender norms within this community and shift the balance by positioning women as active member of their society.When women enter the labor market they begin to feel empowered and thus become a different role model to their own children. By empowering young mothers we also aim to empower their families through meaningful life experiences.
Through FITE we aim to fight unemployment amongst the Bar Elias community of Syrian refugees. By empowering the women within the group we help create alternative modes of income for each household and help provide better overall living conditions. Illiteracy is a major hurdle standing in the way of the economic independence of women but also a major barrier to the future of this community. Indeed, the women are a key element in the education of the children, and their inability to be able, for instance, to help their kids with their homework is a true impediment. By offering these women alternatives to their current situation, this program can give hope to the community and could turn the traumatic experience of displacement into a beneficial opportunity, and alleviate injustice through acquiring new skills. And finally this program will also support the Sawa grass-root initiative by implementing programs based on field needs started by young Syrian men and women.
Teaching 100 women Hairdresser Make up artist skills, through a 5 weeks program. At the completion of this program, participating women will be awarded a certificate of competency in the hairdressing and make-up art field. _x000D_
Sawa for Development and Aid is committed to providing 40% of these participants with permanent jobs and income through our network of local partners.  _x000D_
Upon graduation, the top students will be recruited as assistant teachers to the next session of the program. By training the students to becoming themselves trainers, our goal is to create a self-sustaining system where the old students can insure the perpetuity of the program.  _x000D_
The dedicated space to this program will also be made available to the community so they can utilize it and practice their new acquired skill while earning some income. Upon graduation each batch of 20 women is allowed access to work at their own account by working one of the stations in the Sawa Salon when the classes are not in session._x000D_
Kids educational programs serving as a nursery while the women attend the program will include arts and crafts activities, sports activities and educational games.
To verify our success we hope to measure the following KPIs:-Number of women who have acquired business literacy by the end of the program (and thus are able to use their newly acquired skills and integrate in the professional world)_x000D_

-Capacity to make correct basic calculations _x000D_
-Number of jobs created amongst the initial community of women_x000D_
-Income generated through women labor once the program is completed _x000D_
-Number of women who have pursued more education after completing the FITE program_x000D_
-Number of participants by the end of the program_x000D_

project_summary:
The Bar Elias camp is an asylum for over 250,000 Syrian refugees that have fled the ongoing Syrian War. The word camp is an over-stated term for the agglomeration of tents in a country like Lebanon, hosting more than 2 million Syrian refugees, yet banning the establishment of official camps._x000D_
In an effort to bring relief and help integrate the refugees in their new host communities, Sawa for Development and Aid has engaged with the refugees and launched a series of activities for development. The proposed project is a continuation of our work with the women of this community in our women centers in the Bekaa valley._x000D_
_x000D_
Sawa for Development and Aid is a youth initiative, founded as a reaction to the dire gap in fulfilling the needs of Syrian refugees in Lebanon. Our initiative- now registered NGO in Lebanon- believes that humanitarian relief and development is a matter of social justice, and aims to raise the living standards of Syrian refugees particularly, and the families in need from all nationalities more generally, to the basic standards of a dignified life._x000D_
_x000D_
For the past 6 months, Sawa has been operating in the Bekaa in a locally rented building improvised as school and community center, among other locations. _x000D_
Through extensive field research, focus groups and observation we have identified local needs and have been addressing them through our work. So far, we have launched a local school for the Syrian Children as well as educational activities. _x000D_
Once a week, the school hosts psychosocial support group sessions for women, led by a Female Psychiatrist- a Syrian refugee herself. Through these activities we have been meeting with more Syrian families and have been establishing trust and engaging in more meaningful conversations._x000D_
Our ongoing work with the Bar Elias community has helped us identify the next point of intervention that could help bring more support to this community._x000D_
_x000D_
The average family in Bar Elias is of 5 members and the majority of households today are dependent on humanitarian aid. Through our field research we identified obstacles that make access to steady income possible. _x000D_
Firstly, the Bekaa does not have the capacity to provide work opportunities for this great number of refugees. _x000D_
Secondly, when jobs are available they are usually physical labor type tasks that are temporary and rarely provide any financial stability. Additionally, those professions are often reserved to men. _x000D_
Another unforeseen barrier is that, amongst the sample of refugees that is in contact with the Sawa team, the male figure in 1 in every 3 households is suffering from a serious physical injury that prevents him from performing labor work, thus reducing considerably their access to local jobs. Since the men are traditionally providers amongst this society and faced with all barriers, the community of Bar Elias is left with few possibilities. _x000D_
_x000D_
During the psychosocial support sessions that are ongoing at the Sawa for Development and Aid women centers, the females have expressed their desire to become providers of their households as well as independent agents in society. This need is enhanced by the fact that many of these families are now females heading households after losing their husbands to death, kidnapping, or detention. _x000D_
_x000D_
Naturally our next goal became to empower these women to break the taboo around female providers and thus help them empower their own community. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our identified target is a group of around 100 women, divided into two distinct sub-groups: the older women (age group 40-65 years old) and the young mothers (age group 16-39 years old). Although the two categories have different realities given their age they still share the same needs. About 80% of these women lack a basic skill and around 60% are illiterate._x000D_
_x000D_
Our initial mission was to fight illiteracy to provide these women with more options. And thus we started a series of Arabic writing and reading classes. Yet attendance to these sessions kept diminishing until we had to cancel the program for lack of turnout. Our team followed up with the community to understand the reasons behind their lack of motivation and identified 3 major barriers. _x000D_
Firstly, the Arabic written language is very difficult and different from the spoken dialect, making progress very slow and so with no palpable outcome the women felt overwhelmed. _x000D_
Secondly, they didnÃ¢â¬â¢t see any concrete and direct use for learning to write and read Arabic especially that their main motivation is to access additional income; so they just lost their motivation. _x000D_
And finally, they felt too old (especially the older group) to be learning what their children were also learning in parallel._x000D_
_x000D_
Faced with their lack of motivation, we explored alternative ways to address the initial problem. Through several conversations, the women expressed their desire to learn a skill that could unlock job opportunities. We organized a small poll and the majority voted on taking hairdressing and make-up art classes. In fact this specific line of work is in accord with their culture and how women are viewed in their society. _x000D_
And thus by selecting a rather female oriented skill, they were re-assessing their role within their community without antagonizing the societal hierarchy.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Our proposed program aims to build on the motivation of the Women in Syrian refugees camps to achieve economic independence and sustainability, by offering a target fighting of illiteracy through teaching a comprehensive skill._x000D_
_x000D_
This project aims to start a locally based hairdresser and make-up art school and shop. Through the teaching of the straightforward skills needed for this line of work we will also introduce the basics of writing and reading the Arabic language. The illiteracy program will focus on learning the necessary skills that complement the profession of a hairdresser or make-up artist. For instance, the women will learn the basics of mathematics and introductory classes to technical terms and words, thus giving these women the incentive to become literate._x000D_
_x000D_
On the larger scale, by teaching the women a comprehensive skill we also relieve tension with the host community. By changing the status of passive refugees to active members of society we provide the local host with skilled labor as opposed to an economic burden._x000D_
_x000D_
To allow for the full participation of the women, our program will also launch a complementary project targeting the children and offering educational activities, as often women in the camps are the main caretakers for their children and cannot leave them behind._x000D_
_x000D_
As an end note, grassroots organizations like Sawa are leading local development, and are in need of constant support. Rather than being only used by international organization as implementing partners, this is a great opportunity for Sawa to be solving field needs that we very well know, and can solve but lack the resources or funds. Additionally, most of the Sawa team is made up of activists who have fled the war in Syria themselves, and who work in Sawa to support their families back home.
project_details: For the women of this community, this program will attempt to decrease the unemployment rate by introducing new skills and providing new job opportunities and thus new sources of income.It also fights illiteracy through targeted and contextual teaching of the Arabic language, and thus allows for more opportunities through introductory courses and hopefully creates a motivation to keep learning. This program provides psychosocial support to these women by giving them an activity that occupies their time and takes their minds off the negative aspects of refugee life.The children will benefit directly from the complementary educational activities offered in parallel to the womenÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s program as they will enjoy recreational and group activities with their peers.And, indirect benefit we have identified is the projected decreasing of child abuse when women become active. project_summary:
The number one Millennium Development Goal is to eradicate extreme poverty and hunger, this can be done by bringing more women on board and empowering them substantially by given them equal economic opportunities in all sectors of the economy. When women thrive, society always benefits and succeeding generation is given a better start in life.With this in mind, Africa Neighbours Foundation (A. N. F.) as an NGO has observed that most orphans and children from broken homes in Ghana are faced with a lot of challenges. This is as a result of lack of parental care and control, and lack of support from relatives. The collapse of the extended family system in Ghana puts most orphans and children from broken homes in a vulnerable and insecure state, most especially the females. _x000D_
In a quest to provide a lifeline for some of these vulnerable children who find themselves in an unfortunate situation not by their own doing and at the mercy of harsh and peril economic environment, A.N.F. intends to apply the Project Inspire funds to implement a project on Sustainable Development Empowerment (SDE) for women. As the former UN Secretary General Mr. Kofi Anan said in one of his speech, the most sophisticated tool for a rapid development is effective women empowerment. _x000D_
SDE is an economic empowerment project that will economically empower women through employable and industrial skills acquisition. The beneficiaries will be selected female orphans and those from broken homes living in slums. The project will be implemented in the Ashanti and greater Accra regions of Ghana. Th pilot phase will be in Aboabo, a slum community in the Ashanti Region. The other community in the Ashanti region is Ejura. Nima and Bukuom are the communities from the greater Accra region to benefit from the project.  _x000D_
The selected beneficiaries will undergo training on bakery and pastries production, and training on business management. These training will enable them to start a business with as little as $20 and that will lead them to a sustainable income to be able to take care of their basic needs._x000D_
The project will be in 3 phases. Phase one is the bakery and pastries training. Under this phase, beneficiaries will be taken through the process of baking some food items such as cakes, bread, pie and rough-bakes. In addition will be pastries that include chips (plantain, cocoyam) and doughnuts. Phase two is the business management training. Beneficiaries will be equipped with the basic business managerial skills needed to start and run a small scale business. This will include basic accounting, book keeping, savings and investment. The finally phase is the business establishment and development. Under this phase, there will be established production hub at the carious communities where beneficiaries will come with their ingredients to produce cakes, bread, pie, chips, etc at a commercial scale for six months. After that period, beneficiaries will be charged a token fee for maintenance of the production hub. However, after the whole training, each beneficiary or participant will be a given a start-up capital of 20 USD, to enable them buy some ingredients to start production. _x000D_
There is an existing market for the items the beneficiaries would be trained to produce. Bread is consumed in almost all household in Ghana every day. Other items such as pie, cakes, doughnuts and chips are highly patronized in Ghana. They are in high demand during festive seasons and other occasions such as naming ceremony, weddings, etc. ice cream sellers and the large number of hawkers selling chips in traffic and by the road side points to the fact that one stand to easily make profit when venturing into such businesses. Hence a cycle of sustainable income is developed.  _x000D_

project_summary:
The project is going to inspire entrepreneurship in young girls from Kibera, KenyaÃ¢â¬â¢s largest slum and the third largest slum in Africa, who have just completed high school to start their own businesses. _x000D_
It is notable that some of the girls who complete high school do not have the opportunity to further their tertiary level education because of poor performance in high school or due to lack of financial resources. As a  result the girls end up as casual workers who have no regular source of income and others engage in illegal and immoral activities in search of a source of livelihood. To try and prevent such activities, we are going to offer a one year enterprise development program for a group of  15 girls. _x000D_
_x000D_
The target group  will be drawn from Macheo Achievement Program(MAP) that has been running for 3 years in the Community Service Centre in Strathmore University with  students from Kibera. The University established the Community Service Centre (formerly COP) to help achieve its mission  of being of service to society. Through the Community Service Centre, Strathmore has supported various  educational and social projects in different parts of Kenya. The ground preparation will involve the selection of the girls who have attended Macheo. Currently the number is at 12. project_name: Creating sustainable business for orphan and vulnerable girls through sewing and embroidery
project_summary:
Rural Community Network Tanzania (RUCONET) focuses to improve the quality of life of orphan and vulnerable girls (OVG) who work as casual laborers in the white gravel mines in Orkokola ward by 2016. Through sewing and embroidery, RUCONET intends to increase the income of OVG working in white gravel mines to earn money for themselves and help their siblings meet their daily needs. To accomplish this RUCONET will collaborate with other institutions like Vocation Education and Training Authority (VETA).The project will be implemented in Orkokola ward located in the North West of Arusha city, 15 kms from Arusha along Arusha-Namanga trunk road. The communities living in this area are agro-pastoralists in nature. Economic activities in the area include livestock keeping and cultivation of maize.   Due to climate change, agriculture and livestock production has declined and is not entirely life supportive to the communities. The lack of alternative sources of income in the area makes them opt to engage in white gravel mining. _x000D_
Polygamous life style in the community of Orkokola ward, make most women responsible to take care for their families. Their economy is not good enough to support their families a state which force them to engage in white gravel excavation as casual labourers. They carry white gravel from the underground tunnels to the collection points 500m away which is very risky to them. The gravel is used for making building blocks in Arusha city and outskirts. The working environment is not good because they inhale dust and smoke from local lamps used as source of light which affect their respiratory system and eyes. They are paid low wages for a laborious work. Example, they earn TZS 2500/= (less than US$3) per day per 30 bags of gravel. Some parents go with their daughters in order to earn more income to support their families despite the working condition being bad and many of the daughters are still young (less than 18 years old). After completion of primary education most girls cannot attend any other formal training because their parents cannot pay fees for them._x000D_
RUCONET project aims to improve the quality of life of 30 OVGs working as casual laborers in Orkokola ward through training and empowerment to enable them create sustainable businesses to generate income hence help themselves and their siblings. Each trained OVG will be required to train other three OVGs. The project focuses on the following main activities:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Identification of right vulnerable girls for training: villagers together with the village leaders  and religious leaders will participate in suggesting  30 candidates of the girls to be recruited for the project_x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Hiring of 1 training venue:  Training venue will be located within targeted villages in which the whole training on embroidering and sewing will be conducted._x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Purchase sewing and embroidering  machine and other relevant accessories: For smooth training environment the project focuses to buy 30 sewing and 3 embroidery machines in which each trainee will use her own sewing machine during training and one embroidery machine will be used by 10 trainees_x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Training vulnerable girls on sewing and embroidery: Three groups containing 10 trainees each will be formed  and developed ready for training on sewing, embroidery and entrepreneurship skills (marketing, financial management skills including, records keeping and leadership) _x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Provision of machines and accessories: At the end of the training each trainee will be provided with one sewing machine and its accessories. One embroidery machine will be provided to a group of 10 trainees for them to share. The project will also provide 3 months initial capital for each trainee to rent a place for her machine while still finding customers after completing the training._x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Groups follow ups: After the project phase-out RUCONET will collaborate with village leaders to make follow up to the trainees to see if they are applying the knowledge and skills they obtained to generate income and training other OVG on sewing and embroidery._x000D_
_x000D_

project_summary:
The democracy transition in Indonesia appears to have been seen with declining of tolerance value and increasingly discrimination and violent 	against minority. In fact, women have important positions in the process of breaking the chain of violence and conflicts. Peace practice experiences in Aceh, Maluku and Poso show many women have a strong role in peace building when conflicts occur in their communities. In fact, women have important positions in the process of breaking the chain of violence and conflicts. Their activities are generally done so genuinely and spontaneously driven by a deep sense of moral and political ethics to answer the needs of sustaining and preserving life (UNDP, 2004). Given the importance of the role of women in peace, the Security Council agreed to issue UN Resolution 1325 which underlines the importance of the inclusion of women and the gender perspective in peace negotiations, humanitarian planning, peacekeeping operations, post-conflict peacebuilding and development. To support the UNÃ¢â¬â¢s measure, the Ministry of WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s Empowerment and Child protection along with the Coordinating Ministry of PeopleÃ¢â¬â¢s Welfare also initiated the establishment of RAN P4DK (National Action Plan for the Protection and Empowerment of Women and Children in Conflict Management). This effort is in line with Law No. 7 of 2012 on Social Conflict Management fostering the role of women in phases of conflict prevention, conflict termination and post-conflict recovery._x000D_
The role of women participation in peace building will not run well, if the need to sustain and preserve life is not well-supported. In the context of peace building in Indonesia, peace initiatives by grassroots women is mutually related with the fulfillment of economic needs. Women position is very important part as a Ã¢â¬Ëkey of chainÃ¢â¬â¢ for family economy (ILO, 2010). Therefore, in UN Women explained that when women with a stable income, they will be able to take care of their family and be participating in decision making. Peace building problems are solved when women are involved in their communities and society.  Furthermore, womenÃ¢â¬â¢s economic empowerment is crucial due to a significant contribution to peace building as well as regarded as a key component to elevate equality of womenÃ¢â¬â¢s rights. Economic development for women is very important to bring a significant contribution for peace building and become main component to create right-equality for women. (UN Women, 2013)_x000D_
_x000D_
In that context, the Wahid Institute through Microfinance for Ethnic and Religious Harmony attempts to develop a program in order to strengthen womenÃ¢â¬â¢s participation through economic and political empowerment. We believe that, without affirmative action for women in the economic matters, the strategic position of women in promoting peace would be very difficult. This program is designed to integrate Development and Peace building aspect, which are both of them are inter-related in objective and intervention strategy. Economic empowerment intervention is expected to be a social cohesion between diverse communities both to reduce poverty and social gap that usually be the root cause of conflict in that area. At the same time, women empowerment intervention with different ethnic and religious backgrounds is designed to encourage women participation in decision making and fostering peace in local level. _x000D_
_x000D_

_x000D_
To achieve that impact and social change,   The WAHID Institute plans to use three intervention strategy such as:_x000D_
_x000D_
a) Capacity Building for Interfaith Women Community on Critical Education and Women Social Microenterprise. _x000D_

The intentions behind this are:  1) to enable women to connect and support one another, developing a community amongst themselves while sharing the responsibility of child care; 2) create an environment that empowers women by freeing up a motherÃ¢â¬â¢s time to pursue other ventures and; 3) provide new opportunities for mothers through training and enable the potential to open more day cares. _x000D_

They spend anywhere from 2 to 14 years here, waiting for a chance for their family to re-settle to another country and eventually become citizens there. project_summary:
A report published by the International Center for Research on Women (ICRW) in 2011 assesses the progress made since 2008 regarding the situation of women in the English-speaking Melanesian countries of Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu.  Although the conclusions demonstrate an improvement of womenÃ¢â¬â¢s condition between 2008 and 2011, the situation is still concerning and deserves attention from the diverse civil society groups around Oceania. Moreover, due to the political identity of the French-speaking countries of the South Pacific such as New Caledonia, Wallis and Futuna or French Polynesia, this report does not address womenÃ¢â¬â¢s issues in these peculiar territories, which is an important weakness. _x000D_
The Centre pour le Destin Commun or Centre for a Common Destiny (CDC) is a New Caledonian impartial think tank which aims at finding consensual solutions to local public policy issues faced during the current uncertain period. Our team is, at the moment, composed by three administrators and fours editors, all working voluntarily.  Amongst the numerous social issues we witness in New Caledonia, womenÃ¢â¬â¢s condition is a major one. That is why we have decided to dedicate our efforts towards the goal of improving the current situation._x000D_
_x000D_
Our project to federate womenÃ¢â¬â¢s associations and grassroots groups around Melanesia and the South Pacific region is based on four central current concerns:_x000D_
_x000D_
- WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s conditions in the region are one of the worse worldwide_x000D_
_x000D_
- WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s associations lack visibility and Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) as well as basic technological means to share their work and get fundings in this time of technological revolution_x000D_
_x000D_
- WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s associations around this peculiar region do not share their projects and strategies due to the lack of a gathering platform and the language differences_x000D_
_x000D_
- WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s empowerment around the South Pacific region is very geographically centered and deserves to be open to its regional environment._x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
Therefore, to respond to these four observations, our project is based on three principal steps:_x000D_
_x000D_
First, the administration of the CDC will create the internet website required to publish and share womenÃ¢â¬â¢s associationsÃ¢â¬â¢ work, programs, projects and strategies. Because the three administrators and three editors are bilinguals, weÃ¢â¬â¢ll be able to communicate with the English speaking NGOsÃ¢â¬â¢ teams, translate their publications into French and vice versa. Moreover, we will employ local translators to translate the requests of locals in their own vernacular languages, when required. Concretely, we will first start with the constitution of the team dedicated to gender issues that will have the responsibility to manage the website. This team will, then, get in contact with the local, New-Caledonian womenÃ¢â¬â¢s group and will have the mission to research gender issues. Part of the budget will be devoted to the remuneration of this team (three people paid USD$1200 /month) , memberships to New Caledonian libraries (University of New Caledonia USD$114/year, Library Bernheim USD$45/year, Cultural centre J.M Tjibaou USD$45/year), vehicles renting (USD$17/day) and accommodation (USD$114/day) when required to meet the NGOs of the North or in the Loyalty Islands. _x000D_
_x000D_
Second, the CDC team committed to this platform will have the mission to meet with womenÃ¢â¬â¢s groups in Vanuatu, Fiji, Solomon Islands, Papua New Guinea (PNG), West Papua (if permitted) Wallis and Futuna and French Polynesia. An important part of the grant will be dedicated to the payment of plane tickets (Returns to Vanuatu: USD$500; Fiji: USD$1100; PNG: USD$3500; Solomon Islands: 1900USD$; Wallis and Futuna: USD$2000; French Polynesia: USD$3200), accommodation and car renting (USD$150/day) in these several countries. _x000D_

Third, by offering those associations and groups a way to easily share their work through the website, we will also assist them in proposing their projects on platforms such as globalgiving.org, kickstarter.com, etc. to crowd-fund their projects.

In three years SNF will give paid vocational training to 420 women of the Perna community and offer employment to a minimum of 315 women in Dharampura  and  Prem Nagar. By economically strengthening these women it will spur local economic growth (because the women will have their own money to spend instead of having to ask their husbands. By the middle of 2015 SNF will start researching new regions outside of Delhi/NCR area.  Our mission is to open local production centers so we can economically empower SC communities  forced into intergenerational prostitution thorough out Northern India starting with the Rajnat, Kanjars, Sansis, Bedia, and Nat communities.  The long term impact is that these communities will have the choice to leave prostitution and no longer have to force their girls into early marriage breaking the vicious cycle they are stuck in now. 
During this grant cycle the 50 women and girls that we train, will be financially compensated which will impact the lives of their families as well. Through our training we are building their capacity to bring about economic change for themselves, even if they don't continue to become hired employees of SNF through skill training. Those 50 women will gain confidence from learning new skills. They learn interpersonal skills such as how to work in a team which can help with future employment. We help them open bank accounts and learn how to save the money they earn during this period. 
Impact is not just improving their financial situation but if the women and girls feel empowered enough to have the choice to leave or deter prostitution and are no longer forced into prostitution by their families or into early marriages. Delaying marriage is extremely difficult in this community but we have already seen girls (such as Momal who is 18 and unmarried still) been bold leaders and be able to say, 'No' to their families through the help and support of other girls in the community. This project will be a success when we see them truly having the ability to choice an alternative life for themselves (and it's sustainable through local ownership). 
We use different monitoring and evaluation tools to measure our success. A questionnaire will be administered at training enrollment and a month after program commencement.  The surveys are to be administered by the program staff, after a consent from is signed by the participants and their parents. It is a short survey with 12 questions, and their names will be attached. It is important that the girls are assured that it will not affect their enrollment. The questions are a mix about skill development, financial tools, and empowerment to measure how much they have learned throughout training.  At the end of  three months, a small informal focus group will be held for monitoring purposes, asking the participants how the project is working for them, and how their home situation is faring. The findings from this will be directly fed back into the programÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s operations. Routine data will be collected throughout the project on every girl who enrolls and when they leave, on our database. This is standard enrollment data and does not require a consent form to be signed. _x000D_
Each training session functions as a small group. They pick a name. The last batch was named 'Khushi' (Hindi for happiness). At the beginning of the week we do a 'partner system'. We found that by having a system of small group accountability helps motivate the women while learning new skills ( frustrating for women who have never worked before) and to feel empowered to deter or leave prostitution. _x000D_

project_name: Economically Empowering Women in Forced Prostitution in New Delhi, India
project_summary: Sewing New Futures functions as both a for-profit business as well as a non-profit trust. It was founded in Spring 2014 after two years of building relationships with the Perna women, a schedule caste practicing intergenerational prostitution in New Delhi, India.  This $25,000 grant will go to funding the Indian Trust for six months of full activities in our center in Najafgarh New Delhi starting January 2015.  The activities will include two three-month paid vocational sewing training classes.  During the training we provide technical skills to women to encourage creative design and quality of the products we make (scarves, wall hanging and pillow cases). We offer non-formal education  for girls who have dropped out (average drop out is 5th class), open school enrollment for their children and have a day care for young children/babies. We work with on personal development skills such financial planning, leadership, stress management, and health, (along with regular medical check-ups  as they are scared to go to doctors on their own from fear of caste stigma) workshops on legal rights training to help women have the choice (along with financial freedom) to choice a life free from prostitution. After training The SNF Pvt. Ltd. offers employment to women and teenage girls who have completed the training program. The products they make are then marketed through the Pvt. Ltd. The profits go back into the Trust to expand the business, train and reach more women. We currently have 10 women employed in the Pvt. Ltd and a training class of 10 women in process. This grant will help us directly impact this community to have a choice at a different livelihood and get us to the next level in our business.
project_details: Sewing New Futures works currently in Najafgarh, which is on the Delhi -Haryana border, in the NCR region, southwest district of New Delhi, where three settlements ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢â¬Å Prem Nagar, Dharampura, and Uttam Nagar house over 600 families (2,000+ women) of the Perna community listed as Scheduled Castes (SC). They have been unable to gain traditional employment in order to survive prostitution in the community is passed from mother-in-law to daughter-in-law. Girls are groomed from the time they are born to be put into prostitution as soon as they are married, which on average fourteen years old. This leaves the children and adolescent girls we work with as the most vulnerable group in this community as they are forced into marriage by the time they reach puberty; prostitution is presented as the only source of livelihoods to support themselves and their families.  The population at risk to this exploitation throughout Delhi and Haryana is 10,000+.

project_name: Creating sustainable business for orphan and vulnerable girls through sewing and embroidery
project_summary:
Rural Community Network Tanzania (RUCONET) focuses to improve the quality of life of orphan and vulnerable girls (OVG) who work as casual laborers in the white gravel mines in Orkokola ward by 2016. Through sewing and embroidery, RUCONET intends to increase the income of OVG working in white gravel mines to earn money for themselves and help their siblings meet their daily needs. To accomplish this RUCONET will collaborate with other institutions like Vocation Education and Training Authority (VETA).The project will be implemented in Orkokola ward located in the North West of Arusha city, 15 kms from Arusha along Arusha-Namanga trunk road. The communities living in this area are agro-pastoralists in nature. Economic activities in the area include livestock keeping and cultivation of maize.   Due to climate change, agriculture and livestock production has declined and is not entirely life supportive to the communities. The lack of alternative sources of income in the area makes them opt to engage in white gravel mining. _x000D_
Polygamous life style in the community of Orkokola ward, make most women responsible to take care for their families. Their economy is not good enough to support their families a state which force them to engage in white gravel excavation as casual labourers. They carry white gravel from the underground tunnels to the collection points 500m away which is very risky to them. The gravel is used for making building blocks in Arusha city and outskirts. The working environment is not good because they inhale dust and smoke from local lamps used as source of light which affect their respiratory system and eyes. They are paid low wages for a laborious work. Example, they earn TZS 2500/= (less than US$3) per day per 30 bags of gravel. Some parents go with their daughters in order to earn more income to support their families despite the working condition being bad and many of the daughters are still young (less than 18 years old). After completion of primary education most girls cannot attend any other formal training because their parents cannot pay fees for them._x000D_
RUCONET project aims to improve the quality of life of 30 OVGs working as casual laborers in Orkokola ward through training and empowerment to enable them create sustainable businesses to generate income hence help themselves and their siblings. Each trained OVG will be required to train other three OVGs. The project focuses on the following main activities:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Identification of right vulnerable girls for training: villagers together with the village leaders  and religious leaders will participate in suggesting  30 candidates of the girls to be recruited for the project_x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Hiring of 1 training venue:  Training venue will be located within targeted villages in which the whole training on embroidering and sewing will be conducted._x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Purchase sewing and embroidering  machine and other relevant accessories: For smooth training environment the project focuses to buy 30 sewing and 3 embroidery machines in which each trainee will use her own sewing machine during training and one embroidery machine will be used by 10 trainees_x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Training vulnerable girls on sewing and embroidery: Three groups containing 10 trainees each will be formed  and developed ready for training on sewing, embroidery and entrepreneurship skills (marketing, financial management skills including, records keeping and leadership) _x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Provision of machines and accessories: At the end of the training each trainee will be provided with one sewing machine and its accessories. One embroidery machine will be provided to a group of 10 trainees for them to share. In the long term we will develop a new generation of African female business leaders with a vision of building pan-African companies and the resources to employ thousands of Africans. We will accomplish this by building a trusted community of entrepreneurs, investors and professionals who are working together to increase the number of successful female entrepreneurs at every level - small, medium and large enterprises. As women invest a larger percentage of their earnings back into the family unit, especially education and health, we hope that by helping more women become financially successful we will be creating better educated, healthier children who can go on to be more productive, more prosperous citizens.
In the short term we will significantly increase the ability for female entrepreneurs to access funding through our pitch competition for early stage startups and community building events. Through our pitch competition we will directly provide funding for 3 female entrepreneurs, introduce the top 10 finalists to venture capitalists, and broadcast the best practices and tips gleaned from the experts to not only the 200 entrepreneurs in the audience but our social media and live streaming communities as well. Additionally we will connect 5,000 female entrepreneurs to top quality mentors and highlighting their ventures to financiers looking to invest in growing markets. Finally, we will host community building events in major cities in West Africa and in the US to bring together the founders, investors, and innovators committed to changing Africa. 
In Year 1 after our official launch we plan to achieve:(assumes a formal launch date of September 27th which is when our pitch contest holds. Thus 2015 will be our first full year)_x000D_
+ 10 top tier female entrepreneurs receive mentorship and training from best in class entrepreneurs/ professionals and provide 3 with direct funding to their businesses_x000D_
+ 7500 female entrepreneurs subscribed to our website. Over the next 3 years we plan to triple that number through an aggressive marketing campaign and by utilizing offline engagement_x000D_
+ Host community building events in Lagos, Abuja, Accra, New York, and Boston. In Year 2 we plan to expand to Dakar, Abidjan, Paris, Nairobi, and Johannesburg. In year 3 we plan to expand to Port Harcourt, Calabar, Houston, and Atlanta._x000D_
+ 150 mentors signed up for our weekly office hours_x000D_

project_summary:
She Leads Africa will use the $25,000 prize to further invest in the first pitch competition in Africa solely for female entrepreneurs, develop a web platform that will connect innovators from across the continent to share ideas, and host interactive community building sessions in major African cities. We believe that an investment of $25,000 today will yield multiple returns in the form of independent leaders developed, new businesses launched, employees hired, self-sufficient communities, and a more prosperous Africa._x000D_
Female entrepreneurs in Africa face 4 key barriers to full participation in AfricaÃ¢â¬â¢s growth story: unequal access to education, constraining cultural stereotypes, limited opportunities to develop useful networks and limited access to financing. She Leads Africa aims to be a one-stop shop support system for female entrepreneurs, enabling them to gain access to the knowledge, networks and financing required to build and scale strong businesses.  Though we are based in Lagos, Nigeria, our company has a pan African mission and a key component of our business model is forging intra-African networks of entrepreneurs. Our initial focus will be West Africa after which we will rapidly expand to East, South and North Africa._x000D_
_x000D_
Our first initiative will be an annual pitch contest exclusively for female entrepreneurs on the continent. Our process includes narrowing down our initial pool of applicants to a list of 10 finalists. These 10 finalists will then be matched with young professionals from the finance, VC and consulting industries to help them refine their business plans and work on their pitches. On pitch day the contestants will be invited to pitch their ideas in front of a panel of notable business personalities who will select a winning pitch. However, we will also invite representatives from a number of leading investment firms to be members of the audience, giving our entrepreneurs even greater visibility to potential investors. Our panel will include Bola Adesola (CEO of Standard Chartered Nigeria), Ngozi Edozien (Former director of Actis West Africa), Hakeem Belo-Osagie (Chairman of Etisalat Nigeria) and Tokunboh Ishmael (Managing Director of Alitheia Capital and a 2013 Yale World Fellow). The winner of this contest will not only receive a cash prize of $10 000 but will also receive a series of non-financial prizes including a free business phone and data line for one year, a free smart phone, meetings with legal advisors from one of the continentÃ¢â¬â¢s top law firms and free SME accounting software.  _x000D_
_x000D_
However our broader ambition is to create the content, community and events to support aspiring female entrepreneurs.  In addition to our annual pitch contest we will have 3 other flagship initiatives: _x000D_
Online platform: Our platform will allow entrepreneurs to share their stories and successes and to connect with investors and fellow entrepreneurs from across the continent. It will also include tips and tricks as well as guidance and expert advice from new and experienced entrepreneurs. _x000D_
_x000D_
Networking Events:  We will host networking events in key cities for investors, entrepreneurs and other young professionals. We will identify local volunteers in each city to coordinate organisation of networking events and where possible we aim to work with corporate sponsors (especially banks and telecommunication firms which often have SME specific products) to minimise costs _x000D_
