project_summary:
Microfy is developing a model of sustainable economic growth for refugee communities living in urban environments by targeting women and including local populations to share in the investment and growth, thereby reducing conflict between these communities.  Most refugees in Israel today, and more than half worldwide, live and work in urban environments where employment opportunities are limited, and their presence often brings them into conflict with local populations as resources are stretched thin. In Israel, where there are currently around 50,000 African asylum seekers living without clear legal status, the concentration of most asylum seekers in the poor neighborhoods of South Tel Aviv has resulted in high levels of tension, occasionally breaking out into violence against one group or the other. Women are frequently the victims of this violence, as rape is used as a tool of dominance. Furthermore, the perceived competition between these two groups has resulted in increasingly draconian policies towards asylum seekers, most recently imprisonment, withdrawal of visas, refusal to process asylum claims and pressure to return to home countries._x000D_
A significant part of this tension is the result of conflict over resources. Where once Israeli society was welcoming of refugees, excess pressure on South Tel Aviv due to policies that discriminate against asylum seekers in employment, has sparked racism and conflict. Women on both sides suffer from this reality. Microfy believes that investment in the economic development of this area, most particularly through empowerment of women, as the most vulnerable and the most likely to invest in their families, will reduce tensions and increase the average income across demographics._x000D_
_x000D_
Microfy is raising money to improve business literacy and access to credit for low-income Israeli women and African refugees and asylum seekers.  We seek to stimulate the economic, social, and cultural health of South Tel Aviv, an urban area riddled by poverty but teeming with potential, by creating channels to credit and business education.   These two low-income and vulnerable demographics have historically been neglected by the Israeli governmentÃ¢â¬â¢s development goals   Any funds that Microfy raises will go directly towards improving the quality of program delivery to women interested in business education, seeking to start their own businesses, and business owners already relying on the consultancy and support services offered by Microfy. More specifically, this means recruiting highly qualified professionals to serve as educators and consultants, expanding educational services to include more new entrepreneurs, and improving sustainability for current business owners.  _x000D_
_x000D_
But Microfy sees what itÃ¢â¬â¢s doing as much more than just creating more channels for business literacy and opportunity to vulnerable demographics living in low-income neighborhoods. MicrofyÃ¢â¬â¢s two target groups, asylum seekers and Israelis, face different challenges. Yet as women, and as women living in the marginalized urban area of South Tel Aviv, they also share many obstacles that prevent them from realizing their entrepreneurial potential and achieving economic independence.  Microfy thus creates opportunities to not rely on informal markets or subjection to unfair working conditions. Economic independence, is a powerful tool toward empowerment and control over oneÃ¢â¬â¢s life. Women with an independent source of income earn more, are able to support their families better, and take a larger role in decision making in their families. Small businesses, which can be operated out of the home or in stores close by, provide an opportunity for women to earn money while meeting childcare and other demands. They provide flexibility, and an escape from workplaces where their rights are abused. For many, the idea of opening their own business is important beyond the financial rewards; it is an opportunity to exert a measure of control over their lives, and restore some of the dignity that was attacked in their uprooting.  Strengthening womenÃ¢â¬â¢s knowledge and confidence to seek income-generating opportunities while recognizing the importance of cultural norms as well has the potential to benefit their families and the community at large.   Microfy recognizes that intercultural tensions and grievances against refugees are often caused by local feelings of disenfranchisement. _x000D_
_x000D_
MicrofyÃ¢â¬â¢s mission is to support refugees and marginalized women in host communities not only to challenge traditional roles that restrict women and reinforce gender inequality, but also to alleviate the tension created between the host and asylum seeking populations by the perceived threat of their presence among a predominantly Jewish and Israeli demographic.

project_summary:
Our Freedom Project aims to educate urban slum women in India about menstruation and provide them with access to products that allow them to manage their periods safely and with dignity. The Inspire Award will provide the resources that the Freedom Project needs to achieve its goal of empowering urban slum women in India to lead fuller and more confident lives, and push against the grain of cultural gender oppression. _x000D_
The Freedom Project will create a network of local female micro-entrepreneurs that provide urban slum women with education about and access to menstrual products. These products provide freedom from the negative stigma and oppressive cultural myths associated with periods, as well as freedom from the discomfort of menstrual management methods currently used by urban slum women.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Periods, and women who have their period, are often seen to be dirty and unclean, which negatively affects their dignity and self-esteem from a young age. Women are prevented from going to school or work or contributing to community life while menstruating. This discrimination is perpetrated by uncomfortable, unclean and dangerous methods of menstrual protection such as old cloths, newspaper or even sand. Women suffer from constant infections, boils and skin irritation, as well as reproductive diseases. The Freedom Project will introduce menstrual cups to urban slum women as an option that is more comfortable, more hygienic, provides longer lasting protection, is less likely to leak, is cheaper over the long run and is environmentally friendly. _x000D_
_x000D_
The Freedom Project will be implemented by Pollinate Energy, a not-for-profit social enterprise that has been operating in India since 2012. Pollinate Energy has an existing network of over 500 slum communities in Bangalore, into which it sells life-improving sustainable products such as solar lights. It does this by recruiting and training local micro-entrepreneurs, or Ã¢â¬ÅPollinatorsÃ¢â¬Â, who are employed full-time to provide door-to-door service to urban slums. Pollinate Energy also uses Ã¢â¬ÅWorker BeesÃ¢â¬Â, urban slum residents who are recruited to help Pollinators to make sales and receive a commission for doing so. In the last 18 months, Pollinate Energy has sold over 5,000 solar lights to urban slum communities, positively impacting over 23,000 people. _x000D_
_x000D_
The Inspire Award will fund the Freedom ProjectÃ¢â¬â¢s year-long pilot program to introduce menstrual cups as a new product to the Pollinate Energy range, accompanied by education sessions on menstruation. If successful, the project will be rolled out across a plethora of Indian cities. The pilot program will involve:_x000D_
- undertaking preliminary market research to understand gaps in knowledge about female menstruation within urban slum communities and current menstruation management methods,_x000D_
- engage a local project manager to coordinate the Pollinators, Worker Bees and administer the project  _x000D_
- engage a menstrual cup expert and a womenÃ¢â¬â¢s health consultant to deliver comprehensive training to the Pollinators, Worker Bees, community health providers and local staff in women's health and menstrual cup use?_x000D_
- expanding the delivery of education/awareness sessions as well as the effectiveness of supporting materials, including a video and take home information in the local language,_x000D_
- increasing the number of communities we engage with to reach more women,_x000D_
- delivering menstrual cup training to local health care workers who will provide support to women in urban communities,_x000D_
- implementing digital systems for Pollinators to keep track of sales and customers,_x000D_
- purchasing stock of menstrual cups,_x000D_
- undertaking rigorous trials in slum communities,_x000D_
- undertaking ongoing monitoring and evaluation of the project to track progress and update/improve systems where needed. _x000D_
_x000D_
We understand that this is a complex issue. The Freedom Project is dedicated to delivering comprehensive, useful education about the female reproductive system and full range of menstrual management options to women in slum communities. We will educate women on physiology, phases of the monthly cycle and how to deal with family members who might question the use of menstrual management products. project_summary:
Sukhibhava is a not for profit social enterprise based in Bangalore, India. Sukhibhava aims to tackle contributing factors to gender inequality through provision of products and education that enable and empower women through local female micro-entrepreneurs. Menstrual hygiene management is one of those factors and it is unfairly felt by the under privileged and urban poor. Sukhibhava will hold education sessions and sell menstrual hygiene products to urban poor women who previously did not have access due to economic or awareness factors.  A micro distribution business model has been developed where local entrepreneurial women will distribute and sell products. Working with local women will enable Sukhibhava to build on the trust that these women have already cultivated with their local communities to educate about and distribute menstrual hygiene products like sanitary pads and menstrual cups.  Sukhibhava operates on the premise of full life cycle products. This refers to both to concern for the environmental impact of the product as well as aiming to take the journey towards the adoption of new products and services with the customers it deals with. Which happens on a phase to phase basis starting from education and awareness, to introducing and ensuring 100% utilization of the products, to monthly follows ups ensuring consistent usage to safe disposals of the used products._x000D_
Preliminary Research:_x000D_
A survey of 250 women & girls from government schools, urban slum communities and garment factories within the urban limits of Bangalore has provided valuable information as a starting point. _x000D_
The survey found that among the sample of 250 women:_x000D_
-	78% used uncomfortable, unhygienic or inappropriate methods for menstruation management (including 6.5% who did not want to answer)_x000D_
-	The reasons cited as the main barriers to usage are :_x000D_
1) Affordability: The 89.3% women felt they have better priorities to spend their money on, like milk and education for their children or groceries for the family._x000D_
2) Aspiration: The 84.5% of the women expressed that they these products are not meant or made for them but for the higher section of the society._x000D_
3) Disposal: Most of the urban poor women do not have proper shelters to live in and hence they expressed a strong opinion of not being comfortable in disposing them around where they live._x000D_
4) Accessibility: 76.5% of the women did not have the awareness or the knowledge to go to a local shop and buy the sanitary pads. They were as uncomfortable as a teenage kid going to a pharmacy and buying contraceptives._x000D_
-	86% of women surveyed would be happy to pay for them if provided at an affordable price. Specifically, women surveyed were overwhelmingly willing to pay between Rs. 15 Ã¢â¬â 25 per packet, with 56.9% willing to pay between Rs. 20 and 25 while they expecting good quality sanitary pads._x000D_
The survey also found that at least eight women were willing to try the menstrual cup as an alternative method of menstrual hygiene management. This allows enough women to conduct a small initial trial with this product._x000D_
_x000D_
The information from the survey conducted, helped us build a robust education and distribution model which has the capacity for the maximum outreach while educating and improving the quality of lives of the hundreds of thousands of urban poor women without proper menstrual hygiene in cities like Bangalore._x000D_
Considering the cited barriers, a model has been developed where local entrepreneurial women(Sakhi) reach out to these urban poor women who have problems with accessibility while creating awareness about the availability of affordable menstrual hygiene products and also educating them about safe disposal of used products through the disposal cycle built by Sukhibhava._x000D_
 _x000D_
Products we sell:_x000D_
Sanitary Pads _x000D_
Initially sanitary pads will be the main focus of the implementation. Sukhibhava have partnered with Bella a multinational sanitary products brand in India. A distribution agreement has been made with Bella, to supply packs of 8 pads at a cost of Rs. 16.85 which will be sold at Rs.25 per pack which is lower than the market price. The commercial price of the same quality sanitary pads is Rs.45 , Bella provides it at a subsidized price considering Sukhibhava is a social enterprise. At the end of six months, when a strong distribution model has been built with expected number of consumers, Sukhibhava aims to manufacture its own sanitary pads on a self help group model._x000D_
Menstrual Cup _x000D_
Simultaneously the program will trial menstrual cups. Menstrual cups are just starting to gain attention around the world. They are made from medical-grade silicon, and are reusable for up to 10 years meaning a huge reduction in waste. This is especially relevant for open waste piles in the slums. The cup is inserted into the vagina and collects menstrual fluid in a non-leaking container. The container can then be emptied, washed and re-inserted. The holding capacity is much larger than tampons or pads and only needs to be changed once every 12 hours. The cup is not felt once it is inside and which is much more comfortable than pads or alternative items traditionally used. The cup is upfront more expensive, but is cheaper in the long run. Current estimates place the price at Rs. 625 wholesale, which is less than 1 weeks wage for people in the urban slums. The cup would be offered on a micro-finance plan which will be developed as part of the trial. _x000D_
_x000D_
Model of Operation:_x000D_
Sukhibhava works as an on-the-ground distributor. For each new location either school, factory or  a urban slum communitySukhibhava staff or trained partners begin a two week induction process and then a trial period of two months with follow ups. The first week is an awareness session, the second is an education and sales session. Follow ups are conducted fortnightly over the trial period in which more women can join at any time. After the two month evaluation is complete the new location will be visited on a regular fortnightly basis for sales and queries. After 6 months in each location, another feedback and question session will be held to monitor and evaluate the impact of new products. _x000D_
Phase One: Awareness_x000D_
Sukhibhava research has shown that potential customers may take up to 2 sessions of information building before they are comfortable enough to proceed with a purchase. The program will begin with a awareness session, education women about menstrual hygiene and the necessity through a 20 minute video, will be culturally appropriate, sensitive and in a safe environment for women to talk and discuss. Sukhibhava will partner with local womenÃ¢â¬â¢s and community organizations to organize and advertise the sessions. Relationships with these organizations have already been established.  Products will be available for sale after the session but will not focused on selling._x000D_
Phase Two: Education and Sales _x000D_
In the second week of community engagement another information session will be held making the products available for purchase. At this point feedback will be sought from women who attended the first session, but have not followed through on education and purchasing. The education and sales sessions will be delivered by our distribution staff and partners, and a fortnightly presence in the camps will continue so that women are able to ask questions or give feedback. Our research showed the women did not buy pads in advance so regular contact is best. Education is developed in collaboration with local women, health professionals and suppliers. It will include information on how to communicate with husbands, families or communities about the issue._x000D_
Phase Three: Disposal _x000D_
The used sanitary pads are collected back from the women on a regular basis. Central collection points like bins will be installed in each of the communities, will be maintained discreetly and by which waste can be collected and stored. Specific arrangements with the manufacturer are in the process of being worked out. Menstrual cups last for up to 10 years, disposal at that point will be discussed, and however more focus will be placed on hygienic disposal of the menstrual fluid. _x000D_
_x000D_
The business model of Sukhibhava demands 16 female micro-entrepreneurs(Sakhis) across four divisions of Bangalore( North, south, east and west) to sell 2000 packets of sanitary pads to urban poor women through different institutions and partners. Each Sakhi is given three months of probation to reach the target of 2000 with the ongoing support of the operational staff. Sakhi plays an active role in retention of consumers month after of month, which in return helps her reduce work of finding new consumers every month._x000D_
_x000D_
The Project Inspire grant of USD$25000 will be utilized to set up four manufacturing units in four divisions of Bangalore enabling supply of self made bio-degradable sanitary pads to Sakhis who have already developed a distribution channel and have built a consumer base for themselves._x000D_
This is help us create more employment opportunities for women, while providing locally manufactured bio-degradable sanitary pads with increased incentives to the micro-entrepreneurs and increasing the sustainability ratios of Sukhibhava._x000D_

ORGANISATION BACKGROUND_x000D_
Umodzi Organization for Social Enhancement (UOSE) was registered under the Trustees Act 1962 chap 5:03 of the laws of the Republic of Malawi on 23rd August, 2013.  The women led Community Based Organisation (CBO) is also registered with the Blantyre City and Blantyre District Assembly. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY_x000D_
_x000D_
Mbayani and Chemusa has a population of over 60 000 people whose social economic status is based on basket businesses and low paid jobs in Blantyre. Some of the people rely upon farming within the small shared premises of leased lands._x000D_
The main tribes of the inhabitants of the area are the Yao and the MangÃ¢â¬â¢anja who constitute over 60% of the given population. The area has different religions which include Christians, Muslims, and Local Spiritual Beliefs including Dances which makes a dynamic impact in the behavioral change of the community members. Some beliefs of these groups e.g. polygamy and cultural values like belief in traditional medicines that they are stronger in treating the sexually transmitted infections than the scientific medicines, kuchosa fumbi (sex trial after circumcision) contribute to the spread of HIV.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Despite the Malawi Government playing a major role in improving educational standards, livelihoods and infrastructure in the country, still a lot require attention as far as the women and girls empowerment, adult literacy, business and livelihood skills is concerned. _x000D_
_x000D_
The population of area is retrogressing in terms of social and economic development as they cannot effectively contribute to some developmental programmes intended for the area due to high illiteracy rate and lack of business and livelihood skills. _x000D_
_x000D_
Adult literacy rate among females of ages 15 and older is at 54.0%, and combined gross enrolment ration for primary, secondary and tertiary school is 64% (UN Human Index Trends on MDGs 3-2004). 51% of female population in the proposed project area do not know how to read and write. The national average literacy rate among persons of 15 years of age and above is currently estimated at 60 percent (74.9 % men and 54.0% women) (National Statistics Office, 2002: 46). However, it is conventionally observed that illiteracy leads to social economic underdevelopment, as much of the public social services such as health facilities are literacy demanding for one to understand medical prescriptions. This has also precipitated the contraction and transmission of HIV/AIDS among the illiterate groups._x000D_

It is from this background that The Umodzi Women Group composed of a good number of highly qualified (skilled) members and some non- skilled members with different expertise submit this Concept for funding aiming at empowering the School Drop-out Girls and under privileged women with necessary skills to enhance their capacities on business and livelihood skills in order to uplift their standards of living by 2017._x000D_

project_name: Help Schoolchildren (ages 6-18) in the rural areas of the Arusha Region, in Northern Tanzania.
project_summary: Girls in some parts of Tanzania lack the essential materials needed to have a education that will form the basis of a life free from poverty and exploitation. To that end, these funds will be used on our first project, which is to help Schoolchildren (ages 6-18) in the rural areas of the Arusha Region, in Northern Tanzania. We have already located a number of underprivileged schools and school children in the remote areas of Arusha who are in dire need of assistance.  We will use these funds to begin three discreet programs that address the lack of an adequate education. The major obstacle with getting a good education in this region is a lack of supplies. We plan to use the funds to distribute pencils, pens and small note books to the children in these schools. We plan to work with these schools to get the children more involved such as by writing essays, which will be collected and mailed to our offices, were a team of our staff(who mostly are University graduate volunteers) will read them and select the winner, for a small award. This is to provide small children with a lesson that academic success can have tangible benefits, and give them a glipse of the benefits that an education can have later in life.   Our second goal is to strengthen the problem solving skills of these girls. We plan to use a small portion of the funds to purchase Chess board games and encourage children to play. There are numerous non profits that try to use chess in American class rooms. We wish to expand it to Tanzania. As Benjamin Franklin noted, and other, more recent scholars have agreed with, Chess can be used to stimulate problem solving and strategic thinking. This skills are vital to a poverty free life, and can also assist girls achieve academic success. We will also use the funds to distribute soccer/football balls to schools interested in establishing football clubs. This is to provide girls structure outside of the classroom, and provide them an alternative to returning to unhealthy and unproductive situations back at home.
project_details: Lowering the number of underprivileged children who fail to finish primary school. We do this by lowering the number of children having nothing to do after school, helping to reduce the number of students in the rural areas who can not read or write, lowering the burden on the parents who cant afford to provide their children with basic school needs, and provide children with a fun method to hone their problem solving skills.

By providing access to alternative financial safety nets and education through micro-business opportunities and informal education, the project aims to provide a sustainable platform of support for rural womenfolk, while simultaneously breaking the violence cycle. project_details:
Within the Hmong community in Khek Noi, lack of women's empowerment is the root cause of two deeply seeded sociocultural problems.1. Domestic violence: 40% of Hmong womenfolk have been physically emotionally or sexually abused by their spouses._x000D_
Domestic violence exists as a norm within the Hmong community. Wife and child battering can take extreme forms in some cases, causing injury to women._x000D_
2. Lack of political participation & leadership of women: Within the local governance structure of the village, female representation in political positions of power is lacking. At the lineage and clan level, leaders are mostly men. Women in leadership remain frowned upon._x000D_
3. Extreme poverty especially among women: Hundreds of households live on an income of less than 6 USD / day_x000D_
Poverty perpetuates a vicious cycle, ensnaring Hmong women and girls. Poverty makes acquiring education difficult. Without sufficient education, Hmong women remain without adequate skills to make a living.

project_summary:
With $25,000, Sargy Community Development Center (Sargy) plans to create 20 gardens to provide 20 widows with a garden by their house, a sense of ownership, and a chance to improve their lives.  This project takes place on Rusinga Island, a small island in Kenya.  It is surrounded by Lake Victoria, and it is linked to Mbita point on the mainland by a causeway.  A recent government statistic indicates that Rusinga Island has about 35,000 inhabitants.  The average life expectancy is about 45 years with high number of females than males.  The average income per person averages KES 3,000 ($30) per month.   About 40% of the population on the island suffers from HIV/AIDS.        As the life expectancy is low and HIV/AIDS rate is high, a lot of women end up as widows at a young age.  Many of the women lose their husbands to HIV/AIDS and Malaria, and the women are left to take care of themselves and their children.  Again, due to low life expectancy and high HIV/AIDS, some women are orphans themselves, or they come from poor families.  Thus, the women did not have an opportunity to attend school in the first place or continue their education after primary school, as their families could not afford sending children to school.  _x000D_
Without formal education, the widows do not have any vocational or relevant skills to generate any income.  The women have at least three children, but the women cannot afford sending those children to public schools or feeding their children more than one meal a day.  Fortunately, their children attend Sargy Education Center, an organization under our organization that provides orphans and vulnerable children with free and/or affordable education.  Sargy Education Center also provides its pupils with breakfast and lunch, but the children often do not have anything to eat at home. _x000D_
       The widows are the mothers of our pupils, and they did not have any skills besides gathering firewoodÃ¢â¬â¢s or helping the fishermen.  In extreme cases, the women offered themselves sexually to the fishermen to put food on the table.  In our language, we call such practice jaboya, and it is still practiced on Rusinga Island.  Lake Victoria is often overfished, making fish scarce for the residents.  Therefore, buying fish has become competitive, and the only way the women would receive fish is to offer themselves sexually and trade sex for fish.  _x000D_
      These widows are strong, determined individuals.  To help them maximize their potentials and empower them, we started training them to weave a variety of items such as hats, ropes, and bracelets.  The women sell the items to generate income, but the amount is minimal; each rope sells for KES 30, which is about $0.30.  Weaving and selling the items have not generated enough income for them to improve their situations, so the women themselves came up with an idea to start a garden, a garden of hope._x000D_
      Sargy will use $25,000 to create 20 gardens of hope.  About 96% of the money will go towards the materials, such as cement, nails, pipes, and seeds, and the other 4% will pay for the labour required to start and finish these gardens.  Each garden will be right next to the womenÃ¢â¬â¢s houses; Lake Victoria has lots of hippos that can easily destroy the gardens if they were by the lake.  To protect the gardens from animals such as chickens, dogs, goats, and cows, we will put strong fences around the gardens.  _x000D_
      Our volunteers have helped the women acquire basic business skills such as bookkeeping, and the women will be more than able to take care of their gardens.  To them, the gardens mean more than just crops such as pawpaws, tomatoes, and onions.  The gardens are the hopes that they themselves can take care of their children and provide them with adequate food, books, and other supplies for school.  The garden of hope will help them maximize their potentials that they havenÃ¢â¬â¢t had any chances to utilize yet.  Moreover, the gardens will help the local community and its economy.  As an island, Rusinga offers a couple of economic activities such as fishing and farming, but only to a limited extent.  As mentioned earlier, Lake Victoria is way overfished; it doesnÃ¢â¬â¢t have enough fish for all the fishermen and residents who need food, especially protein.  Our main diet consists of ugali, which is maize.  We consume a lot of carbohydrates, and our diet is not balanced with protein or other nutrition.  By growing and selling fresh, local crops such as pawpaws, tomatoes, and onions, the women will be able to offer the community a chance to eat balanced meals and become healthy.     _x000D_
      The garden of hope will offer the women a sense of ownership: not only the ownership of the gardens, but also the ownership of their lives.  The garden will help them generate income and put food on their tables besides trading sex for fish.   The garden will help their children have a better chance of breaking the cycle of poverty.  Moreover, the garden will help the community eat more than just carbohydrates and eat balanced meals.  With the combination of our teamÃ¢â¬â¢s passion, the widowsÃ¢â¬â¢ determination and your fund, we will be able to make a positive change in the world._x000D_
project_details: This project takes place on Rusinga Island, an impoverished coastal area in Kenya.  Rusinga Island has been decimated by HIV/AIDS, and it is estimated that up to 40% of the inhabitants suffer from HIV/AIDS.  The average life expectancy is about 45 years of age, and females tend to live longer than men.  Therefore, many women become widows at a young age, without any means to provide for their families.  Some of them practice jaboya, which means that they trade sex for fish.  As of now, the women do not have sustainable income generating skills. This garden will help them find an alternative, sustainable way to generate income and help their children break the cycle of poverty.

project_summary:
The total female population covers more than half of the total population in Nepal. But looking at the women status in education, health and employment, the indicators shows still there is need of lots of efforts to be made for women empowerment. The economic contribution of women is substantial, but largely unnoticed because their traditional role is taken for granted. In most rural areas, their employments outside the household generally are limited to planting, weeding, and harvesting. In urban areas, those migrating from rural areas or with a lower economic status are employed in domestic and traditional jobs, as well as in the government sector, mostly in low-level positions. The socio-economic status of women in Nepal is very poor. The women are being discriminated in every aspect of the society. In order to empower women lots of efforts have to be made. Managing solid waste is one of the major challenges in urbanization. A survey conducted in all 58 municipalities of Nepal in 2012 found that the average municipal solid waste generation was 317 grams per capita per day. This translates into 1,435 tons per day or 524,000 tons per year of municipal solid waste generation in Nepal. Many of these technically and financially constrained municipalities are still practicing roadside waste pickup from open piles and open dumping, creating major health risks. Rapid and uncontrolled urbanization, lack of public awareness, and poor management by municipalities have intensified environmental problems in towns in Nepal, including unsanitary waste management and disposal. While solid waste management (SWM) has become a major concern for municipalities and the country as a whole.   _x000D_
The analysis of household waste composition indicated that the highest waste category was organic waste with 66%, followed by plastics with 12%, and paper and paper products with 9%. There is an identified key recommendation for solid waste management (SWM) in Nepal as enhancement of public participation and entrepreneur's development would be effective in advancing SWM practices._x000D_
_x000D_
In this regards entrepreneurship development targeting women and young girls can be much effective as it is clear from the data that lots of the waste categorized is household waste. Recycling of solid waste as a resource will reduce the amount of waste that needs to be disposed as well as the cost of waste management. Composting is a simple and effective way of recycling waste that is already being practiced. There are several different ways to compost waste this project will adopt vermi composting at the scale of household level directly benefiting women from perspective of knowledge, skill and economic growth._x000D_
_x000D_
The Goal of the Project is 'To improve the living standard of Women and young girls through household Solid waste management (SWM) developing entrepreneurship.'_x000D_
First of all there will be identified two municipalities in coordination with various Government and Non- Government organizations and through the secondary data review regarding the economic, social status of women. Then there will be selected 5 wards from each municipality focusing the residence of the most disadvantaged women in coordination with the local organizations and municipalities. After the selection of the wards there will be the conduction of the Scoping orientation programs to around 400 women that is approximately 20 women groups. The Scoping orientation program will focus on the overall activities that will be conducted along with the sharing on how they can be economically independent through Solid Waste Management. They will also be oriented on the benefits of Vermi composting and Waste Arts. After the Scoping orientation program there will be selected 100 interested and enthusiastic women from among those 400 women, their commitment will be taken simultaneously work further. _x000D_
The selected 100 women will be provided the scoping seminar on the Solid Waste Management (SWM) dividing into 2 groups of 50 participants. In this seminar the participants will be made clearer on the scopes and opportunities that are knocking their door if they can work in the field of Solid waste management. After the scoping seminar on SWM the participants will be again divided into two groups to provide the vigorous training on vermi composting and waste arts, according to their performance in previous training their commitments, interests and activeness. The full commitment will be taken from the participants for the active and meaningful participation along with strong motivation  There will be developed training manuals before the conduction of the training consulting with the expertise in respective fieldds._x000D_
The selected 30 women will be provided with intensive training on Vermi Composting and its marketing approach dividing into 2 groups of 15 each. There will be demonstrated hands on practices, demonstration on Vermi Composting along with the scope of vermicomposting in the market and its efficiency in household solid waste management. The participants will be made clear on technical knowledge on vermicomposting and its significance._x000D_
The selected 30 participants will be provided with intensive training on Waste arts through the inorganic waste generated at household level dividing into 2 groups of 15 each. The participants will be given skill based training of the various handicrafts that could be made from the waste along with various demonstration and hands on practices. They will also be made clear regarding the economic benefit they could get from these Waste arts training._x000D_
After the conduction of the intensive training and hands on practices they will be capacitate with basic entrepreneurship development training where they will learn about the local marketing approach on the products they developed and the model of the business enterprise. There will be formed 4 business Enterprise groups for which they will be provided with seed money to start the entrepreneurship. After some months of the starting of the business enterprise there will be regular monitoring and evaluation along with result analysis. They will be under regular supervision and guidance at the beginning but with the acceleration of their work the sole responsibility will be handed over to them and there will be developed a mechanism for the regular follow up and monitoring for the effectiveness of the program in the long term basis._x000D_
At the end of the project, learning documents, compilation of case stories along with short video regarding the whole project activities, its effectiveness will be documented and prepared.

project_details:
Commercial Sex Work among the young women in the slums of Kawempe for survival makes them vulnerable to acquiring and spreading the HIV/AIDS pandemic as well as other Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs), especially when the knowledge of prevention of such illnesses is still insufficient among them. It is therefore common to find out that condoms are rarely used, which increases the risk of infection and spread of the deadly pandemic. _x000D_
Unwanted pregnancies are also an additional problem we desire to solve since many uncared for children end up born to single young mothers with little or no parenting skills, which posses a threat to the welfare of these children whose mothers have no alternative jobs with which to care and protect them. Commercial sex being an illegal activity in Uganda, CSWs are vulnerable to the risk of exploitation, abuse and violence since they are not able to seek protection from the police or other official institutions._x000D_
_x000D_
Some of these Commercial Sex Workers CSWs have been trafficked from other parts of Uganda. In most cases they cannot rely on the help of their families or other social networks. The girls and young women are stigmatized by the society and excluded from the normal community life. Their earnings are minimal and in most cases they barely cover the costs of daily living. In addition, they often have to support their children or even an extended family in some cases. Their poor financial situation, psychological state as well as the lack of professional and personal life skills makes dependence on savings impossible since whatever money is made, does not allow turning their lives around. Worse still they fail to secure jobs due stigma from within the community being well known in the activity of commercial sex. Besides, many have no qualifications for the descent jobs, which still keeps them an easy target to more sexual exploitation by the bosses in the formal employment sector. This therefore will keep their lives revolving around unhealthy sexual behaviour and yet they could utilise the ICT entrepreneurial skills to manage their livelihoods as well as change their future.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Although there are a number of interventions for the CSWs in Kawempe division, there is need for more effort to help them raise their status from vulnerability to independence by acquiring employable skills. Many of the available interventions in this division have invested in traditional skills which have been associated with illiterate people or failures; in turn they have been shunned in favour of their usual risky activities for survival. This has failed to raise the status of young women involved and those at risk of being involved with time in the commercial sex work within Kawempe slums. Modern technology being on demand in many developing countries, the young women entrepreneurs in line with ICT businesses will be able to emerge as better examples of individuals in their communities. _x000D_
_x000D_
The project is designed to equip the young women involved in Commercial sex with soft business literacy, and entrepreneurial skills to be able to set up businesses that can earn them a living, employ more young people and ensure positive contribution that will accord them positive recognition within the communities they live in. _x000D_

project_name: Learn to Earn: Female Led Entrepreneurship Development Project
project_summary:
Background:In Nepal, many women are economically and socially backward. In addition, Cultural norms and traditional values of Nepalese society also promotes gender inequality in many ways. Women are always taken as somebody who will look after her husband, take care of him, give birth to his children, raise them and just spent her life maintaining the status of Ã¢â¬ÅcaretakerÃ¢â¬Â. Women lack access to various opportunities and service facilities. As a result- most of them are unemployed and are poor. Because of that- they donÃ¢â¬â¢t have any dignity in their own home and confined within the territory of their home and are often victims of domestic-violence._x000D_
Moreover, if we look at the problems and challenges of women with disabilities- they are much more severe. In addition to the problems of general women that we discussed earlier, women with disabilities also experiences discrimination due to their physical or mental impairment. They are often considered as burden to the family and society and is not able to do any work that is important._x000D_
_x000D_
Project Introduction:_x000D_
Our project- Learn to Earn will be one year long and will be divided in 3 quarters (4 months= 1 quarter).  In the first quarter we will select at least 35 women from central region of Nepal, preferably rural area and bring them to the capital city- Kathmandu. We will make sure that  at least 30%  of these participants are women with disabilities. Here, they will be provided five day residential extensive training on leadership and entrepreneurship skills. They will learn to be confident and believe in themselves.  Also they will be taught to understand what their interest is or express their business ideas. We will share the best business ideas among the participants and will give some time to come-up with their business idea and we will award the 4 best  ideas ( either in group or individual) and take over them for the second quarter of the project._x000D_
._x000D_
In the second quarter, those 4 group of people or individual who were selected as best idea   will get specific training on their own business ideas and interests. For example if someone wants to start mushroom farming or Beekeeping- we will provide them training, workshops and business consultations related to that specific business idea they have. We will help them throughout the quarter to prepare business plan and other legal requirements they will need to start their business._x000D_
_x000D_
In our third and last quarter, our individuals or groups that were selected in the first quarter and received specific business training in the second quarter will be able to start their own business or social enterprise. Through our project we will provide them a small amount of non-refundable seed money to kick-start their project. But we will make sure that, these people will also contribute some share of the total cost so that- they will feel that are not just spending some projectÃ¢â¬â¢s money and feel ownership in what they are doing. With all the knowledge and skills they have now from the trainings and with the seed money provided by us; they will be able to start their business enterprise. _x000D_
_x000D_
After their business is started we will monitor them and provide necessary guidance, feedbacks and consultation wherever necessary to make their business run smooth. Also this will be the same quarter where we finish up things by documenting the progress report in the form of photographs, audios and videos. We will do the final evaluation of the project and prepare the detailed report of our whole project._x000D_
_x000D_
Result:_x000D_
Even though; our project will end in one year- the work we started will never end. It will be sustainable in itself. The project participants who are our beneficiaries will continuously work towards expanding their business. They will be able to hire other women as their employee and helpers. Their economic status will improve. They will be able to earn for their family. This will certainly change the traditional mindset of people to look towards women. Women will no longer be confined in their homes and now will be taken as a new force in the economic development of the society and the nation._x000D_
Our project will also be able to empower women with disabilities. They will receive the same level of training and other facilities from our project. Thus they will also be able to start their own business. In our society, where a women with disability is looked as no more than useless burden on family- the results of our project will certainly bring about a revolutionary social change. Disabilities will no longer be looked as incompetence or inability. _x000D_
_x000D_
Also another achievement of this project will be able to bring women with and without disabilities together. In Nepal, persons with disabilities are always segregated from persons without disabilities because of physical and attitudinal barriers. Because of this people without disabilities are not always sensitive towards issues of person with disabilities like accessibility. But our project will bring both women with and without disability together in various activities. This will certainly help them to understand each other and work towards building inclusive society._x000D_
_x000D_
Conclusion:_x000D_
Our project Ã¢â¬ÅLearn to Earn: Female Led Entrepreneurship Development Project Ã¢â¬Åwill aim to empower women with and without disabilities from rural part of Nepal economically and socially by providing them knowledge, skills and platform to start and run their own business enterprise. This project will contribute in overall economic development of individual families as well societies._x000D_

project_summary:
More than a business model it is a social model based in promoting entrepreneurial activities through the training of women living in rural areas of Cameroon. The main idea of the project aimed initially to identify sources that can be easily found or produced in rural areas of Cameroon without technical requirements or additional costs to be implemented. Because of its favorable agriculture conditions Cameroon has a large potential and it plays an important role in its economy contributing today with more than 20% of its GDP. 70% of CameroonÃ¢â¬â¢s workforce also is present in rural areas of the country. Poverty in the country is largely a rural phenomenon with 55% of the poor living in rural areas. Women population is another factor to be considered as 50% of the Cameroonian population is formed by women. Considering these factors Ã¢â¬â agriculture potential, poverty in rural areas, large population of women, high number of children dropping out of the school Ã¢â¬â we joined forces to build a project which aims to empower the women economically through entrepreneurial training allowing them to use agriculture resources, which are already available, and at the same time promoting an increment of quality of life and a reduction in the number of children dropping out of the school to engage in inadequate jobs for a low payment. _x000D_
The retail of palm oil is only one of the various agriculture products available in the community of Jinkfuin and we see a potential to develop entrepreneurial initiatives with other products like handicraft products, traditional fabrics, soap, candles and etc. After the Income Generation Project some women were able to implement a variety of products to be sold by the groups showing that the project can be easily replicate even when it includes a variation of the activity. _x000D_
_x000D_
This is a self-sustainable project which will reach independence from external funding within its 4th month of operation. This is achieved through in-built elements of the project, as well as effective strategies for successful implementation of the project. _x000D_
_x000D_
In-built elements include: despite the fact that input cost for first 4 months are covered by the grant money, women will get it at discounted rates to ensure a healthy financial status at group level. Interest earned on repayment of loan will grow principle amount and more interest is generated, money will grow at projected rate of 20%. There is also presence of democratic way of forming lending norms and peer influence, which will help in reducing defaults and ensuring timely payments. Administrative cost is maintained to be minimal. Women group can also leverage on their social capital to form linkages with formal lending institutions, civil societies and agricultural agencies for further diversification._x000D_
_x000D_
Strategies for implementation include: having norms and code of conduct regarding Financial and Social values, as well as terms and conditions for loan repayments which will be agreed upon and followed by members to create a more supportive and productive environment. Loan will be disbursed subject to memberÃ¢â¬â¢s majority approval. Leaders and GMM official will monitor the activities and ensure that all accounting adhere to the provided formats and that there is not much deviation in the figures from projected financial statement. This will ensure healthy numbers both at Group and Member level. Members can change the rules provided majority of women agree for it thus making it more flexible. Group size is small and is homogenous; women sharing the same vision and having commonality like staying in similar locality, having children studying in same school, etc are encouraged to be in same group, this will ensure a better implementation and transparency. Peer pressure will motivate women to save, invest more and repay on time. GMM will also form a complaint cell comprising senior coordinators for this project where women can register their complaints if any in a designated format. And GMM will form a system in place for resolving the complaint._x000D_
_x000D_
How the project function: Women whose primary goal is to arrange for their childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s education will be selected and homogenous group will be formed to ensure better transparency and ease of operation. There will be 10 women in 1 group. Then there will be the selection of a leader Group Leader- will buy oil and will keep accounts related to Buying and selling of Oil in the designated format. Saving and Lending Kitty leader- will keep a record of savings pooled by each member every month in the given format & will collect repayment from the borrower with interest and will close her account in books. At the end of the Project will redistribute the Accumulated Capital. Meetings 1st Month- Distribution of Oil to the members and handing over a communication about -Cost of Oil for the coming months, Asking to keep a Provision for next monthÃ¢â¬â¢s buying, Expectations regarding Saving, Lending Norms and condition and other Code of conduct. Meeting closes 2nd Month- Pooling of saving and keeping the records regarding each memberÃ¢â¬â¢s contribution. There will also be asking of nominations for borrowing of Accumulated savings and after the taking groupÃ¢â¬â¢s consensus, one will open the borrower account and hand over the sum. Distributing the Oil at stipulated price and closing the meeting. 3rd to 12th Month- Collecting the loan Repayment from the borrower (Principal + 2.5% Interest) hereby called Ã¢â¬ÅEarning from S&L KittyÃ¢â¬Â & Closing her account in books. Pooling of saving and asking the nominations for borrowing of Accumulated sum (Contribution + Earning). Distributing the Oil at stipulated price and closing the meeting. On 13th Month the Accumulated Sum in S&L kitty is redistributed to the members; amount is redistributed in the same proportion as it is contributed. If group decides to continue, sum at member level will be carry forwarded else equally distributed if decided to dissolve._x000D_
_x000D_
Differentiating advantage: This project is both sustainable and replicable which achieves a 3S differential advantage of: sustainability, scalability and scope of impact. _x000D_

project_name: EMPOWERING GIRLS INVOLVED IN COMMERICAL SEX WORK WITH ALTERNATIVE LIFE SKILLS FOR SURVIVA
project_summary:
In Kenya, it is estimated that between 10,000 and 30,000 children are sexually exploited either through prostitution, rape, sex tourism and child pornography. The main cause of this phenomenon is high poverty levels because most children engage in, especially, prostitution in order to earn a living for them and their families.This project will utilize the USD$ 25,000 to rescue, rehabilitate and empower girls who are involved in commercial sex work in Nairobi. The activities that will be carried out are as follows:      Street work and meetings_x000D_
This will involve carrying out street work and meetings in the night at least twice every week. Street work will be used as a means for identification of the girls involved in commercial sex work, where they visit, and create a rapport with them. Meetings will be organized and held with them to discuss the issues affecting them and how to come up with solutions to these problems._x000D_
      Formation of associations for girls at risk, or already involved in commercial sex work_x000D_
During interactions in the street work meetings, the girls will be encouraged to form associations of between 15 and 25 members, for girls at risk of sexual exploitation or those involved in commercial sex work. Undugu Society of Kenya has been working with children living and working on the streets through the 'Associations' Model', which is grounded on the principles of enhanced participation, the rights based approach, peer-to-peer rehabilitation, group work, transformation and empowerment. The associations will be encouraged to meet regularly, and each of them will be guided to develop their constitution, rules and regulations. These associations will be used to promote peer to peer learning, leadership development of the girls, and for discussions on issues affecting them and how to develop solutions to these issues. The girls will use the associations to advice and support each other in their efforts to overcome sexual exploitation._x000D_
      Capacity development of the girls to deal with issues of sexual exploitation_x000D_
Through the associations, the capacity of girls involved in commercial sex work, to deal with issues of drug and substance abuse; sexual exploitation; criminal tendencies/behavior, will be enhanced and they will be empowered to improve their self-image for the attainment of dignity. Capacity building workshops will be organized for leaders of the girls' associations. The workshops will focus on:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Leadership development and group dynamics_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Drugs and substance abuse, Sexual and Reproductive health, including HIV and AIDS, STD's _x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Rights of children as per the United Nations Convention on the Rights of a Child, the Constitution of Kenya, the ChildrenÃ¢â¬â¢s Act and the Sexual Offences Act._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Peer to Peer Education and life skills._x000D_
Thereafter, peer educators will be appointed in these associations and they will be taken through a peer education training to equip them with skills to facilitate monthly peer education sessions on life skills with their peers, in their respective associations, covering issues of sexuality, drugs and substance abuse, developing self esteem, among others. The associations will become avenues for advocating for and promoting peer-to-peer rehabilitation, behavioral change among girls involved in commercial sex work, and overcoming Ã¢â¬Ërisky behaviorÃ¢â¬â¢. The associations will also be instrumental in identifying new girls entering the streets and rescuing them before they become accustomed to street life, get sexually exploited and get engaged in commercial sex work as a way of survival. The rescued girls will then be referred, through these associations, for care and protection at the Undugu Place of Safety for rehabilitating children. _x000D_
      Providing alternatives to commercial sex work_x000D_
Through the associations, the girls already involved in commercial sex work, will be encouraged and influenced to seek alternative survival opportunities, such as education, vocational skills training and business and entrepreneurship opportunities. Through this project, young girls, who have dropped out of school, will be removed from street life, reintegrated back to their families and placed back to formal education schools. Those who would prefer to undertake vocational skills will be taken through trade choosing workshops to expose them to different vocational courses in the informal sector, their marketability, advantages and disadvantages. Upon completion, the girls will then choose what course they want to pursue and will be attached to trainers in the informal sector to acquire vocational skills_x000D_
 through the apprenticeship approach. Their training fees will be paid for by the project. The project will also support some of the girls in setting up their own small enterprises in order to earn a living. These girls will be taken through a Business management and Entrepreneurship workshop to educate them on how to create a business plan, run a business effectively and manage their money well. The project will then provide seed capital for their business start up._x000D_
      Working with others {Referrals}_x000D_
Through the project, collaborations and networks will be created with other organizations from where girls referred can receive services such as care and protection, medical services and legal aid. In particular the project will work with: Rescue Dada for provision of care and protection, CRADLE for the provision of legal aid, and Kenyatta and Mbagathi Hospitals for the provision of medical care for the girls._x000D_

Yvonne Namaganda Leadership Programme (YVONNE) is an independent not for profit organisation which aims to promote and support the development of leadership, life skills and entrepreneurship among female youths in Uganda. _x000D_
The project Ã¢â¬ÅYvonne community impactÃ¢â¬Â seeks to create entrepreneurs in community health care through empowering 5 female youths with entrepreneurship skills and providing initial start-up facilitation to set up community based health care enterprises. The project will be carried out in two phases. Phase one will involve selecting 5 female youths who are in their final year of study for a certificate in midwifery from identified tertiary institutions. _x000D_
Phase two will take place after they have graduated from their educational institutions and will involve setting up a modest private practice for each of the trained youths to offer their services to the public on a paid basis._x000D_

The project targets female youths who are enrolled for the certificate in midwifery course because the course normally attracts students who dropped out of formal education after Senior Four (Ordinary Level education) or Senior six (Advanced Level) for social reasons such as early pregnancy, forced marriages or lack of school fees and do the course as a last resort. project_summary:
We will spend USD 25,000 to implement our ChunriChoupaal plans to empower women and girls in (selected) remote and rural areas of Pakistan through capacity building in the use of digital media. The purpose of providing is twofold; economic and social empowerment. We will use the resources to build an online learning platform to provide trainings and capacity building opportunities to our target audience especially in those areas where it is challenging or inconvenient for the trainers to travel. This is to ensure that the trainings or progress is not disrupted. Consequently, we will be able to reach more beneficiaries  through our online platform because the trained people can then train more people from their communities. _x000D_
Due to social, cultural and religious barriers, women in some areas of our community cannot get out of their homes to gain trainings or learn skills. Talented educated girls are left with no choice but to stay at home and wait for their marriages to be arranged. Once they are married off, they have no choice but to produce children and be stay at home moms for the rest of their married life. This is why numerous young women never join the work force or become financially independent women. Women who do have jobs before getting married are more likely to be allowed continuing with their career. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our programs will give the young women the option to either work from home through the use of modern ICTs or start a new business. After basic digital literacy training, the women can choose between our digital media & citizen journalism training or entrepreneurship trainings to start a new business and working remotely. Citizen journalism trainings will allow them to write stories of change and hope from their communities and bring them to the attention of the online world. Ti will also help them connect with the rest of the world and explore new opportunities to improve their lives. _x000D_
_x000D_

Centru Feto Haburas Dezenvolivmento (CFHD) is a grassroots organization in Timor-Leste. The Centre provides small business training and grants to rural women and survivors of violence, provides community training and dialogues addressing issues of sexual and domestic violence and is commencing using social enterprises to assist in creating employment for vulnerable women. As a local NGO, staffed by all women, the Centre is thinking creatively about how to establish more sustainable sources of income, at the same time achieving their mission of promoting vulnerable women in development. If selected to receive the Project Inspire grant, we will use the funds to launch a micro-finance demonstration project as part of Global Sisters start-up operations with refugee and migrant women in Australia. _x000D_

We are not interested in re-inventing the wheel- rather we are joining the dots and linking people, partners, resources and technology to empower women and their communities. Women who come to Australia as refugees and migrants are typically passionate about finding work and are often highly entrepreneurial. Cultural and language barriers however can contribute to a struggle to find meaningful employment.  This can lead to a dependence on welfare and social isolation, which - coupled with the trauma they carry from their past experiences - can have a devastating impact on their efforts to build a new life in Australia and participate fully in the community._x000D_
_x000D_
At the same time, many of these women have extraordinary traditional artisan skills that have been passed down for generations, and are uncommon in modern Australia. _x000D_

project_summary:
The main beneficiaries of the project are the thousands of slum dwellers living in 35 slums across Kolkata and Howrah, especially women and children._x000D_
As per the 2001 Census, Kolkata has an extended metropolitan population of over 14 million, and over 40% of the population are homeless people or slum residents. The majority of these are engaged in the unorganized sector, with average monthly earnings between 500 and 1700 rupees and a household size of five to six persons to support. Slum dwellers are particularly more prone to poor health because of their difficult working and living conditions, coupled with poor access to the most basic of amenities such as water and sanitation and limited knowledge of their healthcare entitlements. _x000D_
_x000D_
During the previous healthcare programme from April 1st  2007 to March 31st  2010, HOPE monitored the heath status of 196,713 slum dwellers through recording the incidences of illnesses encountered through the 35 weekly clinics that were run in 34 different slum areas. The predominant illnesses encountered at the clinics among adults over the past three years were gastrointestinal (17.3%), respiratory (17.2%), musculoskeletal (15.7%), skin related (13.8%), gynaecological/obstetrical (7.7%) and cardiovascular (6.6%). The predominant illnesses among children were respiratory (31.8%), skin related (22.3%), gastrointestinal (17.2%) and ears, nose and throat (5.1%). The alarming rates of gastrointestinal, respiratory and skin related illnesses are directly attributable to the difficult and deplorable living conditions in the slums and the figures also indicate that children are the first causalities of slum living._x000D_
_x000D_
To counter the increasing health crises amongst slum dwellers, parallel to its primary healthcare programmes, HOPE has formed specific action groups called Community Video Units (CVU). The CVU is an advocacy tool as well as a tool of community empowerment. It creates platforms for communities to carry out dialogs to find solutions and empower people to take action on local issues. CVUs are local production entities that are run by community members trained in all aspects of video production and distribution. These community video producers make films on issues decided by community, which are then screened on widescreen projectors to thousands of people in the community. _x000D_
_x000D_
The Community Video Unit has two main aims Ã¢â¬â 1. Raise Awareness in slum communities on healthcare related topics and 2. Advocate on behalf of slum communities to local government for improved healthcare conditions, coverage and facilities. _x000D_
_x000D_
The purpose of this project is to set up community units is to train 24 young and educated slum dwellers how to research, shoot, edit and produce video clips on health related issues that affect slum dwellers' quality of life. A unique element of the community video approach is that it allows beneficiaries to narrate their own experience rather than having their story told from the perspective of an outsider. It also provides an opportunity to develop skills in media for young slum dwellers who would otherwise have been excluded from this type of experience as a result of their social and financial background. _x000D_
_x000D_
The members are trained by a dedicated Media Officer who is qualified in cinematography. Each CVU is equipped with two cameras, two sound systems, two computers, one LCD projector and screen and tables and chairs. _x000D_
_x000D_
Every three months, CVUs create a 'Video News Magazine'. The content of the Magazine is decided by a Community Editorial Board based on viewer feedback and key campaign issues. The Community Editorial Board guides CVUs and is comprised of the Media Officer, Community Video Unit members, project staff and community people. Different segments of the 'Video News Magazine' will typically include:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢ Community News - the issues of poor communities, such as government schemes, local health issues and upcoming events that are not covered by the mainstream news_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢ Opinion Polls Ã¢â¬â that capture community consensus and call to action on particular issues_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢ Success Stories - such as families that have found economic success through educating their girls_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢ Short Documentaries Ã¢â¬â for example, stories with regard to alcoholism, gender issues, reproductive health and so on._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢ Legal Tips - i.e., what to do if your name is not on a voterÃ¢â¬â¢s list_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢ Expose/video raids Ã¢â¬â such as short clips of closed government health services followed by an on-the-fly interview with the concerned government officials_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢ Editorial Ã¢â¬â where the organization and the reporters take their stand-for-change on the issue and give follow up action points_x000D_
_x000D_
Furthermore, once these 'Video News Magazines' are completed (usually over a four week period), each CVU screens their videos in each of the 35 slum communities through utilising their LCD projector and screen and the table and chairs for outdoor screenings. Please note, each 'Video News Magazine' is screened in front of the Community Editorial Board for their approval before screening to the communities. These screenings are attended by local community members, staff and personnel from local healthcare and water and sanitation providers, local business people and local councillors. The purpose of these meetings is to sensitise stakeholders on the healthcare issues affecting slum dwellers and to garner support for improved healthcare facilities for slum dwellers._x000D_
_x000D_
The cost breakdown of the project is given in the uploaded Budget Proposal. The remuneration for 24 trainee community volunteers will be USD 55 /person/ per month, or USD 15,840 in total. USD 4800 is required for purchase of new equipment, and up-gradation and repair of existing video and other technical equipment. USD 4320 will be required for the trainees to travel to locations to shoot videos and also to hold screenings and campaigns for the community dwellers._x000D_

project_name: Innovative Women Vegetables Club (A Journey from Poverty to Prosperity)
project_summary:
AWARD intends to initiate a business model through Project Inspire 2014 by opening innovative women vegetable clubs for less-privileged farm workers. The intervention of AWARD is based on organic and commercial kitchen gardening to transform the lives of women farm workers from poverty to prosperity. Women Vegetable Clubs (WVC) is an idea to club rural women for collective entrepreneurship through organic commercial kitchen gardening. This business model contains 5 distinctive features:_x000D_
1.	It will promote women entrepreneurship by eliminating the role of middle men._x000D_
2.	The model is the exclusive example of indigenous skill based entrepreneurship._x000D_
3.	This Entrepreneurial activity is based on the daily needs of the buyer._x000D_
4.	It is a cost effective, replicable, accessible and self generated model_x000D_
5.	This idea has potential of being recognized at national as well as international level.The Organic farming is the real need of the country due to high diseases ratio in the communities which is the result of the inorganic farming. _x000D_
_x000D_
The business Model of one Women Vegetable Club is: _x000D_
1.	Formation of 1 Women Vegetable Club consisting of 6 low or no-income farm workers._x000D_
2.	Each Women Vegetable Club will be provided 1 week training on organic-commercial kitchen gardening and How to Run businesses effectively._x000D_
3.	Each Women Vegetable Club will recieve  agriculture loan of 50,000 PKR for taking 1 acre land on 1 year lease for the purpose of organic commercial kitchen gardening. It will be a revolving loan._x000D_
4.	Each Women Vegetable Club will organize sessions with the community about the recycling of the byproducts of fruits, vegetable and other livestock waste for the purpose of organic farming. Each woman will collect the waste products from 10-15 homes._x000D_
5.	The process from sowing to picking will be completed in 3-4 months._x000D_
6.	After the production, each member of women vegetable club will identify 5 families as their potential customers to supply fresh organic vegetables on daily basis at their doorstep._x000D_
7.	ItÃ¢â¬â¢s a common practice of the villagers to buy high price vegetable from the hawkers on daily basis at 100-150 Rs. per day. Through the functioning of Women Vegetable Clubs, the selected families will receive fresh organic vegetables at their homes without bargaining from the hawkers. In this way, each member women of women vegetable will earn 12000-15000 Pak Rupees per month._x000D_
8.	The first 2 months of the project will be for trainings and agriculture loan distribution, the next 4 months will be the production time and 10 months for the business growth and loan recovery.  Before the end of the project time period, each women vegetable club will train another 6 women for taking agricultural loan from the recovered amount. The process from training to business, business to loan recovery and then from recovery to new women vegetable clubs will take 15 months. _x000D_
9.	This business model will not only improve the income of women but also provide sustainable economic solution to the rural women. It will provide the facility of revolving agriculture loan but also skilled entrepreneurs as revolving trainers._x000D_
10.	This journey will proceed from skilled entrepreneurs to new entrepreneurs, from one vegetable club to another vegetable club and from one village to another village._x000D_
_x000D_
Project Outline:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	The project will initiate from February 2015._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	The duration of the project will be 15 months._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	10 marginalized rural areas will be selected for the implementation._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	The Project team will consist of 1 Program Co-ordinator, 1 Monitoring and Evaluation officer, 2 Social Mobilizers and 1 Kitchen Gardening Consultant. _x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	The Kitchen Gardening Consultant will provide the trainings to women vegetable clubs and also provide them guidance on regular basis through visitation, pictorial _x000D_
         publications and by telephone._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	In each village 2 women vegetable clubs will be formed. So total 20 women vegetable clubs will be initiated through the grant of Project Inspire, 2014._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	1,000,000 PKR will be allocated for the revolving agriculture loan and will be given to 20 women vegetable clubs. Each vegetable club will get 50,000 PKR._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	The Women Vegetable Club will return the loan amount after the 4 months of loan distribution. 12% service charges will be taken to ensure the sustainability of _x000D_
         the revolving fund. It is worth mentioning that in Pakistan, the micro credit banks issues small loans with the interest of 18% or more. _x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	During the project, the monitoring and evaluation officer will regularly monitor the areas along with the Social Mobilizers._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Each women vegetable club will train another 6 women of their area on the whole mechanism and procedure._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	In the 15 month of the project, this loan will be given to 20 new vegetable clubs and they will also follow the same procedure._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	The monthly meeting with the staff will be conducted every month to discuss the monthly issues related to project implementation._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	This process will continue and gain momentum from Poverty to Prosperity._x000D_

project_details:
Pakistan is a country suffering from economic instability at all tiers due to terrorism, extremisms, low level of literacy and many other problems. One of the biggest resources of our country is Women which comprise 52% of the total population.The majority of the women of our country resides in the rural areas and is more disadvantaged because the majority is neither educated nor skilled. Their preferred profession is farming where they are not considered as direct workers and have no access to any agricultural loan.  The young women of (age 18-35) are mostly associated with this profession. They used to work with their husbands and other family members 6-8 hours a day and not get any income. _x000D_
 Due to this poor situation, women are subjected to domestic violence, early age marriages, sexual harassments, yearly pregnancies, poor health and other psychological breakdowns. The problem we want to solve is the low or no income of the farm workers.
