project_details:
Pakistan is a country suffering from economic instability at all tiers due to terrorism, extremisms, low level of literacy and many other problems. One of the biggest resources of our country is Women which comprise 52% of the total population.The majority of the women of our country resides in the rural areas and is more disadvantaged because the majority is neither educated nor skilled. Their preferred profession is farming where they are not considered as direct workers and have no access to any agricultural loan.  The young women of (age 18-35) are mostly associated with this profession. They used to work with their husbands and other family members 6-8 hours a day and not get any income. _x000D_
 Due to this poor situation, women are subjected to domestic violence, early age marriages, sexual harassments, yearly pregnancies, poor health and other psychological breakdowns. The problem we want to solve is the low or no income of the farm workers.

project_details_other:
Our long-term goal is to create a network of several hundred trainees who are in position to grow businesses, develop links with other countries in the region and ultimately foster economic growth in the DPRK. The demographic we target is transforming society, but operating businesses in a gray area that is creating civil society spaces beyond state control. This has not only resulted in more freedom for individuals, but also has and will continue to drive food security for a very poor population. Finally, greater connectedness and more international aspirations can help drive stability and security in East Asia, as a coalition of North Korean stakeholders is drawn into the international environment. Broadly speaking, this demographic of North Koreans is not in favor of military or political tensions that harm business. Surveys we have conducted suggest that  that female managers we support can more easily progress into international positions as their career advances.
Providing international networking therefore not only help to promote new ideas and open horizons. By the end of the WIB program we expect to see participants better understand business skills, international standards, norms and best practices in management. Participants will also be able to relate how these concepts matter in attracting foreign investment and in economic development, and should be able to produce ideas on how international business best practices can be implemented within North Korea. The majority of these business concepts will be implementable almost immediately by the participants in their work, improving operations and efficiency.
By December 2015 we plan to train 60 businesswomen. We expect these trainees to make official reports to their institutions, increasing the reach. Moreover, we expect them to be able to understand and internalize content that they will find immediately applicable in their places of work. 
To make sure we train 60 females effectively, we will use feedback forms (we have a five page standard form), personal interviews and written statements to judge outcomes._x000D_
We will evaluate the number of participants, satisfaction with workshop content and expertise, and the number of local organizations and business represented to gauge if we are having the predicted levels of participation._x000D_
_x000D_
To measure the efficiency of programs, we are also looking to understand how knowledge and skill-sets have improved from pre-program levels. These will involve surveys or tests to gauge how understanding has changed over the course of the program. We will also conduct qualitative interviews and other feedback statements to capture what participants learn through our programs.
The Choson Exchange Women in Business Program has been running since fall of 2012. It has been supported by a variety of groups, including the British Embassy in DPRK, the Lee Foundation and individual donations._x000D_
We have yet to secure institutional funding for the program to continue into 2015. We hope to continue sourcing individual donations to a degree that the program continues, even if we fail to win grants for 2015.
project_name: North Korean Women in Business Program
project_summary:
North Korea is perhaps the most controlled society in the world. However, the gradual failure of its centrally planned economy has created opportunities for market activities: there is a growing grey market at all levels of society, where private economic activity is reluctantly tolerate and is changing society in significant and generally positive ways._x000D_
Women entrepreneurs are driving North KoreaÃ¢â¬â¢s social transformation by creatively starting small, informal businesses while men tend to be locked into their official jobs. Despite this entrepreneurship, which provides food security for their families, because of travel restrictions, censorship and patriarchal values, women lack access to the business skills and social support networks to get to the top positions at larger businesses. _x000D_
_x000D_
We intend to support young, professional women by boosting their career development through providing business education in Pyongyang, North Korea and bringing the best and brightest abroad for study trips to Beijing, Shanghai and Singapore. The knowledge and networks that they gain access to will increase their relative value in their home country, giving them a better chance to achieve and succeed. This will help counteract both the professional discrimination they face as females and the difficulties of navigating their corrupt, inefficient pseudo-socialist economic environment._x000D_
_x000D_
Finally, in supporting a network of young, female entrepreneurs and managers, we are supporting the development of civil society in a country where freedom of association is severely curtailed. Thus, this project also supports what is generally considered a basic human right._x000D_
_x000D_
We will conduct two workshops in Pyongyang in 2014 for 60 females, 30 at each workshop. Those hundred, in turn, usually give officials reports or presentations to 10-30 people at their home organization, multiplying the total recipients of program content. From the two workshops we will identify 12 people whom we consider to be the most deserving or most likely to affect positive change. This will be conducted through a process of interviews and surveys. Through other funding, this group will be brought to Singapore for a later study trip._x000D_
_x000D_
The organization I founded, Choson Exchange, has been running educational exchange programs since 2009, building long-term relationships and supporting young North Korean entrepreneurs and professionals through workshops and study trips in both Pyongyang and Singapore. Past programs have been funded by the Swiss government, the Lee Foundation, as well as by other individual donors. We have also presented research papers or given lectures at institutions as varied as Harvard University, Seoul National University, London UniversityÃ¢â¬â¢s SOAS (School of Oriental and African Studies), Google Inc., the Singapore Business Federation and the Council of Swedish Industries._x000D_
_x000D_
Our expertise in executing programs in the extremely difficult and highly controlled environment of North Korea has grown steadily over the last several years. We work with capable North Korean partners, who see our work as valuable, to help organize our workshops and secure permissions for young professionals to travel abroad. Since fall 2012 we have been running a Women in Business program, for which we have funding through the end of 2013. This program is composed of four in-country workshops and three study trips to Singapore. We hope to secure funds to extend this program through 2014 and beyond and as the basic format has already been established, we will be able to hit the ground running in December 2013 to set up the first workshops in early 2014._x000D_
_x000D_
We are able stretch our budget through our international network of world-class volunteers, corporate and academic partners, who graciously give of their time, expertise and facilities in order to enable these programs to take place. Thus, the overall costs of our programs are driven down to manageable levels. The key remaining cost is transportation and accommodation for trips to Pyongyang for planning and execution as well as study trips to Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
Through our programs, we expect to see businesswomen better understand business skills, international standards, norms and best practices in management. Participants should be able to relate how these concepts matter in attracting foreign investment and in economic development, and should be able to produce ideas on how international business best practices can be implemented within North Korea._x000D_
_x000D_
The metrics we plan to use in North Korea were selected based on how realistic they are in North KoreaÃ¢â¬â¢s restricted context, and how relevant they are to capturing the impact of programs.  Tracking program participation and satisfaction is important in ensuring that we are reaching the right number of the right people. We are looking to evaluate the number of participants, ratio of attendees to workshop leaders, satisfaction with workshop outcomes, companies or sites visited on overseas programs, and the number of local organizations and business represented to gauge if we are having the predicted levels of participation._x000D_
project_details: North Korean women have been driving marketization, food security and individual options for life in North Korean society. However, the North Korean state imposes strict limits on access to the outside world: women are given fewer opportunities than males to have access to foreign expertise and their foreign peers. Women, then, usually have to run their businesses without properly understanding international standards and practices in a variety of fields. They are also given few opportunities to network amongst themselves, as the state discourages informal gatherings outside official purposes. The WIB program helps address all these issues.

project_name: Enhancing entrepreneurship and Pre Vocational 21st Century skills of girls and young women from marginalised communities.
project_summary:
This project aims to empower girls and young women from impoverished families living in MumbaiÃ¢â¬â¢s slums, with entrepreneurship and pre-vocational skills as well as to increase their social capital._x000D_
People living in MumbaiÃ¢â¬â¢s slums are marginalised because of issues of migration, poverty, lack of organized employment and poor civic infrastructure. Girls and young women of families living in slums are further marginalised due to their gender. They lack access to education, sanitation, health and other basic facilities due to both gender-related restrictions from family and community as well as insufficient government interventions. Symptoms of this problem are rising instances of gender-based violence, early marriage, high drop-out rate of girls from education Ã¢â¬â especially secondary education, and many others. It is proven that when women and girls are empowered, it leads to empowerment of their families and the entire community. WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s economic empowerment is also one of the major factors in achieving equality between women and men. This project will provide relevant skills, knowledge and opportunities to girls and young women in the age group of 11 to 24 years for them to become entrepreneurs in their own communities. The project will be implemented in slum communities of Mumbai and Thane District._x000D_
_x000D_
The project will use innovative practices of building entrepreneurship of girls such as through creation of girlÃ¢â¬â¢s own community newsletters that they will produce themselves. Safe spaces of learning will be created in girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ own communities to ensure easy access for girls. Interventions will be made through conducting regular sessions twice a week, conducting workshops and organising visits to various area resources to increase girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ access and networking with local assets in the area. _x000D_
Girls will learn conversational English, use of computer and photography as well as skills of writing, negotiation, interviewing, speech making, event management, fund raising and marketing. Girls will receive training in leadership with use of traditional and electronic media and networking skills to speak up on relevant social issues. These skills will help them create their own community newsletters twice a year. Girls from our existing projects have released 11 editions of their newsletters till date. The girls will be involved in gathering community news, writing articles, raising funds from local sources, designing, editing and selling these newsletters. _x000D_
Outreach activities will be in the form of awareness and information fairs on topics of Gender, Health and Career information, which will be organized in schools and colleges that poor girls and women attend.  _x000D_
The project assumes that empowerment of women and girls needs influencing the ecology around them. It will therefore adopt a multi sectoral approach involving various stakeholders such as family, peers and community members. Young male peers and parents of participating girls will be engaged through special activities to build their support for girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ empowerment. Networking with local NGOs, CBOs, local leaders will be done to create supportive environment for girls in the communities. _x000D_

project_name: Empowering Rural Women Entrepreneurs of North East India
project_summary:
Foundation for Social Transformation proposes a project that will promote rural womenÃ¢â¬â¢s entrepreneurship in Mahur in Dima Hasao district of Assam, India, which is a conflict zone rife with decades of ethnic clashes that have damaged the socioeconomic fabric. The women of the region have borne the maximum brunt of this conflict, and most now find themselves sole bread winners of large families, with little or no avenue of earning a steady livelihood. Foundation for Social Transformation (FST) had in the past year provided livelihood training to 50 women of Mahur. The women had received training on mushroom cultivation and tailoring. In addition they received training on Rights and entitlements, leadership and peace building along with finance and accounts management. FST had received remarkable response from the women, and most of those who were trained are now emerging as entrepreneurs. They have begun cultivating mushroom at home and selling it in nearby markets for a small profit. The proposed project would take the existing work in Mahur even further and help the women in establishing their own entrepreneurial ventures._x000D_
_x000D_
The project would focus on 30 rural women entrepreneurs selected from Mahur and allow them to set up their own enterprise, sustain it and promote women led entrepreneurship within their community. Out of the 30 women, 5 women will be selected on the basis of their existing small home based business which has the potential of expansion to reach out to new markets beyond their existing reach. These 5 women will be provided a seed funding to take their enterprise to the next level. Building capacities in entrepreneurship will permit the women to increase their income generating activity in an organized manner. Their income level will increase many-fold and they will support other women in their community by employing them and sourcing their products as well. They will find access to new markets and government schemes for women entrepreneurs._x000D_
_x000D_
Exposure to market links and business models will be provided to the women entrepreneurs in the project so that their understanding of business expands and they get new ideas for their enterprise. Training on packaging, branding and marketing will be provided to further develop their entrepreneurship skills. Exposure visits will be facilitated for the women to different organizations/women led businesses within North East India to learn about their activities and links to markets. _x000D_
Linking to banks, local credit and microfinance institutions and other resources for technical and managerial guidance would be organized. Marketing of products by networking with local and external agencies, buyers, would be facilitated. Resource support will be availed from like minded local organizations and institutions for training and exposure visits. Technical skills of the women entrepreneurs will also be developed to help them benefit from the use of technology in their entrepreneurial efforts._x000D_
The program will be documented in detail at various stages so as to track the progress and reflect on challenges faced and outcomes achieved. Once completed, the project will be reviewed to explore the possibility of replication across other parts of the region._x000D_

Everyone is now experiencing shifting seasons, climbing temperatures and rising sea levels that marks that life on earth is transforming.  Environmental degradation and Climate Change pose a threat to well Ã¢â¬â being of the people as well as national and global economy.  _x000D_
Developing country such as Cambodia is mostly at risk on the effects of Climate change which would likely to include more severe water scarcity and more frequent floods, resulting in crop failures and food shortages. Koh Kong for example would likely be affected by the rise of sea level and 1m rise can submerge 56% of the city and will possibly damage the infrastructure, agriculture, tourism, and livelihood.  _x000D_
_x000D_
This project addresses one of the organizations' vision which is to empower communities, especially women, to improve their well-being and the livelihood of their families by promoting the development of viable business practices, better health practices, social awareness and justice. Genesis Community of Transformation Cambodia also addresses strategy on climate change that aims to develop deeper awareness on Climate Change and its impact as well as potential solutions. GCT would like to build its capacity and capacity of other NGOs and local communities to understand and together with the local communities appropriately design and implement successful and sustainable community based Climate Change adaptation/mitigation projects._x000D_
_x000D_
There will be 3 phases on how to spend this grant. Phase 1 include Preparation Stage such as Meetings with 5 District Authorities,  2 Commune Committee on Women and Children (CCWC) and 18 Children and Women Council Committee (CWCC) representatives or the women group representative or the women group;  training on the impact of climate change to livelihoods, education and health; focus group discussion with the CCWC and CWCC; assessment and educational field trip.  Phase 2 would be training and application on adaptation practices on kitchen gardening and saving water in vegetable gardens and access to market. The 3rd phase in monitoring and evaluation._x000D_
_x000D_
The location of the project is in Sre Ambel District, Koh Kong Province.  This district has a total population is 40,576;  20,126 females.  GCT focuses on 2 communes and 6 villages in this district.  Srey Ambel District is located in southeastern Koh Kong Province. The Khmer Rouge controlled the area until 1996 and families are known as KH defectors continue to live there.   Ecologically it is composed of tropical rain forests, higher altitude, pine forests, inundated lowland forests, mangroves, rice fields, streams, coastline and islands.  The district is rich in natural resources.  Its upland forests are virtually the sole source of cut firewood and charcoal Ã¢â¬â used in cooking.  Sawn timber, whole logs and charcoal are exported in Thailand and Malaysia.  Forests provide wood and livelihoods to many of Sre AmbelÃ¢â¬â¢s people; however deforestation is occurring at such a rapid rate that it endangers not only the livelihoods of woodcutters but also the agricultural and marine based livelihoods of the district.  Soil erosion (aggravated by large Ã¢â¬â scale commercial cutting of forest concessions) is the major reason that farmers using slabs Ã¢â¬â and burn techniques in the upland forests abandon their farms after only two or three seasons.  The districtÃ¢â¬â¢s major river is already silted to the point that large boats find it difficult to reach the town, located only seven kilometers from the sea.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Thousands of families of both migrants and long term residents supplement their farming incomes or make their total living by cutting wood directly from the provinceÃ¢â¬â¢s forests.  The wood is sold in the form of whole logs, sawn timber, firewood, charcoal and poles.  Once a log is cut, it takes seven to ten days to bring it out of the mountains and to the saw mill or road where it can be sold. For at least two weeks of labor a woodcutter earns only five US dollars per log.  Logs of lesser quality are cut into small pieces, usually by women and children, and packaged for sale as firewood.  In order to eat, woodcutting families are increasingly forced to rely on cutting younger trees to make firewood and charcoal. As these trees are cut, there is less and less chance for the forests to continue growing to produce more wood for the future.  Responding to this challenge requires a number of strategies.  These could include traditional knowledge techniques, innovative technologies and new forms of social organization.  Taken together these approaches will provide viable alternatives for the villagers as they confront the new demands of making a living in an increasingly globalized environment._x000D_

project_summary:
Domestic violence causes serious damage to the physical and mental health of female victims. Economic dependence is among the top reasons why many accept to live with such danger everyday. Contributing to the economic independence of women survivors of domestic violence, CSAGA has cooperated with economical experts to conduct livelihood support programs in some provinces. Thanks to the support of generous sponsors as the Atlantic Philadeltrophi, Global Fund for Women and the Vietnam WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s Innovation Day, we have implemented numerous livelihood models in three different provinces in Vietnam, which have attracted more than 30 women affected by domestic violence. Currently, we are running two candle and natural soap making clubs in HaNam and BacNinh province and one laundry shop in Hanoi. The survivors are taught the practical skills and initial steps to enter the consumer market.After nearly a year of the livelihood support model, we have concluded that:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Livelihood support program for domestic violence survivors embracing candle and soap production and laundry service is a feasible model, which needs to be invested to develop as a sustainable occupation for the survivors._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Livelihood support program and Ã¢â¬ÅShare ClubÃ¢â¬Â brand have to be identified, particularly in the priority segmentation._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Ã¢â¬ÅShare ClubÃ¢â¬Â needs addressed and unified in the market as a signature brand of domestic violence survivors in Vietnam. This brand creates positive images of women overcoming their obstacles and having autonomy over their lives. As the result, brand development and positioning are essential to assert the strength and the ability of women. As well as promote the responsibility of individuals and the community as a whole in ending violence against women. _x000D_
Since the livelihood models had great achievements during the trial period,  we plan to further evolve the models by focusing on brand positioning and implementing a series of promotion activities to sell the hand-made and natural products. The brand must be tightly associated with positive images of women who overcame violence. Women who participate in the livelihood program increase their capacity and skills, which not only benefits them, but also the friends and children that they pass their skills on to. This program aims to help women achieve economic independence.. Through this program, we also aim to raise awareness about domestic violence, an imminent issues that can only be resolved if people work together. _x000D_
In addition to brand development and positioning, we will cooperate with production teams to implement a business plan for each product line. In this section, the marketing plan will be shaped to help the project meet the final targets of increasing womenÃ¢â¬â¢s life quality, both physicality and mentality._x000D_
The distinguishable feature of Ã¢â¬ÅShare ClubÃ¢â¬Â is that all products are made from natural ingredients from the provinces of the domestic violence survivors. With the monitoring and management of CSAGA, production teams will find the most suitable market segmentation to distribute the products. To gain the most success we will consult technical and economic experts to widen the market to sustainably raise the income for our female workers. Profits earned in the business process will be re-invested for replication of livelihood models and support office for domestic violence victims in CSAGA.

Nikweli aims to be an integral part of the social enterprise community in Tanzania and, potentially, East Africa. In the next three years, we expect to register 50,000 job seekers, have 400 companies paying for our service, and match 5000 job positions. The impact of longer term, more stable, formal sector employment for those who are transitioning out of the informal sector reverberates beyond the individual to their families and communities. Many would be women who are increasingly entering the ranks of paid employment and gaining financial independence. _x000D_
We pride ourselves in our social mission. For example, a top concern raised during our pilot interviews was that female job seekers would be sexually harassed by their employers. Our platform provides an avenue for female candidates to report abuses from companies. From our aggregated data, we can bring cases to organizations such as the Tanzania Gender Networking Programme.
By the end of the grant period, our project would have impacted the 200 people successfully matched with relevant formal sector positions. In addition, the 6000 job seekers that have signed up will have access to job alerts and job seeking tips sent through our network. _x000D_

We are committed to bringing more formal sector employment to informal sector workers who are interested in transitioning. We aim to reach a significant part of the market that is currently under tapped because of the job seekers lack knowledge, connections, and financial capital to search for employment. J-Palm Liberia is an oil palm production company in Liberia, specializing in processing crude palm oil (CPO) and palm kernel oil (PKO). J-Palm is committed to providing reliable access to high quality CPO and PKO to the Liberian Girls Soap Project at concessionary rates. _x000D_
CPO and PKO are the primary ingredients in laundry and toilet soaps in Liberia. project_summary:
The Liberian Girls Soap Project is a social enterprise that will provide soap making, entrepreneurship skills, and marketing training to 50 teenage mothers per annum in Liberia. After the training, every year the 50 young girls will be employed by the Liberian Girls Soap Company to make various kinds of soap (laundry soap, toilet soap, bath soap), and work in other functions such as sales, marketing, and operations management._x000D_
After two years of work at the Soap Company, the young girls will be given the opportunity to work in groups of up to 10 to form their own soap company under the Liberian Girls Soap Company brand/ franchise, and receive up to US$10,000 in startup capital. After two years of working for the Liberian Girls Soap Company, the girls will have developed a solid understanding of the chemistry of making soap to suit the Company's standards, and also understand standard operating procedures related to production and packaging. This will give them a significant advantage in starting and managing a successful company. With investments in marketing and advertising, we intend to develop a strong brand that will ensure demand for the product across Liberia. Thus, the newly formed startup companies will not have to invest heavily in marketing and advertising.

A fundamental explanation for sluggish employment growth in the formal sector is the countryÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s precariously low skills base, which has resulted in a basic mismatch between the skills available in the labor pool, and the skills demanded by employers in the labor market. _x000D_
This situation is even more pronounced among teenage mothers, most of who have to drop out of school and are extremely unlikely to re-enroll due to stigma and lack of income to cover childcare expenses to enable them to re-enroll. _x000D_

My project will bring a new sport and pastime for the girls in Jordan. It will give them a reason to stay active and healthy as well as continue to make new friends and spread the joy of playing.  Our project could even possibly start a youth national team in Jordan in which they would be able to travel the world to play other youth teams in various countries.  
By the end of the grant period, many Jordanian girls will learn skills they never would imagine having.  For those who are already athletic, the sport will challenge how they play all other sports and force them to start playing with integrity.  For the girls who are less athletic, this sport will give them the chance to finally find an activity in which they love and will play with all their hearts.  My project will also bring together girls who would normally never interact and they will start to become friends and change the way they think about 'the other'.  
If the girls are having a fun time and making new friends, I know I have done my job.  This project is not about making athletes out of girls but giving them the freedom to do so if they wish. project_summary:
Nepal Disabled Women Association (NDWA) has been working with women with disabilities (WWDs) in 17 remote districts of Nepal since 2009. We have formed 17 groups of Women with Disabilities, one in each district with 11 members in every group. These are women who have no access to education, livelihood and government entitlements. They are discriminated in their own families, communities and society at large. With the triple discrimination of gender, disability and poverty, Women with Disabilities in these areas live a life of helplessness and disgrace._x000D_
The objective of forming such groups was empowerment of Women with Disabilites through education, advocacy and skill training, so that they live a life with dignity and respect. However, though the groups were formed, due to lack of resources the objective couldn't be achieved. At present, the groups are supporting its members through financial assistance by holding monthly meetings._x000D_
_x000D_
With the financial grant from Project Inspire, NDWA will reach out to the women in all the 17 districts to achieve the said objective. In order to empower women, the groups will be legally registered as Disabled People's Organization (DPO), which will give authority to its members. The groups will be sensitized on disability and rights-based approach; will be trained on forming DPOs, functioning of DPOs, claim legal rights from government authorities and work for the development of Women with Disabilities in their respective districts. Further, the groups will receive leadership training and skill development training to enable them to live an independent life. _x000D_
_x000D_
We believe that process of empowerment of women with disabilities begins with taking charge of oneÃ¢â¬â¢s personal strengths, and using it to achieve oneÃ¢â¬â¢s personal goals. Empowerment lies in the acceptance of oneÃ¢â¬â¢s disability and limitations. Empowerment lies in not looking oneself as a victim but an agent of change for oneself and for others. _x000D_
_x000D_
The project aims at supporting the Women With Disabilities groups to gain an appropriate perspective towards their disabilities and societal attitudes. Due to various cultural practices prevalent in Nepal, people with disabilities are looked down upon as a disgrace to the society, and are mostly isolated and rejected from participation in any kind of development activities. For Women with Disabilities, such discrimination takes a dual fold. In order to break the societal myths and to live a respectful life, Women With Disabilities will have to learn to look at themselves with pride and not as an object of pity, and at the same time educate the society about their rights and capabilities. This can be attained through constant interactions, dialogues, sharing and providing training to the Women With Disabilities groups._x000D_
_x000D_
Formation of DPOs is one of the core objectives of the project for which the Women With Disabilities groups will be provided adequate training. As a member of DPOs, Women With Disabilities will be at a position to legally claim their entitlements from government and advocate for their rights. And as a responsibility of a DPOs the benefits will not just remain with its members, but will eventually reach to every other Women With Disabilities in their respective districts. In order to attain this, the groups will receive extensive training on leadership, rights and entitlements and administration. The groups will be empowered to not only assert their rights but to further empower other Women With Disabilities in their districts, generating more leaders. This will eventually lead the empowerment process to produce multiple effects._x000D_
_x000D_
Once the groups have gained the rights-based attitude and leadership in them, to further enhance their independence, economic empowerment will be a vital step which will make a huge impact on the lives of Women with Disabilities. The groups will receive training on entrepreneurship and business literacy. The groups will initiate entrepreneurial projects in their respective districts and ensure participation of as many Women with Disabilities as possible. The groups will be taught basics in micro financing, enterprise management and financial management. _x000D_
_x000D_
Hence, through the process of revealing oneÃ¢â¬â¢s potentials, giving voice to their opinions, participating in society to advocating for individual and collective rights of Women with Disabilities, to attaining economic independence, Women with Disabilities will be justly empowered in the society. This ladder to empowerment will create ripples and will eventually embrace each and every Women with Disabilities in the target areas of the project. _x000D_
_x000D_

project_summary:
The severe emotional damage of the sex trade on girls and women means that they need more intensive help and guidance than others._x000D_
Through Riverkids Helping Hands Club, we bring together fifteen women for a day when theyÃ¢â¬â¢re not sex workers but girls again. Instead of being pitied or priced, they will have a day with new friends, laughing and talking as ordinary women._x000D_
_x000D_
From trips to the waterpark, quiet picnics at the mountain, cooking lessons or just a game of volleyball, each time theyÃ¢â¬â¢ll try something new and inspiring. WeÃ¢â¬â¢ve lined up mentally wholesome activities that encourage teamwork, creativity and self-confidence. The Club is a social outreach avenue that breaks down barriers and helps them overcome the social stigma of being sex workers. They will share lunch together during their daytrip, and be back by 4pm for a quiet time at our centre to privately share with each other. _x000D_
_x000D_
Under the guidance of our Club leader, theyÃ¢â¬â¢ll be gently encouraged to talk to one another and our social workers towards a goal of integration into vocational training, with counselling and rehabilitation._x000D_
_x000D_
Training begins once they are ready to make the change in their lives, we help match their skills and interests with the training available. Typical classes such as sewing and hairdressing take about six months but some training classes are short, such as simple handicraft._x000D_
_x000D_
Our aim is that all the young women we work with will leave the sex industry. Our target is to have 80% of them enter vocational training or apprenticeships permanently within twelve months._x000D_
_x000D_
Our curriculum is carefully designed with consultation with our beneficiaries to learn what works best for them. Simply having a training program in place for the young women does not bring an end to their problems and suffering. _x000D_
_x000D_
We stress social and work skills, with basic literacy and business skills. Feedback from employers of our past graduates has been invaluable in refining critical work skills for these women to succeed. _x000D_
_x000D_
The program also pays for individual and group counselling, HIV, domestic violence and trafficking prevention workshops, family and financial planning workshops, health and hygiene talks, and Anger and Depression Management workshops conducted by both our staff and our NGO partners. _x000D_
_x000D_
When distance to our centres for studies, work or training is a challenge, we provide them with donated bicycles or subsidised transport. _x000D_
_x000D_
When they lack the capital for a sewing machine, we loan them our machines. This rent-to-own scheme enables our women to pay off the loan with the skills they learn and eventually run a small home business that allows them to watch over their children instead of engaging in unsafe work or leaving their children alone in the dangerous slums._x000D_
_x000D_
We also have a room with donated sewing machines and our trainers and assistant trainers who are our past graduates and very skilful, to provide direct training to our participants. _x000D_
_x000D_
When they do not have any suitable caretaker at home to look after their young children, we assist them by enrolling their children at our free Daycare centre so they can concentrate to complete the entire course. Otherwise, many of them have to rely on their older children to skip school and take care of their younger siblings or pay a large part of their income to a neighbour to look after their child. _x000D_
_x000D_
We assist them to get health checks and medicine, provide psychological support and counselling and visit their families to encourage them to support this new direction. _x000D_
_x000D_
A young girl between 18 and 20 may see giving up sex work to attend training with Riverkids a Ã¢â¬ËsacrificeÃ¢â¬â¢ of the income she used to be able to bring home, but we help them to see that their long-term future will not be possible if they do not choose to change from the high-risk sex work to a job that is safer for their health and will slowly develop to a sustainable income. _x000D_
_x000D_
To help them overcome family pressures and demands to return to their old jobs, we provide their families with Direct Cash Aid (DCA) that provides for weekly essentials such as utility bills, food, rent, medicine and education. _x000D_
_x000D_
The DCA program is vital to the success of the women as illustrated in our sex worker survey (attached) conducted in August 2012. On page 16, the top three reasons for what hindered womenÃ¢â¬â¢s transition out of the sex industry were lack of money (65%), lack of support (23%) and lack of skills (18%). The DCA component provides financial stability during their vocational transition, while linking the income to training attendance, and educational and health goals for their children. _x000D_
_x000D_
As Project InspireÃ¢â¬â¢s grant award is US$25,000, Riverkids will co-share 80% of the US$12,700 DCA, leaving US$2,540 to be sponsored by Project Inspire._x000D_
_x000D_
In Cambodia, we are part of a network of NGOs whom we can send our participants to for specialised skills training. Some of these partners are Hagar International, Friends International, Daughters of Cambodia, Pour un Sourire d'Enfant (PSE) and Bloom._x000D_
_x000D_
We also have an internal list of company contacts such as hotels, restaurants and beauty salons that we send our participants to after they complete the course. Our micro-business team gets regular invites to seminars whereby they showcase the handicraft and school uniforms made by our participants to other NGOs and companies to increase our local client circle. _x000D_
_x000D_
We have developed a sustainable structure to teach sewing over the years and built a co-operative team that measures, sews and quality-controls school uniforms. Our current clients are Catholic Relief Services, Character Montessori, Asian Hope, Who Will, Sunrise, New Life, Hotel Nine and Children for Change._x000D_
_x000D_
We open up our Computer Class for our Recruitment Co-ordinator to guide them to draft basic resumes using the computers and help them to prepare for interviews. This includes appropriate dressing, personal image and handling interviews.

project_name: Touch World: Empowering Women Prison Inmates through the Creative Arts
project_summary:
Time in prisons is designed to reform criminals so that they re-enter society as responsible citizens. However, when released, women lack vocational skills and are often ostracized by their families and neighborhoods, leaving them financially and emotionally vulnerable at a time when they need the most support. Their lack of vocational skills and stigma from time in prisons compounds their financial and emotional struggles as they find themselves in the very conditions that often led to crime, condemning them to a cycle of poverty and crime. Therefore, successful re-entrance into society requires vocational and emotional preparation of inmates through training and practical experience, and the trust and acceptance of society and future employers through the reduction of stigma and empathy. _x000D_
Touch World eases this transition back into society by teaching the creative arts to inmates of Correctional Homes. The women inmates learn creative skills like music, dance, oration, theater, painting, sports and sculpture, from professional trainers while in the Correctional Homes. The inmates then put up a public cultural dance-drama performance, gaining practical experience in performance, music orchestration, sound design, costume making, and event management. Moreover, the women inmates regain their confidence and self-esteem as they and the audience begin to see them as artists and performers rather than criminals, and bonded through culture._x000D_
_x000D_
We plan to use Project Inspire funds to expand our operations in three steps. The first is to cover production costs such as costume hire, performance hall rent and lighting costs, sound design and orchestration, and video projector costs, as we increase the number and size of shows performed. Touch World has already grown from one to three correctional facilities in West Bengal, India, and the inmates have put up 90 shows across India in major cities like Mumbai, Delhi and Kolkata, performing in prestigious art and dance festivals. Widespread appreciation of our productions is essential for our performers to be recognized as professional by themselves and future employers. We will allocate $10 000 to this. _x000D_
_x000D_
The second is to expand the range of courses offered to include other vocational courses including nurse training and beautician courses that would enhance the womenÃ¢â¬â¢s skill set and ensure they gain meaningful employment. These two courses are particularly important as many women inmates have been employed as caregivers upon release. By offering a combination of more prestigious and traditionally vocational courses, we will be able to attract more participants including those who do not or whose families do not view the arts as vocationally practical but will nevertheless benefit from a creative outlet and work experience from partaking in a professional production. We will allocate $10 000 to this. _x000D_
_x000D_
The third is to increase the number of committed trainers, formally hiring current and new trainers so as to ensure a small student-teacher ratio and professional standard for our public performances even as we undertake bigger productions with more participants. Many of our dance trainers are currently teaching pro bono, leaving their commitment and training quality dependent on their financial stability and spare time available. The high quality of our performances is crucial to the sustainability of our project as it allows us to increase total revenue for both our operational expenses and the Prisoners Welfare Fund through an increased number of show tickets sold and higher ticket prices. So far, the Prisoners Welfare Fund, which serves as remuneration and helps to fund the prisoners when they have family emergencies, has accumulated USD $150 000 from our productions. The production also serves as the key platform for showcasing our performersÃ¢â¬â¢ abilities and discipline to the public so as to enhance future employability. This innovative and professional display of the creative arts will have the added benefit of elevating its status in India, making it more vocationally appealing. We will allocate $5000 to this._x000D_

project_summary:
Founded in 2007 and based in the city of Kolkata, India, IswarSankalpa is a registered non-profit organization that aims to ensure the dignity and holistic well-being of persons with mental health challenges, particularly the homeless people with psychosocial disabilities.IswarSankalpa focuses on providing overall resettlement and rehabilitation opportunities to homeless psycho-socially disabled persons, in an effort to help mainstream them as productive members back into society. This is achieved through supervised pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy, as well as, facilitated participation of the beneficiary in select, occupational and vocational activities, all of which ultimately aim in restoring the personÃ¢â¬â¢s self-confidence, self-reliance and independent living. The current projects of IswarSankalpa are Outreach Programme, Community based Day Care Centres, Shelter for urban homeless women with psycho-social disabilities, Vocational Training Programme for the mentally challenged and recovered persons, Urban Mental Health Programme in conjunction with Kolkata Municipality Health Wards and Emergency Response Unit to respond to crisis situations involving mentally ill persons living on the streets._x000D_
Therapeutic Treatment, Capacity Building and Rehabilitation Program for Urban Homeless Women with Psycho-social Disabilities_x000D_
A womenÃ¢â¬â¢s shelter Ã¢â¬â Sarbari Ã¢â¬â was founded by IswarSankalpa in collaboration with the Kolkata Municipal Corporation in April 2010. Sarbari gives mentally unwell women who live on the streets a place of safe, secure shelter away from abuse Ã¢â¬â whether it is sexual, physical and/or social. Every day, approximately 80 women in the shelter attempt learning new skills and get involved in the wide range of activities conducted at the shelter. Apart from comprehensive therapeutic treatment and medical care, daily nutrition and clothing, the residents also receive occupational and vocational training which help them resettle back into the community, living a life of dignity, earning a livelihood and sustaining themselves._x000D_

Objectives:_x000D_
1)	To ensure protection and mental health treatment for urban destitute women with psycho-social disabilities._x000D_
2)	To empower the recovering women with vocational training and functional literacy training._x000D_
3)	To give livelihood support to recovered women through employment/income generation opportunities_x000D_
4)	To reintegrate them with families where possible_x000D_
5)	To ensure the rights of the psycho-social disabled persons in the society and enable their access to social welfare entitlements_x000D_
_x000D_
The grant of USD25,000 will enable IswarSankalpa to provide to 25 urban homeless women with psycho-social disabilities the following support:_x000D_
_x000D_
1.	Shelter care_x000D_
2.	Diagnosis and appropriate mental health treatment _x000D_
3.	Individual and Group Counseling_x000D_
4.	Skills Development Training_x000D_
5.	Recreation Opportunities_x000D_
6.	Livelihood Support_x000D_
7.	Access to social Security Benefit_x000D_
8.	Restoration_x000D_
_x000D_
1.Shelter Care:_x000D_
25 destitute women with psycho-social disabilities will be lodged at Sarbari Shelter for a period of one year or until recovery and rehabilitation. At the shelter, each beneficiary will be provided with individual bedding, 4 times nutritious meals, clothing and personal hygiene items in an environment of protection and care._x000D_
 _x000D_
2.Diagnosis and appropriate mental health treatment:_x000D_
Diagnosis of the mental disorder will be carried out by qualified mental health professionals. Following the diagnosis, a treatment plan will be prescribed and accordingly pharmacotherapy and psychiatric therapy will be provided to the client. Regular check-up will be conducted by in-house psychiatrists to ascertain level of improvement. Often the women, due to unhygienic living conditions on the streets and inability towards self-care are found with medical conditions like maggots infested open wounds, skin diseases, general weakness etc. In such cases, medical care will be provided to ensure their physical well-being._x000D_
_x000D_
3.Individual and Group Counseling:_x000D_
Counseling will be provided by professionally qualified counselors. Counseling will be conducted individually as well as in group. 3 individual counseling and 2 group sessions will be carried out per week. One to One Counseling will include- Rapport Building, Negotiation with the beneficiary/client at every step of treatment and Rehabilitation, Supportive and motivational counseling, Action-oriented counseling involving positive and negative reinforcement and ventilation. Group Sessions will emphasize on recovery of Cognitive Functions and Logical Thinking.  _x000D_
_x000D_
4.	Skills Development Training_x000D_
The skill building intervention program has formulated structures and frameworks for the engagement of these women towards their rehabilitation by addressing the following aspects:_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Life Skills: Maintaining personal hygiene and physical care, self help skills which helps the person in day to day living including household chores like cleaning, washing and cooking_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Communication Skills: Emphasis on the right kind of verbal and nonverbal (especially emotional) expression and interaction_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Functional Literacy Skills: Lessons to include Alphabet training, Numerical training colours and shapes, Currency and cash computation, Signing own name, Common word recognition, Telling time etc. Computers will be used extensively as audio- visual teaching aid will make the teaching-learning transaction effective._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Social Skills: Emphasis on conducting oneself in a socially appropriate manner and instilling small social responsibilities like buying vegetables from the local market, or extending help to mates._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Vocational Skills: Depending on the individual aptitudes, interests and abilities of the person, training is imparted through activities which could meaningfully engage the person and also be a possible future source of revenue for them. The three levels of training to be imparted will be as follows_x000D_
a)	Basic: gardening, jewellery making_x000D_
b)	Intermediate: Paper products, Food items_x000D_
c)	Advanced: Embroidery/Stitching, Tailoring_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Service Oriented Skills: When the above skills will develop to a certain level, the women will be encouraged to take upon service oriented trainings and job placements for their livelihood like Professional Housekeeping, Nursing Training, Training in Beauty Care etc._x000D_
_x000D_
5.	Recreation Opportunities_x000D_
The centre will celebrate various local festivals and occasions giving the residents opportunities to arrange and participate in celebrations and performances like dance, music, drama. At the shelter there is facility to watch TV and listening to radio/music. Various games will be organized to help develop a team spirit and also improve their motor coordination. Weekly outings will be arranged to parks and nearby places of interest. Yearly activity like picnic will be arranged._x000D_
_x000D_
6.	Livelihood Support_x000D_
The items produced by the vocational training unit will be marketed by IswarSankalpa to help the women earn while learning. Participation in various exhibitions, tying up with different city shops will create channels for sale of products. The women can later independently pursue the earning opportunity by applying the newly developed skills or find related employment with assistance from IswarSankalpa. Our former beneficiaries are now employed in hospitals as nurses and as housekeeping staff in hotels._x000D_
_x000D_
7.	Access to Social Security Benefits_x000D_
IswarSankalpa will make application to designated authority and will conduct necessary advocacy, sensitization and follow up to facilitate the receipt of ration cards by the beneficiaries. The ration card is a giant leap towards giving the psycho-socially disabled persons an identity as citizens of India. The Indian ration card, which is mainly used for drawing subsidized food and fuel, is an important document for the economically and socially marginalized people for subsistence, identity and to remain connected with the government database. It has become the proof of their existence. The ration card which is a valid document accepted by all public and private organizations, will guarantee the women a host of social security benefits such as disability benefits, opening of accounts in the bank, and employment. Similarly, Adhar cards and Disability cards will also be organized for the beneficiaries._x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
8.	Restoration_x000D_
As the treatment progresses, the psyco-socially disabled persons start recovering the cognitive faculties and they remember their name and their homes. All efforts will made to locate their home and family members with the help of local police and restore the beneficiaries to their families. If the families cannot be located, or refuse to take the woman back, IswarSankalpa will make other provisions for the safe relocation of such cases in institutions or to integrate them back in the community. In case of reintegration with the family, the family members will be counselled about the state of the restored woman. Emphasis will be given on the treatment plan and information will be given about local hospitals where they will be able to continue with the treatment. The social workers and restoration officers will conduct home-visits to follow-up. _x000D_

project_details_other:
We believe that Somachange will aid greatly in stabilizing communities in Mogadishu. More female heads of household will be able to grow their businesses, creating jobs and raising income for themselves and their employees. Additionally, more girls in Mogadishu will remain in school, giving Somalia an ever-greater chance for a bright future. 
We will have helped between five and fifteen female-headed families keep and grow their business while their young children continue to have access to education. 
We are committed to helping female entrepreneurs in Somalia access the necessary tools for business growth and to decrease the number of children, particularly girls, that are coerced by financial need to quit school at a young age.  
We will carefully monitor the compliance of loan recipients to ensure that they abide by the condition of keeping their children in school. At the end of our pilot program, we will assess the ability of our recipients to adhere to the repayment schedule and the percentage of loans repaid. As we expand Somachange, we will use the data from our pilot program to further refine and expand our operations. 
We currently have no committed funders for Somachange, but we are raising funds through individuals donors on Indiegogo. Past success with donation campaigns leads us to believe that we will be able to gather significant funding through an aggressive social media campaign and campus fundraising at the College of William and Mary.
project_summary:
The overall mission of Aadamiga is to identify and implement various small projects aimed to improve the quality of life for families, particularly women and children,  in Mogadishu, Somalia. Past projects have focused on attempts to build a school serving children living in IDP camps in Mogadishu and providing support services for victims of sexual assault. _x000D_
Our current project is entitled Somachange, and seeks to simultaneously strengthen the economy and education access in Mogadishu through an innovative approach to microfinance. In the summer of 2013, Filsan Darman, the founder of Aadamiga, went to Somalia and asked groups of impoverished female entrepreneurs to identify their primary professional challenges. Their responses indicate that, though their businesses were active and moderately successful, lack of access to initial capital and training was inhibiting their business growth and preventing them from increasing their profits. As a result, many female entrepreneurs employed their children, particularly their daughters, in order to reduce their overhead. These assets are readily available to business owners in more developed nations, and are considered necessary for entrepreneurs of all backgrounds and skill levels to be successful. Our aim is to fill this gap in the local economic infrastructure in order to help jump-start a struggling region. _x000D_
_x000D_
We intend to offer small loans to mothers in Mogadishu who are currently operating small businesses. In addition to capital, these women will be offered business courses aimed at teaching them basic bookkeeping skills and business methodology. In exchange for these services, each woman will ensure their own children's enrollment in school, and will complete the program by repaying their loan in full to Aadamiga. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our hope is that, as Somachange expands, we can simultaneously aid female entrepreneurs in growing their business, and increase the number of children, particularly girls, who complete their education in Mogadishu. We believe that this will aid in creating a more stable environment for families in Mogadishu and a brighter future for Somalia. _x000D_
_x000D_
As a small organization, we intend to begin our project with a low-budget pilot program. We will initially make small loans to five Somali women, identified by Aadamiga as currently active and potentially successful business owners with school-age children who lack only the resources we intend to provide. Our resources will be allocated to the following expenditures. We will be hiring two full-time employees who will be charged with identifying viable loan candidates, training recipients in business methodology, ensuring the proper usage of loans and compliance with terms, collecting payment, record-keeping, and general management. We will be investing in high-quality training materials for our business courses. And of course, we will be granting small loans for qualified business owners. _x000D_
_x000D_
We previously estimated that this venture will cost USD$5000. With the addition of extra funds, we could afford to offer higher loans to those qualified entrepreneurs, and to expand our pilot program to as many as 15 women in Mogadishu.  _x000D_
_x000D_
We anticipate that this pilot program will be successful and that Somachange could have a great positive effect on the economy and education system in Mogadishu. We believe that there is still hope for Somalia, and we intend to do all we can to provide the necessary resources for those living in the region to build a better state for themselves. _x000D_
project_details: We intend to solve two problems. The first is to fill the desperate need in Mogadishu for access to capital for entrepreneurs, particular female heads of household with school-age children operating low-revenue businesses. The second is to give more children, and particularly girls, in Mogadishu the opportunity to complete their education.

project_summary:
As part of Grace Management & Consultancy Services Pte Ltd (GMC)Ã¢â¬â¢s corporate social responsibility in Myanmar, we visited Thaungyi a village in the state of Ayeyarwady in Dec 2013. We saw first-hand the living conditions of the homes of those women from Thaungyi who left for Singapore to work as domestic workers (helpers or maids). We were particularly touched by the warmth and the hospitality given to us by the villagers. We also saw the resilience of the villagers in their efforts in building the community church and its kindergarten for their communities.  Situated in a remote area, the access to Thaungyi is only via boat and is a daily tedious affair. We have submitted a 5 min video pitch to complement the project information at http://youtu.be/o9Wk0zxPiFk_x000D_
_x000D_
In terms of demographic profile of Thaungyi, there are proportional more women and children in Thaungyi. According to our sources, more than 200 women were reportedly to have left Thaungyi to work overseas as domestic workers in Singapore since 2011. _x000D_
_x000D_
It was also around the same time that one of our project members completed the song, Ã¢â¬ËAbove AllÃ¢â¬â¢ which you hear at our 5-min video pitch. This song is dedicated to all migrant workers who travel afar to work in order to provide for the family. We hope the lyrics will encourage, motivate and provide strength for women who choose to work overseas in times of trial.  This is part of GMCÃ¢â¬â¢s new initiative to enhance the emotional well-being of domestic workers working in Singapore, apart from teaching workers the necessary skills and knowledge to work and live in Singapore.    _x000D_
_x000D_
As a leading training provider in Singapore, we see compelling opportunities for gender empowerment through information and communication technologies (ICT Ã¢â¬â internet radio streaming, mobile phones and smartphone applications) as these tools afforded women opportunities to experience in increased socio-cultural, personal, and psychological empowerment. Further, with smartphonesÃ¢â¬â¢ penetration expected to deepen in emerging markets such as Myanmar, fuelled by broadband networks, this convergence is going to transform and accelerate the positive benefits of community radio and telecenters for women._x000D_
_x000D_
Myanmar awarded 2 telco licences to the private sector in early 2013.  While issues on formal award have surfaced and caused delays, we expect major cities and townships to be broadband mobile ready by 2016.  Other technologies available are satellite based immarsat and iridium systems; and multichannel video and data distribution system (MVDDS)._x000D_
_x000D_
With the convergence of Ã¢â¬ÅAbove AllÃ¢â¬Â, the visit in Dec 2013 and the advancement in ICT, it inspired us and the idea of Project Affinity was borne. Project Affinity will be a social enterprise with the support of GMC. Project AffinityÃ¢â¬â¢s present mission is to aim to set up community media center (CMC) at 1 village in Myanmar and communities connecting women working overseas via internet radio streaming. The CMC will make ICT available to villages with the aim to improve the livelihood of women by:-_x000D_
a.  Equipping women with IT knowledge and skills;_x000D_
b.  Enabling access to key information and opportunities;_x000D_
c.  Empowering women through connection via social media, participation in talk-back radio and community-mobilized events._x000D_
d. Building an alumni of ex-Singapore migrant workers. In the longer term, we aim to connect domestic workers through ICTs by:-_x000D_
(i) Using the friends and alliances networks formed in Singapore_x000D_
(ii) Integrating communities across boundaries to contribute to the overall progress of women in ASEAN._x000D_
_x000D_
The support from Project Inspire will enable us to immediately start-up the Project Affinity beginning at Thaungyi with the necessary infrastructure. In terms of mobile networks, there are already data signals that allow for the use of smartphones. For those villagers who do not have phones, the CMC would in turn serve as a communication center.  Standalone electrical power and high-gain antennae are required._x000D_
_x000D_
To assure that the project is sustainable and effective, the following are key guiding principles:-_x000D_
a. Enabling ICT mastery as a knowledgeable user of the internet, is critical in driving connectivity and development acceleration individual women's lives and their communities;_x000D_
b. Ensuring that primary ICT content needs are driven indigenously, and locally relevant;_x000D_
c. Combining physical premises and virtual communities to drive education, development and prosperity for the community;_x000D_
d. Creating the ICT environment to enable women to be self-reliant and providing them with entrepreneurial opportunities to share and develop best practices within the community;_x000D_
e. Tapping into SingaporeÃ¢â¬â¢s ICT infrastructure and the smartphone proliferation to drive innovation;_x000D_
f.  Forming a separate legal entity as a social enterprise so as to better coordinate and manage the above mentioned activities;_x000D_
g. Mobilising Singapore to donate old or un-needed smartphones to be re-deployed to villages in source countries._x000D_

Human Help Network Foundation Thailand (HHNFT) - June 2014_x000D_
Project Inspire 2014_x000D_
Introduction_x000D_
We would be delighted if you would kindly consider our Child Protection and Development Centre for Ã¢â¬ÅProject Inspire 2014Ã¢â¬Â. We are an existing organisation operating in Pattaya and we are pleased to provide you with the following information in support of our application. In addition to this short report, we enclose a recent quarterly newsletter and also details of young girls we have taken into the Centre because of the abuse they have been subjected to whilst living on the street or in the family home._x000D_
The Child Protection and Development Centre_x000D_
The Human Help Network (HHN) was founded in 1990 to help underprivileged children throughout the world and The Child Protection and Development Centre (CPDC) is one of our most successful projects. It is a non-government (NGO) and non-profit organisation, which began its work in Pattaya, Thailand during 2009 to fight child abuse, trafficking and exploitation in Asia and particularly in and around Chonburi._x000D_
As a world renowned tourist destination, Pattaya attracts many foreign visitors on holiday and also nationals with their families looking for employment. Regrettably, as everyone pursues their individual goals, all too often, the young members of our society suffer neglect and abuse. Young girls are sadly the recipients of much of the abuse when they are used in the tourist sex industry and within many of the poorer immigrant families coming into the area._x000D_
CPDC has become recognised for its good work with abused and disadvantaged children in a relatively short period of time and recently achieved 3rd Runner-Up position in the Thailand NGO Awards in 2013, recognising the dedication and professionalism of the entire CPDC Team._x000D_
At present there are 64 children resident at the centre between the ages of 4 and 18. 34 of the children are young girls who have been physically or mentally abused at the hands of unscrupulous individuals on the street or by family members. The girls are referred to the centre by other organisations or they are discovered by Outreach workers who encourage them to visit our Drop-in Centre._x000D_
The CPDC operates on a Ã¢â¬Åfour stepÃ¢â¬Â help and rehabilitation process_x000D_
1) Outreach work: Our specially trained outreach staff visit places in Pattaya where street children seek shelter or employment with the aim of establishing contact and rapport with the children. The outreach team work closely with the local police force and NGOs when they are investigating the circumstances of children who are reported begging, drug-dealing or selling themselves. Our social workers work hard to earn the trust of the children to assess their individual situation before offering them appropriate help and support. In cases of interest to TIP our staff will cooperate to help secure first-hand evidence against child traffickers and the criminal networks behind the scenes._x000D_
2) Drop-in Centre: This is generally the first access point to CPDC for children living on the street. Our drop-in centre is located centrally in Pattaya and provides the childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s basic need for food, clothing, shelter and first aid. The Centre is open 24/7 365 days a year and provides protection, security and advice to children and young adults as required. As part of the centreÃ¢â¬â¢s rehabilitation plan, social workers explore the possibility of reuniting the children with their families, organize counselling and psychological help for victims of TIP or, when necessary, organize long term accommodation. The drop-in centre works closely with government authorities such as the Social Development and Security Office of Chonburi, anti-trafficking NGOs (most notably MOU and the Chonburi Emergency Home), as well as Police Region II and the local police force._x000D_
3) Rehabilitation: The CPDC offers a more permanent residence to children taking the journey into rehabilitation and reintegration into society and we will be able to accommodate up to 80-100 children annually.  A team of professional social workers, teachers, psychologists and nurses provide the children with a safe and loving home environment and are devoted to the childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s care and development. Education is a crucial factor in our rehabilitation program therefore we ensure all the children attend local schools or boarding schools and, if necessary, receive special tutoring or non-formal education if appropriate._x000D_
4) Prevention: To combat child trafficking and exploitation we begin at grassroots level, conducting awareness-raising activities with the parents and children of poor communities in and around Pattaya. For example, we conduct activities to educate parents about the danger of any involvement with traffickers. We also run programmes in the slum communities to provide advice to the parents and encourage them to send the children to school and protect them against involvement with drugs and criminals. A mobile team provided by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime and the Japanese government, support and help our staff to intensify their activities in the slum areas._x000D_
Looking Forward_x000D_
Since CPDC was established it has received local and national recognition for its initiatives and programmes, which it has implemented to improve the lives of countless young children at risk. During the course of our work however, we have come to recognise the extent of the problem we are fighting. There is still so much that can be done to improve the lives of the boys and girls who are being or have been abused. _x000D_
It is particularly heart breaking to see young single mothers abort their babies or place the babies into the local orphanage as soon as they are born. We want to provide a day care facility for the babies to allow the mothers to learn how to eventually support themselves and their babies. To achieve this goal we plan to set up a media centre in our education centre at CPDC and use the internet and Facebook to advertise this service to those in need._x000D_

Human Help Network Foundation Thailand (HHNFT) - June 2014_x000D_
Project Inspire 2014_x000D_
Introduction_x000D_
We would be delighted if you would kindly consider our Child Protection and Development Centre for Ã¢â¬ÅProject Inspire 2014Ã¢â¬Â. We are an existing organisation operating in Pattaya and we are pleased to provide you with the following information in support of our application. In addition to this short report, we enclose a recent quarterly newsletter and also details of young girls we have taken into the Centre because of the abuse they have been subjected to whilst living on the street or in the family home._x000D_
The Child Protection and Development Centre_x000D_
The Human Help Network (HHN) was founded in 1990 to help underprivileged children throughout the world and The Child Protection and Development Centre (CPDC) is one of our most successful projects. It is a non-government (NGO) and non-profit organisation, which began its work in Pattaya, Thailand during 2009 to fight child abuse, trafficking and exploitation in Asia and particularly in and around Chonburi._x000D_
As a world renowned tourist destination, Pattaya attracts many foreign visitors on holiday and also nationals with their families looking for employment. Regrettably, as everyone pursues their individual goals, all too often, the young members of our society suffer neglect and abuse. Young girls are sadly the recipients of much of the abuse when they are used in the tourist sex industry and within many of the poorer immigrant families coming into the area._x000D_
CPDC has become recognised for its good work with abused and disadvantaged children in a relatively short period of time and recently achieved 3rd Runner-Up position in the Thailand NGO Awards in 2013, recognising the dedication and professionalism of the entire CPDC Team._x000D_
At present there are 64 children resident at the centre between the ages of 4 and 18. 34 of the children are young girls who have been physically or mentally abused at the hands of unscrupulous individuals on the street or by family members. The girls are referred to the centre by other organisations or they are discovered by Outreach workers who encourage them to visit our Drop-in Centre._x000D_
The CPDC operates on a Ã¢â¬Åfour stepÃ¢â¬Â help and rehabilitation process_x000D_
1) Outreach work: Our specially trained outreach staff visit places in Pattaya where street children seek shelter or employment with the aim of establishing contact and rapport with the children. The outreach team work closely with the local police force and NGOs when they are investigating the circumstances of children who are reported begging, drug-dealing or selling themselves. Our social workers work hard to earn the trust of the children to assess their individual situation before offering them appropriate help and support. In cases of interest to TIP our staff will cooperate to help secure first-hand evidence against child traffickers and the criminal networks behind the scenes._x000D_
2) Drop-in Centre: This is generally the first access point to CPDC for children living on the street. Our drop-in centre is located centrally in Pattaya and provides the childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s basic need for food, clothing, shelter and first aid. The Centre is open 24/7 365 days a year and provides protection, security and advice to children and young adults as required. As part of the centreÃ¢â¬â¢s rehabilitation plan, social workers explore the possibility of reuniting the children with their families, organize counselling and psychological help for victims of TIP or, when necessary, organize long term accommodation. The drop-in centre works closely with government authorities such as the Social Development and Security Office of Chonburi, anti-trafficking NGOs (most notably MOU and the Chonburi Emergency Home), as well as Police Region II and the local police force._x000D_
3) Rehabilitation: The CPDC offers a more permanent residence to children taking the journey into rehabilitation and reintegration into society and we will be able to accommodate up to 80-100 children annually.  A team of professional social workers, teachers, psychologists and nurses provide the children with a safe and loving home environment and are devoted to the childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s care and development. Education is a crucial factor in our rehabilitation program therefore we ensure all the children attend local schools or boarding schools and, if necessary, receive special tutoring or non-formal education if appropriate._x000D_
4) Prevention: To combat child trafficking and exploitation we begin at grassroots level, conducting awareness-raising activities with the parents and children of poor communities in and around Pattaya. For example, we conduct activities to educate parents about the danger of any involvement with traffickers. We also run programmes in the slum communities to provide advice to the parents and encourage them to send the children to school and protect them against involvement with drugs and criminals. A mobile team provided by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime and the Japanese government, support and help our staff to intensify their activities in the slum areas._x000D_
Looking Forward_x000D_
Since CPDC was established it has received local and national recognition for its initiatives and programmes, which it has implemented to improve the lives of countless young children at risk. During the course of our work however, we have come to recognise the extent of the problem we are fighting. There is still so much that can be done to improve the lives of the boys and girls who are being or have been abused. _x000D_
It is particularly heart breaking to see young single mothers abort their babies or place the babies into the local orphanage as soon as they are born. We want to provide a day care facility for the babies to allow the mothers to learn how to eventually support themselves and their babies. To achieve this goal we plan to set up a media centre in our education centre at CPDC and use the internet and Facebook to advertise this service to those in need._x000D_
