project_name: Support for Income Generating Activities and Capacity Building Efforts for Young mothers (SUFIGA)
project_summary: The project will alleviate extreme poverty and hunger among 95 young mothers who dropped out of school due to teenage pregnancy in urban poor communities of Kampala city. They will be identified in the community by opinion leaders and peer educators and will be enrolled for practical skills training in making soil bricks also known as stabilised compressed earth blocks which will allow the girls to easily manufacture high quality bricks and as a result, they will receive a high income for themselves and their children. Stabilised soil bricks technology offers a cost effective, environmentally sound masonry system. It is manufactured by compacting earth (murrum/sub soil) mixed with a stabilizer such as cement or lime and has a wide application in construction. The girls will be availed with a number of manual machines which compact the readily available soil to attain dense, even sized masonry. The bricks are then laid out in the sun and cured rather than being fired.  There is a high growing demand for construction bricks in Uganda since this is a quickly growing sector of the economy yet almost all forests have been encroached propelling government to enact strict regulations on cutting down trees. This trend has resulted in fired bricks becoming expensive to be afforded creating opportunity for this low cost new invention which applies environmentally friendly local technology. After a successful completion of the course, the young mothers will be encouraged to form groups of 5s and further be trained in business proposal writing and small business management skills as well as saving, thereafter, they will be asked to submit proposals which will be funded under the revolving fund scheme and each group will supervise its members. Started businesses will be monitored and evaluated on performance by the organization, groups will return interest free cash loaned to them as start up capital to the fund. This give chance to the rest of the mothers to benefit in the next round thus ensuring project continuity even after the elapse of funding from Project Inspire.

project_name: RE-USABLE SANITARY PADS FOR GIRLS IN NYANZA- KENYA
project_summary:
About 65% of women and girls in Kenya cannot afford sanitary pads. Evidence suggests that the period around puberty is one in which many girls drop out of school or are absent from school for significant periods of time. Menstruation causes Kenyan adolescent girls to lose an average of 3.5 million learning days per month.Limited access to safe, affordable, convenient and appropriate methods of dealing with menstruation has far reaching implications for the rights physical, social and mental well being of many adolescent girls in Kenya. Our project is about making re-usable pads (N-Care pads) which will radically prove to create an environment where women and girls can step boldly into the promise of their future._x000D_
The goal of this project is to empower vulnerable girls and women through the provision of re-usable pads, capacity building on menstrual hygiene management and reproductive health for improved performance and self esteem. This will entail the production and distribution of re-usable sanitary pads as well as ensuring provision of menstrual hygiene management education and facilities to girls in primary schools in two counties of Nyanza Region. _x000D_
One packet which we will name Ã¢â¬ËProject Inspire N-Care PadsÃ¢â¬â¢, of the re-usable pads will be sufficient to meet the sanitary needs of a girl for a year. The adoption of re-usable pads is also more environmentally friendly than the disposable type and the training provided covers safe disposal and management aspects as well._x000D_

The active involvement of female adolescents, as well as all citizens of Cambodia in violence against women using ICT and social media for information sharing and dialogues will push the agenda for change and progress toward protecting the rights of women. Recognizing, addressing, and eliminating violence against women in Cambodia benefits not only women, but also the overall society of Cambodia such that it promotes gender equality and empowerment of women, and the country's social and economic development. Bridging ICT and VAW will help create a platform for increasing awareness on VAW and be one step further toward the advancement of Cambodia's people livelihood.
We expect that ICT will aide efforts toward raising awareness on VAW in Cambodia. ICT allows female adolescents the ability to connect and organize ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬ÃâadvocatesÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬ÃÂ of women's rights in Cambodia, especially for many women of Cambodia who are unable to share their voice or join movements, thus serving as a facilitator to garner attention from many key support networks/groups that act as springboards for social impact and support. The project directly impacts female adolescents by providing information on political and human rights for women and training on how to use ICT for ending gender based violence. At the completion of the project, female adolescents will develop ICT skills, familiarity with journalism practice, learn about equality policies and women's rights, and participate in prevention of violence against women activities. 
The project is committed in providing a safe platform for female adolescents to share grievances, engage in open dialogue, receive advice from survivors of violence or specialists in women's empowerment, and provide information about women's rights using ICT and social media. Open Institute will achieve this goal by providing the necessary ICT and CJ trainings and information about government policies and women's rights to female adolescents in Cambodia. _x000D_
Through ICT training, we are committed in providing the tools that will assist participants in learning how to manage a social media account, create newsletters, operate an online blog, and navigate email functions. project_name: Ã¢â¬ÅI am woman, hear me roarÃ¢â¬Â: The catalytic role of ICT in ending violence against women in Cambodia.
project_summary:
Over the past 20 years, the Royal Government of Cambodia have greatly invested in enhancing the quality and living conditions of the people, Ã¢â¬Åimproving the status of women who are the backbone of national economy and society, and to transforming youth to become an important driving force for development in every sectorÃ¢â¬Â (Rectangular Strategy, 2013). To achieve this goal, one area of focus was on Cambodian women's empowerment (Neary Rattanak) and the implementation of the National Action Plan to Prevent Violence Against Women. However, the body of law needs strengthening and it alone is not suffice. For instance, Cambodian Gender Assessment Survey 2008 (Ministry of Women's Affairs-MOWA) indicated that nearly a quarter of Cambodian women suffered from some form of violence and most perceive domestic violence as the norm. Despite the seemingly low reported cases, violence against women (VAW) is prevalent across Cambodia. Results from such gender based violence research only provides a glimpse of the reality of a woman's life in Cambodia. Violence Against Women Base Line Survey (2005) found that only 11% of victims of violence seek assistance or justice. _x000D_
In order to have a social impact and increase in the quality of life for Cambodian women it is necessary to change the attitudes and perception of violence against women from being socially accepted. This project aims to use information and communication technologies (ICT) as the catalyst to reduce violence against women by focusing on female adolescents as social change agents and advocates for women's rights in Cambodia. How can female adolescents effectively share their stories of being victims of violence? How can we increase female adolescents' voice on women's rights and equality in the media? _x000D_
_x000D_
The goal of the project is breaking women silence on VAW by strategic use of ICT._x000D_
_x000D_
The objectives of the project is twofold:_x000D_
1) The use of ICT for ending violence against women (eVAW) by women&girls will be strengthened_x000D_
2) Women&Girls voices asking for eVAW be increased and heard_x000D_
_x000D_
The project will be comprised of two components: 1) Training, and 2) Advocacy campaign._x000D_
_x000D_
Target group: Direct target group 460 mostly Young women and girls from Ã¢â¬Å Young Women LeadershipÃ¢â¬Â and from Green Youth Association from 30 Universities in Phnom Penh, Battambang and Siem Reap province. Indirect target group will be 2300 student of universities._x000D_
_x000D_
Period of the project: 12 months from 1 October, 2014- 30 October, 2015_x000D_
_x000D_
Component 1: Training_x000D_
_x000D_
The project consists of female adolescents' participation in ICT and Citizen Journalist trainings, and OI hosting Barcamps. The objective of each training session will focus on how to use Internet tools for emailing, researching, writing, and disseminating information openly and effectively on issues raised around violence against women. Participants will be introduced on how to use various social media (e.g., Facebook, Twitter, blogging), and effective internet posting approaches such as for newspaper articles or video recordings. For example, blogging provides a platform for women to become active advocates and disseminator of knowledge on violence against women, sharing their personal stories and supporting victims of violence. _x000D_
_x000D_
Three ICT training courses on Ã¢â¬ÅFemale Adolescents Using ICT for eVAWÃ¢â¬Â will be held once in November 2013,  and January 2014,  with a total of 60 female adolescents participation. ICT training allows the target group to gain knowledge on how to use technology as a vehicle to communicate and share information about promoting awareness on VAW to a larger audience. _x000D_
_x000D_
Two Citizen Journalist (CJ) training on Ã¢â¬ÅFemale Adolescents 's Engagement in Citizen JournalismÃ¢â¬Â will be held once in November 2013 and January 2014,  with a total of 60 female adolescents participation. CJ training is critical toward the target group's development of good journalism skills on a) how to identify credible sources of information, b) how to package information on social media to gain VAW awareness, and c) how to use ICT to present sensitive material on VAW. _x000D_
_x000D_
Component 2: Advocacy campaign_x000D_
_x000D_
During the project, Open Institute (OI) will participate in 8 March WID and a 16-day global campaign (25 November Ã¢â¬â 10 December 2014)  called Ã¢â¬ÅTake Back the Tech!Ã¢â¬Â (TBTT) https://www.facebook.com/CambodiaTbtt to promote the awareness on using ICT to end violence against women in Cambodia (part of the Association for Progressive Communication -APC). The objective of the campaign is to increase female adolescents use of social media (Facebook, twitter, blog) as a medium to share information and stories about gender based violence and the challenges in achieving gender equality. OI will present an award for those who demonstrate a strong active involvement in the campaign such as postings and discussions on the OI and Take Back the Tech! Facebook and Twitter pages. Posters (approximately 900) and stickers (2000) will be used during the campaign and mailed to universities and organizations.  _x000D_
_x000D_
OI will host two Barcamp on Ã¢â¬ÅFemale Adolescents Using ICT to Promote Awareness on VAWÃ¢â¬Â for 200 participants per workshop, thus a total of 400 expected participants.  Barcamp serves two main objectives: a) provide several workshop sessions with various topics on bridging ICT and VAW and b) attendance and participation of members from various university in Cambodia, local authorities, group advocates/organizers, and organizations._x000D_
  _x000D_
Monitor and evaluation:_x000D_
_x000D_
A progress assessment will be performed over the implementation of the project. A detailed plan and schedule will be developed to use for coordinating and monitoring events and training sessions in order to achieve project goals. Meetings between Open Institute's Project Leader, project team members, and Executive Director will be held on a regular basis to discuss the status of training and workshops, address and respond to challenges, and report learning outcomes. In between project meetings, E-mail and phone communications will be used as the main method of correspondences._x000D_
_x000D_
Activity reports will be prepared by the project team to monitor the project's progress and to measure the effectiveness of training sessions. Evaluation of training sessions and workshops will be assessed through results obtained from participants' feedback and comments. A Monitor and Evaluation report will be prepared at the end of the project, followed by a Final Narrative Report and Financial Report.

project_summary:
Sporting Chance International proposes a girls empowerment program by empowering them with ICT skills, specifically with skills in animation and mobile app development. The program will operate from Githurai. It will target girls, who due to their poor background, are an able to proceed to college. Such girls turn to menial jobs which are at times demeaning. The project will aim to reach 100 girls annually. Due to the fact that income from sales of apps and animation products may not be immediate, the project will also have an agribusiness venture. This will include a rabbit rearing unit. Rabbits have a ready market in Kenya. Further, their gestation period is short and they do not require a lot of space. This business will keep the program going until we can get income from apps and animations. The program will also include financial literacy training which will be conducted by Kingdom Sacco, a financial Institution which has served the residents of Githurai for about two decades. This will allow the girls to be better managers of their finances. There will also be a mentoring program that will link the girls with elder people who have succeeded in the areas of agribusiness or app development and animation. It is envisioned that after going through the program, the girls will be able to develop apps, or animate or start their own agribusiness. strategy_x000D_
ICT training_x000D_
SCI has already established and built a relationship with a consultant  company called Nett consultants . Nett Consultants  and its consultants have won several awards in the app making arena in Kenya. Nett has also participated in other training initiatives including training parents and teachers from Githurai in making animations for their children. We plan to utilize his experience in ICT and working with communities and especially in Githurai. The training will be on two areas. These will be in mobile app development and animation. _x000D_
The mobile apps developed will be sold online to enable the girls to fetch income. A useful app will fetch an average of 1 USD per download. The number of Kenyans accessing the Internet has grown five-fold to 19.2 million users as at September 2013, according to data from the Communications Commission of Kenya (CCK). The internet penetration has thus risen to 47%. This has created a great demand for ICT products including apps and animations. _x000D_
The other area will be animation. In this, the girls will we trained in making cartoons and advertisements based on animated characters. They will first be trained on Crazy Talk, first in 2D and then later in 3D. We envision that after the program has been running for a while, we shall be able to sell cartoon shows to be aired on TV._x000D_
Both the training in animation and mobile app development will be done in modules. The trainees will have to pass in one module to go on to the next. By the end of the training, a cohort of trainees will have acquired enough skills to be able to either make mobile apps or animation._x000D_
_x000D_
Financial literacy training_x000D_
Alongside the ICT skills that the girls will learn, there will be financial literacy skills. This stems from our belief that resources make little difference unless they are managed well. The financial literacy skills will be taught in partnership with Kingdom Sacco Ltd. Ksacco is a fiancial institution that has served the residents of Githurai for almost 20 years. Kingdom Sacco has previously engaged in training youths in fincial literacy, and thus, have the capacity and resources. _x000D_
As part of the training, each trainee will be given an account with KSACCO. No money will be charged on opening the account and no minimum balance will be required. They will also be issued with a piggy bank to help develop a saving culture. This accounts will later be used to acquire loans from Kingdom Sacco. _x000D_
Income generation_x000D_
We acknowledge that the ICT training cannot act as an immediate source of income. Further, as a nation, we have challenges in food security. In response to these problems, the trainees will be trained on rabbit keeping and sack farming. Through other initiatives that SCI has worked with such as Horeb Youth Group, we have identified community resource person who are willing to train any person willing to start rabbit farming. These two activities are not resource intensive and are easy to learn. Rabbit keeping involves rearing of rabbits in batteries for commercial purposes. Rabbits require little space since an area of two square feet can hold nine rabbits; 3 cages on top of each other each holding three rabbits. Feeding of rabbits is also easy since for the bigger part, they will be fed of foliage which will be collected from the surrounding. There is a ready market for rabbit meat. Each kilo of meat fetches between USD 4 and USD 7. The rabbits can either be sold live or slaughtered. They will be the main immediate source of income. Sack farming involves planting vegetables in sacks filled with soil. The sacks can be placed near verandahs, hanged from the walls of the house and placed in corners near a house. The vegetables will provide food to the trainees and the surplus will be sold to earn an income. _x000D_
Mentorship_x000D_
In our more than 10 years of operations among the youth we have identified mentorship as one of the most effective tools in social transformation. Information is not adequate to change an individual. Due to this, we usually link our target youths will other older people to help them navigate through different stages in life. We envision that the trainees will be linked with other women working in the areas of ICT to allow them to have a broader perspective of the activities and also to motivate them beyond the initial challenges. _x000D_
_x000D_
About USD 4,000 will be used in establishing a rabbit rearing unit. about USD 7,000 will be used in the purchase of computers, about 3,000 will be used in the renting, maintenance of a training facility/class, repairs and utilities, about USD 7,000 will be used in training and development in the areas of mobile app development and animation.
project_details:
'Enhancing gender equity in the means of production' _x000D_
Despite the significant advancement in gender equality in Kenya, significant gaps exist in many areas. One such area is ICT. The ICT sector is highly dominated by men in all levels. This, though seemingly normal, poses a threat to the gains made in issues of gender equality and empowerment of women. Gender equality can only be achieved and maintained if men and women both own the means of production. The ICT sector has become one of the major sources of income for the country, corporates and for individuals. Leaving women behind in this jeopardizes the gains that have been achieved. _x000D_
This project targets young girls in remote region in Kenya that has an apparent resource lack but overflowing with opportunities that can be tapped for sustainable development. With the immense difference in gender equality in terms of ICT development, this project acts as an important bridge to this divide.

project_summary:
About 65% of women and girls in Kenya cannot afford sanitary pads. Evidence suggests that the period around puberty is one in which many girls drop out of school or are absent from school for significant periods of time. Menstruation causes Kenyan adolescent girls to lose an average of 3.5 million learning days per month.Limited access to safe, affordable, convenient and appropriate methods of dealing with menstruation has far reaching implications for the rights physical, social and mental well-being of many adolescent girls in Kenya. Our project is about making re-usable pads (N-Care pads) which will radically prove to create an environment where women and girls can step boldly into the promise of their future._x000D_
The goal of this project is to empower vulnerable girls and women through the provision of re-usable pads, capacity building on menstrual hygiene management and reproductive health for improved performance and self esteem. This will entail the production and distribution of re-usable sanitary pads as well as ensuring provision of menstrual hygiene management education and facilities to girls in primary schools in two counties of Nyanza Region. _x000D_
One packet which we will name Ã¢â¬ËProject Inspire N-Care PadsÃ¢â¬â¢, of the re-usable pads will be sufficient to meet the sanitary needs of a girl for a year. The adoption of re-usable pads is also more environmentally friendly than the disposable type and the training provided covers safe disposal and management aspects as well._x000D_

project_name: Transforming the livelihoods of 300 disadvantaged women in Bumula Sub- County Ã¢â¬âKenya through sustainable agribusiness technologies.
project_summary:
Jubilee Farms-Kenya is a registered community based welfare organization whose Primary objective is to provide care and support to vulnerable women and children in Bumula Sub-County of Bungoma County Ã¢â¬âKenya. Our mission is to alleviate poverty through improved nutrition and increased access to social amenities such as property ownership, proper sanitation, and access to education and clean water through agricultural technology transfers for wealth creation as well as improved value added organic food production.Evidence shows that agriculture-led growth in Kenya is more than twice as effective in reducing poverty as growth led by other industries. The key to better performance in agriculture lies in boosting smallholder productivity and by making financial services widely available to rural communities to enable the growth of smallholder enterprises_x000D_
The Bumula Sub- County is dependent majorly on rain fed agriculture as the main economic bread basket; however, with changes in climatic conditions, farm yields have since dwindled to bare minimum. We will promote agricultural economic growth activities through increasing productivity by use of sustainable agricultural farming technologies as well as creating markets both local and regionally thus effectively eliminate poverty for the three hundred families that we are going to target._x000D_
Women issues have been most articulated with regard to sustainable agriculture decision making process since they provide most of the labour in agricultural production and are actually the major food producers. We will strive on activities that promote prudent and deliberate measures to promote gender equity and greater participation of women in social, political and economic processes.  The main objective is to incorporate women in decision making at all levels.Women and girls in Bumula Sub County are faced with common challenges that are characterised with rural poor women globally. Without a purposive shift in our activities, the following challenges continue to persist:_x000D_
1.	High rural population growth rates and decreased efficiency in agricultural production which lead to increased levels of unemployment and underemployment, and a consequent migratory drift to cities in search of work and better standards of living. _x000D_
2.	Rural women and children find difficulty in obtaining a basic education of the same quality as urban youth, and hence have difficulty in gaining entrance to higher education institutions. _x000D_
3.	High food prices have also put a drag on economic growth. Agricultural productivity growth and access to food has become insufficient to eradicate extreme hunger and nutritional deficiencies in a growing population	.	_x000D_
4.	Smallholder women farmers and rural agricultural businesses continue to lack access to markets and financial	resources, and	 thus are not able to overcome the poverty traps associated with small holdings and/or poor soils. _x000D_
5.	Lack of roads, clean water, technology empowerment and electricity will continue to make it	 impossible to	significantly improve	 the lives of the rural	poor.	_x000D_
Our target population is women within the reproductive age 18-55 and adolescent girls. The project will benefit 300 women mostly widows and 50 adolescent girls in providing basic  educational material support to the adolescent girls and support the 300women in agribusiness and sustainable organic farming training that will boost farm yields and  progressively create economic independence amongst the target families._x000D_
Food security can only be achieved when all people at all times have access to sufficient food for a healthy and productive life, and have three main components: food availability, food access, and food utilisation. Finding solutions calls for agricultural interventions that have been identified as having the potential to meet the increased food demands and to contribute to alleviating food insecurity problems .Developing Bungoma County should reap the benefits of these technologies_x000D_
We also aim at increasing the potential of Empowerment of rural women development through Innovative application of ICTs in rural areas. ICT interaction will be beneficial particularly towards;_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Decision-making process - Sound decision making is dependent upon availability of comprehensive, timely and up-to-date information. Food security problems facing developing countries demonstrate the need for informed researchers and planners._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Market outlook Ã¢â¬â farmers could promote their products and handle simple transactions such as  getting orders over the web while also pontentially receive payment transactions for the goods. _x000D_

With ICT, rural communities can acquire the capacity to improve their living conditions and become motivated through training and dialogue with others to a level where they make decisions for their own. Rural areas also get greater visibility by having the opportunity to disseminate information about their community to the whole world._x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Targeting marginalised groups Ã¢â¬â Most rural poor people lack the power to access information. ICTs could benefit all stakeholders including the civil society, in particular youth and other disadvantaged groups that could be targeted include the disabled and subsistence peasants. _x000D_
Through capacity building in modern sustainable agricultural technologies, the organization will in collaboration with key stakeholders, work closely with women towards increasing their food sufficiency and empower them with sustainable livelihood skills and use of technology at the grassroots level._x000D_
Besides resource mobilisation and accumulation through improved yields, we will also empower the beneficiaries with entrepreneurial skills that will not only encompass marketing but will in the long run boost the beneficiariesÃ¢â¬â¢ economic power. _x000D_

Diversification in agriculture will involve shift in cropping patterns from traditionally grown crops to mixed farming as a way of maximising all the resources within the farm .it also includes livestock and fishery enterprises and small scale agro based industries. Diversification increases the employment opportunities, optimum use of resources and profitability._x000D_
Organic farming is a venture that has been growing very fast particularly at the international market levels. This sector provides great business opportunities to agro based entrepreneur .Area under organic farming is increasing but has been unable to meet the market demands for organic produce. Jubilee farms will train farmers on organic farming and actively utilise ICT in marketing the farmers produce both locally, regionally and explore the international markets through other partners and stakeholders_x000D_
A huge amount of farm produce is wasted due to improper storage, lack of transportation and processing plants .there is significant shift in consumer food preference towards processed food products and as enterpreneurs, the women can add value with proper management and marketing initiatives. Processed food market opens a great potential for entrepreneurs. Value addition on dairy produce can be through yoghurt production that will last longer and sell at a higher value as compared to fresh milk whose prices are lower and gets spoilt faster .We will also train farmers on preserving tomatoes as tomato paste and tomato sauce. We will also train the farmer on how to process nutritious flour out of cassava, yam, and sweet potatoes. We will also train the farmer on how to utilise soya in making soya drink powder, soymilk and soya chunks(meal).During the wet season there is usually a surplus in production of assorted vegetables to which during the dry season the region struggles with getting enough vegetables to feed the family. We will train our beneficiaries on how to dry and store vegetables which can be exported to other regions or simply stored for the dry season to ensure continuous supply of nutritious vegetable all year round_x000D_
Farmers will be trained on production of seed, organic fertilisers and pesticides using locally available resources that will not only lower their own cost of farm production but will also allow them to sell the same to other farmers at subsidised rates. We will explore the use of farm wastes in production of organic manure as well as emphasis on the importance of recycling within the farm_x000D_
Jubilee farms will seek to respond to these concerns by investing in knowledge creation and use of modern technology. Knowledge should result in an improved development, such as the higher incomes resulting from increased crop production due to better soil and water conservation resulting from the use of sustainable Agriculture. We intend to undertake on-farm demonstrations in which improved technologies developed on-station are tried out on farmers' fields. We will also utilize Jubilee Compassion demonstration and resource center in conducting our research and farmer demonstrations for training purposes. _x000D_

Rationale_x000D_
_x000D_
Oral Healthcare is a focus area because only 4% of Indian population (urban and rural) are fully aware about oral health and hygiene of which only 2% approach a dentist and of this population 0.2% seek dental treatment. As a result caries/periodontal index is extremely high in India, especially in women. In the area of de-addiction from tobacco (chewable 60% and smoked 40%), India follows the WHO, FCTC guidelines of MPOWER. Dentists therefore, need to connect with the masses to advocate de-addiction and provide accessible and affordable oral healthcare and tobacco de-addiction therapy. _x000D_
_x000D_
Women personal hygiene is a focus area to prevent pelvic inflammatory disorders which is widely prevalent in India. A combination of lack of awareness of personal hygiene and prohibitive cost of widely available sanitary napkins has led to large instances of such disorders among women. We seek to address the issue of ignorance through awareness programs and make available low cost sanitary napkins for wider penetration and in the process also enable employability through social enterprise._x000D_

project_details_other:
Investing in local women's entrepreneurship has a multiplier effect on a community, because the dollars loaned circulate extensively among rural economic networks. Our long-term goals are to impact poverty in rural Kenya using inspired women as the instigators of success and to increase employment opportunities by nurturing new businesses. The effect is to raise the status of women, who will enjoy increased respect and status. They become equal partners in their communities, their children can stay in school, families are able to gain medical insurance, and the number of families living in poverty decreases. Entire families benefit and with 4.1 household people per family, this equates to over 10,000 people ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢â¬Å all being lifted out of dependency and poverty by women. Entire communities benefit as success breeds success, education continues for the young and pride of ownership and entrepreneurship creates increased participation in society by these successful women.
In the next few years, we will help over 6000 women, their families and communities create stable incomes by encouraging their natural gifts and abilities. We will educate a minimum of 3000 individuals in financial literacy (2500 female entrepreneurs and 500 additional community members), helping them learn how to budget and save. Whenever entire communities become empowered to earn their own incomes, the future becomes more Peaceful. Viable tools to fight Want and Ignorance become reality. They can begin to have Hope to fulfill their dreams, not someone elseÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s. 
We are committed to making 3500 loans over the course of the granting period (January 2015-December 2015). We will continue to invest in individual entrepreneurs and expand the business capabilities into larger enterprises. This will grow skills, confidence and the impact of a business over time. Women will be empowered to rise up and become more vocal towards better community management and societal debates. 
We conduct both qualitative and quantitative evaluations three times a year. Clients are interviewed by the Project evaluator to determine the quality of services provided and the impact on participantsÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢ lives. Clients fill out questionnaires periodically on program quality, and we provide anonymous opinion boxes in all of our branches. Quantitative evaluations track the growth of our microfinance enterprise by charting the number of active clients, active loans, hours of financial education completed, default rate, and the growth of the companyÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s human resources and capital base. Both qualitative and quantitative reports are regularly distributed to our partners and are compiled yearly to comprise our Annual Report. Wings of Hope staff review all collected data quarterly.

project_summary:
The Transfedha project in rural Kenya empowers women by teaching them how to start and manage a small business, and providing the start-up capital to begin earning a sustainable income. Janeth, a fruit seller in Bomet, is a great example of someone who has changed her life in one year through help from Transfedha/Wings of Hope. She is raising her family as a single parent and has struggled to keep her children fed and in school. One year ago, she joined Transfedha/Wings of Hope and received financial education and mentorship. She has successfully paid back her small initial loan. Janeth says: Ã¢â¬ÅNo words can describe the satisfaction I have in my heart and among my children. One may be surprised that I am shedding tears, but these are tears of joy and success. I am a bread winner with children going to school. A friend introduced me to Transfedha/Wings of Hope Microfinance. I did not hesitate joining a group of other women who were succeeding in business. I have just cleared the second loan of 10000 Kenya shillings and have applied for a new loan of 15000 Kenya shillings to expand. I am inspired by the hundreds of clients who were seeking membership registration. I asked the Managing Director, Ã¢â¬ËWill you be able to help all of us?Ã¢â¬â¢Ã¢â¬Â _x000D_
With a Project Inspire grant of $25,000, we will be able to double our reach, helping more than twice as many women, their families and their communities create their own paths out of poverty. With average loans of only $60 per entrepreneur, we are able to make staggering differences in the lives of thousands._x000D_
_x000D_

We offer in-depth business counseling which results in simple business plans so that entrepreneurs understand why and how their business will be successful and plan for expansion before it is necessary. We only lend to women who complete an intensive, two-week entrepreneurship training program. Transfedha/Wings of Hope supports the women with knowledge and creativity in how to make a small business successful, and offers flexibility in various repayment processes. We make loan repayment and saving easier through the use of mobile technology. Secondly, the interest income offsets TransfedhaÃ¢â¬â¢s costs of lending and allows for slow, sustainable growth._x000D_

Currently the pass rate on the School Leaving Certificate (SLC) exams is unacceptably low. We are hoping Sabaila School will assist in alleviating the impact of many of the pitfalls in the current education system of Nepal such as reducing the impact of the shortage in teachers staffing schools causing multiple grades to be taught together, inevitably decreasing the quality of education. Though Sabaila School does not supplement the shortage in teaching staff directly, our use of technology should help increase the pass rate on the SLCs.  We are also doing this to retain students in the areaÃ¢â¬âa problem we saw in these wards of Okhaldhunga is that many students who can afford it actually leave the village. When successful students leave to complete their education in a neighboring city, it creates a literacy desert in this village. We are also assisting with food and water shortages this village faces because in order for kids to study and do well on their exam, they need to have reduced stress in other aspects of their lives such as hunger and thirst. _x000D_
Our impetus for using technology to bolster the studentsÃ¢â¬â¢ learning is threefold.  First, the students will be seeing the material again: repetition. Second, they will be using the material  and applying it in various games and integrative activities:   this does two things for us, increases comprehension AND assists assimilation of the material. Three: they will be using a different medium and style of learning, so concepts that they cannot understand or cannot focus on in a classroom  have a second chance to be absorbed by the student when they see it again presented differently.  What we will do, is present two teachers (who we will hire) with 40 tablets already programmed with the apps we will prepare for these students. The teachers will supervise the children while they, somewhat independently do the learning with the tablets and the apps on the tablets. In addition, because affording food and water has proven to be difficult in this area, students who have perfect attendance at our program will earn two hundred Nepali Rupees a month for their family, as a small stipend._x000D_
 _x000D_
Our tablet applications and curriculum will target three major age groups. The youngest children, in the ECD stage: Early Childhood Development stage, will have games that help teach them basic skills that will be useful later in their academic careers such as simple interactive games identifying the alphabet, numbers and general knowledge facts such as fruits and vegetables. The next age group we have is fourth grade to seventh grade students. For them, we will have math games, Nepali to English and English to Nepali translational games and other activities focusing some on math, but primarily on their comprehension of what they read and write, both in Nepali and in English.  Finally, grades 8-10 is the critical years where our sole goal is to train them to  successfully write and pass the SLC exams. The activities we will have for them will be very focused on the subject material, lots of practice questions, ways to track their progress and have sample full length tests that give them an idea where they stand and hopefully build their mental endurance to being able to concentrate for the entire duration of the test._x000D_
 _x000D_
The money we receive from project inspire will help us in purchasing the tablets, generating applications ideal for processing the material that will be covered on the SLC exams which the students in Okhaldhunga are not passing. Other expenses we will have to accommodate for include paying for supplying electricity and facilities for the tablets to be charged and for a teacher to supervise and guide the children as they use integrative technology to supplement and further their classroom studies. There will also be administrative costs involved in marketing this program throughout the village, in gauging starting level of the students so that we can track progress and continuously monitoring the progress. Especially in a venture such as this one, where the lucrative technology could be taken by many as a passtime or signature of sophistication instead of as primarily a tool of furthering oneÃ¢â¬â¢s opportunities and both having teachers present in the room and having assessments periodically to check for improvement in the understanding of the course material will undoubtedly prove vital for the success of this  social venture. _x000D_

One in three women and one in six men feel insecure on public transport. This includes the fear of pickpockets, sexual harassment and personal injury. We at SEE-W have come up with Pink Bus Project.  It is a timely solution for the Nepalese society, and is extremely necessary given to the diminished awareness, equality and security available to the women in this community. Whatever the mode of transport used the number one problem for all commuters is overcrowding. In their quest to maximize profits, drivers cram in passengers who are forced to endure Ã¢â¬Å disgusting & sweatyÃ¢â¬Â journeys. Considering that 83% of Nepalese women are working and women amount to at least 1/3 of the travelling public, it is especially important to consider how these difficulties affect them.If we are to receive the fund we are planning on expanding this dream project in 10 routes with 10 buses operating at a full capacity in Kathmandu Valley. The buses will be colored pink as to make it recognizable and most preferred by girls. We will spend the money on Hiring and Training 20 individuals, bus renting, fuel, coloring of the bus, social awareness in media and operations. It will not only benefit about 5000 female passengers every day, it will also provide economic independence to 10 female drivers and 10 female conductors. It will also help fund out other programs, which will be targeted to help females and children all around the country._x000D_
The population of Kathmandu is increasing at a phenomenal rate, putting enormous pressure on the public transport system. Finding a way through the maze of buses, microbuses, tempos, and taxis is a daunting task not to mention the actual overcrowded uncomfortable journeys. A new report: 'Gender and Public Transport in Nepal 2014' published by the world bank states that young women aged 19 Ã¢â¬â 25 are more than twice likely as all other age groups of women to specifically relate their feelings of personal insecurity to fear of inappropriate touching with 43% noting this concern. In fact, one in four young women aged 19-35 years have had direct experiences of this as the perpetrators are middle aged men and more than half of all women surveyed said they would avoid standing or sitting next to a middle aged man while travelling._x000D_
The Pink Bus Project is a  unique project of SEE-W, which is currently operating in a pilot phase. It is facilitating the safety and safe travel of over 100 female passengers in just two rounds of travel, where 8 rounds per route is possible. Due to lack of funds we are operating only during office and school hours, which is morning and evening hours, on one route. Women and girls have appreciated this move and are encouraging us to operate more buses and more routes as possible. It is also providing employment for two female operators, driver and conductor. It is receiving positive feedback's from the females in the society and is sound financially as well._x000D_
We plan on spending 50% of the earning on expanding the pink bus project all over the county. We will be spending 25% of our earning on skill development programs for women in rural areas of the country where the literacy rate is low and the females are bound to stay home. 15% of our earning will be spend on educating girls from all grades in the rural areas where they are forced to stay home and labor from an early age. The last 10% will be spent on micro credit, providing low interest rate to women to empower them. This is a growing trend in the capital but we would like to gain this success in the rural areas._x000D_

project_name: Pay it Forward - Innovations for better life options and opportunities for at risk adolescent girls (working children of non brothel based commercial sex workers)
project_summary:
DISHA plans on providing better life options to 300 girls in the age group of 12-16 years who are living in difficult circumstances. These girls are the children of  non-brothel based sex workers from slums of Kanchan basti and Rewari Line urban slums of south west Delhi.  They are forced into a life of commercial sex activities to augment the family income. They live in overcrowded and often dangerous conditions and face the risk of teenage pregnancies and multiple abortions posing serious threat to their lives. Recent report of December 2013 ( by Dasra ) mentions that there are around 3 million adolescent girls who are engaged in commercial sex work in India. Over 60% of these are adolescent girls in the age group of 12-16 years. Out of this, more that than 35% girls in India enter commercial sex activities before reaching 18 years.     _x000D_
Most of the families of these girls, who belong to the ''Tharo'' tribe,  have migrated to Delhi from the states of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh  in search of better livelihood options.  They live in various slums in Mayapuri Industrial area in  Delhi.  In the slum clusters they  who are forced to live in an unhygienic surroundings next to the  railway line, empty industrial plot of land and open drains. They have low or no literacy levels and in addition to commercial sex activities,   these girls work as rag pickers, collecting scrap generated from the factories and shops and are  trapped in a vicious cycle of sexual exploitation and abuse. They are ostracized by the community in general and are forced to living a life of neglect and denial of rights by circumstances beyond their control. As a result, the girls are exploited and abused,  getting trapped in the flesh trade seriously threatening their well being. However, it is reported  that  it is an accepted norm in the families of Tharo tribes  to  encourage their girls to become sex workers from an early age.  _x000D_
_x000D_
With this grant of USD 25,000,  DISHA plans to educate 300 such girls in enhancing their awareness and understanding about adolescent reproductive health,  providing quality basic education, livelihood skills and family life education to  provide them with an alternative that bridges gender and social category gaps.  DISHA will work with the adolescent girls and their families by providing complete and accurate knowledge on adolescent reproductive health, the importance of reproductive health services and how to access them.  DISHA will enlist community support and enlist their participation for interventions that address reproductive health needs of adolescents and young adults. This will reduce unmet demand for information regarding reproductive health for adolescent in line with the goals of Health for ALL & improve the acceptance of reproductive health services in the project area. Its will enable adolescent to make choices & options for a healthy, productive and happy future.These interventions, we hope will increase their economic empowerment, decision-making capacity, improve their reproductive health,will provide them with identity and dignity to contribute positively and live self-esteem and confidence in the society. _x000D_
_x000D_
DISHA will set up five open schools to educate these girls up to at least primary level so that they are able to enter the school system and get mainstreamed in the government middle schools. In addition, DISHA will provide remedial support to the mainstreamed girls for retention and completion of education for  older girls up to grade 8._x000D_

SHE InvestmentsÃ¢â¬â¢ vision is a world where investing in women in developing countries is seen as an opportunity, not charity.  $25,000 will help us to reach this vision by allowing us to implement our pilot project in Cambodia from early 2015.To address the barriers facing women entrepreneurs in Cambodia and to support them to scale their micro businesses to profitable and sustainable SMEs, our pilot project will: _x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Work with a small group (10 participants) of women who own existing micro businesses through a 6 Ã¢â¬â 12 month incubator program, which will include regular and culturally tailored training workshops, inclusive peer support structures, and field trips to support participants in identifying markets, customers, and existing successful businesses. _x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Provide one-on-one mentoring and ongoing support throughout the incubator program _x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Linking women and their businesses to opportunities for investment from impact investment firms and other national and international agencies _x000D_
This pilot project will allow us to review, reflect on and adjust our model and programs based on feedback from participants and facilitators. _x000D_
This program has been designed based on our research that has been completed over the past 12 months, the key lessons from this research have been:_x000D_
CambodiaÃ¢â¬â¢s economy, government and key international supportive agencies are ready to invest in women and SMEs.  _x000D_
The Cambodian governmentÃ¢â¬â¢s MDG Accelerated Framework focuses on the economic empowerment of women,  key aspects of which are directed towards improving womenÃ¢â¬â¢s employment opportunities and structures for female entrepreneurs.  Major agencies such as USAID have been directing resources towards enterprise development, and there are increasing opportunities for investment into the private sector in this country.  _x000D_
Paying back a loan is not a true indicator of success.  _x000D_
So many MFIs and MF programs exist in Cambodia, and loans are so easily accessible that many people are getting stuck in the Ã¢â¬Åborrowing cycleÃ¢â¬Â.  This means that women are able to access loans to start micro-businesses, and receive some training, however they often lack the ability to grow their business into an enterprise that no longer needs to rely on annual loans.  _x000D_
The key barriers facing women entrepreneurs isnÃ¢â¬â¢t necessarily monetary.  _x000D_
NGOs and Microfinance Institutions (MFIs) are common across Cambodia, and many women are able to access micro loans and investment, along with basic training in business and financial literacy, to support them in starting a micro-enterprise.  However, the key barriers facing women entrepreneurs are in scaling their business.  This is due to their businesses usually existing in the informal business space, lack of access to larger capital investment, and lack of ongoing business support.  SHE Investments believes that there is a difference between managing a micro-business and earning just enough income to keep it surviving, to thinking like an entrepreneur and scaling.  Economic, educational, social and cultural barriers often cause women to lack the self-confidence, knowledge, or support to become business owners of SMEs.  _x000D_
Our next steps are to test and pilot our model through our first Entrepreneur Incubator Program for women business owners in Cambodia.  We will work with existing NGOÃ¢â¬â¢s in Cambodia who work on gender focused programs to identify 10 women who are already managing their own micro businesses and who are determined to grow to SME level.  Our goal is to have a group of women and their businesses that are eligible and ready for investment by the end of 2015. _x000D_

project_name: Healthy Food for 400 Children in Al-masara  Village
project_summary:
Summary_x000D_
This project will support a women-led initiative to cook healthy, fresh, and affordable meals and snacks for the 400 children at the local schools in Masara Village outside of Bethlehem. The project is important for the children's physical well-being as well as modeling the importance of nutrition and eating fresh, local food._x000D_
What is the issue, problem, or challenge?_x000D_
_x000D_
In 2008, a group of women became concerned about the food served to children in the village schools. They took over the cafeteria that serves children at the local kindergarten and schools and removed all of the junk food. These women wake up each day at 5:30am to cook food for the children but the children cannot afford to buy healthy food and after four years of getting small donations of flour or milk or meat from different farmers and shopkeepers, they have run out of places to turn._x000D_
The women in Ma'sara been doing this for years getting by on donations from here and there. But Um Hasan explained 'we have the desire but we need support.' For example, their small gas stove is broken and they can't repair it or get a new one so have been getting by with rocks to balance it. _x000D_
_x000D_
In 2008, Fatma Breighiyeh (Um Hasan) became concerned about the food served to children in the village schools. As a farmer, she takes an interest in healthy food and believes itÃ¢â¬â¢s important for the childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s physical wellbeing as well as for their future to learn the importance of nutrition and eating fresh, local food. She told me 'I have 26 grandkids and I'm doing my best to help raise them well. But we have to take care of all the children.' _x000D_
She organized a group of women and they took over the village schools' canteen (one kindergarten and two schools) and emptied them out of all the junk food. Um Hasan explained that she and the other women volunteers see this work as a totally political venture- their small contribution to the resistance - ensuring that the children grow up healthy and strong and are not weakened by junk and cheap food._x000D_
Each day at 5:30am women from the village gather in the basement kitchen to prepare food such as zaatar pies, meat pies, popcorn, fava beans, fruits, termos, and muffins for children attending the village schools. The children get a healthy snack (and at times a breakfast, since many are living under the poverty line).Today they made delicious orange muffins, fresh popcorn, termos (similar to fava beans and served with a bit of salt and lemon), and zaatar pies. They also offer yogurt and juice drinks which they sell at cost to the children. The women use only Palestinian products and use organic, fresh vegetables and fruits that Um Hasan grows herself. She even donates the zaatar (wild thyme) which she picks, dries, and grinds before bringing it to the kitchen. _x000D_
The women in Ma'sara been doing this for years getting by on donations from here and there. But Um Hasan explained 'we have the desire but we need support.' For example, their small gas stove is broken and they can't repair it or get a new one so have been getting by with rocks to balance it. _x000D_
_x000D_
With MECA's support, the women hope to buy an industrial blender to make juices and smoothies as well as to cover their monthly expenses for flour, milk, gas, cleaning supplies, etc. _x000D_
project_details: The project will purchase basic necessities like flour, milk, meat, and vegetables so that the women can continue to serve healthy, fresh food in the school cafeteria. The project will also allow them to buy a new stove (they have to use rocks to balance their current one and it is unsafe) and other maintenance for the kitchen equipment.

Through this initiative a batch of 5 girls will be empowered by receiving skills based training  in creative  digital print media and eventually owning their own digital print media kiosks.
project_details: In Malaysia, majority of girls in orphanages and shelter homes are made to leave these facilities at the age of 18 years.  Unfortunately, these girls are not equipped with the necessary life skills to be able to safely sustain and lead a productive life.  Having worked with 20,000 over underprivileged children to date in Malaysia, we have observed an alarming trend amongst these girls who are asked to leave these shelters at the age of 18 years.  They usually return to a legal guardian, sometimes to their relatives or their single mother.  Mostly they are asked to work so as to provide an income to the household and as a result they usually end up working as a waitress or do odd jobs and receive below minimum wages.  This keeps them within the vicious circle of poverty.  The other alarming trend that we have seen and experienced first hand, is that many girls end up having a speedy affair with boys that are ready to take advantage of these girls and in turn many of them end up pregnant

project_name: Support for girls in crisis situation through the work of social development bank of women in the Issyk-Kul oblast.
project_summary: According to the crisis centers in Kyrgyzstan 80% of marriages in mono ethnic villages are accomplished through bride kidnapping.  This was pointed out by the UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan in 2006.  Since that, this problem was repeatedly drawn on the alternative reports of the CEDAW Committee of Kyrgyzstan. In the period from 2010 to 2012 there was a high dynamics of suicide cases among girls exposed to kidnapping. Criminal practice of forcing marriage of girls continues, despite the recently adopted amendments to the Criminal Code. Many marriages have committed in this way break. Girls - victims of kidnapping brides after leaving home of groom subjected to humiliating discussion from both the groom's family, as part of society as a whole, sometimes not excluding parents of the girls. project_summary:
At Human and Hope Association, we believe the underlying cause of poverty is a lack of education and training. This is why our organization focuses on empowering Cambodians to create sustainable futures through projects focused on education, vocational training and community support. _x000D_
Receiving a $25,000 grant would give us the opportunity to further the reach of our sewing program, and empower more women to create sustainable futures as a result. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our sewing program was launched in April 2012. Since that time, 19 students have graduated from our beginner sewing class, and five students from our advanced sewing class. In July we will launch an expert sewing class, resulting in the students that study all three levels having a complete set of sewing skills and an advantage in the job market. _x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬ÅThe staff are so friendly and they do not hold back their knowledge from us.Ã¢â¬Â Ã¢â¬â Chomrong, beginner sewing student, aged 30. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our sewing semesters run for four months, with each student studying for three hours a day, five days a week. These students are recruited from the community, and are classified as Poor Level One, Two or Three, meaning they live below the poverty line and lack the basic necessities required to survive. These students receive 1kg of rice a day and some flavorings as a stipend to encourage them to study. In these classes, they learn how to make a range of products which are popular in Cambodia (see attached budget) and receive ongoing support and commitment from our sewing teachers. _x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬ÅHHAÃ¢â¬â¢s sewing program gives the students knowledge so then they have pride in themselves because they can support their families.Ã¢â¬Â Ã¢â¬â Saroem, sewing teacher, aged 24. _x000D_
_x000D_
On Fridays, our Vocational Training Manager teaches our students life skills to address some social issues which are prevalent in Cambodia. This includes topics such as hygiene, money management, domestic violence and C.V preparation. Our life skills lessons are a crucial part of our studentsÃ¢â¬â¢ development, as it improves their knowledge and confidence at home and in the community. _x000D_
_x000D_
We offer Opportunity Scholarships for our sewing students children to study English at Human and Hope Association. Each semester, they receive a pack of study resources which enables them to study without having to worry about not lacking the materials to do so. Through the commitment of our education staff, these students learn to love education and understand the importance of it._x000D_
 _x000D_
At the end of each semester, we hold a ceremony and present each student with a pack of sewing materials, a certificate and a C.V so they can apply for jobs. The sewing students are given the opportunity to purchase a sewing machine through our microfinance program. We currently have a 100% repayment rate, with all the ladies earning money making and fixing clothes for their neighbors at their homes. Each week, the sewing repayments are collected by our team, and we can offer any advice needed. _x000D_
_x000D_
We also have sewing assistant job opportunities for some students, where they are hired part time to assist our sewing teachers in class. This enables the sewing assistants to also have their own home sewing business for the other half of the day. _x000D_
Additionally, two students from each class are selected to be seamstresses in our home sewing business program. The students hired will be classified as Ã¢â¬Ëcasual employeesÃ¢â¬â¢ at Human and Hope Association and will receive employee benefits. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our seamstresses will be paid the equivalent of 50 cents per hour. They can earn a minimum of $15 a month, and a maximum of $30 a month. If HHA receives a special order, they can earn up to a maximum of $70 a month, dependent on how many products they make. The hourly payment and minimum and maximum salary will be reviewed every six months. When giving feedback, the sewing students said the salary was fair, and they agreed there should be a maximum salary so they are motivated to fix their neighbours clothes, thus they are not completely dependent on HHA and are empowered to make their own income._x000D_
Our products are currently being sold at several outlets across Siem Reap, with the profit being put back into our sewing business and other projects. and later this year we will launch an online store. We are planning a domestic expansion to match growth, with the aim to have our own dedicated store so we can have a dedicated source of income for this project. _x000D_
_x000D_
Ã¢â¬ÅI like studying at HHA because the teachers are good. HHA has good rules, and all the staff are friendly and kind. The teachers tell us everything they know, they do not keep the knowledge for themselves.Ã¢â¬Â Ã¢â¬â Leak, beginner sewing student, aged 39._x000D_
_x000D_
With $25,000USD, we can increase the amount of students enrolled in the program. Up until now, it has been challenging due to the amount of funds it takes to run the program, and also the fact that some students have to travel many kilometres on their bicycles to get to our program. In November, we are moving to our own building in a more rural area where many of our students come from, which means we can expand our reach due to our location. We already have an effective system set up, which we are constantly seeking feedback from the students and teachers on, and making improvements where necessary. A grant would allow us to purchase more sewing machines, fund more students through the program, provide additional microfinance loans and transform our community. The repayments from the microfinance loans will be allocated to our sewing budget, so we can continue to train community members and provide small business loans. _x000D_
_x000D_

project_details:
The main problem we are solving is poverty. Poverty in our commune is caused by a lack of stable employment opportunities, underpayment of work and physically demanding labor, which causes health issues. Due to a lack of child care available, many women must stay at home to take care of their children, meaning their employment opportunities are limited. For those women who are able to work outside, most did not finish school, and as a result have limited options for employment. This leads to a lack of confidence, where they generally feel as though they cannot be good role models for their children and encourage them to study to move out of the poverty cycle. _x000D_
In our commune, domestic violence is a serious issue linked to poverty, with women not having the confidence or money to leave their husbands. The majority of poor people in our commune are dependent on rice crops and farming, and due to climate change, their crops have been impacted and their livelihoods affected drastically. _x000D_

To be empowered means to have something of great value, the power to get things done.  If we are powerful, we will be able to express what we need for ourselves and our families and have the capacity to get those things.   We donÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢t know for sure what problems we will be facing.   We will need clean water, more sustainable fuel, better health care, and the resources to keep our children in school.  No matter how we get the power and strength now, we know we will be able to apply it later as new challenges arise, one after another.
The actions implemented in this first grant period will strengthen us in three ways.   We will get financial resources that will give us the independence to act for the benefit of our families.   We will get practical experience that will allow us to expand our business efforts in the future..  And will have a leadership trained in the modern skills we need to make our organization adaptable and sustainable and more capable of serving us.
We Maasai women and our sister pastoralists in the districts of Tanzania near Monduli will be engaged in funds-generating businesses that will allow us individually and collectively to set priorities that we can not now set because we do not now control enough of our family finances.    We will be able to bring a focus to the things we and our children need.     We value improvements in our homes, improved access to resources like clean water and fuel, and most important,   better and more sustained education for our children.     We have to learn a lot ourselves to accomplish these goals effectively, so we will include our own education in our program.   We need business skills, modern communication skills, and even the ability to drive a car or a motorcycle.   Our results will be founded on empowerment with integrity.  That means the  power we create for ourselves will be general power.  We will be better able to help ourselves and our children to prevail, succeed, and lead when future problems and issues come that we can not now  predict._x000D_

Our organization is intimately embedded in the communities where we will be working to accomplish these goals.  We will have feedback and testimony from the Maasai women every day.   We are the women of these communities ourselves.   It will be strongly in our interest to be very sensitive to accomplishments and obstacles as we work, and we will report them openly.  We will keep good records of everything we do and they will be available to all. We don't yet have a website and facebook page but will be establishing them._x000D_
We are also close to the sponsors and implementers of the Maasai Stoves and  Solar Project.  Many of us got our training and some of out inspiration through the work with them.    The organization doing that, the International Collaborative for Science, Education, and the Environment, is registered and known as the  ICSEE(Tanzania) and ICSEE(USA).  They have established a firm culture of direct contact with the village women with whom they work.    We can use their social media to reach the public and our supporters until we have established our own.   Their web site is      www.internationalcollaborative.org
The ICSEE is our ally, and is committed to helping the MPWO.   It can not provide the funding for the full program we are developing, but will be there to ensure we move forward and prevail as we seek larger scale funding.
project_name: Maasai Women Taking Command:  the Monduli Pastoralist Women's Organization
project_summary:
In 2009, an international Non-profit NGO began work in Monduli district, Tanzani, to introduce clean cookstoves to us Maasai women who were cooking with open fires in our poorly ventilated homes._x000D_
The leaders of this NGO, the International Collaborative for Science, Education, and the Environment, were very sensitive to the situation of the women.   They could see that we had little opportunity to learn new skills and earn money that we could use according to our own priorities._x000D_
_x000D_
The NGO approached each aspect of their project as an opportunity to broaden and improve the lives of us women.    Most importantly, our homes were smoky and sooty because of the way we were cooking.  The smoke was very bad for our children.   And we were wasting too many hours gathering wood to burn. The project realized a chimney-stove was necessary for our health.   But a chimney-stove canÃ¢â¬â¢t just be bought in the market and carried home.  It has to be installed.  And for the chimney to be cool enough to be safe for our children, it had to be made out of bricks.   _x000D_
_x000D_
The stove project used this opportunity to train the women, and now over 100 women, 10 to 15 women in each village, are masters of stove installation.  We learned how to use tools, to mix cement mortar, to lay bricks, to cut holes through our roofs, to install and maintain stoves.   We also learned how to conserve wood and have a clean, smoke-free home.   We also installed solar electric systems, solar panels, lights and cell phone chargers.   Of course, we developed a thirst for more learning, gaining more modern capabilities._x000D_
_x000D_
The project paid the women a stipend for each stove they helped install.   As individuals, we were very happy to get this money and to be able to use it for things we needed without having to ask our husbands for it.   But we realized that we could do much more if we joined together in an organization of our own.   We are continuing to work with the stove project because the benefits for our childrenÃ¢â¬â¢s health and for our clean new homes must still be brought to many more women.   But with an organization of our own, working together, we can accomplish much more for ourselves and our families.  So in April of this year we created the Monduli Pastoralist WomenÃ¢â¬â¢s Organization, the MPWO._x000D_
_x000D_
We are beginning with 100 members who come from the stove installation teams.   However the organization welcomes all pastoralist women of the districts near Monduli town._x000D_
_x000D_
Due to the large scale of Monduli district, we are organized in two zones, one centered at Monduli Town and the other in the rift valley at Mto wa Mbu.    Officers for the Monduli zone and the Rift Valley zone have been elected; these officers include coordinators responsible for keeping the women of the two zones working together well._x000D_
_x000D_
We are just getting started but have the benefit of advice and assistance from the ICSEE leaders in our community and have acquired valuable experience from working with them.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Our plan   _x000D_
_x000D_
We are planning and have begun two kinds of activities;   Our program has four parts._x000D_
_x000D_
1.   We will start appropriate businesses for profit and make them a success._x000D_
_x000D_
Profits will be put back into the businesses but with some distributed directly to the members for their own needs.   Maasai women normally have only $200 per year of income that they control and the shared profits from these businesses will help them do more for their families (e..g, keeping their daughters in school)._x000D_
_x000D_
2.    Our leaders will get rigorous training in finance, management, fund raising, public relations, and utilizing internet and social media In college in Arusha_x000D_
_x000D_
3.    Some of our members will be trained in other skills we need, like driving._x000D_
_x000D_
4.   We will add social service and public education work that is urgently needed in our communities._x000D_
_x000D_
Specifically in these four categories we will include:_x000D_
_x000D_
1.  Businesses:_x000D_
_x000D_
1a.  The first small business was started in May of 2014.   40 young goats were purchased.  They will be sold for a profit in September.   Purchase price, $30 each (U. S. dollars).  Expected sales price $50 each._x000D_
_x000D_
1b.   Larger scale livestock business.    45 young male cows and 90 young male goats will be purchased, cared for, and sold at high market process.  This will yield an expected profit in six months of between  $8,000 and $11,000.    		_x000D_
_x000D_
1c.   Cement brick production and sales                     _x000D_
_x000D_
There is a lot of construction going on in the towns and even the rural areas that requires good quality cement-based bricks.   For good quality, motorized mixing of ingredients is needed.   We will build a brick making factory on the grounds of the ICSEE stoves project factory.  _x000D_
_x000D_
2. Business Training courses:						_x000D_
_x000D_
Kimahama College in Arusha provides a variety of 3 month courses.  These include Project development, Planning, and business management.   Four of our leaders will go for these courses._x000D_
_x000D_
3.  Other Practical training 						 _x000D_
_x000D_
3a.    None of us can drive a car or ride a motorcycle.   This creates a dependence that we wish to overcome.  We will send two women to driving school for both cars and motorcycles._x000D_
_x000D_
3b.   Many of us have small farms, and our productivity can be improved.   We will send two of our members to a course on farming productivity.  _x000D_
_x000D_
4. Social Service and Public Education_x000D_
_x000D_
As we accumulate profits, we will start activities around some of our deepest concerns and worries.   Many young Maasai girls and boys stay in secondary school no matter how hard it is on their families or what sacrifices are required.     But they are often not well-taught in the schools and, as a result, they often fail national exams and are not allowed to continue in government schools.    There is nowhere for them to go, and no further education they can afford.    We want to work with local government and NGOs to start an institution to provide vocational training for those forced out of school with no possible employment before them._x000D_
_x000D_
We will also set up a fund to help the poorest women among us to keep their daughters in school.  _x000D_
project_details: We Maasai women know our lives can be better with less time devoted to menial labor, and with healthier and better educated children taking us toward a better future.   Most of us have little education.  We want more for our children.   Most of us spend our labor just maintaining the traditional households, but these households are not healthy and do not provide the environment our children need to be ready for the rapidly changing conditions they will face in life.    Our husbands sometimes share our needs and goals, but not always.  We must push forward for ourselves.   We have values and priorities and we can get them expressed only by organizing ourselves and providing the leadership that is traditionally lacking along the lines we need followed.    We have learned how strong we can be through our participation in the Maasai Stoves and Solar Project of the ICSEE.   Now, with that new strength, we can organize ourselves to achieve many other goals that have been neglected up to now.
