project_name: Functional literacy and vocational training for School Mothers in South Sudan
project_summary:
School Mothers (SMs) are locally nominated women that act as role models and spokespersons for girls since 2008. School Mothers successfully address gender inequality in schools by providing guidance for girls in schools; representing girls at school and community meetings and visiting families of out-of-school girls. Low enrollment and high drop-out rates of girls in community schools in South Sudan reflect challenges such as early marriage, pregnancy, the prioritization of boys' education and domestic work. In Western Equatoria the work of 25 School Mothers has resulted in the enrollment of 2,320 girls in the project schools since 2011 and the proportion of girls increased from 42.1% to 45% in comparison to control schools. _x000D_
School Mothers are the major change makers in this project. While being well-respected community members, the majority of SMs are illiterate or have only enjoyed a few years of primary school. The project aims to ensure 25 School Mothers have the capacity to advocate for and support girls' education independently by providing them with literacy and numeracy training, vocational training and start up grants for income generating activities. Ultimately, the project will provide over 4,000 disadvantaged school aged girls and boys with improved access to and support for primary schooling. The project will also advocate for increased involvement of men and boys in primary education, specifically the promotion of girls' education. _x000D_
_x000D_
School Mothers report that attitudes towards girls' education and girls' rights are beginning to improve, but that continued support is essential to combat early marriage and pregnancy and that many neighboring school communities are in need of assistance. Drops in the number of forced and early marriage have been directly attributed to the work of the School Mothers by community members and teachers. School Mothers said they speak with the teachers and advise them on their conduct towards the girls in their class and teachers say in turn SMs Ã¢â¬Ëare doing an excellent jobÃ¢â¬â¢. School Mothers explained that they also support boys at risk in their school and family visits. They requested skills training in order to generate funds and to provide more support for school girls in need as well as training on how to engage boys and men._x000D_
_x000D_
Undertake a needs and market analysis in each of the four States to tailor the training programme for School Mothers so that it is relevant to their needs and local environment. Support School Mothers to visit schools at least weekly, and continue their activities representing girls in the community. Train 25 School Mothers in functional English literacy and numeracy skills depending on their current literacy and numeracy skills set. A flexible approach to course delivery and timing will be adopted based on AETÃ¢â¬â¢s experience of non-formal education programmes. This will include training local tutors to deliver training to School Mothers from a cluster of schools. Literacy and numeracy training will build the confidence of School Mothers and increase their ability to advocate and take on vocational training. The project will furthermore provide vocational training on the basis of the preference of School Mothers and provide small start-up grants. _x000D_
_x000D_
Run an advocacy campaign through radio broadcasts and school based community involvement days to involve men and boys in supporting girls' education. The radio based advocacy campaign will support SM's advocacy efforts and respond to the need 'for a massive advocacy campaign that will involve male community leaders and male church leaders, as well as compel fathers to take their children to school and stop child marriages' (needs assessment, September 2013).

project_summary:
SEVA, the organization has been working for poor and vulnerable women for more than a decade now. It has wide experience in dealing with issues of women and is now recognized as a pioneer organization working on women issues in the district. With the grant money the organization aims to work for the victims of trafficking and help them become economically independent in the long run. It also aims to create awareness on issues of women at the community level thereby trying to create a violence free society in the long run. It is a known fact that even after 6 decades of Independence, women continue to be a victim of violence in one form or the other. Victims of trafficking are one of the most vulnerable groups who lose all control on their lives. When these victims are rescued great care has to be taken to ensure their social integration in a dignified manner. One of the tools that can be applied here is ensuring their economic independence so that they are able to live a dignified life. _x000D_
The project will play proactive role to ensure that the victims of violence are provided with suitable support as per their need. This would help them to revive from the agony and pain they have faced to some extent. In the long run the project will go in for providing them with vocational training and help them to start their own business to help them live a life with dignity in coming days. _x000D_
The project will directly intervene to provide support to 25 victims of violence who have been rescued by the initiative undertaken by SEVA. But indirectly it will reach out to a greater number of victims by organizing training programs, awareness initiatives and providing immediate counseling support and linking them with appropriate government agency or program for support, in case of need. The indirect beneficiary would be around 5000 community members, including women and children. This initiative would help to ensure that community people become aware and hence do not fall prey in the hands of traffickers.  Attempt will be made to strengthen already existing mechanisms for ensuring justice to women who are victims of violence so that they are able to get justice on the one hand and on the other are socially integrated thereby ensuring a decent life for them. _x000D_
The team would identify the most vulnerable women/girl who had been rescued at different time by the initiative of SEVA. These women would basically be identified on the basis of their social background and their vulnerability. This would be followed by identifying their interest and strength area so that a suitable training program can be devised accordingly. Thereafter they would be given a support to initiate the business plan. Regular support would be provided to them to ensure the proper establishment of the business. _x000D_

The current situation is 4 out of 5 girls in the settlement area do not go pass grade 10 education, they get pregnant before reaching the age of 24 and are pushed into marriage. The women who do not have formal ways of earing income end up bearing children raising, gambling most of time, turning to sex for money and or engage in polygamy practices. The number of teenage pregnancy is growing in the area with many unplanned and unwanted pregnancy resulting to unsafe abortions. The women and girls are victims of domestic violence, drug (marijuana) and alcohol (homebrew). project_details_other:
Research has shown that empowering girls has tremendous impact on the community. If 1,000 girls become healthy, stable, and either acquiring education or employed, the township community will be significantly affected. We expect to see economic improvement, a decline in HIV/TB infection rates, teenage pregnancy, and unemployment, as well as a measurable increase in psychosocial,  and health and stability markers for girls and women and their families, who will be immediately impacted.
The project will affect the community by bringing immediate relief to the immediate families of the girls and women in the program. Food security will increase as women bring in more income and, where appropriate, grow their own food or obtain government assistance. Babies will be born virus-free, saving their families from lifetimes of pain and worry. School attendance and success rates will rise. Unwanted pregnancy will fall as we educate both men and women. Besides the tangible metrics, we expect to see an immediate shift in self-confidence in our clients.
We have two aims:_x000D_
1. Level the playing field between the sexes so that girls/women have the same opportunities, possibilities, and access to health and education as boys/men._x000D_
2. Provide comprehensive gender-sensitive services to our clients in order to empower them, their families, and the entire community._x000D_
_x000D_
These aims fit into the Ubuntu Model, which provides comprehensive services to clients from cradle to career. In concrete terms, this means we will be there for these 1,000 beneficiaries in every possible way. We will assess and meet all their needs, from school uniforms to pre- and post-natal care to cheering them on when they graduate or bring home their first paychecks. We will ensure that they are confident and prepared for lifeÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s challenges._x000D_

Every client will have an Ubuntu Passport, a personal document where we record every interaction, visit, workshop, intervention, immunization, and any other statistic about her trajectory at Ubuntu. This will help us follow our clients' progress and ensure that all team members, from counselors to nurses to teachers, are fully informed at all times. McKinsey and Company helped us develop a tracking system, and we use metrics to categorize our clients as Off- or On-track, using health, education and social indicators, pretest and post-test results, observations of household stability, and other measurable metrics.  _x000D_
UbuntuÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s Monitoring & Evaluation team kept meticulous track of each and every intervention, while ensuring that our data was both standardized and confidential. We used myriad monitoring processes, which involved a compilation of registers that tracked school lunch distribution, workshop attendance, client intake forms, home assessment forms, and services logs on a weekly basis. Monthly internal and external reports reflected the number and type of interventions, while six-month cumulative milestone reports detailed targets and actuals. These reports, along with our counselorsÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢ case reviews, have ensured that our systems are effective and efficient. _x000D_

project_summary:
Life in the townships of Port Elizabeth is hard and, for women and girls, it is exponentially harder as they must cope with severe gender inequity and discrimination at all levels. From higher risks of contracting HIV to fewer economic opportunities to gender-based violence, women face particularly daunting challenges. Our project seeks to redress this imbalance while lifting up the entire community. _x000D_
1,000 girls and women will receive comprehensive household stability, health, and education services._x000D_
_x000D_
Household Stability_x000D_
We will conduct regular home assessments, in which our Family Support Specialists will assess presenting problems, track progress toward family goals, and adjust case management plans. We will provide child protection initiatives including food support, assistance accessing government grants, ventilation and hygiene education, as well as security improvements like installing doors, burglar-proofing windows, and distributing padlocks. Families also benefit from psychosocial services, encompassing one-on-one intensive and basic counseling, memory box therapy, and support groups for HIV-positive clients. UbuntuÃ¢â¬â¢s household stability programming engages entire families. We provide parenting courses to our caregivers, offer comprehensive healthcare, and encourage them to attend our drop-in computer, beadwork, baking, and gardening classes. These courses develop parentsÃ¢â¬â¢ and grandparentsÃ¢â¬â¢ marketable skills, helping them generate additional household income. _x000D_
_x000D_
Health_x000D_
ChildrenÃ¢â¬â¢s success in school is deeply connected to their health and well-being. Girls carry the additional burden of being the ones more likely to miss school in order to take care of sick people at home. _x000D_
In 2011, Ubuntu opened the regionÃ¢â¬â¢s first pediatric clinic. We maintain a cross-referral relationship with local healthcare facilities. Equipped with a fully stocked pharmacy, world-class medical technology, and a team under the supervision of our doctor, our clinic will addresses all our clientsÃ¢â¬â¢ needs. _x000D_
_x000D_
HIV and TB Services_x000D_
Women are three times more likely than men to be infected with HIV. 1,000 South Africans die from AIDS every day. This epidemic is compounded by widespread tuberculosis (TB), with local infection rates of more than double the regional average and triple the global average. We offer comprehensive annual HIV and TB screenings for all our clients, periodic testing campaigns at the Ubuntu Centre, as well as community outreach screening initiatives. HIV-positive Ubuntu women and girls will receive their antiretroviral treatment from our pharmacy, participate in age-appropriate support groups, attend monthly routine check-ups with our doctor, and benefit from our adherence support services. We will provide one-on-one counseling, status disclosure support, and empowerment seminars. Clients receiving their TB treatment at Ubuntu will also receive their medication at our pharmacy and benefit from follow-up appointments with our medical team, and be able to enroll in adherence support programming. To keep these patients healthy, UbuntuÃ¢â¬â¢s medical team will offer offered comprehensive health screenings, nutritional support, treatment for all minor ailments, and referrals for chronic conditions._x000D_
_x000D_
Sexual and Reproductive Health_x000D_
We will provide Pap smears, breast exams, sexually transmitted disease testing and treatment, distribution of birth control, family planning counseling, as well as sexual education seminars.  Teenage girls will receive menstruation kits and education. Our Prevention-of-Mother-to-Child Transmission program will provide prenatal and postnatal care to HIV-positive pregnant women. Services will encompass routine check-ups with our doctor, ultrasounds to track fetal development and complications, HIV drug regimens specific to pregnancy, HIV inhibitors for newborns, infant HIV testing, nutritional counseling, vitamin supplements, and breastfeeding support. Previous participants have all given birth to HIV-negative babies, saving them from a lifelong virus. _x000D_
_x000D_
Primary Care, Preventative Care, and Wellness_x000D_
Ubuntu will offer preventative healthcare and education for families. They will receive annual comprehensive medical screenings, routine check-ups with our nurses and doctor, dental and vision care, immunizations following the World Health Organization timeline, deworming, as well as treatment for all minor ailments and outside referrals when necessary. _x000D_
Our dietician will administer regular nutritional screenings, offer counseling, and distribute vitamin supplements. She will conduct growth-monitoring assessments for our toddlers and design case management plans for malnourished clients. Our counselors will hold seminars on substance abuse, hygiene, healthy eating, cancer, and exercise. _x000D_
_x000D_
Education_x000D_
We design our academic initiatives to take into account the failures of the local education system, supplement our clientsÃ¢â¬â¢ lessons at school, and provide programming to everyone from toddlers to university students to out-of-school youth. _x000D_
_x000D_
Early Childhood Development (ECD)_x000D_
Our ECD program includes 3 toddler classes, and has expanded to include the students who have moved on to Grade R in local schools. We now have 51 girls enrolled in the initiative, which provides world-class numeracy, literacy, and social/emotional programming to establish adequate academic foundations._x000D_
_x000D_
After-School Program (ASP)_x000D_
Many clients require significant supplementary support. Our ASP will provide leadership, confidence building skills workshops, computer literacy, and tutoring. These workshops instill the life skills that girls need to succeed in the classroom and beyondÃ¢â¬âtime management, communication and debate, decision-making capacity, literacy, and numeracyÃ¢â¬âwhile folding in academic material. We will also offer extracurricular activities like baking, debate, ceramics, art, yoga, and ballroom dancing. _x000D_
Ubuntu will run holiday camps during school breaks. Topics will range from human rights to gender equality to leadership. Both ASP and holiday camps include workshops on teen pregnancy, gender paradigms, substance abuse, and peer pressure. _x000D_
_x000D_
Future Leaders Program_x000D_
This initiative will prepare high-performing Grade 12 girls for university. These scholars will receive intensive academic support, particularly in science and mathematics, to prepare them for higher education. In addition to helping our students study for their matric exams, our teachers will guide them through the university application process, and help them access financial aid. We will simultaneously prepare them for the inevitable social and emotional challenges of university._x000D_
_x000D_
Ubuntu Pathways (UP)_x000D_
The Eastern Cape continues to have the lowest matric pass rates in South Africa; approximately 40% of secondary school students fail. Ubuntu will always have a percentage, albeit a decreasing one, of clients who either drop out before secondary school or fail their matric exams. With UP, they will receive intensive career guidance, classes on CV writing strategies, interviewing skills, computer literacy, entrepreneurship workshops, and job readiness training. _x000D_

project_summary: Meri Toksave is a youth-led, non-profit organisation that is based on providing youth engagement and solutions towards combating gender based, family and sexual violence in Papua New Guinea (PNG). The first initiative the Meri Toksave carried out was centered on overcoming the inaccessibility and invisibility of contact information for emergency services. Meri Toksave create the first country wide 'Directory of Emergency Services for Those Affected by Family and Sexual Violence.' The online copy was launched in December 2013 and the hard copy launched in January 2014. It is significant for this directory to be consistently updated as a living document, as the information it carries has the potential to save lives. Therefore Meri Toksave would use the money from Project Inspire to continue keeping the directory updated on a yearly basis. Funds would be used to re-verify the directory and have the updated hard copies printed in English and Tok Pisin (the most spoken language in the country). Meri Toksave would also like to see the directory in app form that would be free to download, as the use smart phones in PNG is growing. Further in September of 2013 the PNG Government passed the Family Protection Bill making domestic and sexual violence a criminal offence. In addition the grant money would also go towards developing the next campaign. Meri Toksave would like to create a mass advertising and awareness campaign that is centered on educating the public about their rights but also responsibilities under the Family Protection Bill, through the used of popular media mediums (tv advertisements, flyers, radio ads etc).
project_details:
Meri Toksave being a youth-led organisation is attempting to provide youth engagement and solutions towards combating gender based violence. _x000D_
Firstly, the Directory attempts to overcome the information asymmetry, strengthen existing referral systems, and map services so that members of the public and other organisations are able to identify what services are available. The directory has allowed other organisations that work in the fired of gender-based-violence (GBV) to map existing services and therefore identify gaps. Meri Toksave has identified through the directory that there are substantial gaps in counselling services, legal support and available safe houses. Secondly, the mass advertising and awareness campaign of the rights and responsibilities individuals have under the recently passed Family Protection Bill is attempting to educate and inform the public and therefore overcome the lack of knowledge that the general public has about this bill.

project_details:
As refugee women seek refugee in their countries of asylum, little do they know of the challenges that awaits them. Once in asylum refugee women face unemployment, limited access to health, education and social services. Many times and in the situation of South Africa, they suffer xenophobia. They therefore rely on their male counterparts to rescue them. Many girls are forced to marry early and mothers are forced to remain in abusive relationships._x000D_
Due to their legal status refugee women do not qualify for business loans with banks. Those who have managed to save up a little bit to start a business, often lack the required knowledge and skills to grow and sustain their businesses._x000D_
This denial to a critical aspect of their development also creates a group of third class citizens formed of poorest of the poor of which refugee women are part of. Women and girls whose voices go unheard of year in year out despite their potential to become agents of change in their communities.

Within the next 3 years, the DREET Centre will reach 25% or 330 000 people in South Korea and estimated 10% or 120 000 people, treating and preventing hearing impairment. In addition to treatment, education, and prevention of hearing impairment, Fair Women Fair World project will continue the peace initiative, and create interactive sessions between North and South Korean women who are deaf. In North Korea especially, Fair Women Fair World will help give access to public education to over 600 children in hopes it will break the cycle of poverty. Once this project is stable, we will replicate similar projects globally, and in Israel and Jordan specifically as there are established Solar Ear operations in both areas. 
By the end of the grant period, Fair Women Fair World project will empower 10 women who will continue to work at Delight Co., reduce potential hearing loss in Korea by 10% or 1.2 million people (Est. since 50% is preventable) through DREET Centres with existing audiologists, provide the cheapest hearing aids (exact price of government subsidy $299.99), and start a peace initiative between North and South Korea. Most importantly, in the short-term, once oppressed people will be empowered, valued, and gain confidence. They will speak-up and be an inspiration throughout the media we will provide. It is our hope that our efforts with these empowered people will create a fair world. 
The project results are simple. We want to create a Fair World with Fair Women. Through empowerment of women with the internship program, DREET Centre, and peace initiative, we are committed to achieve the mission this project stands for: Let the world hear the sounds of peace through the oppressed. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 360 million people would benefit from a hearing aid. Yet only 10% of hearing aids are sold, mainly to affluent members of these countries. Solar EarÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s mission is make total hearing health, possible for people worldwide with a priority in developing countries and underserved communities by providing: ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ãâaffordable and sustainable hearing amplification equipment to all who need itÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬ÃÂ. To achieve our mission, we refused to patent our technology, so it will be more accessible. With each region we target to reduce hearing impairment, we give the opportunity for the empowered deaf, and deaf women in particular to make a difference. In Botswana, it was HIV AIDS education, Fair Women Fair World, aims to create peace between North and South Korea.  Finally, for this project, is to give children the opportunity for an education. Article 26 of UN Charter on Human Rights, states 'everyone has the right to educationÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬ÃÂ. This project aims to empower and encourage women to stand for a cause for a Fair World.

For this project, the most obvious evidence to verify success is the level of confidence in the women who will participate in the internship program. Their self-worth will present itself. Perhaps the most ambitious source of evidence would be for the government of Korea to be moved by this initiative, and turn their efforts to not only empowerment of women, but peacemaking with North Korea. project_summary:
Mfariji Africa through their program Sanitary Sanity Campaign intends to reach the marginalized and disadvantaged corners of the country where the communities live by myths, traditions, beliefs and hearsay's about menstruation and all misinformation about the same. The organization seeks to enlighten the women in such communities on menstruation, teenager and growing girls on puberty and provide the school going girls of puberty age the sanitary towels to ensure they keep in school even during their menstrual flow. The organization further seeks to support such schools girls from poor social economic background with annual packs of sanitary towels in a way that they shall never drop out of school anytime with a reason tag Ã¢â¬â menstrual flow or lack of sanitary towels.  _x000D_
According to APHRC (2010), Limited access to safe affordable, convenient and culturally appropriate methods for dealing with menstruation has far reaching implications for rights and physical, social and mental well-being of many women and adolescent girls in Kenya. It undermines sexual and reproductive health and well-being and has been shown to restrict access to education. UNESCO estimates that one in 10 African adolescent girls miss school during menses and eventually drop out because of menstruation-related issues, such as the inaccessibility of affordable sanitary protection, the social taboos related to menstruation, and the culture of silence that surrounds it (All Africa, 2011).  According to UNICEF, (2005), one in ten schoolgirls in Africa miss classes or drop out completely due to their period, and substitute pads or tampons for less safe and less absorbent materials such as rags, newspaper or bark. _x000D_
In the Kenyan scenario, a study conducted by the Federation of African Women Educationists (FAWE) in 2010 found that about 500,000 Kenyan girls miss school every month because they cannot afford sanitary towels. The major concern for Kenya as a pioneer country in east Africa for free and compulsory primary education (FPE) eight years ago is the challenge of high enrolment. This has been too challenging that it has started eating up the achievement gained in the free primary education (FPE) which was aimed at enrolling high number of children in the school system. _x000D_
_x000D_
Acknowledging the threat that lack of sanitary towel pose to the girl child education in Kenya, the government rolled out a programme to provide and distribute sanitary towels to the girls in primary and secondary schools in Kenya as a matter of necessity in FPE. According to the KenyaÃ¢â¬â¢s ministry of education, the government allocated Ksh. 240 Million in the Financial Year 2011/2012 for provision of sanitary towels. This was targeted to benefit 443,858 girls in public primary drawn from 82 targeted districts. However, this allocation is not adequate to meet needs of the 2.6 million girls in primary and secondary schools. Kenya has got 254 districts as of July 2009; the target of 82 districts only, means provision of Sanitary towels to only 32% of the primary schools in the whole Nation. The Ministry of education further stated that the funds provided by the government will only be able to help primary schools in the targeted 82 districts. This implies that secondary schools in the said districts will never attain any help from the government provisions. This also does not factor in those others schools that fall in the untargeted 172 districts. _x000D_
_x000D_
The biggest challenge to the Government provision is that it is lacking by 91% to ensure a full rollout of the programme. This is because; the programme requires 2.6 Billion shillings and the Government provided only Kshs. 240 Million shillings which is only 9% of the required amount of money. The Government programme does not cater for the Puberty education that is also very essential for the communities where these teenagers are coming from. This implies that if no other measures are taken, then the rate of school dropout by the teenagers and girls in their puberty age will still remain or even increase due to lack of knowledge, help or sanitary towels. This therefore prompts Mfariji Africa to act through Sanitary Sanity Campaign rather than wait and watch the young girls suffer due to lack of sanitary towels. The fact is that the organization can never make to rollout the whole programme satisfactorily, but with the necessary support, itÃ¢â¬â¢s optimistic that they can make a change to the marginalized school going girls, disadvantaged and to those from poor social economic background._x000D_

We thank them all for their concern, commitment and generous support to the girls who without them would not be in school due to lack of sanitary towels or could be missing their classes during their menstrual periods. _x000D_
As you can see from the proposed overall budget of 25,000 USD Sanitary Sanity Campaign (SSC) is not including most of the personnel labour and technical managerial experts as they have got Volunteer members who by offering their services have significantly lowered this budget to ensure 500,000 girls are reached. _x000D_

project_summary:
We want to create a Fair World with Fair Women. Even in the most globalized and socially advance societies of today, complacency and neglect has taken at toll on millions. According to the World Health Organization, approximately 5% or 360 million people suffer from disabling hearing loss, and 33% of seniors over 65 are impaired. Nearly half of hearing losses are avoidable through primary prevention, and for those impaired, current production of hearing aids supply less than 10% of the global need. Of these 360 million people, women are marginalized to the greatest extent._x000D_
Current solution of providing hearing aids is limited in its scope and brings only temporary relief. Rather, we will be addressing the root of the problem. Now is especially an apt time to launch our project Ã¢â¬ÅFair Women Fair WorldÃ¢â¬Â, because of the synergy we expect from global attention. Most recent example is the private advisory group composed of prominent individuals - like the CEO of McKinsey & Company - in conjunction with the UN Women Committee. Fair Women Fair World will directly affect 1.5 million people within the next 5 years through the empowerment marginalized women (especially women who are deaf), preventing hearing loss, creating global awareness, and starting a peace initiative in its domestic country: Creating a Fair World with Fair Women._x000D_
_x000D_
This project will take place in South and North Korea for reasons of efficiency, urgency, and sustainment. Because of our existing partnership with South Korean companies (specifically catered for the deaf) in addition to our manufacturing facility established in China, North and South Korea is an ideal and efficient place for the launch. Moreover, this is an urgent issue for both countries. North Korea is one of the most politically reproached regimes. While developing countries like Botswana often evoke sympathy, North Korea evokes hostility. Thus humanitarian aids are limited Ã¢â¬â even legally - and are one-time events at best. Lack of infrastructure and aid with their patriarchic culture puts women, in dismay. Its neighbor to the South is on par. South Korea, despite the fact it is a socially advanced country, women (and especially those who are deaf) are mistreated severely. The most notable case is the sexual assault case of 9 deaf-mute students from 2000-2003 in Gwangju Inhwa School. These girls were raped multiple times by their teachers including the principal until the incident was reported by a newly appointed teacher. As such, silenced victims exist even in the most socially advanced societies. Our objective is to make lasting changes. _x000D_
_x000D_
We can start making this difference with the help of Project Inspire. Fair Women Fair World implementation is divided into three tiers: short-term, mid-term and long-term. In the short term, we are planning to launch a 10 week internship program in partnership with Delight Co. for women who are deaf. Starting with 3-day training with audiologists and current employees, these women will be equipped to help build hearing aids. Every three months from then, 20 hearing aids will be sent to North Korean children. Only hearing aids to children will be provided because of legal issues surrounding seize fire. Furthermore, children, will be able to receive public education if they receive hearing aids before the age of 3, making them the prime target in order to break the cycle of poverty in North Korea. Deaf women will personally lead the change because the deaf have more in common than the average citizens of each country Ã¢â¬â the culture of deafness. Closer to the end of the internship, the media (TBS, who has done a similar feature of a deaf female Starbucks worker, or KBS if possible) will be contacted to capture the change in these women, and what these women stand for. By using the media, we want to let everyone see these marginalized women change the world. _x000D_
_x000D_
On the mid-term, the increased attention created by the media will allow these women to be full-time employees. Additionally, the usual one-time gift of hearing aids to North Korea will be a sustained donation as profits from these women, as well as sponsorship from Solar Ear. Our ambitious project is to open a DREET Center (Detection, Research, Education, Equipment, Training) in both South and North Korea. Detection: free hearing test facility, Research: hearing-impaired demography, Education: prevention education, Equipment: Solar rechargers & hearing aid manufacturing, Training: sign language & hearing aid user guide. To reiterate, nearly half of hearing loss can be prevented. DREET will have $3500 allocated initially, and additional funds will be raised through crowd funding and microfinance. With our network of experts in the field including university professors, this strategy has an optimistic outlook. _x000D_
_x000D_
In the long-term, the entirety of the project will be featured by the media for a second time to show the peace initiative shown by the most marginalized population. Once silenced people will have a chance to speak, and be the source of inspiration. With that momentum, and publicity, and help of other organizations like the public advisory for womenÃ¢â¬â¢s rights, we will replicate this initiative all over the world. _x000D_
_x000D_
Our mission is not to only provide hearing aids Ã¢â¬â itÃ¢â¬â¢s to change the world. We have already successfully educated deaf men and women about HIV AIDS in Botswana, and the rate was lowered from 38% to 10% in the deaf population. Deaf youth of Botswana went to Brazil and trained new employees to empower them. In Brazil we offer auditory, speech language and voice therapy for free to over 6,000 children a year in Sao Paul. In Botswana, employees started at minimum wage, and now make 6-8 times the minimum. We have already implemented projects with great success, and our mission this time is to let the world hear the sounds of peace: Creating a Fair World, with Fair Women_x000D_

Twenty four years now after multi-party democracy was ushered into Malawi, many non Ã¢â¬â governmental and civil society organization have been engaged in civic education to raise awareness as a way of complementing government efforts to safeguard the interests of Malawians. Though efforts have been made, still many people i.e. women, girls, elderly, people living with HIV and people with disabilities do not receive adequate information and support on  empowerment to uplift their quality of life and wellbeing based on social economic growth and improvement. _x000D_
Studies conducted by the organization in some selected communities of Karonga District like Iponga, Wiliro, Nyungwe, Uliwa, Khwawa, Mlare, Kaporo, Songwe and Fuliwa indicated that the poor and marginalised such as women and girls are lacking the technical know-how to handle and run business and concerted efforts to uplift their lives, and Financial support to enable girls pursue with education in their respective communities. These studies targeted women and youth with the aim of tracking knowledge of rural citizens on democratic decentralization processes and women empowerment. The studies involved two hundred fifty three students in twenty five secondary schools in all five Traditional Authorities in the district. These studies revealed that women and girls are lacking skills of business management to reach at higher accelerate their lives economically. This retards economic growth and district development because the majority of women and girls are not illiterate on how to balance their business to meet their needs. _x000D_
_x000D_
The most significant cause of the problem is income generating capacity and financial support to run their business properly and financial capital to accelerate their business which occurs because of gender differences and bad cultural practices. The other core problem is lack of initiatives by civil society organizations that help to facilitate enhancement of influencing policy strategies of gender equality, equity, women empowerment and girl retention to education as way of improving their concerted efforts in business management and education pursuit. Disadvantaged women and girls are used to as employees of men to sell their commodities in the district. This has been a challenge to Karonga women and girls as they have consequently been at low level of education to the part of girls and low economic development to the part of women for them to be self-reliant. Such situations intimidate women and girls as marginalised groups to act on issues affecting their lives socially and economically due to lack of interaction and dialogue between and amongst the innovators, non-state actors and women themselves when making decisions on economic development. This remains a challenge for women to accelerate their businesses for more women to reach at high level of economic development in the district. _x000D_
_x000D_
In addition, inadequate access to information financial resources is also a challenge for the marginalised and discriminated groups of people because implementers are providing information which is not user-friendly when implementing interventions in rural communities. This prevents the people from taking part in issues affecting their lives socially and economically because they do not understand their roles in the socio Ã¢â¬â economic development activities. As a result, it is difficult for them to have any tangible impact on helping to women empowerment in developing the country. This state of ignorance on the part of the community merely retards local and district development economically._x000D_
_x000D_
A key factor in creating conducive environment for women and girls is the existence of equitable economic opportunities in development at local and national levels. Equitable economic opportunities availed to all groups of people is important as it increases greater social inclusion in the development of the individual, district as well as country. This ensures that government utilises local and national wealth for the benefit of all Malawians. In this regard, it is imperative that women and girls are fully empowered to uplift their lives economically. However, the foregoing paragraph highlights some gaps that include lack of women involvement in economic development gaps, linking gaps between funders and disadvantaged women._x000D_
 _x000D_
In view of the identified gaps, Karonga Debate Club (KADEC) intends to implement interventions that are designed to increase information sharing, capacity building and links in business management. KADEC will work with existing structures including volunteers, entrepreneurs and women with an aim of enhancing increased disadvantaged women investments. It is believed that this shall contribute to increased disadvantaged women engagement business operation to uplift their lives through capacity and financial support. _x000D_
_x000D_
The project will undertake a series of trainings of women and girls who are the most disadvantaged in business management and empowerment, conduct public meetings that will carry messages of giving chance to disadvantaged women to keep themselves busy with stable businesses and support them with financial capital developing of pass goat project, mat making and selling rice for them to sustain their lives comfortably, and girls to learn without fear for furtherance of education. It will also lobby private sectors to link with these business women for them be business oriented. Similarly, girls will also be empowered and supported with school fees for them to pursue with education. It is assumed that through these interventions, women and girls will acquire knowledge and understanding of proper management of business which will enable them live a good and stable life. The proposed project shall conduct trainings, and distribution of IEC materials. This means that funds requested shall be used for capacity building of women and girls, public meetings, purchasing of goats for pass goat project, supporting women with financial capital for the to start small scale businesses in their respective homes and salaries for project team._x000D_

project_name: Building the socio-economic status of women and girls living with HIV and AIDS for self reliance
project_summary:
The project intends to contribute to poverty reduction  among women and girls living with HIV/AIDS in Uganda by mitigating the socio-economic impact of the epidemic at individual, household and community levels in line with the Government of UgandaÃ¢â¬â¢s National Strategic Framework (2001/2 Ã¢â¬â 2005/6), The project will contribute to attaining this goal by targeting women and girls living with HIV who have been traditionally marginalised, and by addressing their specific needs and rights to improve their quality of life in the districts of Wakiso, Buyende and Manafa .  The project will  improve the economic livelihood of young women and girls affected and infected with HIV to harness their socio-economic potential and increase self-employment opportunities and income levels._x000D_
Nacwola's operations on the ground closely reflect this purpose.  A key strand of our strategic plan is Ã¢â¬Åenabling an environment for social protection and social transformation of poor, vulnerable and marginalized groups.Ã¢â¬Â NACWOLA believes that socio-economic empowerment is key to poverty eradication, self-sustainability and financial and social independence. Our projects reflect this belief closely and therefore we have extensive experience of implementing these types of projects_x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
Nacwola has direct experience of planning and implementing projects such as this. All over Uganda NACWOLA run projects that facilitate economic empowerment and self-sustainability amongst highly marginalised groups. For example, in Ndejje, the district NACWOLA group run a project making jewellery from recycled paper to sell locally. From a small initial investment, providing for training and start up costs these women have been able to successfully create a sustainable business. This had led to economic security for some 30 young women anf girls who collectively manage time, resources and their own bank account. NACWOLA has been able to add value to this project by introducing the women to international buyers who are able to sell the jewellery at a highly increased price in the UK maximizing profit and therefore return on investment. In the last 12 months the groups have made 8,000,000 UGX, with a net profit of 1,500,000UGX since the project began in 2012. This reflects both the objectives and the operational model for the Youth Livelihood Programme. While the group is self governing and self-sustaining NACWOLA engages in detailed monitoring and evaluation procedures, again closely mirroring the operational model for the Youth Livelihood Programme._x000D_
_x000D_
Through 20 years of experience NACWOLA has found that with a relatively small initial investment groups with the right training and support are able to establish self-sustaining IGA's relatively quickly. In 22 district groups are engaged in bag making activities. For a small intital investment of 2,500,000 UGX NACWOLA was able to train 20 women to make and sell bags locally. This project again is now self-sustaining and has provided economic stability and increased income for more than 80 women in the district. Similarly to the jewellery making project in Ndejje._x000D_
NACWOLA believes that economic independence and self empowerment is key to fight stigma and discrimination and eradicating poverty. All of the training we provide in our projects not only focuses on practical, marketable skills but also on life skills, budgeting, team working and entrepreneurship. For example, our Ã¢â¬ÅGrowing TogetherÃ¢â¬Â project in Bugiri trained a number of women in agriculture including high value crops. However, as part of their training these women were taught book-keeping and record-keeping, accounting and how to maximize return by investing in seed for high demand produce. While this project is still in its pilot phase it has been a great success. After only 3 months the project is beginning to be self-sustaining, the women are harvesting and selling food produce at market and are reinvesting in high value crops that are responsive to the demand in their local area. These women were also trained to train others. This maximises return on investment as the original 5 women who were trained have trained others how to farm the land and the whole group is now working together. Further, the original 5 trainees were democratically elected from the district group reflecting a key process from the Youth Livelihood Programme's operational model._x000D_
_x000D_
NACWOLA'S message is one of hope and positive action to improve one's own livelihood. We believe that empowering marginalized groups to be self-sufficient and economically independent instills a strong work ethic amongst these groups and encourages people to work for themselves. The Ndejje jewellery making project has reported that all women involved have experienced positive attitudinal change. They have reported that the success of their business has boosted their morale and encouraged them to work even harder to provide jewellery for both their local and their international buyers. _x000D_
_x000D_
Operating Principles:_x000D_
_x000D_
NACWOLAÃ¢â¬â¢s  operational model already  reflects the operating principles of the YLP. Thus we are ideally placed to help implement this project. All our projects are demand driven and are conceptualized in conjunction with our district groups and are therefore responsive to need and innovation instead of dictating form from a centralized position. For example, the Bugiri farming pilot has developed to such a level that they are diversifying into poultry and egg production. As the group has made such a success of the farming project NACWOLA is currently helping them to plan and cost the poultry project. Therefore NACWOLA can prove that we have extensive experience of demand driven projects with active participation and ownership. As a women's organization we are ideally placed to ensure gender responsiveness in the overall YLP. Furthermore our countrywide network of district based groupsÃ¢â¬â¢ means that we can ensure equitable geographic distribution amongst local groups that are already highly engaged. As we operate as a network of district groups we are able to guarantee that cultural sensitivity will be observed as the projects will be demand driven and led by the groups themselves. _x000D_
Our operational model, as mentioned already closely reflects the operational principles of the YLP and we have a proven track record of viable and sustainable investments, provision for youth with special needs and supporting local community procurement_x000D_
_x000D_
project_details: In Uganda youth make up to 6.5 million representing 21.3 % of the total population of the country. It is also alarming that we have an annual population growth rate of 3.2%. Culturally the country is predominantly a patriarchal society where most decisions and productive resources such as; land, capital, information, technology, training and markets are controlled by elders and in particular men. Young women and girls in particular youth, shoulder most of the productive and community roles; they receive little or no income or benefits from the proceeds. project_name: Extend technical knowledge to Tribal Girls/Women for undertaking small business on Minor Forest Produce (MFP) and Surplus Agriculture Produce (SAP)
project_summary:
We are going to implement proposed project in tribal dominated district of Jaspur (Chhatisgarh) and Latehar (Jharkhand). In the proposed project areas more than 81% population is tribal but they are ignorant due to illiteracy, poverty and simplicity. All the socio-economic indicators are against them. Political direction is imposed on them without knowing the impact on them, due to above prevailing situation number of problems have arises in the area.  Tribal people do not have economic or employment opportunities, basic facilities like proper education, poor health delivery, lack of connectivity, clean drinking water; do not have sanitation facilities and living life un-hygienically. Tribal women in the proposed project areas of Jaspur district of Chhatisgarh and Latehar district of Jharkhand are forest dwellers and away from the mainstream society hence ignored completely. Economically they are poor and more than 70% of them living below the poverty line. Majority of the   tribal women are trapped in the vicious cycle of poverty and women are worst sufferer due to discrimination and to gender bias. They are deprived in all front of their life, sexually and physically exploited by the market force.  Though there are different plans and programmes said to be implemented for tribal women empowerment despite of the fact, they are unemployed, deprived and becoming poorer. Due to grim situation in the tribal far flung, remote and inaccessible tribal villages and poorly managed tribal areas tribal women are migrating/trafficking to different place in large number to find out a suitable job and are being exploited physically and sexually, denied social justice, deprived in front of their life, suffer rape, violence and even killed in one pretext or other. We are in firm believed that migration of tribal girls/women can not be stopped; however, it required to be managed properly.   Therefore, to manage the migration problems and to provide them suitable economic activities at their own place, we have planned to extend technical knowledge and provide them small financial support  to process the Minor Forest Produce (MFP) and Surplus Agriculture Produce  (SAP) and do small business for enhance income and get enhanced remunerative price.  MFP and SAP is abundantly available in the forest villages where these women live.  We will also extend all required technical knowledge to tribal women to extract the MFP from the forest, process it and sale it to better income, we will also provide the market for MFP and SAP to tribal women.  At the same time we will also create total knowledge to have clean drinking water, adopt sanitation and live creative and hygienic life. _x000D_
This will be done in order to prevent and manage the single tribal women trafficking/ migration.  Proposed project will help the tribal women who are likely to be trafficked or migrate from their village in the pretext of seeking job will be managed. It will also help technically to have job in their villages.  Through this project tribal women would be economically active.   US $ 25000/- would be exclusively used to promote small business exclusively in Minor Forest Produce (MFP) and Surplus Agriculture Produce (SAP) which are abundantly available free of cost from the forest.  It includes training, techniques to extract the MFP and process the SAP for better price. _x000D_
 We will also Strengthen tribal women to enjoy the right of natural resources, improve livelihoods by creating awareness through the US $.25000/- grant.  It will sensitise the tribal women and their community to enjoy the rights of natural resources of water and sanitation, protect the rural water bodies for their sustainable healthy life, inculcate importance of sanitation and hygienic living on them, and develop leadership quality on tribal women to lead others. Through this programme we are going to reach 1000 rural tribal women who are  at the edge of trafficking/migration in one district each of Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh on different issues.  Out of the 2000 tribal women participants, project is going to develop leadership quality among 400 young women and promote small business among 250 tribal girl/women who are likely to migrate from their habitat. _x000D_
 For doing these activities of training and supporting them on different matters, we are going to teach them at local language for use of   technology, education and leadership in our approach. Our organization is integrates all tools to achieve our goals and activities effectively and see the tribal women get economic  benefits While generating awareness imparting training we are going to use all available technology like mobile, video, leaf lets, poster/banners and all available communication means. By adopting various techniques we are creating awareness among the tribal tribal women. Our approach would be to educate, help build girlsÃ¢â¬â¢ and womenÃ¢â¬â¢s knowledge, skills up-gradation, and self-confidence building etc by imparting short duration training. _x000D_
US$.25000/- would be use to provide (1) short duration Training to tribal women who are likely to migrate from their habitat  (2) Conduct Focus Group Discussions (3) Provide small financial support (4) help technically to collect MFP and process SAP (5) generate total awareness through different media and communication means. etc._x000D_

project_summary:
The COOP46 Team will visit each of the 23 LGA in Rivers State, train the women in business expansion methods, help them setup 2 sets of a 20-member cooperative society and link them directly to businesses they can sell their products to. To sustain the impact COOP46 Team has develop a business toolkit that uses mobile phone platform to send lectures in bits to these women. The project will last for 10 months and will involve USD$ 24,835.GRAND PREPARATION_x000D_
The first one month will be used for grand preparation. The Team will start by identifying local businesses managed by the women in these communities that could be developed into larger industries in each of the 23 LGA of the State (Rivers State (RS))._x000D_
The Team will then get the endorsement of the RS government through four of the state ministries: Rivers State Ministry of Women Affairs, Commissioner for Local Government, Chieftaincy and Community Affairs, Rivers State Local Government Service Commission, and Rivers State Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The Ministry of Women Affairs will help appoint 23 liaison officers, women leaders in the local community, one for each community. The Team will train these liaison officers for one week before the pilot phase starts. The RS government through these Ministries will mandate certain businesses operating in the State to buy their raw materials locally, especially from these COOP46 industries. The LGA will support the women (Participants) by providing conducive environment and support networks to assist the women in the setup process._x000D_
COOP46 will establish relationship with Microfinance Banks (MFB) in the State to provide loans to the cooperatives that will be formed. COOP46 Team has developed a business toolkit that operates on any simple mobile phone using voice and text to daily send business tips to these women, and to help them easily communicate, network and get direct instruction/support from the Team._x000D_
PILOT PHASE_x000D_
COOP46 will use the next six months to visit the 23 LGA in RS. Four LGA will be visited per month. One LGA will be visited per week. The Team will visit one LGA per time. In each LGA, two cooperatives will be formed each with a startup capacity of 20 women. Based on the success of this pilot phase the number will be increased to 50 women._x000D_
COOP46 Team will have a training for about 100 women for each LGA. 40 of these participants will be selected and divided into 2 cooperatives, each having a 20 member capacity. The grouping criteria will include business interest, relevant skill and family location._x000D_
TRAINING PERIOD_x000D_
The training period is five days. _x000D_
Day 1 includes arrival of the Team, visit to the LGA chairman and the village head of the community. _x000D_
Day 2 the first part of the training will include an introductory section about COOP46, aim and objective, the Team, Project Inspire and its objectives, the Project implementation plan, the expected results, the partnering organizations and the need for cooperative development. The schedule for the training will be preset by the women based on a day and time that is convenient with them. The training will be in 4 sections. Each section will be for a topic. One hour will be added for break and refreshment. The time breakdown for the training is 30minutes teaching, 15minutes group work/case studies/exercises, 15minutes questions and answers section. The training language is local English. The 4 topics for the training include (1) Opportunities and the need for locally driven sustenance. (2) Marketing/Customer Service. (3) Operations/Quality Control. (4) Finance/Management._x000D_
The women will be trained mostly on how to produce and sell in large quantities (1) palm kernel and its related derivatives to industries that are into cream making, soap making, (2) packaging of dried sea foods, (3) poultry products for restaurants etc, and other products based on availability in the community.  The cooperatives will be designed such that the startup capital will be very small since most of the women may already be operating these businesses individually. The aim of the cooperative is to help them bring their resources together to serve a larger market, and have access to funds to develop bigger corporations._x000D_
Day 3 training will include the benefits of cooperatives, how to setup, manage and sustain cooperative based businesses, the individual, group and community benefits. The women will be more interested when they discover that forming and joining a cooperative will benefit financially and will be a means of employment for their children, the youths. The MFB will introduce the banking system and the lending modalities. The Team and the MFB will use the third section to help the participants form the 2 cooperatives needed. Leaders of the cooperatives will also be appointed. The COOP46 Team will use the fourth section to introduce the phone based business toolkit, and how the women can use it to increase their knowledge. For example, they will be taught how to use their phones to prepare their financial statement. Each participant will get daily business techniques daily for 3 months after the training._x000D_
Day 4 is the graduation ceremony and visit of the participants to the setup location for their industries._x000D_
Day 5 is departure, but first the Team will visit the community leaders to inform them of the success of the Project and to appreciate their support, and also intimate them on next action._x000D_
MONITORING/EVALUATION/REPORTING _x000D_
The team will prepare its first report and submit the sixth day. Each cooperative formed will be mandated to setup and startup within one month after the training. _x000D_
The evaluation period is three months. A member of staff of COREHEAD will evaluate the training based on their ability to startup, based on their ability to sell, based on COOP46 and Project Inspire standards. The COOP46 team will develop the SMS based business toolkit, while the staff will send the messages to the participants.
project_details: COOP46 solves the problem of poor implementation of grassroot women based projects in the area of entrepreneurship and business. Our aim is to develop a template that can be used in other communities worldwide on how to engage women and get them directly involved in their development and in the socioeconomic development of their communities.Most base of pyramid projects for grassroot women in business have been developed without including the women themselves in the process, others have been developed without a self-sustenance plan, and many have been developed without looking at the at the use of simple technology or the inclusion of the authorities. Most women empowerment projects in RS include workshops, seed funding and training. While these may be good, they are not productive and sustainable. We included 23 women as liaison officers, included training, looked at business expansion not business development, include government authorities, used the simplest mobile phone technology

project_summary:

For this action to kick off there is need to have fuel to move the heavy load out of the female world to enhance free minded people with equity in mind, work and decision making. The fuel lies in youth minds. They need to take actions that can impart women and girls with business literacy and entrepreneurship skills.In Malawi, for example, ladies adore men to support them financially. They canÃ¢â¬â¢t make decisions because they canÃ¢â¬â¢t stand on their own feet to oppose what seems to be oppressive behavior from men.  Women and girls are good at composing songs, performing drama, writing stories and poetry with heart moving messages. That talent can be incorporated with some educative messages into business literacy and entrepreneurship skills to enable women and girls live independent lives. Girls in Africa and Asia are abused because they are not economically empowered. The messages will also teach people the importance of empowering women and girls by helping them to discover themselves from the artistic activities. There are some simple businesses, like selling second-hand clothes, opening up hair dressing salons, baking cakes, just to mention a few of them, which do not require much capital but they bring much benefits._x000D_
Mind you, the modern world needs skilled people in their respective sectors. We need to compose these artistic activities which will turn out into business skills. Be Also, the acting skills imparted to these women and girls will help to enhance their confidence hence carry out their businesses with ease._x000D_

In turn, these women and girls will have the knowledge to train others within their community. This shall be the determining factor for sustainability.  To strategist this, there is supposed to be cooperatives which will provide easy access to women and girls. If these women and girls are on a cooperative, they can easily access loans and markets. This will see them out of dependent lives to independent ones, free of oppressions. Empowering women and girls economically will also help them to be emotionally, physically and socially stimulated with great heights of innovative minds. We, the youth can and it starts with us. Let women and girls shine._x000D_

Fate was not generous to these children, to say the least._x000D_
Their mother left them four years ago because she could not bear the poor and wretched conditions in which they lived. After leaving home she became a prostitute to earn money and provide for only herself._x000D_

project_details:
Like other former Soviet states, Armenia's economy suffers from the legacy of a centrally planned economy and the breakdown of Soviet patterns. Soviet investment in Armenian industry has disappeared, so that few businesses are still able to function. In addition, the effects of the 1988 earthquake, which killed 25,000 people and made 500,000 homeless, are still being feltSince gaining independence in 1991, hundreds of thousands of Armenians have gone abroad every year, mainly to Russia and the US, in search of work. An unemployment rate of 73% for women and 62% for men has been the cause of this emigration._x000D_
Men are the majority of those who leave. Consequently, women now constitute seventy percent of the country's population and are left to support their families.Thus like Kristine and her sisters they are the first victims of unemployment._x000D_
By providing a sustainable livelihood program Hrazdan Stitches aims to solve this problem and give the women of Armenia the hope they deserve._x000D_

project_details:
Like other former Soviet states, Armenia's economy suffers from the legacy of a centrally planned economy and the breakdown of Soviet patterns. Soviet investment in Armenian industry has disappeared, so that few businesses are still able to function. In addition, the effects of the 1988 earthquake, which killed 25,000 people and made 500,000 homeless, are still being feltSince gaining independence in 1991, hundreds of thousands of Armenians have gone abroad every year, mainly to Russia and the US, in search of work. An unemployment rate of 73% for women and 62% for men has been the cause of this emigration._x000D_
Men are the majority of those who leave. Consequently, women now constitute seventy percent of the country's population and are left to support their families.Thus like Kristine and her sisters they are the first victims of unemployment._x000D_
By providing a sustainable livelihood program Hrazdan Stitches aims to solve this problem and give the women of Armenia the hope they deserve._x000D_

Saath conceptualised Urmila Home Manger programme in 2004 and started its implementation in 2008. The programme was designed looking into situation of women doing domestic work in the houses.  For the women working as domestic maids there is no social and financial security. They have no formal contracts with their employers and their work is still not recognised as work in legal terms by the Indian Constitution. Currently there is Domestic Workers Act in formation for providing legal protection to domestic workers but it still hasnÃ¢â¬â¢t been passed. Saath is part of a National level platform for passing of this bill. While the women have no legal protection  their employers also lack empathy towards them. There is platform where the women can come and raise their voice. _x000D_
SaathÃ¢â¬â¢s Urmila Home Manager Programme attempts to bridge this gap between domestic servants and urban households. The main objective of the project is to empower slum residents from simply being house helps to working professionals, Home Managers, with a significant increase in incomes, and to provide reliable, efficient and professional home managers for the clients. SAATH aims to develop a fair and formal platform to train and place women and men who work as house-help. We offer a reliable, efficient and professional domestic service, highly sought after by the households looking to employ domestic help. The programme also makes the clients aware of the rights and duties of the home manager, and vice versa. Further, it gives women from underprivileged households a sense of pride and achievement from the fact that they are now able providers to their families, they feel empowered._x000D_
_x000D_
Saath has trained 744 women till date through the project. The training course of women has 6 basic components Ã¢â¬â housekeeping, child care, patient care, old age care, basic numeracy and literacy, fire aid and safety. It will also ensure the protection of these women workers through contracts with clients, registration with local police stations and health checkups._x000D_
_x000D_
Through the support from Project Inspire we aim to train 100 women in the year 2015 from January to December. These women will be provided jobs by placing with their employers with a formal contract enabling them to get decent wages as pet the work and time involved. Saath will work towards sensitizing the employers regarding the situation of the workers and also work towards providing social and financial inclusion to the women. Saath aims to make the women trainees as role models within their communities for them to inspire other women and make them aware of their rights. _x000D_
_x000D_
The objectives of project will be: _x000D_
1.	To identify domestic workers and provide them skill development and training opportunities to upgrade their skills for the current needs of the urban Indian household_x000D_
2.	To place them with work in households through a formal contract with a focus on decent wages, and work hours.
project_details: As per National Sample Survey Organization, In 2009-10, estimated total number of domestic worker in India is around 2.52 million out of this 2/3 reside in urban areas and 57% of them are women. In the last 10 years there is almost 75% increase in domestic workers mostly accounted for by women. The situation of domestic workers remains same across country ÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢â¬Å no bargaining power, no leave, no legal access, sexual harassment, over worked, and underpaid. There is no platform through which these women can come together to demand their rights. With the rapidly changing urban scenario the demands of the clients have changed but they are not ready to pay more the domestic workers as there is still a very traditional mindset regarding house work. Through project we aim to formalize the informal relationship between a women and her employer and also sensitize the employers regarding the situation of the workers.

project_summary:
Begging has today become an age long phenomenon in the Gambia. As of late, the number of female beggars in the streets has increased including children been exposed to harsh conditions on the streets by older beggars to garner the sympathy of passerby. Frequently these children have to stay outside for extended periods, inadequately fed and clothed. Successful begging discourages children from going to school._x000D_
_x000D_
Female beggars face discrimination and isolation from the public and are usually introduced into crime, prostitution and drugs._x000D_
However, many beggars are perfectly capable of working but feign disabilities in order to be pitied. _x000D_
All begging is wrong. Beggars have the right to live a respectful life, the right to good health, education, freedom and most importantly acquire skills and training to generate income for themselves and their families. Beggars also have the right to be heard, listen to and they should also be given a chance to express themselves._x000D_
Research has shown that most of these women and girls are desperate to move on, but are without support and services necessary to do so. Most of them suffer from poor skills, no income, bad housing or bad health, others beg as a result of abuse, lack of parental control and domestic violence._x000D_
_x000D_
Our project therefore will reachout to engage and train these women and girls, high in demand vocational skills such as tie and die, tailoring, petty trade etc to enable them become self reliance and earn income for their livelihood so that they can change their condition to an honorable stage through their own management and skill. _x000D_
Vocational education is an essential component of strategies to reduce and prevent Beggary and will prepare the target group for gainful employment._x000D_

project_summary:
Use the funds to help an orphanage in a remote and poor island of Nias (Indonesia), to have the capacity to earn sustainable income from producing and selling affordable high quality eyeglasses. St. Margaretha Orphanage is run by Sister Klara Duha since 2005 and has 50 children from the age of 2 to 16 under her care. The orphanage also has a clinic which regularly serves women to deliver babies, free of charge. Klara does not have gynecologist on her payroll, but as a well-respected person in the community, she can call up a gynecologist in Nias island for help when needed._x000D_
Klara depends entirely on donation to keep the orphanage and clinic running. _x000D_
All of the funds from Project Inspire will go towards the project, none on administration/management overhead. The funds will be used towards training Klara and her team new skills to earn sustainable income from selling low-cost high-quality eyeglasses (cost USD$2, sell for USD$4 a pair)_x000D_
Eyeglasses are much needed by many Nias residents, especially children who suffer from refractive error (an error in focusing the light by the eye, correctable by wearing glasses). The glasses are a necessity, not accessory._x000D_
A New Vision will also put in co-investment (45%) towards the project, to purchase the necessary equipment, furniture, fitting and materials.
project_details:
Sister Klara runs a well-managed orphanage, it is clean and the children are happy. However, her income is entirely from donation, which is ad hoc and unpredictable. It makes it difficult for her to take in more orphans and needy children. Nias is a remote island located in Western part of Indonesia with 800,000 residents, most of them earn less than USD$1 a day from collecting rubber saps and coffee beans. Indonesia Government data statistics (2005) estimated that 20% of them suffer from refractive error. These people continue to live with visual impairment because a pair of glasses costs USD$30 at local optical shop, not afforded by those who earn less than USD$1 a day._x000D_
This project gives the orphanage ability to earn sustainable income, at the same time, the project helps thousands of school-age children to be able to see better, from having a much needed pair of glasses.

project_summary: The proposed project is unique in that it gathers the energy and commitment of a group of Palestinian females from Hebron Governorate to foster the professional dialogue dynamics necessary for empowering Palestinian women and raising their awareness through the medium of puppet theatre.This will be achieved through an array of activities aimed at empowering Palestinian women, provide additional tools to marginalized women to know about, and claim their rights and support early learning and provide much needed recreational activities to low-income families. Participatory and Human Rights Based Approaches are the main conceptual frameworks that have been adopted during the development process of the proposed project. It is worth mentioning that these approaches were used in such a way that ensures a full involvement of the projectÃ¢â¬â¢s main stakeholders.

This classification embedded the male authority in the everyday decisions and discussions and rendered the womenÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s participation.  Marriage, family, and children are viewed as an important shelter for the women in the absence of social security system.
