Political analysisFrom the ashes of war was the birth of the World newest Nation the Republic of South Sudan after decisive referendum in which the southerners voted overwhelmingly for independence on the 9th of July 2011 has faced a number of challenges both from the militia groups within its territory and from its Neighbor, the republic of Sudan over unresolved border and oil resources distribution issues. Efforts are currently underway to gain the recommitment to the unconditional implementation of the September 27, 2012 (Addis Ababa) agreements that would outline a Joint Political and Security Mechanism for withdrawal of the armed forces of Sudan and South Sudan as well as the deployment of the Joint Border Verification Monitoring Mechanism. The country is also working towards the resolution of Abyei's final status that would entail establishment of the Abyei Area administration, council, and police service in an effort to promote sustainable peace. There are numerous intra and inter ethnic conflicts related to resources such as water, land, grazing grass, boarders as well as abductions of women and children._x000D_
_x000D_
Socio- Economic Background_x000D_
South SudanÃ¢â¬â¢ economy is relying heavily on a depleting oil resource (South SudanÃ¢â¬â¢s economy is considered to be most dependent economy in the world on a single and volatile commodity). In the year 2011, the budget of the Government of South Sudan derived 98% of the revenues from oil. In January 2012, the Republic of South Sudan decided to shut down its oil pipeline over disagreement over the oil transit fees with its neighbor Sudan has also led to drastic reductions in the government expenditure making it difficult for the government to provide public services such as security, education, health and infrastructure. The countryÃ¢â¬â¢s economic situation has been worsened by limited domestic production, a high reliance on oil revenue, imports and lack of buffer savings through the CPA period that predisposes the government to volatile revenues and expenditure pattern. The austerity measures taken by the government of South Sudan as a result of limited Government revenue has reduced government spending on development projects. The market exchange rates in South Sudan are below the official rates causing the loss of confidence in the South Sudanese Pounds._x000D_
_x000D_
The Nation has experienced a rising trend of social vices such as; poor livelihood opportunities, tribalism, corruption; power grabbing, limited capacity and many other leadership problems undermine democratic institutions and good governance, which further threaten economic growth, sustainable development and the improvement of livelihoods of the people of South Sudan.  _x000D_
_x000D_
As more IDPs return to South Sudan, the problem of homeless children and orphans in almost all the ten state capitals of South Sudan and main towns like Yei, and across the country, is escalating. The major leading towns among others include Wau in Western Bahr el Ghazal, Rumbek in Lakes state, Torit in Eastern Equatoria and Juba the National capital. In 2011, Upper Nile state was reported to be having the highest number of street children and orphans._x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
During the two decades of civil war residents of Yei River County fled to Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Uganda and some to Central African Republic. Many had no access to education and skills training during their refugee life and currently can hardly get employment opportunities in the area. This has affected mainly the women, girls/boys whose parents cannot afford to pay their school fees. _x000D_
Given the equatorial climate in the three Payams of Lasu, Mugwo and Tore; the major economic activity is subsistence farming by almost all the people. They grow food crops such as maize, cassava, groundnuts, beans and vegetable while some people grow coffee for sale. Although farming is predominant, the farmers, still have no proper agricultural tools and the few available in the market are expensive and difficult to afford, therefore with the poor farming system Ã¢â¬â traditional methods, viable seed varieties are rare to get as such little produce is obtained at the end of the season which may not sustain the family for long period hence resorting to brewing local alcohol, selling bamboos, firewood and grass in order to get incomes. Animals like goats and sheep mostly reared for cultural functions such as marriage and other celebrations. _x000D_
_x000D_
Some few individuals running small scale business in the local market selling basic goods like soap, salt, biscuits, paraffin, second hand clothes, vegetables and small bars for local drinks (liquor). Local alcohol brewing has become the only viable predominant economic activity coupled with sales of firewood, bamboo, grass and tea in market area by the non-literate and semi literate women and young girls. _x000D_
_x000D_
The overwhelming poverty leaves many parents unable to provide for their families, so that many children turn to the streets to survive. Tragically, many of these children are dying from preventable diseases, suffering abuse and harassments, becoming addicted to drugs and other substances, or getting involved in gangs, with no hope of having a better life._x000D_
_x000D_
Problem analysis_x000D_
Today, South Sudan stands at a crossroad between peace and conflict, stability and insecurity. Currently social services and livelihood opportunities are very limited due to the increase in unplanned population settlement of returnees and IDPs in the town. Conflicts over land in rural areas like Lasu and in Mugwo Payams arose between the host communities and refugees/IDPs and returnees. Tokori Boma, Lasu Payam and Mundu Boma, Tore Payam has also experienced land disputes fuelled by creation of constituencies during the April 2010 elections. The most common forms of conflict have been over land use and settlement, boundary of land given to refugees/IDP, water points, use of forests and grazing areas for animals, and the domestic disputes in families and among family members. These conflicts further cause pressure to many IDPs and returnees to flee to Yei Municipality (formally Yei Town) to seek better services and comfortable resident without taking into consideration major factors of skills that will be needed to earn living. project_summary:
In 2007, Rohini, a Mumbai resident was an engineering student, discovered the Ã¢â¬ËeditÃ¢â¬â¢ button on a page of a Wikipedia article. And thus began her love affair with the world of Wikipedia. Gradually, she discovered a passionate and an active community of volunteers that edited Wikipedia on a regular basis. However, she soon found out that she was the only women in these meet-ups. RohiniÃ¢â¬â¢s experience is not an isolated one. According to a study conducted by Wikipedia in 2011, only 9% of the editors at Wikipedia were women. India fares even worse. Only 3% of the editors in India are women. Why are there such few women editing Wikipedia? Why is it an issue that should concern all of us? We will try and explore the issue. _x000D_
Internet as a public sphere_x000D_
The famous sociologist, Jurgen Habermas came up with the following idea of a public sphere._x000D_
The public sphere (German Ãâffentlichkeit, f) is an area in social life where individuals can come together to freely discuss and identify societal problems, and through that discussion influence political action.  _x000D_
The above definition of a public sphere can very well apply to the Internet, especially social media in its present form. We live in a widely interconnected world. There are more Indians on the internet than ever before. At the last count, there are about 200 million and counting. We live in a world mediated through multifunctional devices and the internet. Internet can be just like a physical public space except that it exists in the virtual realm. Just as the physical space consists of both private space (homes) and a public sphere (a common space which is open to all), Internet also has similar parallels. While personal email can be an example of a private space in the virtual sphere, sites like Twitter, Facebook (to a certain extent), Wikipedia etc. are very similar to public spaces that people access in the physical realm._x000D_
However, the above defined version of public sphere is problematic because it doesnÃ¢â¬â¢t take into account the structure that results in exclusion of many groups based on gender, class, caste, religion, sex among others. Nancy Frazer, in her book, Ã¢â¬ËRethinking the public sphereÃ¢â¬â¢ critiques HabermasÃ¢â¬â¢ idea of public sphere. Frazer elaborated that the public sphere is not egalitarian and its exclusionary structures results in invisibilising many groups that it discriminates against. If we apply this theory against Wikipedia, it brings out striking parallels. Just like women experience harassment in physical public spaces, women also experience harassment in virtual public sphere too. ItÃ¢â¬â¢s a vicious circle. Less number of women on a street, will ensure that the few women that are on the street feel insecure resulting in the further dwindling of numbers. Lesser the number, more the harassment women face on the street. It is essential to break the cycle._x000D_
 _x000D_
Wikipedia is now the worldÃ¢â¬â¢s biggest and most accessed encyclopaedia. It has also become the first go-to website to gain first hand information about any topic. Its wide reach is evident by the fact that an internet search on any topic will have its corresponding Wikipedia article listed in the first ten items on the first page of the search. Not only are people accessing Wikipedia in large numbers, there is also a vibrant community of editors that edit Wikipedia on a regular basis. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Problem_x000D_
Lack of gender sensitivity in Wikipedia articles needs to be addressed because issues of grave concern viz. issues of domestic violence or sexual assaults lack gender sensitivity and at the same time are accessed by a huge number of people. Case in point is  the Wikipedia entry of unfortunate 2012 gang rape incident. The page was apparently closed down for edits because it experienced rampant vandalism. The details of it all can be found here._x000D_
Noopur Raval, a Delhi resident and an active Wikipedia volunteer, in this article, shares her experience of editing an article on the Guwahati molestation case._x000D_
While she was working on the Wikipedia article about the Guwahati Molestation Case in 2012, she felt that well-meaning editors saw this article as the publication of a shameful incident and a misrepresentation of the Indian people. She says: Ã¢â¬ÅTo write responsibly and acknowledge women's expression Ã¢â¬â is not a universally obvious and accepted notion and runs into obstacles given the stakes of people involved in women's projects.Ã¢â¬Â_x000D_
 _x000D_
One of the reasons for less number of women editing Wikipedia can be seen in this case, which is a perfect example of vandalism within Wikipedia. Anita Sarkessian, a feminist with an avid interest in gaming found her page vandalised on a regular basis so much so that her page had to be blocked to prevent rogue edits._x000D_
 _x000D_
Solution_x000D_
To address these issues, Breakthrough proposes to undertake the following activities. We plan to organise a series of editathons encouraging more women to come and participate in various capacities as editors of Wikipedia. By doing this, the aim is to have more women participate in creation of open knowledge. The other resulting expectation of this is that this will lead to more women and women-related information being highlighted on Wikipedia. This will also lead to decrease in the invisibilisation of information about women and lead to a larger systemic change of women's role being highlighted more on this widely accessed platform._x000D_

project_details:
The problem of poverty and low education in ?South Vietnam, specifically in the Mekong Delta ?region._x000D_
There are numerous villages in the Mekong Delta region, inhabited by villagers whose living is made out of rice-farming. The majority of these rice-farmers make the bare minimum to survive and feed their families. Most of them cannot afford education for their children so it is normal that most children in these families do not study beyond high school if they even finish primary school. Without education, the children become rice-famers like their parents and the cycle of poverty continues. _x000D_
_x000D_
PGPL seeks to promote the importance of education by supporting tuition fees for poor students, purchasing bicycles to ease their long journeys to school, providing school supplies like books and stationery so they have what they need to study. At the same time, we strive to meet the basic needs of poor families (that many of these children come from) by providing food and clothes donations.

project_summary:
Poverty Disproportionately Impacting Harari Women and Girls: The majority of Harari women and girlÃ¢â¬â¢s live in areas that do not have access to better business opportunity. The exclusion of women and girls from the socio-economic sphere is due to a range of causes, including: limited financial resources within the household; the burden of household chores assigned to young girls, particularly in rural areas; the absence of adequate educational, communication, and transportation infrastructure; and beliefs that prioritize the education of the male child in the family. Importantly, personal status codes discriminate against women, particularly in marriage, divorce, and inheritance. Among some social groups, ownership of property is almost exclusively limited to women. Women may be exposed to such practices as forced marriage and honor crimes. In sum, women are secluded and segregated, with the majority continuing to occupy the private domain of the household, and with public space reserved for males. The roles most available to women are those of daughter, sister, wife, mother, mother-in-law, etc. Ã¢â¬â with few professional careers available. Women are relegated to marginality by the prevailing social, political and economic organization.Woman and girls in particular are disproportionately affected by economic problem. In times of crisis, women tend to stay home with their children, while men more away to look for alternative means of survival. Women also have fewer options to find other ways of making a living especially since womenÃ¢â¬â¢s literacy rate is not even half of that of men. Women are also not given a say in house hold decisions and are frequently without cash saving or assets to sell to buy food and other basic items. _x000D_
So our project proposal advocates empowerment of women and girls by business entrepreneurship spirit through direct training and finance help. The project provides financial support for poor girl and female headed households and selected income generation jobs. The project promotes the use of locally based requires and localized technologies that can be easily supported and sustained. _x000D_

Each startup capital and the equipment with a total value of not more than USD 7500 will be given on a 12-month interest free loan. For a group completing the loan before the 12 months, will receive additional loan if required to boost their business._x000D_
This project will apply participatory planning activities in its design process and in all project phases, which is a key feature in womenÃ¢â¬â¢s economic empowerment process.  The broad-based support programs will build social cohesion and young girlÃ¢â¬â¢s and house headed womenÃ¢â¬â¢s skills to analyze their situation, reach consensus, make decisions, and take action to improve their circumstances. project_summary:
The grant will be used to create a business sustained empowering linkage between rural women vegetable sellers in Bomba, 20kms from Gokwe, and at-risk girls and young women living on the streets of Harare. In Bomba, Can-Do will set up an agricultural value addition plant and information Centre next to the Bomba market place where female local micro-entrepreneurs sell vegetables and fruits to travellers. The Can-Do plant will source excess fruit and vegetables from the women and transform them into either canned or dried goods for sale in urban areas. The Can-Do information Centre will make available relevant agricultural market information targeted at increasing the competitiveness of the women's products. Project Can-Do views the women who grow and sell their produce in this area as micro-entrepreneurs. As such, the Can-Do information center will also provide subsidised business/entrepreneurship and financial literacy training to local women and girls with an aim to create a savings culture and, where possible, assist them in starting new agro-based micro-enterprises. Taking into consideration the upsurge of mobile banking and mobile penetration rates in Zimbabwe, this saving culture will be nurtured through mobile banking products. The Information Centre will also act as a mobile banking agent to facilitate the use of mobile banking products. As a mobile banking agent, Project Can-Do will be able to offer services such as deposit collections and withdrawals as well as facilitate mobile banking loans.In Harare Can-Do will operate a half-way house and training center. The purpose of the Can-Do Training Centre will be to empower at-risk girls and young women living on the streets of Harare and lessen their vulnerability. By providing them with short term accommodation, counseling and mentorship, as well as the knowledge, skills and opportunities to make better lives for themselves. The girls will be given vocational training, entrepreneurship skills and financial literacy training.  The vocational training will center on horticultural production and marketing as well as the preparation and preserving of produce. As an additional part of their training the girls will be given a chance to get directly involved in the marketing, distribution and sale of Can-Do products from Bomba. The Can-Do food processing plant will act as an ongoing case study for them, with the girls being able to get first-hand experience on how a small scale agro-business is run from growing the produce to its marketing. The primary aim of the training and practical experience is to equip the girls to start their own agro-based businesses in groups, or as individuals, which will enable them to create incomes and move them off of the street. In the event that they choose not to start agro-businesses, the Centre will assist the girls to find jobs with the skills they have learnt, or further their vocational training in their chosen field._x000D_
The grant money will be split for use in the two locations of the Can-Do project. In Bomba the funds will be used to fit the Can-Do food processing plant with basic canning machinery and structures for drying of produce. In Harare, the grant money will be used to pay the initial operating expenses of the Can-Do Training Centre until proceeds from the sale of produce made in the Can-Do food processing plant start covering them. These expenses include rentals, rates, bills, training materials, transport, consumables, and various other sundry expenses._x000D_

project_summary:
Building livelihoods through micro-enterprises for women (especially widows and teens) is one of the remarkable ideas for developing sustainability, improving household income and creating jobs in the poorest regions of the world like Cameroon. There is need to enhance the business development skills of women for sustainable development. Nowadays, the creation of hundreds of jobs and significant increase in income for women has become inherent to poverty alleviation in Sub Saharan Africa.Our goal being to provide micro-enterprise development training and support systems to help widows and teens in the North West Region create micro-enterprises through enterprise development and micro financing that will create jobs and generate incomes. Thus, with USD$25,000, our project will directly empower 20 disinherited widows and 10 economically challenged teenage mothers as well as secure a brighter future for over 240 children of Baba 1 community in the North West Region of Cameroon. This will ensure their financial independence and secured livelihood. We will provide business and entrepreneurship training, business management training, core life skills development tips, seed money of between US$200 to US$1,000, one-on one accompanied mentoring; and access to business networks. _x000D_

project_name: The Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescent Girls project (ELAG)
project_summary:
(ELAG)  is designed to improve the lives of adolescent girls through a twin-pronged provision of skills. The project will be implemented by the New Generation Thinkers Foundation (NGETF) in Wakiso District, Nangabo sub-county Uganda.  ELAG will operate through adolescent development clubs (ADCs) that will be established in different schools, both single sex and mixed schools through collaboration between school authorities and NGETF management. The ADCs will typically open every week and timed so that girls enrolled full-time in school can attend.  ADC activities will be led by female mentors. Mentors will be selected by NGETF Management. They will be prepared for their role during a week-long initiation program, as well as monthly cafes during which performance and progress will be assessed. The fact that the ages of mentors are not significantly different from the ages of mentees and, therefore, are likely to have similarly confronted challenges related to economic and social empowerment, is likely to facilitate the transfer of knowledge. _x000D_
Classification of schools will be based on the number of students they hold (e.g 300-500; 500-1000; 1000-1500, etc). Sample groups will be grouped according to their ages (i.e. 12-14, 15-18 and 18-20 years). A suitable unbiased method will be used to select the schools and individuals that will participate in the project. We aim to have 30 groups made up of 200 girls each._x000D_
ADC participation will be voluntary and eligibility will be based on gender and age only Adolescent girls aged between 12 and 20 will be permitted to participate. Given the difficulties of verifying ages in this setting and the demand for club activities arising from other girls, in practice some girls outside of the 12-20 age range also attend the clubs. The two forms of skills training to be provided in the ELG project are life skills vocational and non-formal skills training, which will take place within the clubs. In addition, the ADCs will host popular recreational activities such as reading, staging dramas, singing, dancing and playing games. The ADC will thus serve as a protected local space in which adolescent girls can meet, socialize, and privately discuss issues of concern with others outside their group and to continue to develop their skills. _x000D_
The vocational skills training will comprise a series of courses on income generating activities. Although many of the skills are applicable for either wage or self-employment, more focus is placed on the adolescent girls establishing small-scale enterprises of their own. Courses relating to a broad range of income generating activities will be provided including hair-dressing, tailoring, Jewelry, Bee keeping, Mushroom growing, agriculture, poultry rearing and small trades operation. _x000D_
The vocational training modules are to be taught by entrepreneurs engaged in the respective activities or by hired crosscutting professionals. These courses will be supplemented by a financial literacy course covering budgeting, financial services, and negotiation and accounting skills. The process of matching girls to income generating activities will be partly demand-driven, but account will also take of the girlÃ¢â¬â¢s educational level, the local business environment and demand for such services. The overarching aim of the vocational skills component of the Project is to promote the economic empowerment of adolescent girls._x000D_
The key topics to cover in the life skills training sessions include: sexual and reproductive health, menstruation and menstrual disorders, pregnancy, sexually transmitted infections, HIV/AIDS awareness, family planning, protection against rape and environmental health. There will be sessions covering enabling topics such as management skills, negotiation and conflict resolution, and leadership among adolescents. There will also be life skills training focuses on providing girls with legal knowledge on womenÃ¢â¬â¢s issues such as bride price child marriage and violence against women. These life skills training sessions will be conducted either by the trained mentors and/or professionals. The overarching aim of the life skills component of the program is to socially empower girls by enhancing the control that adolescent girls have over their own bodies._x000D_
project_details: As a result adolescents face many sexual and reproductive health problems that affect their health and development i.e. STDs and HIV/AIDS, early pregnancy, early marriage and childbirth, maternal mortality, and high infant mortality rate. They are also affected by many social problems that lower their quality of life i.e Poverty, drug and alcohol abuse, and dropout of education and sexual harassment. To make matters worse they have little knowledge on the risk of unprotected sexual acts. According to the Ministry of Health, presently, 25% of the Ugandan teenagers become pregnant by the age of 19.  About 49% are married before their 18th birthday and they start getting babies until their mid-40s.A recent analysis of national survey data in Uganda reveals alarming proportions of adolescents living in poverty, deprived of full educational attainment etc. Economic discrimination against girls and women persists, and high levels of gender-based violence.

project_name: LIVELIHOOD IMPROVEMENT AND EMPOWERMENT OF VULNERABLE WOMEN AND GIRLS IN WAKISO DISTRICT
project_summary: Livelihood improvement amongst vulnerable women and girls in wakiso district will assist in improvement of their living standards; their health status through improved nutrition, food security as well as improving their economic status via the incomes realized from the sales of surplus production. The project is expected to support 50 vulnerable households which are female headed during the project cycle. The knowledge and skills acquired through trainings will assist the participants to sustain the project by the end of the project cycle. The income from the poultry enterprise will be used to sustain the scholastic material component of the project. RACDI is requesting for 25000US dollars to run the project from the beginning to the end. Procurement for the supplies required to run the project will follow the guidelines given by the donor and all participants/beneficiaries are expected to participate in the project implementation up to the end of the project. Periodic reports and accountabilities will be submitted to the donor as required during the project implementation period.in addition, the income from the poultry enterprises will be used to sustain the scholastic material component of the project.
project_details: The livelihood of several families in Nangabo sub-county and Kira town council Wakiso district have been greatly affected by HIV/AIDS scourge and many women and girls have been left without hope for meaning full livelihoods; mainly these include HIV/AIDS hit families, where the  girls children are left without proper guardian, under care of aged grandparents and with single infected parent. Under such circumstances children are denied proper nutrition, suffer from poor health and denied access to education due to lack of funds for scholastic materials among others. Since vulnerable households are characterized by aged, infected single parents, under guidance by older siblings; the economic situation is usually uncertain and its upon this background that RACDI designed this proposal to address the above mentioned immediate challenges of poor livelihoods and lack of education requirement among vulnerable households in the project area. The project is in line with government programs of poverty eradication and access to education for all. This project was determined through a baseline survey research using a pretested data collection tool focusing on affected households. The government has tried to put up structures to address the livelihoods and education in general without paying particular attention to the vulnerable households. Therefore; this project is expected to address the above challenges facing vulnerable households[female headed] with in the above mentioned administrative units.

The Hairdressing for Livelihoods and Economic Empowerment Project (HLEEP) will use $25,000 to give entrepreneurship skills to out of school girls through hairdressing, selling hair extension and beauty products used in beauty saloons. HLEE Project will recruit 50 out of school and adolescent mothers within Huye city of Rwanda to give them training on hairdressing as a way of helping them to become agents of change within their communities through access to livelihoods and employment knowledge, skills and resources that will enable them to access income opportunities.$25,000 US Dollars will be used to rent a training room, to buy initial training materials for hairdressing, a salary for trainers, project managerÃ¢â¬â¢s transport and communication facilitation and initial support for girls to start a hairdressing saloon in the Huye city. The hairdressing training will last 10 months will enable out of school girls and adolescent mothers to gain skills in hairdressing and hair extension business, entrepreneurship, project management, livelihoods and youth employment, financial management, customer care and women empowerment. _x000D_
HLEE project aim to reduce the vulnerability of out of school girls and adolescent mothers through engaging them into skills development.  We will create a space for girls to meet and share life skills in order to prevent them being on street and prevent actions that lead to unwanted pregnancy and sexual transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS. The grant will be used to enable girls feeling safe, to learn for creating and managing their own business and to plan for their future. The $25,000 dollars will be used for the projects activities which will make the target group to stay together in their saloon by learning to make money in the future within their saloon._x000D_

project_name: Comprehensive education for improved maternal and child health
project_summary:
Location: Iganga, Uganda      Setting: Urban      Established: April 2003 _x000D_
Background:_x000D_
Comprehensive education for improved maternal and child health is a project conducted by Uganda Development and Health Associates (UDHA). UDHA started its operations as a Community Based Organisation (CBO) in April 2003 in Iganga district, in Busoga Sub Region, Eastern Uganda. It is a rural based organisation dedicated to serving the poor and vulnerable members of our society. Initially, the organisation has been involved in various community-based activities in health, specifically in the areas of HIV/AIDS, malaria control, sanitation, adolescent sexual reproductive health, school health and immunisation._x000D_
_x000D_
Since August 2005, UDHA has expanded its operations to Mayuge, Luuka, Iganga and Namutumba districts in a new capacity as a Non-government Organisation (NGO). In the future, we intend to consolidate our work in the entire Busoga region, which together has a total population of about 3 million people in seven districts._x000D_
The organisation has attracted a significant number of members of different professions such as: public health, social work, agriculture, community development, education, environment and economics among others. This is in recognition of the fact that community problems are multi-causal and therefore need multi-sectoral approaches with strong community participation._x000D_
_x000D_
  _x000D_
Vision:_x000D_
A society in which young people are fully empowered to participate and take care of the communityÃ¢â¬â¢s own health and development._x000D_
_x000D_
Mission:_x000D_
To engage a multi-sectoral and professional approach with strong community participation and ownership for the enhancement of reproductive health, rights and empowerment of people_x000D_
_x000D_
Objectives_x000D_
1.	To promote the health of people including children, youth and young women with their full participation._x000D_
2.	To promote empowerment of young people especially the most vulnerable through social related activities and capacity building to work for income generation._x000D_
3.	To network, collaborate and develop strategic partnerships with local, national and international organizations with similar interests._x000D_
_x000D_
UDHA is a rural service organisation dedicated to serving the poor and vulnerable members of our society mainly women, youths and children. Initially, the organisation has been involved in various community-based activities in health, specifically in the areas of HIV/AIDS, maternal and child health, provision of primary health care at UDHA health units, Youth and women empowerment and reproductive health education and nutrition._x000D_
_x000D_
What we plan to do with the USD$25,000;_x000D_
- We plan to come up with a house hold register for the all the house hold members of Nawaningi sub-county. From the register all the girls aged 1 day and  24years will be recuited in the study project. _x000D_
- Using the government policy of Universal primary Education and Universal secondary education, we shall ensure that all the girls are enrolled in schools and this will be enforced by involving the district Education department, community development department, district health offices and legal structures plus the parents. _x000D_
- We shall train women/mothers and teenage girls, and female school drop-outs into income generating skills. _x000D_
- After training the women will be supported to form savings schemes and credit cooperative organisations (SACCOs). The women who would  join SACCOs will be given a refundable once off capital which they can use to raise more funds for their SACCO. The main objective for raising funds will be to pay school fees for their girl children. However they may also pay school fees for the boys but the first priority will be girls. _x000D_
- We shall also support the teenage mothers to go back and complete their education after six months of breastfeeding their babies._x000D_
- We also form conselling clubs as supportive structures for retaining girls in schools. The counselling clubs will be platforms for empowering girls and young women to develop lifeskills; for example; self awareness, self esteem, creative thinking, problem solving, critical thinking, peer resistance, among others. We hope that when the lifeskills are developed in the women and girls they will be in position to address their challenges in a positive and developmental manner by utilising locally available and affordable resources._x000D_
The supportive structures will involve all affected parties; for example the parents, boys and men, religious leaders,  traditional leaders, teachers, local leader, security and the legal entity. This will be to make sure that no girl of school going age drops out of school. _x000D_
After we have established the total number of all the girls and women in the sub-county and where they school from we shall make sure that the girls are in school by doing spot checks especially at schools that are within the project implementing district. For the children who would be schooling outside the district where the project will be implemented, we do a telephone check with the administrators of the school. However, during holidays we shall make sure that we meet all the girls in the implemtation area(Nawaningi sub-county). This will done through holding meetings at village level. These meetings will not only be for roll calls, but will also be for carrier guidance and counseling, setting goals in life, reproductive health education, HIV/AIDS counseling and testing, family planning among others._x000D_
We shall also hold annual meetings with the girls and those who excelled at school will be given praises and this will act as a motivation for others to work hard the following year._x000D_
We hope to all the above to improve the education status in Nawaningi sub-county in order to improve the maternal annd child health in Nawaningi sub-county.
project_details: In Uganda, health outcomes are poor for both mothers and newborn babies, with only 59% of mothers having a skilled attendant at delivery and yet maternal mortality ratio is 438/100,000 live births. Besides, Uganda remains one of the countries with the highest numbers of teenage pregnancies and yet the teenagers are a population that is supposed to be still in school. Adolescent pregnancy in Uganda stands at 25%. Adolescent pregnancy in Uganda is associated with high morbidity and mortality for both mother and the child. They are also significantly disadvantaged because they are poor as they dont usually own any property and so cannot afford to meet then needs and the needs of their children. They are also more likely to be victims of domestic violence especially when they get pregnant and drop out of school and marry so young!  We are solving the problem of maternal and child morbidity and mortality which has for a long time been a result of teenage pregnancy in Nawaningi sub-county.

project_name: Production and Sale of Lemon Grass Essential OilÃ¢â¬â¢s Project
project_summary:
With USD $ 25,000 the project will   sustainably improve the income levels of Women, female youth affected by HIV/AIDS through production and sale of lemon grass essential oil as a source of livelihood. Their redundant land will be made productive; will have produce for selling. They will also be able to meet their basic needs including being able to meet travel expenses to and fro Health units for ART. The project will have environmental benefits of providing a permanent soil cover to the currently eroded bare grounds.In this area, lemon grass is still only grown in the courtyard for tea scenting Ã¢â¬âThere has been no effort in Mubende to process oil from lemon grass. Yet this is possible with simple and appropriate technology to women and youth to extract oil from the leaves of lemon grass (Cymbopogon strata) through steam distillation. Yellow in color and thin in consistency; oil with a strong aroma will be produced. Lemongrass essential oil has anti-odor and antiseptic properties, and is often used in talcum powders, bath salts, in insect repellants as well as in herbal medicines to ward off ringworms and fungal reactions._x000D_
Women and female youth in our community have accepted to grow this crop due to the Health benefits of lemongrass oil which include:_x000D_

Ã¢â¬Â¢	This oil acts a tonic for the entire body and can help to boost the parasympathetic nervous system, which is necessary when you are recovering from a sickness. It also revitalizes the glandular secretions_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Lemongrass oil is good for treating respiratory infections like fever, laryngitis, and sore throats. It also stops the spreading of disease_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	This essential oil is often used to treat gastroenteritis, indigestion, and colitis_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Lemongrass oil can tone the tissues and muscles, relieve pain in the muscles by making the muscles more flexible. It also improves the blood circulation and acts an insect repellent_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	This oil is used to keep pets free of lice, ticks, and fleas_x000D_
Ã¢â¬Â¢	Lemongrass oil is used for treating acne and for clearing up oily skin. It also treats athlete's foot, and stops excessive perspiration_x000D_

This project will primarily benefit, Widows, single teen mothers, out of school female youth persons aged between 18-35.These are subsistence farming residents of 4 rural sub-counties selected from Mubende district. They are part of the SORAK community based women and youth group membership that have been identified and engaged in the previous TB/HIV projects._x000D_
Fifty of the 125 members targeted to initially benefit from this project have so far benefited from our previous livelihood support through the provision of revolving piggery, goats, chicken and seed grants. They have now with other 75 expressed their readiness to engage in lemon grass production for essential oil as another best option of creating employment, utilise the redundant land while promoting environmental conservation._x000D_
During this award period, the project will aim at expanding the growing and processing lemon grass into essential oil for sales. The project will in addition move to another level of further value addition and development of other value and product chain. Women and female youth will be trained in entrepreneurship, savings and credit mobilization, essential oils value addition. They will be empowered to explore the making of soap, cosmetics, and tea blending, packing materials among others. They will be supported to participate in annual trade fairs organized at national level as we liaise with Uganda Bureau of Standards (UBS) to certify our products._x000D_
Part of the grant will support the two team members to contribute to their salary and allowance costs during the project period._x000D_
project_details: Young widows and teen mothers affected by HIV/TB have special difficulty in meeting their basic needs and those of their dependants. They have to cater for routine travel costs in search of medical reviews, ARVs and TB drugs. Their ill-health deserves better. They face discrimination on accessibility to land partly because of their status and gender discrimination .They lack gainful employment because they were not educated to acquire the requisite skills. They depend on annual crops for food and cash. In seasons of crop failure, they face abject poverty. Most of the farm holdings which are three to five acres are over-cropped. The key crop with potential to generate income for the rural poor women and youth is the lemon grass. Youth in Mubende lack gainful employment. They lack knowledge and skills to invest into innovative agro-enterprises. The few engaged in productive agriculture have never explored value addition and the related chain of agro-product development and marketing.

project_summary:
In culinary and fishery contexts, the term fish also includes shellfish, such as molluscs, crustaceans and echinoderms._x000D_
Fish has been an important source of protein for humans throughout recorded history._x000D_
_x000D_
Contents._x000D_
'Fish provides a good source of high quality protein and contains many vitamins and minerals. It may be classed as either whitefish, oily or shellfish. Whitefish, such as haddock and seer, contain very little fat (usually less than 1%) whereas oily fish, such as sardines, contain between 10-25%. The latter, as a result of its high fat content, contain a range of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K) and essential fatty acids, all of which are vital for the healthy functioning of the body._x000D_
Therefore, it can be seen clearly that fish products can be employed to meet the increasing demand for vitamins and proteins nutrition. This is of great essence with the increasing population in many countries as well as the limited spaces for keeping other sources of proteins like cattle, which require large spaces and much feeds to rear. _x000D_
_x000D_
Fish farming is currently associated with renown countries such as Japan which have large coasts , whereas in majority of  countries worldwide, fish are naturally found in lakes and other natiral water bodies, making  demand for fish to be hire, as the supply is inadequate._x000D_
few people venture into fish farming since it is an activity often looked down upon and in other places, people do not care to think about it._x000D_
 My project aims at establishing fish ponds in places that have all weather rivers, which are very available in Kenya and East Africa.Given that ladies are hardly choosy when it comes to occupation, I would involve them in ponds management and in fish feeding, hence provide employment for them._x000D_
_x000D_
Eventually, This project will not only provide adequate nutrition to the society, but will also make use of the natural resources to promote economic  empowerment for ladies health. It will also provide supplementation for other locally known sources of meat. Given that meat is delicious, its availability in the society will combat the increasing  consumption of red meat, hence its associated unhealthy effects.

project_summary: Acacias for All aims to fight desertification, poverty and gender inequality in rural Tunisia by empowering women in a tree-planting and entrepreneurship training program. Each woman is included in a training program 'Najah (Success)' where she get access in a 5 days training on entrepreneurship and collaborative work, and the opportunity to access the cooperative of women of her village where she will sell the production of the trees. project_name: Women in crafts making for livelihood
project_summary:
According to Kisoro District Report, 2002 Uganda Population and Housing Census, Kisoro Town Council has  total population of 11,328, (5,474 males and 5,854 females) with unemployment  accounting for 70%. Based on this, Future hope foundation Uganda   is requesting for USD 25,000 to support 50 women /girls engaged in craft making business between ages of 18-35 years with adequate skills and knowledge in quality craft making for sustainable livelihood in kisoro town council. The grant will help to equip 50 women/girls  with skills through trainings in key business areas _x000D_
The project goal: Improved quality of life of women and girls in Kisoro town council. _x000D_
 objectives:_x000D_
1. To equip women/girls with business skills that could lead to economic independence hence able to supplement household income for sustainable development._x000D_
 2. To create a platform where women are empowered with knowledge to advocate for social change by actively participating in community decision making processes._x000D_
project_details: Unemployment among the young girls have led to most of the girls engage in risky behaviors that could lead to HIV/Aids infections for example commercial sex work, illegal abortions resulting from unwanted pregnancies, drug abuse among others,they do all these  as  ways of securing survival . This has made Kisoro register a big number of  child mothers  due to early marriages without proper care strategies for the infants. project_summary: .The main idea is agricultural enterprises and  livelihoods enhancement for selected rural communities in  Uganda specifically targeting girls and women. The project interventions is to establish and develop Agricultural  enterprises while investing in value chains for certain products to enhance  livelihoods and diversified economic opportunities for rural women in  Uganda. The project will be implemented  by Providing  basic business skills training and support to 180 (6 groups of 30 members each, 1 group per district) mobilized girls and women develop business plans for their selected enterprises, Provide mentor ship support to 180 (6 groups of 30 members each, 1 group per district) mobilized girls and women, Provide support and facilitate 180 (6 groups of 30 members each, 1 group per district) mobilized girls and women to establish Village Savings Loans Associations (VSLA), Link existing active produce marketing groups and/or farmer groups of girls and women to markets
project_details: The problem we are solving is that girls and women of Uganda  who engage in farming activities, typically do it at a subsistence level. In this context they typically possess limited knowledge and skills in modern farming method, and basic business skills and are not inclined to think of farming as a potential business. They typically practice traditional farming methods characterized by low input use and consequently low yields. Those who sell products are not sufficiently aware of existing markets and commodity price trends in the area, leading to exploitation by middlemen. Moreover, some of the products  are highly perishable and are prone to waste in the absence of value addition production.  Accessing credit remains a particular challenge for these women, as there is only few financial institution which provides agricultural loans and its requirements are very stringent.

project_name: Warehouse(bulking centers) &warehouse receipt services in marginalized rural areas of primary production of the maize value chain.
project_summary:
Until the early 1990s, maize trade was of less value in Uganda because quantities available for trade were very low. Besides, quality and standards for Ugandan maize was not valued. Maize production in Uganda has increased from 900,000 to 1,300,000 tones per annum in 2000s. Maize was primarily produced for domestic consumption until regional demand pushed its increased export. Despite these regional & domestic market forces of demand and supply, the structural barriers to market access faced by the smallholder farmer hamper productivity and profitability in the value chain demoralizing farmers at primary areas of production. This causes food insecurity and perpetuates cyclical poverty. At household level, maize contributes nutritional value due to its high content in carbohydrates, proteins and fats. The limited technology to preserve the harvest for future use, lack of awareness from a policy perspective in promoting traditional technologies has also exacerbated food insecurity problems in many parts of the country._x000D_
The lack of adequate storage facilities at household or community level, the maize grain cannot be protected and held for future sales. As such farmers accept whatever prices they can get before their produce gets spoilt due to poor storage on farm. This is a contributing factor on rural household poverty and food insecurity. In the months of April, May and June, when the stocks are depleted, any available grain is great in demand. _x000D_
   _x000D_
In-spite of the many interventions made by government and Non-government institutions in the agricultural sector, agricultural productivity and financing in Uganda has continued to decline. Financing Agriculture in Uganda today requires mitigating two principal risks, 1. Production Risk (the probability that the crop may never be harvested) and 2. Price Risk (the probability that cost of production may be higher than market price). These realities discourage financiers from engaging in financing agricultural value chain activities that are long term or non-collateralized. _x000D_
Most Financial Institutions consider that the only way to finance agriculture is the traditional wayÃ¢â¬âthat is financing production. Looking through the production finance lens, small producers can rarely access loans because they lack collateral, loan amounts are small and the time frame for lending is too long. _x000D_
The Business Plan herein focuses on implementing an integrated market oriented, sector specific, public-private intervention aimed at introduction of a Warehouse(bulking centers) &warehouse receipt services in marginalized rural areas of primary production of the maize value chain. _x000D_
_x000D_
This package resolves many of the constraints to financing agricultural sector and the associated agricultural production and marketing challenges because the product (crop) is financed only after production, product is self-collateralizing and the loan terms are normally short. Access to warehouse receipts encourages production and productivity because opportunities for greater revenue (through temporal storage) become realistic to producers and cash in hand from receipts directly finances production at no risk to the lender._x000D_

project_details: Busiro is a rural village in Wakiso district. Largely comprises of rural poor subsistence farmers.  Literary rates are low, way below the national average. It has a large population of youths and women largely engaged in subsistence agriculture for survival as commercial agriculture has been viewed unprofitable due to many factors. While most of the land is fertile, the structured imbalance between maize value chain actors and other commodity chains drives the loss of morale among smallholder farmers. There are individual efforts that continue to push the barriers to make Maize production profitable from which a lot of potential can be seen. These early adopters of commercial agriculture even on small scale clearly needs affirmative action. Because of the high prevalence of poverty, farmers still sell off their crop while in the garden. A majority sell off their harvest cheaply to middle-men at prices set by the later which leaves farmers in awkward positions and powerless. This little money has driven up high levels of alcohol consumption and drugs especially among the youths, domestic violence and mental health problems.

Project  will empower women and girls in  selected communities along the Northern corridor  Road in  Uganda  at the Kenya/Uganda Border of  Busia , Idudi (Bugiri district) and Busembatya (Iganga district) stop points along the corridor.  This initiative targets vulnerable women and girls involved in informal trade and businesses at border crossings and truck stops who are exposed to high risks including unstable working conditions, harassment by customs officials, and situations where sex is exchanged for money or business opportunities. This situation adversely affects their fair and equitable socio-economic participation and undermines overall development.  _x000D_

project_details: The women and girls working within the cited  communities  face many challenges among which are lack of skills on how to improve their trade and services, harassment by police, truck drivers, and other customers and abduction and rape by truck drivers. Consequently these women and girls are exposed high risk of HIV and other related sexually transmitted infections (STI). These women and girls have no working premises and use survival tactics of running here and there, as they protect their items from authorities. They also lack working capital and many women and girls resort to exchanging sex for money particularly with truck drivers, a situation that undermines their health, education and other socio economic participation. They have no representation and participation in decision making related to their activities and livelihoods and access to reproductive health information and services is limited

project_name: Save a woman from obstetric fistula in the Rwenzori Region.
project_summary:
The project is intended to mobilize women and girls living with obstetric fistula due to early marriages at the hands of Traditional Birth attendants and lack of health facilities near them. They will be referred to the health facilities for repair and after repair; they will be trained on selection, planning and management of ING and will supported with income generating activities.Rwenzori region is well known for this condition. Women with fistula always shy away from the community and are always neglected, rejected and isolated._x000D_
This project will cater for their transportation to and fro the hospital and the fund will train and supply them with IGA at their choice e.g pigs, chicken and ducks for their income generating to be integrated in the community. It will also create a platform for them to air out their views on the local media houses for other women with the condition to come out and get repaired._x000D_
project_details: The project will work on repairing of women with obstetric fistula and support them with income generating activities.  During the radio talk show, women will be discouraged from using traditional birth attendant, sensitized on early marriage.  RD F is trying to resettle these women after repairing the condition for community integration and participation.We are also trying to encourage government to extend health facilities in the hard to reach areas to avoid the use of Traditional Birth Attendants and reduce on the cost of delivery. It will also discourage early marriages as a cultural norm in the area. We aim to have mobilized 35 women living with a condition and refer them to health facilities in the region. It is expected that 20 women will be repaired and resettled by supporting them with income generating activities and be integrated into the community by October 2015._x000D_
